DOC.HEAD: Iraq Orders Embassies in Kuwait Closed
DOC.TEXT: The United States has done nothing about an Iraqi instruction to close the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, the State Department said Friday night. Iraq told all embassies in Kuwait, which Iraq claims to have annexed, that ``all embassies should move to Baghdad by the 24th,'' said an official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``So far no action has been taken,'' this official said. ``I don't know what will be done.'' The European Common Market said in a statement in Brussels earlier in the day that it considers the annexation null and void, and, ``The same applies to the announced removal of diplomatic missions from Kuwait,'' according to an account in Saturday editions of The Washington Post.

DOC.HEAD: National Guardsmen From 11 States Help Regular Forces In Mideast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to ADD New Hampshire; ADDS 1 graf to give detail on New Hampshire unit; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US Military Bjt, Guard Units
DOC.TEXT: National Guard members from at least 15 states, many of them described as volunteers, are joining or supporting the movement of U.S. forces to Saudi Arabia, governors and guard officials said Thursday. Their destinations and exact jobs were not revealed, but they included air transport and aerial refueling units, communications specialists, and medics. The number of people involved ranged from five from South Carolina to 500 from Kansas, but most of the states did not disclose numbers. Contingents were drawn from Army and Air guard units in Arizona, New York, New Jersey, Kansas, Rhode Island, Delaware, Tennessee, West Virginia, Illinois, North Carolina, South Carolina, Texas, Utah, Washington state, Ohio and New Hampshire. Although most of those going on active duty were described as volunteers, the South Carolina Guard's spokesman, Lt. Les Carroll, said that by just being in the guard, an all-volunteer service, his state's five men placed on active duty volunteered to participate. He said he wasn't sure if they actually raised their hands to be sent, but should be considered volunteers. A contingent of the 105th Military Airlift Group of the New York National Guard volunteered to support the movement of troops to the Middle East, Gov. Mario Cuomo announced late Wednesday. 7 The 105th, based at Stewart International Airport in Newburgh, has 12 C5-A Galaxy jet transports. It is the only Air National Guard unit that has the huge aircraft, which can carry 290,000 pounds of cargo. It flew 48 missions during the U.S. intervention in Panama, transporting almost 2.3 million pounds of cargo and more than 750 soldiers. A second New York contingent of 40 nurses and medical technicians from the 139th Aero Medical Evacuation Flight based at the Schenectady County Airport was approved Thursday by Cuomo. Part of the 109th Tactical Airlift Group, they would provide air evacuation of casualties in a combat situation, said Guard spokesman Lt. Col. P.C. Kutschera. Seventy-four West Virginia Air National Guardsmen were mobilized, Adjutant Gen. Joseph Skaff said. The Pentagon called the West Virginia National Guard on Wednesday night seeking volunteers, Skaff said. ``Within two hours, we got all the volunteers we needed, which made us very proud of our people,'' he said. The West Virginia volunteers include medics, nurses, medical technicians and cargo specialists. Twenty-one members of the 156th Aeromedical Evacuation Flight of the North Carolina Air National Guard volunteered, Gov. Jim Martin announced Thursday. ``This unit is made up of personnel that run the gamut from nurses and physician's assistants to doctors,'' said National Guard spokesman Lt. Col. Baron G. Hignite. New Jersey Gov. Jim Florio said aircraft and volunteers from the Air National Guard's 170th Air Refueling Group at McGuire Air Force Base were called into service. He said he had no details. Kansas Gov. Mike Hayden agreed to active duty for 500 members of the 190th Air Refueling Group, which is stationed at Forbes Field just south of Topeka. The 500 will go on active duty on a voluntary basis, said Joy Moser, spokesman for the Kansas National Guard. ``It is not mandatory,'' she said. About 100 members of three Tennessee Air National Guard units were mobilized and some were deployed beginning three days ago, said Adjutant Gen. Carl Wallace. The units are the 134th Air Refueling Group, the 228th Combat Communications Squadron, and the 118th Aero Medical Evacuation Squadron, which functions as a ``flying hospital,'' Wallace said. ``We all know about Tennessee volunteers,'' said Wallace. ``They went to Texas and all that. This time we'll be more successful than at the Alamo.'' Major Gen. Harold G. Holesinger, adjutant general of Illinois, said 108 members of the 126th Air Refueling Wing volunteered. South Carolina Gov. Carroll Campbell released five members of the 228th Signal Brigade to go on active duty. Thirty-four members of the Ohio Air National Guard will take part as volunteers, Gov. Richard Celeste said Thursday. He said that included 14 from the 160th Air Refueling Group at Rickenbacker Air National Guard Base, and 20 from the 179th Tactical Air Lift Group at Mansfield. Washington Gov. Booth Gardner said National Guard volunteers would go on active duty. But he would not identify the units or give other details. Utah Gov. Norm Bangerter said 25 members of the Utah Guard's 151st Air Refueling Group and three members of the 169th Electronic Security Squadron volunteered. Texas Gov. Bill Clements said he approved a Pentagon request for 11 volunteers from the 136th Tactical Airlift Wing, based at Hensley Field in Grand Prairie. An undisclosed number of members of the Arizona National Guard were allowed to volunteer, Gov. Rose Mofford said. Press secretary Vada Manager said they included members of the 161st Refueling Group. Delaware Gov. Michael Castle approved the participation of 60 Delaware National Guard members. Sgt. Frank Donkin, a maintenance worker at Dover Air Force Base, left Tuesday, said his wife, Chris. He was told to bring his gear and gas mask, she said. In Rhode Island, three members of the 143rd Tactical Airlift Group based in North Kingston volunteered, the governor's chief of staff said. New Hampshire Gov. Judd Gregg said he approved a Defense Department request for 40 members of the guard's 157th Air Refueling Group. Lt. Col. Joseph Riley, a guard spokesman, said tanker jets from Pease Air Force Base, N.H., were meeting and refueling planes en route to the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Problems Persist 25 Years After Watts Riots
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Anger and frustration still simmer in Watts, 25 years after a week of rioting reduced entire blocks to charred ruins and seared black rage onto the American conscience. But Watts today is not the powder keg it was when the streets of Los Angeles exploded on Aug. 11, 1965, and burned for six nights and days, according to residents, community activists and academics. Some people say such post-riot developments as a new shopping center and a health clinic have improved the community. Others contend that negative forces are responsible for keeping the lid on any more riots. In recent years, gangs and drugs have joined the longtime problems of crime, joblessness and despair, making the area both violent and stagnant. Watts today directs its rage at itself, rather than at society, reducing the risk of another riot but doing nothing to solve the community's woes. ``Drugs are a deterrent, a lazy deterrent,'' said Ted Watkins Jr., president of Watts Labor Community Action Committee, a leader in the effort to rebuild the area. ``I don't think that in 1990 the will is here'' for another riot. Watts became a symbol of inner-city anger, sparked by an event that didn't even happen inside the community of 30,500 people eight miles due south of downtown Los Angeles. Four blocks west of Watts, two white California Highway Patrol officers stopped a 21-year-old black motorist for investigation of erratic driving. A scuffle started between the patrolmen and the motorist. A crowd gathered and quickly grew angry. Rocks were thrown. More police arrived. The crowd swelled. In about an hour, the disturbance spread to surrounding communities, including Watts. Rioters torched buildings, looted stores and pulled white drivers from their cars and beat them. Snipers took to the rooftops. A 50-square-mile area became a combat zone. National Guard jeeps with machine guns patrolled the streets. When it was all over, 34 people were dead, 4,000 others arrested, and damage was estimated at $40 million. A stretch of 103rd Street was lined by burnt-out skeletons of buildings, giving it the name Charcoal Alley. The McCone Commission, named after Chairman John A. McCone, former head of the CIA, issued a 101-page report, finding that the cycle of poverty and despair gripping the area set the stage for the riot. The report recommended a series of ambitious reforms, from job training to efficient public transportation. Many community activists and politicians say some important reforms went into place and made Watts a better community. Charcoal Alley has become a pleasant street with a post office, city council field office, shopping center with a bank and supermarket and a station on the city's new Blue Line light rail system. Relations with the Police Department are the best ever, many say, thanks in part to increased minority recruitment, community outreach and the common enemies of drugs and gangs. Ola Mae Toler, a Watts resident since 1947, said Watts has improved to the point a riot could not happen today. ``I don't think people are thinking of that anymore,'' she said. ``There's a lot of people who want progress. I know I do. But I have never thought that Watts was the worst place to live.'' Others say many of the reforms recommended in the McCone report never materialized, got lost in the shuffle or were scaled down. The Lockheed aeronautics plant near the Watts-Willowbrook border, built in response to the riots, was closed in 1988, putting thousands of people out of work. The Martin Luther King Jr.-Drew Medical Center, built south of Watts to provide more accessible health care, has been battered by allegations of administrative negligence and inadequate services. The schools have a serious dropout problem. The failure rate was 35 percent at D.S. Jordan High School in Watts in the 1988-89 school year and nearly 36 percent at Locke High School, just west of Watts, according to the Los Angeles Unified School District. Estimates of unemployment run as high as 40 percent. The county Department of Public Social Services says more than half of Watts' residents receive some sort of public assistance, most of them children. Crime is rampant in Watts and surrounding communities, with homicides about one every four days in the Police Department's Southeast Division, about a third of which is Watts. Ninety-four murders were committed in the division last year. In the first half of this year, 49 homicides were reported. ``The ground gained in `65 for the most part has been lost,'' said Tommy Jacquette, a Watts resident and head of the Watts Summer Festival, a local arts celebration. ``Health programs and human services programs have been cut out by local government. Organizations designed for self-help are gone. Then there's the onslaught of drugs and gang activities.'' UCLA professor James Johnson, director of the UCLA Center for the Study of Urban Poverty, describes Watts as a community at war with itself, with Watts residents killing Watts residents. ``I personally don't think we'll have another Watts rebellion of '65,'' he said. ``I think today it takes place on a daily basis.''

DOC.HEAD: Weak, Suffering Masses: The Living Casualties of Liberia's Civil War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
Eds: Some material may be offensive to some readers.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Liberia
DOC.TEXT: The woman was probably in her 20s but she had the look of those who have lost all hope. At first glance, she appeared at least 50 years old. She sat in the tropical rain on the curb of Sekou Toure Avenue with a days-old baby cradled in her lap. The baby was crying in the darkness. No one else was to be seen. It was after curfew, and she risked being shot by President Samuel Doe's soldiers. Passers-by stopped to offer her dollars and to advise her to get her baby out of harm's way. She refused the money. ``I want food,'' she said, ``I can't buy food with that.'' She was told if she walked into territory held by rebel chief Prince Johnson, she might get some Red Cross rice. There had been a distribution of rice that morning in the part of Monrovia. The woman shook her head. ``I couldn't make it,'' she said. ``I'm too weak to carry the baby.'' It was a statement of fact, not a cry for help. Liberia's civil war trudges on in its heartless manner. Civilian lives matter little in the immediate battle for a street crossing or a gas station, and reports from rebel-held territory indicate people there face the same dangers. In the morning, the woman had gone. Was she taken in by people living nearby, or killed by the troops, or had she just wandered down the deserted, rubble-strewn street in search of ... what? Even news of an impending intervention by a force of troops from several West African nations couldn't lift the gloom. ``I don't believe anyone can help us in the mess we've made of our country,'' said Elwyn Jackson, a gas station attendant until the war closed his station and government troops killed his boss. Monrovia has no first aid stations, no facilities for the poor, no one to whom to turn for help. Not even ambulances or fire brigades are functioning. Fires started in the fighting blazed out of control, sometimes all night. When the rain comes, every day or so, the flames go out by themselves in a sizzle of hell. Stray dogs _ abandoned, lost _ wander through the streets. Their bones show through their backs, and they have the strange slow movements of those too starved to care. The rotting, bloated corpses of the human victims are seen everywhere, in strange postures in gutters, on sidewalks, along the beach or in the uncut weeds on empty plots of land. There's no one to remove the bodies, and no one is worrying about dying later from some disease spread by the corpses. Feet, hands, and faces of the corpses are often missing. The bodies are being attacked under cover of darkness by rats to the stray dogs. Acnid Farnat is a diminutative Lebanese who used to run the Arabic School on the seafront. He still lives there, but his students have long since gone. He came to the nearby British Embassy pleading for special help. The odor from a human body that had washed up in front of his house was making his family sick. He wanted help to move the body. Neither the British nor anyone else was willing to assist him. The body remained where it was until it disappeared a few days later in the waves. The downtown streets are empty. Cars without wheels or with their windows shot out are parked everywhere, long past anyone's capacity to get them moving again. The steel shutters of supermarkets, most of them owned by Lebanese or Indians who have long gone, have been blown apart by rifle bullets, their contents looted. The crackling of machine-gun fire whipping across the long, straight streets has become part of daily life. Every morning, the remaining downtown inhabitants slink out of their homes in search for food and water. Long lines of civilians can be seen making their way across the old bridge over the Mezurado River, toward a haphazard rice distribution set up by Johnson. On Benson Street, there is a solitary figure in a red T-shirt, crouched on the sidewalk, eating garbage. He ignores the roadblock set up by Johnson's ``freedom fighters'' across the street, and they ignore him. ``He's crazy,'' said the sergeant in charge. ``Even if everyone in this town gets killed, he'll still be there.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Military Buildup Sparks Anti-American Feeling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The deployment of U.S. troops to protect Saudi Arabia prompted an outburst of anti-American sentiment in the Arab world, ranging from demonstrations to calls for a holy war against the United States. The U.S. troops were dispatched to protect Saudi Arabia in the wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait one week ago. Although the move came in response to a Saudi appeal for protection, it fanned resentment among Arabs who consider it unwarranted interference. Arab nations have so far refused to participate in any multinational military effort against Iraq and have concentrated on diplomatic efforts _ so far unsuccessful _ to peacefully resolve the crisis. Even before the deployment of U.S. troops, there was strong anti-American feeling in much of the Arab world because of the United States' close ties with Israel. But the deployment brought an upsurge in such sentiment. The head Moslem clerics, or mufti, attached to the military wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization declared that if the United States attacked Iraq, holy war ``is a duty for all Moslems.'' The Amman-based mufti, Sheik Nader Assad Bayoud al-Tamini, said in a statement clearly aimed at the Saudi royal family that ``those who ally themselves with the enemies of God, the Americans and the Westerners, and participate in the killing of Iraqis, are considered apostates, and their blood should be shed.'' In Jordan, where King Hussein said he continues to recognize the deposed Kuwaiti government, the powerful professional Engineers Association called on all Arab governments to form ``popular armies'' to confront the danger posed by the ``attempt of America to impose its will.'' ``We call on all Arabs to awaken from their slumber after seeing for themselves that imperialist countries stand together against the Arab nation and its interests,'' the group said in a statement. A group calling itself the Jordanian Committee for the Defense of Kuwait urged volunteers to go to Iraq to help President Saddam Hussein, who has annexed Kuwait, resist any U.S. attack. Mohammed Rashdan, a Jordanian lawyer who is the secretary of the committee, said the number of volunteers swelled following the arrival of the first U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. He said he expected the number would grow to more than 10,000 by the end of the day. The United States and Saudi Arabia have said the American forces will act only defensively. Libyan radio announced during the day that thousands of Libyans were ready to go to the region to fight against U.S. interference in Arab affairs. In the Yemeni capital of San`a, about 1,000 people gathered in front of the U.S. Embassy and chanted slogans denouncing the U.S. intervention. But Yemen, the only Arab member of the U.N. Security Council, joined in the unanimous vote Thursday declaring the Iraqi annexation of Kuwait ``null and void.'' The official Egyptian Middle East News Agency reported an anti-American demonstration was staged outside the U.S. Embassy in the Sudanese capital, Khartoum. Critics claim the United States has no reason to intervene to protect Saudi Arabia because it has not moved to end the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which Israel seized in 1967. Faisal Husseini, the leading pro-PLO activist in the occupied lands, accused Washington of using a ``double standard'' with the Arabs. ``Why ask only Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait?'' he said. ``Why not ask Israel to withdraw from the West Bank?''

DOC.HEAD: Food Cutoff Likely To Cause Immediate Hardships for Iraqis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqis rushed to stock up on rice, sugar, cooking oil and other foodstuffs after economic sanctions were announced, fearing shortages in a country that imports $2 billion worth of food a year. After Iraq invaded Kuwait, attention was focused on the world embargo on Iraq's oil exports. The food cutoff could impose even greater suffering on Iraq. Because the world embargo applies to Kuwait, too, the residents of the Iraqi-annexed emirate are likely to feel the food pinch just as much. Kuwait imports effectively all of its food. Foreigners who fled Kuwait after the invasion reported immediate shortages as residents rushed to supermarkets and prepared for siege-like conditions. London's Financial Times on Thursday quoted a source inside Kuwait, whom it did not identify, as saying in notes shipped to the newspaper: ``Tuesday morning some residents queuing at banks and food shops, but no sign of them opening.'' Iraq imports about 70 percent of its food, according to Omar Kader, a Middle East expert and board member of the Arab-American Affairs Council. Food accounts for a quarter of all Iraqi imports, and one-third of the food brought in comes from the United States. It consists mainly of wheat, corn, rice, barley, sugar, poultry and eggs at subsidized prices. Washington has also provided agricultural credits to the Arab country. Even before the invasion, the Senate voted July 27 to halt $1 billion in agricultural credit guarantees, citing in part Iraq's recent threat to use chemical weapons against Israel. That measure required presidential approval but became moot after the post-invasion sanctions cut off all credit. Omar Kader, a Middle East expert and board member of the Arab-American Affairs Council, said on ``Good Morning America'' that a food cutoff would have almost immediate impact. The Iraqi people are accustomed to shortages. During the 1980-88 war with Iran, many foodstuffs were rationed, including rice, sugar and cooking oil. People stood in lines stretching around city blocks to purchase small quantities at government stores. Local Turkish and Iraqi officials have been trying to figure out what to do about thousands of trucks blocked on both sides of the border since Turkey decided to cut off trade with Iraq. Turkey is both a supplier of food to Iraq and a crucial overland route for imports from Europe and other points. A major route for Iraqi food imports during the Iran-Iraq war was the truck route from the port of Aqaba in Jordan, a country where feelings in support of Iraq run strong in some quarters. But businessmen in Jordan said ships carrying food or other products have not unloaded at Aqaba since the U.N. Security Council voted Monday for global sanctions against Iraq. Another possible route for food imports, the long Iran-Iraq border, has been shut to trade since the 1980 outbreak of the Iran-Iraq war. It is now patrolled by U.N. cease-fire monitors, with no trade allowed across it. Marking an exception to the world blockade, Sri Lanka said it would continue selling tea _ a major staple in every Arab country _ to Iraq despite the embargo. ``We are a poor country and must continue to pick and sell our tea,'' said Deputy Defense Minister Ranjaan Wijeratne. ``Sanctions can be imposed by rich countries. We cannot afford to stop selling our products.'' Iraq is Sri Lanka's second-largest customer after Egypt, having bought 24 percent of last year's tea exports.

DOC.HEAD: Winner Completes Race Up 11,674 Steps in Less Than One Hour
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
With LaserPhoto of Aug. 9
DOC.TEXT: The world's longest staircase has six times as many steps as the Empire State Building and is nearly twice as long as its nearest rival in China. But it is virtually unknown, even in Switzerland. In a bid to end its obscurity, local enthusiasts this week staged the first official race up the 11,674 steps of Mount Niesen, in the Swiss Alps. Organizers say the ``Niesentreppen'' run will be an annual event, attracting the world's top racers in a test of stamina and skill up a hodgepodge of concrete, wooden and metal steps. For the rest of the year, the steps give maintenance workers access to a cable railway and are off limits to others. The 80-year-old railway runs from this Bernese Oberland village up the 7,794 feet mountain. The lineup at Wednesday's race included a sports professor, a diving instructor, a ski-tour organizer and a shop assistant. They were among 20 people, all men, competing for the $7,692 prize. Swiss medical student Christian Aebersold averaged 223 steps a minute to complete the dizzying course in 52 minutes, 26 seconds. Jairo Correa of Colombia clocked 53.11 minutes. Correa is the world champion of mountain racers, whose sport involves running up mountains. U.S. runner Jay Johnson said one of the reasons he entered the race was because it was different from the usual courses in the mountain-racing circuit. The narrow steps, through tunnels and over bridges spanning great drops, extend for only 2.1 miles but scale 5,344 feet from valley to summit. After finishing sixth in 56.42 minutes, Johnson, the 1988 mountain-racing champion, declared the race great fun. ``But I had problems with the open metal steps toward the top as when I looked at the drop below I felt dizzy,'' he said. One of the few competitors who had raced on steps before was Villa Frades from Colombia. He scaled the 6,600 steps at the Chinese temple of Tai Chun. Mike Ballmann, a former stuntman who helped organized the race, said his goal was to put the Niesentreppen on the map. ``It is a great pity that we have the world's longest steps here in Switzerland, but they are mostly unknown,'' he said. Ballmann said he first hit on the idea of organizing a race when he scaled the steps in 1979 while training for a race in Nepal. He then persuaded fellow mountain enthusiast and Swiss mathematic professor Jacques Berlie to take up the challenge. Berlie's time last year of one hour and three minutes, in a run televised worldwide, set the standard for this year. Fabiola Rueda, a two-time women's world mountain-racing champion, also ran up Mount Niesen on Wednesday but was not competing. Ms. Rueda, a Colombian national married to her Swiss trainer, clocked 1:05.50 to set the target for women racers next year. Ballmann said he hoped four to five women would participate next year. But the overall number of competitors will stay fixed at 20 for safety reasons, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-guerrillas Will Return Bolivar's Sword They Stole
DOC.TEXT: Former leftist guerrillas who signed a peace treaty with the government say they will return the sword of Colombian liberator Simon Bolivar they stole 16 years ago. The M-19 Movement, which became a political party in March following years of armed struggle, said Thursday that it will hand over Bolivar's sword to the government on Dec. 17, the 160th anniversary of the liberator's death. The sword was used in Colombia's battle of independence from Spain. M-19 stole it in 1974 from Bolivar House, the patriot's former residence in Bogota. The rebels in 1985 took over the Palace of Justice. About 115 people died in fighting with the army, including 11 supreme court justices. After signing the peace treaty the group's presidential candidate, Antonio Navarro, placed third in the May election. When President Cesar Gaviria took office Tuesday, he appointed Navarro as minister of health.

DOC.HEAD: List of Previous Spacecraft That Visited Venus
With PM-Magellan-Venus
DOC.TEXT: Magellan is the latest of many spacecraft to visit Venus. NASA and the National Space Society list these earlier missions, most of their launch and arrival dates, and tasks. The Mariners and Pioneers were U.S. spacecraft; the Veneras and Vegas were Soviet. Mariner 2, launched Aug. 27, 1962, flew within 21,594 miles of Venus on Dec. 14, 1962, found the planet lacked a magnetic field and had 900-degree Fahrenheit surface temperatures. Venera 4, June 12, 1967, entered Venusian atmosphere Oct. 18, 1967, returning information for 93 minutes. Mariner 5, June 14, 1967, flew within 2,500 miles of Venus on Oct. 19, 1967, measuring surface temperatures and atmospheric makeup. Venera 5, Jan. 5, 1969, parachuted into Venusian atmosphere on May 16, 1969, confirming it is mostly carbon dioxide and lacks water vapor. Venera 6, Jan. 10, 1969, parachuted into Venusian atmosphere May 17, 1969, similar to Venera 5. Venera 7, Aug. 17, 1970, used parachute to make first soft landing on Venus on Dec. 15, 1970, then transmitted data for 23 minutes. Venera 8, March 27, 1972, orbiter-lander, landed on sunlit side of Venus on July 22, 1972, measuring surface temperature and pressure. Mariner 10, Nov. 3, 1973, flew past Venus on Feb. 5, 1974, en route to Mercury. Made visible and ultraviolet light images to track circulation patterns in Venusian atmosphere. Venera 9, June 8, 1975, orbiter-lander, with lander providing first glimpse of Venusian surface in a panoramic picture of landscape near the touchdown site. Venera 10, June 14, 1975, orbiter-lander, sent panoramic view of landing area and returned information about surface conditions for 65 minutes. Pioneer 12, also known as Pioneer Venus Orbiter, May 20, 1978, started orbiting Venus on Dec. 4, 1978, first spacecraft to carry radar to Venus, mapped 92 percent of the surface. Discovered Venus has large rift valleys and 7-mile-high Mount Maxwell, a mile taller than Earth's Mount Everest. Pioneer 13, Aug. 8, 1978, sent four probes into Venusian clouds on Dec. 9, 1978, obtaining information on wind patterns, temperatures and pressures. Venera 11, Sept. 9, 1978, flyby and lander, touched down on Dec. 5, 1978, detected electric discharges and noises in Venus' atmosphere. Venera 12, Sept. 14, 1978, flyby and lander. Imaging system failed to return photos after Dec. 21, 1978 landing. Venera 13, Oct. 31, 1981, orbiter-lander, relayed first color images of Venus' surface after landing on March 3, 1982. Venera 14, Nov. 4, 1981, orbiter-lander, drilled soil samples, returned color pictures and conducted a seismic experiment. Venera 15, June 2, 1983, and Venera 16, June 7, 1983, orbiters only, used radar to map the northern 25 percent of Venus with ability to picture features larger than about 1 mile. Pictures revealed numerous volcanoes, meteorite impact craters and complex deformation of Venus' crust. Vega 1, Dec. 15, 1984, and Vega 2, Dec. 21, 1984, missions to Comet Halley and Venus. Probes decscended into Venusian atmosphere.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Bid to Stop Chemical Weapons Shipment
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Thursday denied an environmental group's request to immediately halt the shipment of U.S. chemical weapons from West Germany to a Pacific island pending a hearing later this month. Greenpeace USA had asked U.S. District Judge David Ezra to grant a temporary restraining order preventing the Army from moving the weapons from a storage site at Clausen, West Germany, to Johnston Atoll, 800 miles southwest of Honolulu. Ezra denied the request, but scheduled a hearing on Greenpeace's plea for a preliminary injunction for Aug. 20. The decision was a partial victory for the Bush administration, which has pledged to remove the weapons from West Germany by the end of the year. Government attorneys had said any halt in the shipment could delay the operation until 1991. ``Events unfolding in the Middle East have painted up with precision and clarity the importance to the national security of the United States that commitments made by and between representatives of nations be honored,'' Ezra's 21-page ruling said. Greenpeace filed a lawsuit last week naming Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Michael P. Stone, secretary of the Army, as defendants. The organization said the munitions and plans to incinerate them pose a threat to the environment and people of the Pacific. Government attorneys said Johnston Atoll is the safest location for the weapons. They said every precaution has been taken to ensure the safety of the shipment. Ezra ruled that failing to immediately halt the shipment would not cause irreversible harm to the plaintiffs' goal of keeping the Army from transporting the munitions to Johnston Atoll, since the weapons are not scheduled to leave West Germany until next month. The weapons are to be loaded onto trucks, then transferred to rail cars bound for the North Sea. Two U.S. Navy ships are to take the weapons to Johnston Atoll by an undisclosed route sometime after Sept. 1. About 30 percent of the 100,000 rounds of nerve gas shells already have been removed from the Clausen facility or packed into shipping containers. Greenpeace attorney Skip Spaulding said he was confident the Aug. 20 hearing would allow him to prove the Army has violated U.S. environmental laws. Spaulding contended the Army violated the National Environmental Policy Act by not filing an Environmental Impact Statement covering the movement of the weapons within West Germany. The Army said it prepared an Environmental Impact Statement on the ocean portion of the weapons' journey to Johnston. However, the report is classified, and Ezra has not seen it. The Army has yet to obtain approval to incinerate the weapons at the new Johnston Atoll Chemical Agent Disposal System. The facility is still being tested. Ezra said nothing leads him to believe U.S. environmental laws apply in West Germany when the removal of the munitions is being assisted by that nation. However, he said the laws do apply to the proposed incineration of the weapons at Johnston Atoll. President Bush has assured the West German government the weapons will be removed by the end of the year. Congress has required that all U.S. chemical weapons be destroyed by 1997.

DOC.HEAD: Hammer And Sickle Come Down In Bulgarian City
DOC.TEXT: Three mountaineers dismantled a hammer and sickle and anti-Communist demonstrators wrapped a statue of Soviet founder Vladimir Lenin in cardboard in Bulgaria's second largest city, Plovdiv. Other countries in eastern Europe have dismantled the icons of the communist ideology that held sway across the region for more than four decades. In Bulgaria, where the former Communist party still holds power, such de-ideologization has proceeded more slowly. The official news agency BTA reported that onlookers applauded as three mountaineers scaled the local headquarters of the Bulgarian Socialist Party, the former Communist party, to remove the hammer and sickle on Wednesday. City authorities authorized the job as they prepared to move into the building. Anti-Communist demonstrators were denied permission to wrap the Lenin statue in cardboard but went ahead anyway. They are circulating a petition to remove the statue altogether.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman's Hope Spurs Hunger Fight a Year After His Death
DOC.TEXT: A year after his death, Mickey Leland's hope and vision to end world hunger is still alive. It's in $500,000 worth of food and supplies scheduled to leave New York this month for Fugnido, the Ethiopian refugee camp the Texas congressman was heading for when his plane crashed Aug. 7, 1989. It's in a drive expected to yield at least 30,000 pounds of food for the Houston Food Bank. And it caused 336 House members to vote for more food stamp benefits in the 1990 farm bill last week. Just after the vote, many of them sang ``God Bless America'' in Leland's honor at a moonlight vigil on the Capitol steps. ``They feel committed to make sure that things and issues that matter to him carry forward, get attention,'' Leland's widow, Alison, said after the tribute. Leland, a Democrat who served a predominantly black and Hispanic inner-city Houston district, was best known for starting the House Select Committee on Hunger in 1984. He chaired it until his death. ``Mickey had become a conscience in the Congress for fighting malnutrition across the world,'' civil rights leader Jesse Jackson recalled. ``Mickey Leland was unique. He was bilingual. He had a great sense of coalition-building. He could get strange and odd couples to do things together.'' Leland's friend and former colleague in the Texas Legislature, Craig Washington, was elected to his House seat in December. Washington has taken up several of Leland's causes, most notably the reunification of Ethiopian Jews. Mrs. Leland, who is an attorney, briefly considered running for the seat. She was pregnant then and has since given birth to twin boys. Her sons and a feeling there wasn't ``any unfinished business on Mickey's part'' made her decide not to run, she told The Washington Post. Leland and 15 others were killed shortly after the plane carrying them left Addis Ababa, the Ethiopian capital, for refugee camps on the Sudanese border. Leland took the trip to call attention to the plight of Sudanese teen-agers who fled to Ethiopia from the civil war in their country. ``These particular refugee situations are among the most totally hidden from Western view,'' said Michael Toole, an epidemiologist with the federal Centers for Disease Control who spent June at Fugnido and two other camps. Ethiopia's own hunger problem has been compounded by 380,000 Sudanese and 385,000 Somalis who fled to the country from unrest at home. There are 77,000 Sudanese refugees at Fugnido. Relief workers still talked about Leland during Toole's visits, he said. ``Relations between the U.S. and Ethiopia being as they are, not totally good, Mickey helped overcome that obstacle to providing humanitarian aid,'' Toole said. ``Humanitarian aid was provided despite the shaky relations.'' Aid is reaching the refugees, but their mortality rate remains high, particularly among the Somalis, he said. Funding problems at the United Nations High Commission on Refugees have made the situation worse, Toole said. But Leland's legacy, the hunger committee, helped earlier this summer by obtaining millions for the commission in a supplemental appropriations bill. Neil Flieger, a committee staff member, said Leland galvanized Congress to end hunger. ``It was a lifetime and four terms in Congress of having worked on and paid attention to this issue and trying to get other people to pay attention to this issue that came to an untimely end, but also reached a crescendo that day a year ago,'' Flieger said.

DOC.HEAD: Hubble Investigation Finds `Astonishing' Error of About 1 Millimeter
DOC.TEXT: An error of about one millimeter _ called ``astonishing'' by one expert for its large size _ has been found in a measuring device used to guide the manufacture of a flawed mirror on the Hubble Space Telescope. A NASA committee investigating the defect that has crippled the $1.5 billion telescope announced Thursday that the millimeter mistake was found while testing the measuring device, called a null corrector. The space telescope, touted as an orbiting observatory that would be able to see objects up to 14 billion light years away, was launched in April. Engineers discovered two months later that a mirror in the device had been manufactured wrong. As a result, the telescope's views of stars are blurred and of severely reduced value to astronomers. The investigation committee said in a one-page statement that it found the millimeter error while testing a null corrector on Wednesday at the Hughes Danbury Optical Systems plant in Danbury, Conn., where the mirrors were made. Hughes Danbury had preserved the null corrector in the exact position that had been used to grind and polish the mirrors in the early 1980s. Preliminary results of the test, the statement said, ``have revealed a clear discrepancy of approximately one millimeter between the design of the null corrector and the device as it exists.'' A millimeter is about one twenty-fifth of an inch, or about the size of the very tip of a ballpoint pen. Daniel Schulte, a senior scientist at the optical laboratory at the Lockheed Palo Alto Research Laboratory in California, said an error of that magnitude was ``astonishing.'' ``That's gross,'' he said. ``There's no reason for an error of that size to be tolerated.'' Schulte said that in normal optical manufacturing, a difference of a 20th or a 50th of a millimeter is considered ``standard tolerance.'' He said the error was so large ``it had to be a transposition of numbers or something like that, that was carried through. It had to be something clerical like that.'' Schulte, an astronomer, was a member of an independent panel named by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to evaluate the Hubble focusing flaw just after it was discovered in June. After confirming that the focusing error was in the spacecraft mirrors, the panel was dissolved and NASA named another committee, headed by Jet Propulsion Laboratory director Lew Allen, to investigate the mistake. A null corrector is a device that can be adjusted to create a pattern of light in the exact shape desired in an optical lens or mirror. The light pattern from a null corrector is interpreted by another device to tell a computer the precise grinding and polishing pattern that must be followed. However, if the null corrector is set wrong, the lens or mirror will be ground to an incorrect shape. In effect, the optics then are made to the wrong prescription and cannot give the expected focus. An engineer, who asked not to be identified, said that during the 18-month-long mirror grinding and polishing process, at least two measurements had been made with a second null corrector and that errors had been found. But the errors were ignored on the assumption that the main measuring device had the correct pattern. Sarah Keegan, a NASA spokeswoman, said the space agency's investigation board would have no further statements this week. But the board plans to conduct hearings at the Hughes Danbury plant next Wednesday and Thursday, and more information may be released after those hearings, she said. Thomas Arconti, a spokesman for Hughes Danbury, said the company was informed of the committee finding and ``we are not in disagreement with their release.'' He said Hughes officials were ``surprised to find the discrepancy,'' but ``we're not going to speculate about what might have happened.'' Arconti said a single null corrector was used to guide the polishing process for the Hubble mirrors. Dick Wollensak, vice president of Litton Itek Optical Systems, an unsuccessful bidder for the Hubble optical contract, said he was surprised at the size of the error found by the investigation committee. ``That is a very large error,'' he said. ``I can't imagine how they would have missed something like that.''

DOC.HEAD: With GIs and Diplomacy, U.S. Tightens Vise; Arab Leaders Mark Time
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for 36th `The Saudis...' to UPDATE with Australia to take part in international force; pickup graf 37 pvs `A few...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CAI2, NY16
DOC.TEXT: American GIs dug into position in Arabia's searing sands Thursday while American diplomats worked the air-conditioned corridors of power, both tightening a vise, step by step, on an increasingly isolated Iraq. The dangerous U.S.-Iraqi standoff in the desert rattled nerves across the Middle East. Israel fired off a test missile as a warning to the Iraqis. Air raid sirens wailed mysteriously in Jordan. Turkish villagers said Iraqi tanks had rumbled into position near the Turkey-Iraq border. And Iraq closed its frontiers for foreigners, heightening concerns about hundreds of Americans stranded in Iraq and Kuwait. The tension reached as far as the hills of Tennessee and farms of Wisconsin, where local Air National Guardsmen were hurriedly called from their civilian jobs to help ferry U.S. troops and gear the 5,000 miles to Saudi Arabia. A Pentagon source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the United States was prepared to put ``many divisions'' in Saudi Arabia in the face of a continued Iraqi buildup in Kuwait. ``We have contingency plans that could result in the insertion of up to 200,000 to 250,000 ground forces before it's all done,'' said the source, who spoke on condition that further identification be withheld. Such moves could take up to two months, the source said. The Pentagon earlier reported that 50,000 Iraqi combat units were moving south inside Iraq, and that if they entered Kuwait, the total invasion force would number ``about 170,000.'' Only a day earlier, the intelligence estimates had put the Iraqi force at 100,000 men. American leaders believe the Saudi oil kingdom could be the next target of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, whose invasion force conquered Kuwait last week. Arab leaders, desperate to defuse the explosive crisis, gathered in Cairo in search of a peaceful resolution _ possibly an all-Arab force to act as a border buffer between the Saudis and Americans on one side and the Iraqis on the other. The summit was postponed a day until Friday. The official reason for the postponement was some late arrivals. But unconfirmed reports said the summit hit a snag because the Iraqi delegation brought its own representative for the new Baghdad-installed Kuwaiti government. The Iraqis, according to some reports, refused to accept the presence of Kuwait's emir. Taha Yassin Ramadan, the leader of the Iraqi delegation in Cairo, asserted that the U.S. force in Saudi Arabia would be used to attack Iraq. Any such move ``will be answered decisively,'' he said. Iraq's ambassador to Greece suggested the Iraqis would unleash poison gas on any attacking American troops. While the Arab presidents and sheiks marked time in Cairo, American diplomacy pressed forward in world capitals: _Secretary of State James A. Baker III, in Ankara, told Turkish leaders they could depend on their NATO allies in any showdown with neighboring Iraq. _In Paris, a U.S. envoy reassured a 21-nation energy conference that Washington would tap its huge emergency oil stockpile if the crisis causes shortages. France promised to send an aircraft carrier to the gulf and strengthen its naval and air forces there. _At U.N. headquarters in New York, the United States helped shepherd a resolution through the Security Council rejecting Iraq's announced annexation of Kuwait. On Monday, the council ordered a worldwide economic embargo against Iraq. The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2 was rooted in grievances over oil, money and land. Saddam complained that Kuwaiti overproduction of petroleum had driven down world oil prices and Iraq's oil revenues. He also rejected Kuwait's demands that Iraq repay an estimated $15 billion in loans. And he reasserted longstanding claims on Kuwaiti territory. On Thursday, a day after ``annexing'' the wealthy emirate, the Iraqis announced they were ``cancelling'' their debt to Kuwait. World opinion, led by the United States, has almost universally condemned the invasion. Iraq's neighbor and longtime enemy Iran joined the chorus Thursday, declaring it ``will not tolerate'' the Kuwait annexation. On Wednesday, President Bush announced the deployment of U.S. troops to buttress the outmanned Saudi military and declared, ``We must resist aggression or it will destroy us.'' An Iraqi takeover of Saudi Arabia, a key source of U.S. oil, would endanger the U.S. economy, he said. On Thursday, however, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said the Iraqi troops in Kuwait ``seem to be in a defensive posture.'' At least 2,300 American soldiers, mostly from the 82nd Airborne Division's ``ready brigade,'' were flown to Saudi Arabia on Wednesday. Pentagon sources said elements of two other divisions _ the 101st Airborne and the 24th Mechanized Infantry _ would be among the units to be sent. The United States also was dispatching some 140 F-15s, F-16s and other warplanes, including ``tank killer'' A-10s, Pentagon and other sources reported. Sources in the Middle East said the U.S. units were being deployed at strategic airports and bases across Saudi Arabia, but the main grouping was in the remote northeastern region of Hafr al-Baten, near Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Travelers leaving Saudi Arabia, and speaking on condition of anonymity, said the flow of American forces to the border region appeared to be increasing Thursday. The dimensions of the global U.S. operation _ many of whose details were being kept secret _ could be seen Thursday at the Lajes air base in Portugal's Azores islands, where eyewitnesses reported 17 U.S. Air Force aerial tankers lined up on the runway at one point. On Wednesday, diplomatic sources said hundreds of U.S. Marines had been flown to Saudi Arabia's northeast corner and deployed at Khafji, just seven miles from Kuwait. But on Thursday a Pentagon source denied that, saying no Marines were in Saudi Arabia ``at this time.'' Besides the ground forces, powerful Navy units were converging on the tense Persian Gulf area. Fifteen vessels, the biggest of them the aircraft carrier USS Independence, were in the gulf or near its entrance. About 20 more will be in Mideast waters by next week, including the battleship Wisconsin, bristling with cruise missiles programmed for targets in Iraq.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Government Adopts Measures to Cure Economy
DOC.TEXT: The government has moved to get the Soviet economy out of its slump by ordering a 32 percent increase in prices paid to farmers for their produce and setting up a fund for state property. The Tass news agency said the Council of Ministers, the Soviet Cabinet, on Thursday ordered the increase as of Jan. 1 for sugar beets, sunflowers, cotton, flax goods, tobacco and tea leaves. Also covered are cattle, poultry, milk and cream. The measure was clearly aimed at encouraging farmers to produce more, to help end chronic food shortages that have left many grocery shelves bare nationwide. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is trying to move from a centrally planned to a regulated market economy. His advisers' latest proposals are to be presented to the Supreme Soviet legislature next month. Tass said Gorbachev decreed that a fund be set up to manage the state's vast property. For decades, private property has been illegal in this communist state, but Gorbachev has been moving toward it as part of his economic reforms. Tass said the new fund would organize transformation of state enterprises into joint stock societies and other new arrangements. Its goals include breaking up state monopolies in production, protecting state property and ``carrying out measures to privatize property,'' Tass said. Gorbachev's chief economic adviser, Deputy Premier Leonid Abalkin, told Soviet television the decree envisages widescale denationalization of property and sale of property to individuals. A third measure announced by Tass suggests that government agencies help small businesses get established and procure material and technical support. State ministries tightly control these aspects of the economy. Many would-be entrepreneurs say their efforts are stifled by the ministries' strangehold.

DOC.HEAD: Precede JALAPA
Hurricane Diana's Toll: 38 Dead, 80 Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with death toll rising to 38 sted 14; details of storm's effects in Hidalgo state; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Diana killed at least 38 people and injured 80 as it battered the states of Veracruz and Hidalgo this week, relief officials said Thursday. Eleven people were reported missing. Officials said the death toll could still rise as reports come in from isolated areas. The storm brushed the Yucatan peninsula, roared through Veracruz state Monday night, and then went on to dissipate in the mountains north of Mexico City. It subsided to a tropical storm Wednesday. The office of the federal Civil Protection Agency, which is coordinating relief efforts, said it did not have a complete death toll yet. However, relief officials said at least 24 people died in Hidalgo, a small mountainous state north of Mexico City. In addition, 80 were injured and 1,270 were left homeless there. Of the 24 who died, 20 drowned and four were killed when buildings caved in, said Marco Antonio Heras, an officer with the Hidalgo State Civil Protection Agency, in a telephone interview. Heras said eight townships suffered severe damage, with 333 homes partly or totally destroyed. He said Gov. Adolfo Lugo Verduzco declared a state of emergency in those communities so they can qualify for state aid. Another 14 people were killed in Veracruz state, on the Gulf of Mexico, and 11 were missing, the relief officials said. About 30,000 people were left homeless and have taken shelter in schools and other public buildings, state spokeswoman Rosa Maria Ahuja said in a telephone interview from Jalapa, the state capital. The spokeswoman said state and federal officials were helping residents in 29 communities struck by Hurricane Diana. A total of 17 rivers and one lake swelled by rainwater had overflowed their banks, Ahuja said. The government has given hurricane victims 16,000 food packages and 15,000 slabs of building siding, Ahuja said. A state agricultural commission is assessing the damage to banana, orange and corn crops, she said. At least two other nearby states suffered serious damage in the storm, news reports said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Charlie Sheen has checked into a drug and alcohol rehabilitation center for a month, his spokesman says. The 24-year-old actor, who played a raw recruit in ``Platoon'' and a rookie securities trader in ``Wall Street,'' is suffering from ``extreme exhaustion due to an arduous filming schedule of four features back-to-back,'' Jeff Barnard said Thursday. The spokesman refused to say whether Sheen has a drug or alcohol problem and would not disclose where the actor was undergoing treatment or when he checked in. Sheen is the son of actor Martin Sheen and brother of actor Emilio Estevez. In his most recent movie, ``Navy SEALs,'' he plays a member of an elite anti-terrorist squad. He also has leading roles in ``Men At Work,'' which opens Aug. 24, and ``Cadence'' and ``Rookie,'' due to be released next year.

Princess Diana used sign language to address 800 delegates at a British Deaf Association conference. The princess, who has been learning to sign since she became a patron of the association in 1983, thanked delegates Thursday for a book she was presented. ``I am very proud to receive this book, thank you. I offer my congratulations to the British Deaf Association for 100 years of service,'' Diana said, using her hands. The delegates responded with a standing ovation. ``There were no mistakes, no fluffs and everyone in the audience understood what she said,'' said Bernard Quinn, spokesman for the British Deaf Association. ``She made a very important gesture to deaf people.'' It is the first time the 29-year-old wife of Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, has used the complex sign language in public.

Delta Burke says she will return to the set of ``Designing Women'' next week despite her bickering with the series' producers. Production on the Emmy-winning CBS comedy resumes Monday, and Miss Burke said she plans to continue her role as the feisty Southern belle Suzanne Sugarbaker. Miss Burke and ``Designing Women'' producers Harry Thomason and Linda Bloodworth-Thomason have been slinging accusations about problems on the set. The producers have claimed Miss Burke behaved badly on the set last season. The actress has contended she was harassed about gaining weight. The actress recently was nominated for an Emmy for best actress in a comedy series. Thomason earned a nomination for his directorial work on an episode called ``They Shoot Fat Women, Don't They?'' in which Miss Burke's character dealt with a weight problem.

Folk singer Arlo Guthrie says it's ridiculous to put labels on records warning the lyrics may be offensive. ``The fact that people can spend their time thinking about all that stuff when there are disasters going on all around us is kind of silly, I think,'' Guthrie said. He added, ``The fear of music is more harmful than bad music.'' Guthrie, the son of folk legend Woody Guthrie, is known for his hits ``Alice's Restaurant'' and ``City of New Orleans.'' He was scheduled for a concert tonight at the Tennessee Performing Arts Center. In May, the Recording Industry Association of America unveiled a voluntary ``parental guidance'' label for recordings that might be deemed objectionable because of lyrics dealing with such themes as sex, violence, suicide or drugs.

DOC.HEAD: West African Force Heads for Liberia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf `Thousands of...' with 2 grafs to CORRECT that Mandingos in Guinean Embassy, unclear what happened to them. Pickup 9th graf `Nigerian Foreign...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON1
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is based in part on a pool report from journalists including AP correspondent Michael Goldsmith.

A presidential spokesman said U.S. Marines fired from a helicopter at President Samuel Doe on the porch of his executive mansion Thursday in an unsuccessful attempt to assassinate him. In Washington, the State Department denied the charge. Doe spokesman Selly Thompson, speaking in a radio telephone call with the British Broadcasting Corp., said a Doe adviser, former Justice Minister Isaac Nyaplu, was hit in the chest and neck and was hospitalized. The incident came as West African peacekeeping troops headed for a showdown with rebels, who battled Doe's troops and fought to within a mile of his mansion in a bid to take Monrovia before the African task force arrives. Rebels loyal to former bureaucrat Charles Taylor pushed into eastern Congo Town suburb, where they ransacked the Nigerian Embassy and attacked the Guinea Embassy. They forced thousands of people seeking refuge at the Nigerian Embassy, most from Nigeria, into streets where battles raged. It was not clear what happened at the Guinea Embassy, which had given sanctuary to thousands of people from the Mandingo tribe seeking safety from the rebel who have killed thousands of their people, accusing them of supporting and enriching themselves on Doe's corrupt regime. Nigerian Foreign Minister Rilwanu Lukman said in Lagos that his government sent word to Taylor ``that we will hold him personally responsible for any harm done to Nigerians inside the embassy at the time of the attack.'' In alleging the U.S. assassination attempt, Thompson asked the international community to pressure the United States to stop ``excessive harassment'' to remove Doe. ``He said ... Doe and all those in the Executive Mansion have felt under contant harassment from the U.S. Marines, and he was sure that the United States government was now going out deliberately to kill the president,'' said the BBC report. Last month, Doe accused a U.S. submarine of firing on his mansion. The United States denied it. State Depapartment deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said the United States has evacuated 150 people from Liberia this week, including the French and Italian ambassadors. He said prior to the alleged assassination attempt that Prince Johnson, a rebel leader who is a rival of Taylor, ``has not carried out his threat to fire on the Marines.'' He said the Marines ``are there to protect the embassy and the Americans there. ... They're not in Monrovia to intervene in the fighting or to take sides. Diplomats say Taylor wants to capture the city by the weekend. The five-nation West African force, dominated by Nigerian soldiers, mobilized to move into Liberia and impose a cease-fire, by force if necessary. Troops and tanks were reported massing across Liberia's northern border in Guinea and to the east on the Sierra Leone border, according to military sources in Ghana and Sierra Leone. Reports said 500 troops were on standby and may be airlifted into Monrovia. Nigerian troop transports and warships were reported headed for Monrovia harbor. A contingent of 225 U.S. Marines set up defensive positions around their embassy and key U.S. installations on Sunday. They evacuated scores of foreign nationals. France announced it was closing its embassy and evacuating the small remaining staff and any French nationals who could reach evacuation points. Taylor's men on Thursday fought Doe's troops in Congo Town, an eastern suburb in which lie embassies and St. Joseph's Catholic Hospital, the only hospital still operating in Monrovia. ``There is fighting going on all around the hospital and workers there are cut off from an embassy where they were staying,'' a European relief worker said in a radio communication from Monrovia to Europe. The name of the agency was withheld to protect its workers in Liberia. Rebels reportedly met little resistance in their overnight advance. The relief worker said Taylor's rebels ``plundered the (Nigerian) embassy and forced the refugees out.'' She said it was not clear if anyone was wounded. There were no reports about what had happened at the Guinea Embassy. A Foreign Ministry spokesman in Bonn said 300 people from the Nigerian Embassy sought refuge at the West German mission. He said about 500 refugees now were at the mission, including Americans, Belgians, French, Dutch, Irish, Liberians and Filipinos. A relief worker said doctors in Monrovia asked Doe Thursday for permission to burn down St. Peter's Lutheran Church to prevent a plague being spread by decomposing bodies of up to 600 refugees. Survivors said the victims were massacred by Doe's troops July 30. Doe said the killers were rebels in dressed in government uniforms. The attack on the Nigerian Embassy raised tension in the region two days after leaders of the West African Economic Community decided to send troops to end the 7-month-old civil war, in which at least 5,000 people have died. President Joseph Momoh of Sierra Leone told his troops in Freetown on Thursday, ``The need for you as soldiers going to Liberia is due to the deterioration which has resulted in the displacement of innocent citizens, and also in anarchy.'' He said about 80,000 refugees who fled to Sierra Leone were affecting his country's economy and social life, while Sierra Leoneans stranded in Monrovia and sheltering at their country's embassy had no food or medicines. There are more than 400,000 Liberian refugees in neighboring states. Doe and Prince Johnson have welcomed the West African initiative. Taylor is opposed. He fears Nigerian participation because its president, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, in the past has been an ally of Doe. Momoh emphasized the task force ``is to maintain neutrality and our intention is not to take over Liberia.'' Gambian leader Sir Dawda Jawara told the BBC there were no plans to ask the Nigerians to withdraw from the joint force because of Taylor's opposition. The West Africans say they will enforce a cease-fire to allow formation of an interim government charged with organizing free and fair elections within a year. On Wednesday, Johnson freed the last of dozens of foreign hostages seized Monday and Tuesday in a bid to force foreign intervention. The civil war began when Taylor led an insurgent force across the border from the Ivory Coast, accusing Doe of corruption and mismanagement.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Challenges Georgia's Runoff Election System
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department's challenge to Georgia's majority vote election runoff system ultimately could aid Republican candidates in the South and Southwest _ not blacks, a political observer says. The department sued Thursday, contending that Georgia's election runoff system has had ``a chilling effect on black political participation.'' Ten states in the South and Southwest have laws requiring a runoff election if no candidate receives a majority of the votes in a general election. ``The Republican Party can be made overnight in the South if that runoff law is eliminated,'' said Claiborne Darden, an Atlanta-based pollster. ``That would do more for the Republican Party than Republicans could do for themselves in 125 years.'' Without runoff elections, Darden said, blacks would win more Democratic primaries. But they would lose general elections to GOP candidates backed by white voters who previously supported white Democratic candidates, he said. John R. Dunne, assistant attorney general for civil rights, said more than 35 black candidates in over 20 counties in Georgia have finished first in multi-candidate primary elections in recent years, only to lose in runoffs against a single white candidate. He said the law amounts to ``an electoral steroid for white candidates'' because it gives them ``an extraordinary power'' over black candidates in states with racially polarized voting. The suit, filed in U.S. District Court in Atlanta, contends that the 1964 Georgia law requiring candidates to receive a majority of the vote to win an election deprives black voters of an equal opportunity to elect candidates of their choice. The suit marks the first time the Justice Department has used the 1965 Voting Rights Act to challenge a state's majority vote runoff system, a position Jesse Jackson first advocated during his 1984 presidential campaign. Jackson tried unsuccessfully that year to persuade the Democratic Party to take a stand against majority vote runoff elections in its presidential platform. Democratic presidential nominee Walter Mondale opposed the effort. Jackson's Georgia coordinator in 1984, state Rep. Tyrone Brooks of Atlanta, renewed the effort earlier this year when he filed suit in federal court asking that Georgia's runoff system be invalidated. A federal judge refused to rule on the issue before this summer's Georgia elections. Former Atlanta Mayor Andrew Young, who was seeking to become Georgia's first black governor, opposed the lawsuit. Young finished second in the Democratic primary and then was swamped by Lt. Gov. Zell Miller in Tuesday's runoff election. The runoff law, however, has made the political careers of other Georgia leaders. Sen. Sam Nunn, Gov. Joe Frank Harris, and Rep. John Lewis, all Georgia Democrats, were elected for the first time after finishing second in Democratic primaries and then winning the runoff. ``I think the runoff is enormously important, and I think majority rule is important,'' Nunn said Thursday. ``And I believe that if you deprive the people of the right to make that decision by majority votes, you've greatly damaged the election process.'' Asked if he believed the suit was an effort by Republicans to weaken the Democratic Party in the South, Nunn said, ``I wouldn't want to make that charge. But I certainly disagree with the Justice Department getting involved in this.'' Dunne said the department has no immediate plans to challenge the election systems in Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, Florida, Louisiana, Oklahoma, Mississippi, South Carolina, and Texas, the only other states with laws requiring a majority vote to be nominated or elected to office. But he said those state runoff laws, because of their similarity to the Georgia law, likely would be overturned should the department prevail in the Georgia case. Dunne said the department's lawsuit challenges only elections where the majority vote requirement has been used to dilute the voting strength of minorities. That would include most statewide elections, he said, and many local elections where blacks are a large bloc of the voting population but have been unable to elect black candidates. Dunne said about 24 percent of Georgia's voting age population is black, but less than 10 percent of the elected offices in the state are held by blacks, and most of those are at the local level.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Reagan White House Thwarted Study
DOC.TEXT: Congressional investigators say a Reagan White House plan to deny federal liability in toxic exposure cases led to the cancellation of a major study of Agent Orange's effects on Vietnam veterans. A House panel concluded in a report issued Thursday that the White House ``controlled and obstructed'' the study Congress ordered from the Centers for Disease Control. The report by the House Government Operations Committee supported arguments by the American Legion and the Vietnam Veterans of America. They filed a lawsuit last week seeking to have the CDC resume its study of the health effects of Agent Orange exposure during the Vietnam war. ``While the Reagan administration defended the Vietnam conflict as an honorable war, it worked behind the scenes to deny benefits to the very people who sacrificed their health for their country,'' said Rep. Ted Weiss, D-N.Y., chairman of the subcommittee that wrote the report. The report followed a 14-month investigation and hearings by Weiss' subcommittee. In a written dissent, the subcommittee's ranking Republican said the report's conclusion of a White House plot to cover up the truth about Agent Orange ``is simply not supported by the facts.'' ``Instead of advancing the debate on Agent Orange in a positive direction, the human resources subcommittee has abused this issue in order to launch an ideological assault upon a Republican White House with which it has never agreed,'' Rep. Richard K. Armey, R-Texas, said. Agent Orange was a herbicide used to destroy ground cover during the Vietnam war. It has been blamed by veterans groups for 19 cancers and a variety of other health problems, including birth defects. Congress ordered the CDC study to determine whether Vietnam veterans had been exposed to Agent Orange. It was to be used as a basis for other studies measuring links to health problems. The report said the White House ordered the study's cancellation after the CDC said it was scientifically impossible to use military records to identify veterans who had been exposed. The committee said the study should have continued ``because CDC did not document that exposure could not be assessed'' and disregarded alternate methods of measuring exposure. ``The White House compromised the independence of the CDC and undermined the study by controlling crucial decisions and guiding the course of research, at the same time it had secretly taken a legal position to resist demands to compensate victims of Agent Orange exposure and industrial accidents,'' the report said. At the CDC in Atlanta, spokeswoman Gayle Lloyd said the agency would have no comment because it had not seen the report. But she said, ``We do stand by our studies and our decisions.'' A spokeswoman for the Department of Veterans Affairs, Donna St. John, said the agency had no comment. The study was officially monitored by a White House task force called the Agent Orange Working Group. The House panel concluded the White House controlled the study through the working group and the Office of Management and Budget. The panel said that despite evidence Vietnam veterans are more susceptible to certain forms of cancer and birth defects in their offspring, the federal government has consistently refused to acknowledge any link to Agent Orange exposure. ``The federal government has suppressed or minimized findings of ill health effects among Vietnam veterans that could be linked to Agent Orange exposure,'' the report said. But Armey said in his dissent scientific information has failed to establish any conclusive link between Agent Orange and health problems. He said that ``compensating veterans for simple exposure to Agent Orange is a political decision, not a scientific one.'' The VA this year decided to award compensation for two rare cancers, soft-tissue sarcoma and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, linked to Agent Orange.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Measures Bring Chaos to Peru's Streets
LaserPhoto NY11
DOC.TEXT: Stores were closed, buses stayed in the garage and soldiers in tanks patrolled the streetson the first day of an economic austerity program. Three people died in isolated protests and looting. The capital's normally crowded downtown streets were nearly deserted Thursday in the hours after the new government of President Alberto Fujimori announced a plan to end soaring inflation. A military state of emergency was declared early this week to prepare for the rigid measures, announced Wednesday by Prime Minister Carlos Hurtado Miller, also the country's economy minister. Under the plan, the price of gasoline jumped from 7 cents per gallon to more than $2. Many basic foods tripled and quadrupled in cost. Price subsidies, a staple of government policy for four decades, are to be eliminated. Controls will be removed to allow the inti _ the nation's currency _ to float free. If the value of the inti against other currencies falls as expected, Peruvian products would be cheaper abroad and spur exports. Import duties will be drastically cut, forcing Peruvian industry to compete with foreign-made goods. Taxes will be raised, especially for the rich. ``God help us,'' Hurtado said after announcing the measures. The austerity plan aims to slash the 3,000 annual inflation rate. The government also hopes to provide the basis for rebuilding Peru's collapsed economy, which has shrunk by 20 percent in the last two years. Industry runs at less than half its capacity. Automobile sales last year were 10 percent of 1967 levels. Only one in five Peruvians holds an official job. Peru's worst drought this century has deepened the crisis. Up to 70 percent of many crops, including staples such as the potato, have been lost. Authorities are uncertain how Peruvians will respond to the measures. Many people voted for Fujimori because of his strong opposition to the harsh austerity plan proposed by campaign opponent Mario Vargas Llosa. The poor are especially liable to feel betrayed by the austerity program. About one-third of Peru's 22 million people live in critical poverty and the great majority voted for Fujimori. Nevertheless, it is this sector of the population that will likely suffer most from the measures. Many of the poor will simply be unable to afford food or bus fares. The government has said it will hand out food and subsidize water and bus service. The government has promised $450 million to help the poor survive the economic adjustment, Hurtado said Wednesday. But new bus fares had yet to be set Thursday night and most municipalities lacked the food to set up soup kitchens. The government has yet to raise most of the $450 million. Markets were shuttered Thursday, exacerbating the situation. Most of Peru's poor buy food on a day-by-day basis. ``What am I going to eat? What are my children going to eat?'' Maria Vidaurre said Thursday before the locked gates of a shantytown market. She held an empty plastic bag. Many economists, including top Fujimori advisers, have said Peru's economy is too weak to absorb an extreme austerity program. They said vastly higher prices accompanied by a tight monetary policy could paralyze the country. Many believe the key to the austerity program's success will be the military's ability to keep order. The army has taken a major role in Fujimori's government, with active generals running the ministries of defense and interior. Many police responsibilities were transferred to military control last week, after a purge of top police officials. The state of emergency _ which allows the army to arrest people without hearings and to search houses without warrant _ was decreed two days before Hurtado's speech. The strict security measures are to help quell a 10-year-old insurgency by leftist Shining Path rebels in which more than 15,000 people have died.

DOC.HEAD: Crisis Not Keeping President From Maine
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Bush leaves White House 1:15 p.m. EDT, arrives Maine home at 3:15 p.m. EDT; may be led
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is headed to Maine on a 3{-week vacation, saying ``life goes on'' despite the Persian Gulf crisis. Bush and his wife Barbara were leaving the White House for their summer home in Kennebunkport, three days after Bush sent American troops and warplanes off to defend Saudi Arabia against Iraqi aggression. ``Life goes on,'' Bush said Thursday evening when asked if he really planned to go on vacation. ``Gotta keep moving. Can't stay in one place all the time,'' the president said, bantering with reporters after leaving the Oval Office. He later went out to dinner with his wife, who had flown down from their oceanside home for the day. She had been in Maine with grandchildren since July 27. The White House said Bush was taking extra staff with him to Maine to help monitor events in the Middle East in the wake of last week's Iraqi occupation of Kuwait and the deployment of U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia. Bush also will fly back to Washington on Wednesday for a military briefing, then return to Maine, where he will stay until Labor Day, Sept. 3. ``The president will be conducting the business of the presidency at Kennebunkport just as he does every year and every vacation,'' press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. That goes on ``24 hours a day, every day of the week, wherever he is.'' Bush's oceanfront home at Walker's Point has its own helipad, sophisticated communications equipment, and is heavily protected on land by the Secret Service and at sea by Coast Guard ships hovering offshore. Fitzwater said the White House never seriously considered canceling the vacation plans. Bush has gone to Kennebunkport every summer of his life except 1944, when he was off in the Pacific flying bombing missions for the Navy against the Japanese in World War II. Either Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, or his deputy, Robert Gates, always accompanies Bush to Kennebunkport and provides daily briefings on the latest U.S. intelligence from hot spots around the world. ``Our forces are in Saudi Arabia on a defensive basis. They're not involved in conflict, and there's not the need for any kind of minute-by-minute or hour-by-hour update that might be necessary if they were actually involved in combat,'' said Fitzwater. Bush plans to fly to Baltimore on Aug. 20 to address the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention. He also will attend several fund-raising events for GOP candidates in New England during his vacation.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Agency Seeks $40.9 Million From Keating, Five Associates
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators want Charles H. Keating Jr. and five associates to pay $40.9 million to the defunct Lincoln Savings and Loan Association for losses it suffered from three sour business deals. But a spokesman for Keating and lawyers for his company accused the Office of Thrift Supervision of trying to harass the Phoenix businessman because regulators have failed to prove allegations raised in court cases. OTS launched administrative proceedings Thursday against Keating, the chairman of American Continental Corp., and five of the company's top officers. The regulators are seeking to recover money they say was improperly used to finance questionable business deals. The agency also seeks to remove Keating and the five executives from the company and bar them forever from the thrift industry. American Continental, which owned Lincoln Savings and Loan, filed for bankruptcy protection a day before the Irvine, Calif., thrift was seized by federal regulators in April, 1989. Lincoln, which Keating's company acquired in 1984, invested heavily in the junk bond market. A federal grand jury in Los Angeles is investigating possible criminal wrongdoing in the S&L's $2 billion failure. Keating has repeatedly claimed he is broke. But OTS Director Timothy Ryan said regulators ``just do not believe him right now'' and want a full accounting of Keating's personal assets in five days. ``There was much too much money that was available to him and too short a time for it all to disappear,'' Ryan said. A temporary cease and desist order demanding that he account for his assets also bars Keating from moving any money out of the country. It also forbids him from making any transactions over $5,000 without first notifying OTS. American Continental spokesman Bradley Boland said Keating and his associates would ``take every legal opportunity that is available'' to fight the charges.
