Ryan said an administrative law judge will hear the case in late October. OTS may seek additional restitution after completing investigations of other deals financed by Lincoln, he said. A statement issued by lawyers representing American Continental said the OTS action ``appears to be a case of duplicative and harassing litigation. ``In its claim for restitution, the government is again seeking the same relief against the same individuals with respect to the same transactions that are at issue in the civil RICO suit it filed nearly a year ago,'' the lawyers said in a statement read by Washington attorney Leonard Bickwit Jr. Last September, the Resolution Trust Corp. and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. cited the same three transactions outlined in the OTS charges in a racketeering suit against Keating and his associates filed under the Racketeer-Influenced Corrupt Organizations law. Keating in turn sued federal regulators, charging that the seizure of Lincoln Savings was unwarranted. The case is still unresolved. The agency's complaint details a loss to Lincoln of $24.2 million for an investment in a money-losing hotel in Detroit, and a $4.4 million loss on what regulators called the sham sale of desert land in Arizona. It also outlines how Lincoln lost $12.3 million when it financed an employee stock ownership plan's purchase of American Continental stock from Keating and others. The charges also were filed against five other American Continental officers: Judy J. Wischer, president and chief executive officer; Robert J. Kielty, a director, senior vice president and general counsel; Keating's son, Charles H. Keating III, an executive vice president and director; and two of Keating's sons-in-law who are vice presidents, Robert J. Hubbard and Robert M. Wurzelbacher Jr. The Justice Department is investigating whether Keating illegally donated $1.3 million to five senators who in 1987 intervened with federal regulators on his behalf, sources say. The Senate Ethics Committee is also investigating the allegations of misconduct against the five lawmakers.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts: Iraq Has No Chemical Warheads Able to Reach Israel by Missile
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Despite threats by Iraqi president Saddam Hussein to use chemical weapons against Israel, analysts say they do not believe Iraq has developed a chemical warhead capable of reaching the Jewish state by missile. The experts said Iraq's only option was to deliver the chemical weapons to Israel by artillery bombardments or air raids, which would have little chance of success. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, meanwhile, compared the Iraqi leader with Hitler and warned him that the Jewish people would retaliate if attacked. Saddam has threatened to attack Israel in case of an American military strike in the Persian Gulf. Speaking to graduates of the army's defense college on Thursday, Shamir said he was not taking the Iraqi leaders threats lightly and warned any attempt to harm Israel ``will cost him and his army a heavy price.'' After comparing him to Hitler, Shamir noted that the decades since the Holocaust has changed the Jewish nation, which lost some six million people during World War II. ``This time the Jewish nation has the ability and the tools to defend itself, and if need be, to repel and defeat,'' he said. Iraq has the Soviet-made Scud B or SS-1 surface-to-surface missiles with a range of 170 miles and the Iraqi-modified version of these, al-Hussein, with a range of 370 to 430 miles. Israeli generals decided last weekend to step up the distribution of gas masks nationwide. But Chief of Staff Lt.Gen. Dan Shomron told Israel television the army was refraining from distributing the masks because the hysteria would be ``playing into the hands of Saddam Hussein.'' ``We have the ability to prevent the attacks on Israel,'' he said without elaborating. Joseph Alpher, an analyst at the Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies, said he believed Saddam did not yet have chemical warheads for its surface-to-surface missiles despite Iraqi efforts to develop rockets capable of carrying the payload. Moshe Shlonsky, Israel television's military affairs reporter, said Iraq could only deliver chemical weapons on Israel through atillery bombardment from batteries deployed along the Israel-Jordanian border or from long distance air raids which involved mid-flight refuling. ``The chance of this happening without being foiled by Israel is not great,'' he said. However, Aharon Levran, a strategic analyst and former brigadier general, believed Saddam would not have made the threats to us chemical weapons against Israel if he did not have the capability of delivering them.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers in Saudi Arabia Learned Desert Warfare in California
DOC.TEXT: U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia prepared for the searing heat and gear-grinding sand of the Middle East by taking part in mock combat on a 1,000-square-mile patch of the Mojave Desert near Death Valley. Summertime temperatures at the Army's Fort Irwin National Training Center reach about 120 degrees, about 10 degrees hotter than Saudi Arabia, where President Bush sent troops to defend the oil kingdom against Iraq. At the outset of the deployment, Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, noted that troops of the departing 82nd Airborne Division learn desert warfare and chemical combat at the California base. In fact, every Army brigade visits about once every 18 months and spends two weeks in war games. Since 1982, about 390,000 Army soldiers have battled the elements _ and each other. Visiting soldiers face the resident 177th Armored Brigade, a 2,300-member unit trained in Soviet tactics, including gas attacks, said Maj. John Wagstaffe, a base spokesman. ``You can die every day for 14 days at the National Training Center, and that's a sobering thing for most soldiers,'' Wagstaffe said Thursday. ``What we're hoping is that by dying 14 times out here, we'll help prevent our soldiers from dying when they have to go into real combat.'' Fort Irwin is on a high desert plain. The nearest town is Barstow, 37 miles away. The isolation allows a full range of military operations, including artillery fire, radio jamming and low flying of jets and helicopters. President Bush visited the center in February and interrupted a mock battle to address troops by radio. ``Military challenges to democracy persist in every hemisphere and America must always be prepared to fight for freedom and security,'' he said. From a hill, Bush watched bursts of artillery and streaking jets. He saw the Soviet-style opposing force break through the Army team's lines. Making mistakes is part of the training, Wagstaffe said. One lieutenant had his squad prepare for a tank attack by digging a deep trench, but forgot to close one end of the ditch, allowing tanks to pour in. ``The lieutenant who dug this hole, I guarantee you, will not make the same mistake in Saudi Arabia, in Panama or anywhere else,'' said Wagstaffe. Soviet desert warfare features a speedy, swarming style based on surprise and a ``be-damned attitude about taking casualties,'' he said. U.S.-Soviet tensions have eased, but Iraq and 30 other nations train with Soviet military tactics and use their equipment. Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein, who boasts a battle-hardened army of 1 million, has used poison gas in his war with Iran. Gas also was used against Iraq's Kurdish minority. Tear gas is substituted for mustard gas and nerve gas in the Fort Irwin war games, which count ``kills'' with laser beams and sensors. The ``enemy'' soldiers of the 177th use the gas freely, Wagstaffe said. Targeted soldiers scramble into protective clothing. It takes 15 seconds to put on gas masks and hoods, eight minutes to don hot, cumbersome full-body suits. The war is make-believe, but sometimes the dying is real. Helicopter accidents, bad-weather parachute jumps and vehicle accidents have killed at least 20 soldiers in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Baghdad's Opponents Face Terrorism, Intimidation
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Although Iraq was removed in 1982 from the U.S. list of countries that support terrorism, the Baghdad government still uses force and intimidation against opponents at home and abroad, experts say. Iraqi exiles say President Saddam Hussein uses an extensive network of informers, especially among the Iraqi student community abroad, to finger opponents of his government and to plot their assassinations. Prof. Bernard Reich, specialist in Middle East politics and terrorism at George Washington University in Washington, said Saddam is ``demonstrating that those not bending to his views will face terror and intimidation. Without question he has employed state terrorism and chemical warfare and has been willing to use it against his own people.'' Saddam has used poison gas against Kurds seeking independence from the Baghdad government. Within the Arab world, Saddam's goals are ``Iraqi leadership and that he is prepared to use virtually all means to achieve that end, from economic intimidation to the use of force and terror,'' Reich said in an interview. The United States resumed relations with Iraq in 1984 after a 17-year lapse, citing in part Iraq's improved record on terrorism. The U.S. State Department said in its annual report on terrorism last April that Iraq was still working toward improving its image and wasn't known to have sponsored any acts of terrorism in the past year. But the latest U.S. State Department report on human-rights practices around the world said: ``Iraq's human-rights record remained abysmal in 1989.'' ``The intelligence services engage in extensive surveillance and utilize extralegal means, including torture and summary execution, to deal with anti-regime activity,'' the report said. As recently as April, the U.S. State Department expelled an Iraqi diplomat at the United Nations because of his suspected role in an alleged plot to murder two opponents of the Baghdad government in California. Two years ago, Sudan accused an unidentified Iraqi diplomat of assassinating an Iraqi opposition leader who was killed by two gunmen as he sat in the lobby of the Khartoum Hilton hotel. On terrorism, the department said Iraq has continued to provide safe haven to some Palestinian groups, including the Iraqi-created Arab Liberation Front and Abul Abbas' Palestine Liberation Front. It cited press reports that Abu Ibrahim, whom it described as the former leader of the now defunct 15 May terrorist organization, had returned to Iraq. ``Abu Ibrahim is known for the skill with which he built highly sophisticated and lethal suitcase bombs,'' the department said. Notorious terrorist mastermind Abu Nidal once lived in Baghdad but he was kicked out more than a decade ago as Saddam sought a more moderate image in the West. Abu Nidal, the nom de guerre of Sabri al-Banna, reportedly lives in Libya where his movement is riven with an internal feud. He was expelled from Iraq in 1978, but reportedly returned for a while in late 1982. Nowadays Iraq provides a haven to only a few such international terror groups _ most of which are thought to operate from Libya or Syria. But Reich said Saddam might try to exploit any terrorist groups that remain headquartered in Baghdad. In the current Middle East crisis, the focus is on major military intimidation, Reich said. But he said that if Saddam should make a face-saving retreat he might revert to terrorist attacks on American and other Western targets outside the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Lower
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 27,329.55, down 286.18 points or 1.04 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Far from Main Arena in Gulf Crisis But in Touch with White House
DOC.TEXT: An hour into the inauguration of a new Colombian president, with the ornate oratory just getting started, the emergency call came from the White House to Bogota with word for Vice President Dan Quayle. American troops and warplanes would be sent to Saudi Arabia to defend against possible invasion by Iraq. Word of the decision was seeping out, and the White House wanted Quayle forewarned that what had been secret was becoming public. The vice president couldn't take the call himself. He was in a front row VIP seat on the inaugural platform of Cesar Gaviria, a spot too prominent to leave for a phone call. ``I had a pretty good idea what it was about, and I was right,'' Quayle said Thursday as he flew home from a three-day Latin American mission that had left him far from the arena as the administration dealt with the Persian Gulf crisis. ``I knew that we were going in.'' Quayle wouldn't say when he knew. ``I'll leave it to others to get into a tick-tock situation,'' he said. The vice president left Washington for Bogota on Tuesday, the sixth day of the crisis triggered by Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait. There had been crisis conferences with President Bush every day since Friday, and the administration had planned its course. ``There was no reason for me to cancel this trip,'' Quayle said. By late afternoon Tuesday, Bush's decision to send forces to Saudi Arabia began to leak, prompting the call to alert Quayle. William Kristol, his chief of staff, took it in a sitting room of the Colombian presidential palace, set aside for Quayle and for U.S. Embassy use that day. Quayle got word of the message before the inauguration was over, and details before he left Bogota for Lima, Peru. Aides said there was no thought of returning to Washington, and no need. While Bush delivered his televised address to the nation Wednesday morning, announcing what he called a defensive stand against ``an aggressive dictator threatening his neighbors,'' Quayle was at a breakfast meeting with Peruvian business and civic leaders. He couldn't break away, and the U.S. ambassador's residence in Lima doesn't have cable television anyhow. Kristol was the relay man again. This time he slipped out of the breakfast meeting and went upstairs, telephoned Quayle aides at the Sheraton Lima Hotel, and had them hold the phone up against a television set so that he could take notes on the Bush address. It turned out to be unnecessary; the White House had faxed a text of the speech to the vice president, and it got there before the breakfast was over. Quayle said he had a good idea of what Bush was going to say from their conversations on the crisis before he left Washington. In Bogota, Quayle had talked with Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez about the crisis, and had assurances that he would work to make up the oil shortfall stemming from the crisis _ about 4.5 million barrels a day in Iraqi and Kuwaiti production. Perez was said to have told Quayle that Venezuelan production would be increased by 500,000 barrels, and that other OPEC oil nations also would boost production. That message went the other way, from Quayle's traveling party to the White House. ``We're in contact. I wouldn't say on an hourly basis, but every couple of hours,'' Quayle said. But it was long distance, very long distance. While Quayle was dealing with drug control efforts and Latin American development and aid programs, the Middle East crisis came up constantly, in his conferences with the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia, and in his public statements. Once, he was asked about the danger of Iraq's ``poison bombs,'' a reference to the threat of chemical weapons in the Gulf conflict. ``We are fully appraised of the military capability of Iraq,'' he said. ``We will be able to defend ourselves and to work for the defense of Saudi Arabia.'' Quayle returned to Washington Thursday night, after a four-hour stop in Haiti in the cause of free elections there. Elections are scheduled on Nov. 4. Quayle met with leaders of the provisional government, the armed forces and an electoral commission to urge that they work to enable the Haitian people ``to go to the polls to vote in free, secure and credible elections.'' Elections in 1987 were aborted by violence in which at least 34 people were killed. ``Haiti deserves democracy,'' Quayle told about 200 military men and government officials. ``So my message is: no coups, no murders, no threats. ``And instead, free and fair elections that will bring honor to the brave people of Haiti.''

DOC.HEAD: Andrews Air Force Base Guard Shoots, Kills Intruder
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force Security Police airman shot and killed a man who drove through a security checkpoint at an entrance to Andrews Air Force Base. The man, described as a 34-year-old civilian, was pronounced dead at Malcolm Grow Medical Center on the base about 1:05 p.m. Thursday, Lt. Col. Temple Black said. The man drove through the base's manned west gate shortly after 12:30 p.m., base officials said. Guards shouted at the man to stop, but he continued driving erratically for about 200 yards, officials said. It was unclear whether the driver stopped when asked, Black said. It also was unclear whether the man was inside or outside of the car when he was shot. The incident was being investigated by the Air Force's Office of Special Investigations and the FBI. Hospital officials said the man's relatives had been notified of his death. Base officials gave no reason for withholding his identity.
DOC.HEAD: Government Orders Sulfur Cut in Diesel Fuel
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency is ordering an 80 percent cut in diesel fuel sulfur content, saying the move would help get rid of black smoke belched from truck tailpipes. ``This control measure is an important step for cleaner air and protection from the harmful effects'' of pollution, EPA Administrator William K. Reilly said Thursday. The regulation will boost the price of diesel fuel as much as 2.3 cents per gallon, he said. It requires refiners to reduce sulfur content of the fuel used on the road from 0.25 percent by weight to 0.05 percent, effective Oct. 1, 1993. Small refiners have until 1995 to phase in the new standards as they install equipment to remove the sulfur, Reilly said. During that period, they will have to meet a set of interim standards. The new regulation will help manufacturers of large diesel engines meet a 1985 requirement to curtail emissions of diesel ``particulates,'' said Jeff Alson, an engineer with the EPA's Office of Mobile Sources in Ann Arbor, Mich. The particulates _ tiny bits of soot, hydrocarbons and other materials _ are inhaled and tend to remain in the human respiratory tract, Alson said. They often are contaminated with poisonous fumes. EPA recently declared the diesel particulate a probable carcinogen. It is believed to cause about 600 cases of cancer a year. ``It's nowhere near as big a carcinogen as cigarette smoking, for example, but we still want to minimize the damage,'' Alson said. Reilly said the new regulation on diesel sulfur and the 1985 rule on particulates, which will be fully effective next year, will ``virtually eliminate the black smoke from diesel tailpipes, cutting particulates by 90 percent,'' Reilly said.
DOC.HEAD: Former Chicago-Philadelphia FBI Agent Gets Pay-Plus-Pension
DOC.TEXT: Settlement

A black FBI agent who charged in civil suits he was racially harassed by white agents will receive full pay and pension benefits, possibly worth more than $1 million, under a settlement of the case, his lawyer says. Attorneys for Donald Rochon, 40, and the FBI signed an agreement this week that settles the three-year-old legal battle arising from the black agent's charges he was harassed by white colleagues when he worked in the FBI's Chicago office. The settlement is a further admission by the FBI of racial problems in its ranks. Officials earlier this year acknowledged that the FBI had settled three other racial discrimination suits, including one involving 30 employees of the fingerprint identification division. The FBI announced the settlement with Rochon on Wednesday but declined to give details. Rochon, who has been on disability leave since April because of emotional stress, will receive full compensation and full pension benefits under the terms of the settlement, said his attorney, David Kairys of Philadelphia. Rochon will remain on disability leave until he is eligible to retire in 11 years, Kairys said. As a result of the emotional strain, ``he never wants to go back to the FBI,'' the lawyer said.
DOC.HEAD: Report: Navy Fleet Maintenance Costs Higher Than Projected
DOC.TEXT: The cost of maintaining and overhauling the nation's naval fleet exceeded original estimates by about 30 percent with expenses rising to $3.7 billion over a three-year period, congressional investigators say. The General Accounting Office, the watchdog agency of Congress, found cost growth and schedule overruns at the eight public shipyards and 44 private shipyards across the United States between fiscal years 1985 and 1988. Public shipyards generally work on more sophisticated ships, including submarines, carriers and nuclear-powered surface ships. Private shipyards usually handle auxiliary and amphibious ships. The GAO blamed the problems at private shipyards on an inability to determine beforehand what repair work must be done, unplanned work added after the government contract has been awarded and difficulty in obtaining materials. In the study, released the end of July, the GAO also found that the market for ship maintenance and modernization is highly competitive, forcing contractors to submit low bids to obtain Navy work. Similar problems also existed at public shipyards, where the GAO found that in some cases the companies did not have enough labor to do the work properly. At the private shipyards, the GAO said that over a three-year period, contract costs increased from $2.8 billion to $3.7 billion with the final prices exceeding the contract award prices on 357 of 402 projects.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Still Unable To Leave Iraq, Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Despite pressure from the United States, Iraq continues to deny permission for more than 3,500 Americans to leave Iraq and Kuwait, the State Department said. Deputy spokesman Richard Boucher confirmed Thursday that a 10-year-old American girl, Penelope Nabokov, was allowed to leave the Hotel Rashid in Baghdad and to enter the American Embassy, The girl had been flying unaccompanied from France to India when she was taken into custody by Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait during a stopover there at the time of the Iraqi invasion last week. But Boucher said Iraqi officials have refused exit visas to Americans and other foreigners in the two countries. The United States and several Western allies have made joint appeals to the Iraqi government to let citizens of their respective countries depart, he said. The administration has become increasingly concerned about Americans in Iraq and Kuwait as military tensions between the United States and Iraq have escalated. There are about 3,000 Americans in Kuwait. Boucher said Thursday there were 580 Americans in Iraq. U.S. officials have focused their concern on 38 Americans at the Hotel Rashid. Almost all were bused from Kuwait by Iraqi authorities last week and are confined to the hotel under armed guard. The State Department is refusing to call them hostages. Boucher said that 10 dependents and nonessential personnel from t he American embassy in Baghdad departed the capital by road Thursday and reached the Iraqi-Jordanian border. They were turned back by Iraqi officials at the border, but subsequently the foreign ministry in Baghdad informed U.S. officials that they will be permitted to cross, Boucher said. Although Boucher contended the borders in both Kuwait and Iraq were closed, Jordanian officials said thousands of foreigners, mainly Arabs, had fled Kuwait in recent days. They entered Saudi Arabia and then crossed the border into Jordan 60 miles southeast of Amman. The officials, insisting on anonymity, said most of the Arabs arriving from Kuwait were Egyptian workers. After crossing into Jordan they traveled to the Red Sea port of Aqaba to await transportation to Egypt by sea, the officials said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. News Media Left Behind in Troop Moves
DOC.TEXT: Journalists are protesting to the Pentagon that U.S. troops have arrived in Saudi Arabia, but no reporters have been given access to cover the story. ``The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia controls its borders and decides who enters that country, and that's not for us to tell the Saudis who comes in,'' Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams told reporters at a briefing Thursday. Williams said he was ``sensitive'' to such requests and said he was attempting to get reporters on the U.S. Navy ships that have been deployed to the region. Several reporters responded that they would prefer to be in Saudi Arabia with U.S. troops, given that placement on a ship would prevent them from covering any ground conflict, should such an event occur. ``I think you all know that we want very much for this to work. Obviously as we continue to commit forces to Saudi Arabia, that's something we have to be mindful of,'' Williams said. ``It's a very sensitive subject ... Let me just say that we'll try to get you out on the ships as soon as possible to continue to work the rest of it.'' Burl Osborne, president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors and the president and editor of The Dallas Morning News, has written Williams to protest the situation. ``We now have a situation in which an increasing number of American troops are deployed in dangerous areas in the Middle East, and the American press is not being given access to the U.S. military forces,'' Osborne said. ``We urge that somehow _ either with the use of press pools or by other means _ you take immediate action to insure that the American press has access to the air, ground and naval forces in the Middle East.'' On Wednesday, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was queried about the same subject. He said the Saudis had established ``the ground rules under which people have access to cover activities inside the kingdom.'' Cheney said the Pentagon would work on the problem. He didn't make any promises and wasn't specific. In the invasion of Panama last December, the U.S. forces took along a small group of reporters selected in advance by their employers and pledged to keep their movement secret to protect the security of the military operation. This ``pool'' arrangement was set up after the U.S. invasion of Grenada, when journalists were kept away from the Caribbean island entirely. Although there have been several tests of the Pentagon media pool, it didn't work in Panama. Instead of being taken to the front lines of battle as promised, the reporters were kept bottled up away from the action.

DOC.HEAD: Military Takes Part in Sweep of Marijuana Growing Area
DOC.TEXT: Army soldiers, National Guardsmen and federal agents claimed to have destroyed more than 1,400 marijuana plants in a 12-day sweep that drew protests and a lawsuit from residents and civil libertarians. The operation, which ended Thursday, was the first time that active-duty soldiers have been used to fight marijuana growing in the United States. About 50 agents from the Bureau of Land Management and the Drug Enforcement Agency and an estimated 150 Guardsmen and soldiers from Fort Ord took part in Operation Green Sweep, a raid on pot fields in the King Range National Conservation Area. There were no arrests. The rugged, 60,000-acre area and its environs along California's northwestern coast was settled in the early 1970s by hundreds of hippies and homesteaders. Marijuana was widely planted on both public and private land. On Thursday, six residents and several groups, including the Civil Liberties Monitoring Project, filed a lawsuit in federal court seeking to bar the use of soldiers to enforce drug laws. The lawsuit also seeks $100 million in damages. The lawsuit alleges the troops engaged in illegal searches, roadblocks, interrogations and detentions. The soldiers used ``excessive force to terrorize, intimidate and otherwise distress residents,'' the lawsuit said. Roger Bruckner, BLM agent in charge, called the operation a ``fantastic success.'' He said 1,408 marijuana plants with a potential street value of $4.2 million had been confiscated from 28 marijuana-growing sites and destroyed. The BLM said 12 tons of growing equipment, including pipes and water storage tanks, was seized. ``What's important is that we've made the point that marijuana growing will not be tolerated on BLM land,'' Bruckner said. ``Would-be growers will not only lose their crop and their labor, but they'll also lose their investment in irrigation systems and other agriculturl equipment.'' The operation cost about $100,000 above normal expenses such as salaries, said Art Lunklay, BLM state drug coordinator. Soon after the raid started, 11 demonstrators were arrested on minor charges involving violation of government closure of some areas. But Bruckner said such protests never attracted more than a small percentage of the area's residents. Some residents called to voice their support, Bruckner said. ``I particularly want to thank the person who mailed us a detailed and, as it turned out, surprisingly accurate map of one area,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Marlon Brando Takes Center Stage in Son's Murder Case
LaserPhoto LA12 of Aug.9
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando commanded center stage in his son's murder case, promising to post the $2 million bail and declaring, ``My son is not a mad dog killer.'' The usually reclusive 66-year-old actor stood on the courthouse lawn and spoke with reporters for an hour, accusing ``the sleaze bags'' of TV news and ``the carrion press'' of turning the case into ``a circus ... some kind of animal show.'' Bail for Christian Brando, 32, was reduced to $2 million from $10 million Thursday. He has been in jail since the fatal shooting on May 16 of Dag Drollet, the boyfriend of Brando's half-sister, Cheyenne Brando. Brando said his offspring suffer unfairly because of his celebrity. He admitted his son, an unemployed welder, has a history of alcohol and drug abuse. But he said: ``My son isn't a mad dog killer and I hate to see anyone portrayed that way. There is another Christian and I hope to have the opportunity to present that.'' Defense attorney Robert Shapiro was uncertain how long it would take for Brando to post the bail, either by putting up the cash or offering the deed to his $4 million home in the hills above Bel-Air. The trial is set for Oct. 9.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force General Named to Head `Desert Shield'
DOC.TEXT: The front-line Air Force general directing U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia is a highly decorated Vietnam War fighter pilot who blends toughness with a sense of humor, neighbors say. Lt. Gen. Charles A. Horner, 53, was named Thursday to head Desert Shield, the U.S. military effort to prevent further Iraqi advances in the Persian Gulf. ``He's the forward commander. He's the one that's on the ground and out in the boonies directing the show,'' said one Pentagon officer. The three-star general, a native of Davenport, Iowa, has lived here since 1987 with wife, Mary Jo. He commands the 9th Air Force and the U.S. Central Command Air Forces at nearby Shaw Air Force Base. Friends in Sumter, a city of 29,000 about 45 miles from Columbia, are impressed with the man known as much for his quick wit and love of golf as for his military exploits. ``He gives the appearance of a real tough guy, and he is tough. But he also has a delightful sense of humor,'' said Phil Ballinger, president of the Sumter County Chamber of Commerce. ``He could be a professional comedian. He keeps people laughing, but when the time comes, he's certainly a no-nonsense guy.'' Horner is a pilot with more than 4,500 flying hours. He regularly flies a variety of jets. During the Vietnam War, Horner tallied more than 100 combat missions in F-105 fighter bombers. He was an instructor at the Fighter Weapons School at Nellis Air Force Base in Nevada and went on to hold a number of positions in the Tactical Air Command at Langley Air Force Base in Virginia. A graduate of the Armed Forces Staff College and the National War College, he commanded units at Nellis, at Luke Air Force Base in Arizona and at Holloman Air Force Base in New Mexico. In 1985, he was named deputy chief for plans at the Tactical Air Command Headquarters. He assumed his present command in 1987. Horner's decorations include the Distinguished Service Medal, the Silver Star with one oak leaf cluster, the Legion of Merit, Distinguished Flying Cross, Meritorious Service Medal, Air Medal and Air Force Commendation Medal. ``Gen. Horner is a down-to-earth professional, a superb general officer who knows his stuff but genuinely cares about the people under his command,'' said Rep. John Spratt, D-S.C. Mayor Steve Creech said Horner has about a 12-handicap but could be a better golfer if he had more time. City officials work hard to maintain close ties with the base and they say Horner is the best of neighbors. He joins in Chamber of Commerce projects and meets frequently with community leaders. But right now, his neighbors are glad he's a tested fighting man. ``He's a very skilled and knowledgeable Air Force commander,'' Ballinger said. ``I'm glad he's on our side.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Chemical Weapons Pose Small Threat To U.S. Troops, Experts Say
LaserPhoto FAYX1 of Aug. 9
With PM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's chemical weapons might slow U.S. troops down in the Middle East but are unlikely to claim many American lives, arms experts say. Brad Roberts, a chemical-arms specialist at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, said Iraq's chemical weapons could not stop a U.S. naval blockade or defeat an American defense of Saudi Arabia's oil fields. If ground warfare broke out between Iraq and the United States, Iraq's President Saddam Hussein could use chemical weapons to attack U.S. forces and to deny them access to certain terrain, Roberts said. ``But to do it over an extended period of time, he would need a lot of chemical agent,'' and it would have to be packaged in artillery shells, bombs or missiles, and he would need the ability to move the weapons into place quickly. ``Those three things are difficult, and it's not clear he can do them,'' Roberts said. Iraq's use of chemical weapons against Iran led to ghastly pictures of victims covered with severe blisters, but most of those victims recovered, Iran has reported. As of April 1987, for example, Iran had reported 27,000 victims but only 262 deaths, said Seth Carus, a fellow at the Naval War College Foundation in Newport, R.I. Iraq has also used chemical weapons against the Kurds, an ethnic minority in Iraq. John Deutch, provost of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a member of the Defense Science Board, said it's likely the United States would dramatically escalate the conflict if Hussein used chemical weapons against U.S. troops. ``I fear to speculate what the response would be by the U.S. or its allies,'' he said. The threat of chemical weapons could reduce the effectiveness of U.S. troops forced to wear protective suits and gas masks in the fierce desert heat, the authorities said. But most said that wouldn't give Iraq a very important tactical advantage. ``There is a popular misconception that you have to wear the protection buttoned up all the time, and that's simply not true,'' said Matthew Meselson of Harvard University, who has been a government consultant on chemical weapons. ``When the detectors show there aren't chemicals around, you don't zip up.'' Meselson said protective gear would make it seem 10 degrees hotter than it really was. If the temperature is 100 degrees and the humidity 50 percent, a soldier probably shouldn't carry a 90-pound pack for more than 40 minutes, he said. If he has to pull on a suit over his uniform, that might be cut to 20 minutes. ``It would be an annoyance, but nothing to compare with the incoming high explosives,'' Meselson said. Deutch disagreed. He argued that chemical weapons pose an important military threat, although not a major threat to American lives. Even a few badly aimed chemical weapons ``would cause every ship, every military unit to conduct themselves in a more prudent way and reduce their effectiveness,'' he said. Iraq has known stockpiles of at least 1,400 tons of mustard gas and perhaps 200 pounds of the nerve gas tabun since it ended its war with Iran in 1988, said Carus. Actual stockpiles could be several thousand tons. Under ideal conditions, it takes 4 tons of airborne mustard gas or 2 tons of airborne tabun to kill 50 percent of unprotected people spread over about a third of a square mile, Carus said. If the people are wearing protection, the death rates are far lower, he said. And much more gas is needed in the hot, dry conditions of the Middle East, where gas evaporates much more quickly, Carus said. Mustard gas and tabun work in entirely different ways, said Gordon Burck, formerly director of studies on chemical and biological warfare at the Federation of American Scientists in Washington. Mustard gas is an odorless alcohol compound to which sulfur and chlorine have been added. (Impurities in the first versions used in World War I gave it the faint smell of mustard.) It causes severe blistering but is rarely fatal. Tabun interferes with nerve-to-nerve communication. ``You can't see, your stomach throws up, you go into convulsions,'' said Burck. But American soldiers carry injectors they can stab into their thighs to give themselves a dose of atropine, a chemical that counteracts the nerve gas. ``It doesn't leave you in top fighting form, but it doesn't leave you dead,'' Burck said.

The National Endowment for the Humanities is honoring five Americans for their work in making history, literature, philosophy and other humanities topics more accessible to the general public. The award is named after Charles Frankel, a former philosophy professor at Columbia University, assistant secretary of state for educational and cultural affairs and first head of the National Humanities Center, a statement by NEH said Thursday. The recipients are Mortimer Adler, director of Chicago's Institute for Philosophical Research; Henry Hampton, founder and president of the media production company Blackside, Inc.; Bernard M.W. Knox, director emeritus of Howard University's Center for Hellenic Studies; David Van Tassel, founder of National History Day and a professor at Cleveland's Case Western Reserve University; and Ethyle R. Wolfe, provost emerita at Brooklyn College in New York City. ``Each of them exemplifies the commitment to scholarship and public affairs that characterized the life and work of Charles Frankel,'' NEH Chairman Lynne V. Cheney said in the statement. The awards carry a stipend of $5,000.

DOC.HEAD: Steady Stream of Foreigners Leaving Gulf Region
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Many of the estimated 6 million foreigners living in the oil-rich Persian Gulf region are sending their families away but sitting tight themselves through the Middle East crisis. They face a dilemma: If they leave, they face losing the lucrative jobs for which they left their homes. If they remain, they may face the dangers of war. George Jacobs, an Indian working for Falcon, a video and camera company with branches throughout the gulf area, said he sent his wife and daughter home to India on Thursday. In Dubai, the United Arab Emirates, contingency plans for employees at foreign companies have been drawn up, according to executives who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``All the employees in our company have been told to pack their bags and be ready to leave immediately if the situation worsens,'' said one executive in Dubai, located in the southern Persian Gulf. One Dubai executive estimated 10 percent of expatriates had already left. There is more of a sense of urgency among the foreigners living in Eastern Saudi Arabia, near where American forces were landing. U.S. troops and Saudi forces face the Iraqis along Saudi Arabia's northeastern border with Kuwait. Many fear not the gun and missile fire, but chemical weapons reportedly being readied by Iraq in case of a confrontation. Eastern Dhahran is the Kingdom's oil center and houses the Saudi Arabian Oil Co. complex, with 38,000 employees. Of the between up to 28,000 Americans living in Saudi Arabia, the Eastern Province is home to about 20,000. News that U.S. Embassies were advising Americans to leave and that American, British and other foreigners were sending their families to safer regions enhanced the tension and kicked off panic buying of dollars. Black market rates of the dollar and British pound sterling jumped, while banks reported heavy withdrawals of cash and transfers abroad. At the immigration offices in Dammam and Al-Khubar, hundreds of people lined up to get exit and re-entry visas, required under Saudi law to leave and later return to the kingdom. At Saudi Aramco Co., nearly 6,000 foreign employees lined up with their passports for visas. Similar lines were reported at many multinational companies. One company reportedly gave its employees six months' paid leave along with exit and re-entry permits to wait out the crisis, which began when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 then started massing troops along the Kuwait-Saudi border. In Tokyo, the Foreign Ministry today urged the about 1,600 Japanese living in Arab countries nations in the Persian Gulf region to leave for safer ground. Saudis also were leaving for safer places such as Jiddah, Abha and Riyadh. Those who could afford it were leaving the country. There are now mostly Indians, Pakistanis, Filipinos and Bengalis, the poorer foreigners, on the streets of cities in Eastern Saudi Arabia. Embassies for the Asian communities have reacted differently to the crisis. The Indian Embassy in Riyadh has told its community to stay put. Those foreigners chosing to stay in the Eastern province, have put away enough supplies for months and have suitcases packed and ready for an emergency.

DOC.HEAD: Middle East Crisis Prompts Film Projects
With PM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Coming soon to a theater near you: ``Iraqnophobia.'' The gathering military storm in the Middle East could bring a downpour of films inspired by the crisis. It may also boost the fortunes of films now in release or production. The co-writer of ``Team 6'' has been dispatched to Israel from Los Angeles to update the script with references to the Persian Gulf crisis. ``Navy SEALs,'' a new movie about Navy commandos in combat in the Middle East, will be promoted with an advertising campaign this weekend that will try to link the action title to last week's invasion. Other companies _ including Walt Disney Co. with ``The Ultimatum'' _ have films in development whose focus on Middle Eastern terrorists will have sudden relevance. ``The movies are entertainment _ you go there fantasizing what we wish we could do in Iraq,'' said actor Chuck Norris, whose 1986 film ``Delta Force'' was about a plane hijacked by Middle Eastern terrorists. Norris said the sequel ``Delta Force III,'' starring his son Mike, is also set in the Middle East and ``is closely related to what's happening now.'' Norris and several film producers said they expected an increase in the number of movies related to the area. ``Team 6,'' which will begin filming for 21st Century Film Corp. on Sept. 24, was first a story about Navy SEALs attacking a missile installation in a generic Middle Eastern country. After Iraq moved into Kuwait, the story was changed: the Navy unit will now invade Iraq to disable chemical-weapon missiles aimed at U.S. ships in the gulf. ``History is writing the script for us,'' said Menahem Golan, chairman of 21st Century. He said he hopes to have the film in theaters by early 1991. ``I only hope I'm first.'' He said the script changes should make the action-adventure film more accessible. ``The drama is connected with real life and people usually identify better with those situations,'' Golan said. The cast, he said, includes Rob Lowe. ``Navy SEALs,'' which is playing to modest business in the nation's theaters, could improve its fortunes at the box office this weekend because the Middle East is so much in the news, the film's producer said. ``As a filmmaker trying to make a buck, I'm embarrassed that we got it so right,'' producer Brenda Feigen said. ``I can assure you that the Navy SEALs are in the Middle East right now, although the government won't confirm it.'' Orion Pictures plans to introduce an ad campaign that will link the film to the Middle East crisis without mentioning Iraq specifically, said David Forbes, president of Orion's distribution arm. He said box-office returns appear to be improving slightly. In ``The Ultimatum,'' being developed by Disney's Touchstone Pictures, an American city will be destroyed by a nuclear bomb planted by Middle Eastern terrorists if the American government does not order all Jews out of Jerusalem. The script languished for three years until the Middle East became a focus of world tensions this year. Hollywood has a history of predicting history. Weeks before the release of 1979's ``The China Syndrome,'' a movie about a nuclear meltdown, a reactor at Three Mile Island near Harrisburg, Pa., came close to doing the same thing. In a memorable piece of dialogue, a nuclear expert in ``China Syndrome'' told Jane Fonda's character that a meltdown could wipe out an area the size of Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: Travelers Report Beatings, Looting by Iraqis in Kuwait
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait, Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Some Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait beat up residents and looted stores, while others were apologetic about their country's invasion of its tiny oil-rich neighbor, travelers reaching Bahrain said. Resistance to the invasion has dwindled but there are still scattered demonstrations in support of the deposed Kuwaiti emir and against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, the travelers said Thursday. In addition, Iraqis in Kuwait have staged demonstrations in support of Saddam. An unspecified number of women with Iraqi accents shouted pro-Saddam slogans, one traveler said. For the most part, however, an eerie silence prevails, punctuated only by the sound of gunshots. Iraqi soldiers squat and sleep on the pavements of the near-deserted streets, they said on condition of anonymity. Kuwaiti businessman Mohsen al-Ajmi, 28, said he participated in garbage clearing and maintenance operations to help out housewives whose husbands were stranded outside Kuwait when Iraq invaded the country on Aug. 2. Al-Ajmi said that at one point he and others participating in the operations were stopped for questioning by Iraqi soldiers. ``They did not search us. In fact, they apologized and cursed Saddam. One of them said `Why are we here? We have been hurting Kuwaitis and drinking warm water in this heat, while Saddam sits in his air-conditioned palace,''' al-Ajmi said. He said that as he was being questioned by the Iraqis, two Egyptian workers passed by. The soldiers called to the men, asked them to produce identity cards then said: ``Egyptians? You don't deserve to live.'' ``They beat the two Egyptians so savagely that we implored them to stop,'' said al-Ajmi. ``They let the Egyptians go. They were hurt quite badly.'' In London, one traveler reported the rape by an Iraqi soldier of a woman on a British Airways flight that was stranded in Kuwait by the Iraqi invasion. Her nationality was not immediately clear. Jamal Alsane, managing director of the Regency Palace Hotel in Kuwait City, said the woman was attacked on a bus as the passengers and crew of Flight 149 were being transferred from one hotel to another. Speaking at the Kuwaiti Embassy in London, he said a Lebanese crew member pleaded with the soldier to show the woman mercy. ``The soldier took his gun and said, `One move and I blow you up.' The other soldiers laughed, Alsane said. Travelers reaching Bahrain said Iraqi soldiers often knocked on doors to ask for cold water, and sometimes food _ mainly beef and fruit. But others said Iraqi soldiers forced Kuwaitis to provide them with water and fruit. In the sweltering summer heat ``profusely sweating Iraqis soldiers look tired and, I would say, ashamed of themselves,'' said 26-year-old Kuwaiti, Youssef al-Rashidi. ``A number of Iraqi soldiers came to us and tried to calm us down, saying `we will do you no harm ... we have nothing against you ... we only carry out orders,''' al-Rashidi said at the Diplomat Hotel in Bahrain. But Al-Rashidi's four companions had different stories to tell. ``I saw Iraqi soldiers heap in lorries sacks of money and bits of furniture stolen from the Gulf Bank,'' one of the four said on condition of anonymity. He said his brother watched soldiers loot two car showrooms in Kuwait. Another Kuwaiti said he saw Iraqi soldiers loot jewelry shops. ``I saw Iraqi soldiers armed with rifles stop uniformed Kuwaiti soldiers, force them to remove the uniforms and then order them to return home in their underwear,'' he said. The man said he took part in what he called ``minor resistance operations,'' knocking down two Iraqi soldiers with a speeding car, and distributing anti-Saddam leaflets. One shipping company executive said contacts in Kuwait told him Thursday that more than 70 percent of Kuwaitis had left the country. Those reports could not be confirmed independently. Kuwaitis are a minority in their country, comprising 27 percent of the total 1.8 million population. The rest are Palestinian, Egyptian, Iranian, Indian, Pakistani, American and other expatriate workers.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Decline in Tokyo; Dollar Up
DOC.TEXT: The market failed to sustain early gains on the Tokyo Stock Exchange and share prices declined Friday, while the dollar finished marginally higher. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 286.18 points, or 1.04 percent, closing the week at 27,329.55. The index lost 893.41 points on Thursday. The dollar closed at 149.75 yen, up 0.07 yen from Thursday's close of 149.68 yen. After opening at 149.75 yen, the currency ranged between 149.53 yen and 149.85 yen. Traders said the stock market started moderately higher, but market players sold issues in the afternoon over gloomy prospects in the Middle East. Toshiyuki Nishiguchi, a stock analyst with Daiwa Securities, said though the market was beginning to recover from a recent slump, ``As a whole (investors are) taking a wait-and-see position, while watching the Middle East situation.'' The Nikkei index, the market's main barometer, lost 4,348 points between July 20 and Thursday's close because of increasing interest rates in Japan and the Persian Gulf crisis, which began Aug. 2 when Iraq invaded Kuwait. In currency dealings, the lack of significant news from the Middle East also was why the dollar traded in a relatively narrow range, exchange dealers said. ``It's very quiet,'' said Kozo Yoshida, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. ``At this time it is difficult to determine the dollar's direction, unless there will be new developments in the Middle East.'' Other dealers said many market players Friday were waiting for results of the emergency Arab summit in Cairo called in hopes of resolving the Gulf crisis. The meeting, originally scheduled for Thursday, was postponed to Friday because some Arab leaders had not arrived in time.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Caught in Kuwait Invasion Begin Returning Home
With PM-US-Iran, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A family of four who huddled on their kitchen floor during an Iraqi bombardment and a swimming coach who offered a soft drink to get past an army checkpoint were among Americans who fled Kuwait and came home to tell of their frightening journeys. Meanwhile, President Bush's decision to sent U.S. troops to the Middle East was greeted with support and protests around the country Thursday. Several Arab-American groups denounced the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait but said they did not support the American military presence in Saudi Arabia. In San Francisco, a noisy anti-war protest in front of Chevron Corp. headquarters drew more than 50 people. Marchers held signs with such messages as ``U.S. Out of the Gulf'' and ``No Vietnam in the Mideast.'' In Atlanta, 10 members of the Quakers' American Friends Service Committee held a vigil to protest U.S. intervention. U.S.-based companies, including Texaco and the Boeing Co., on Thursday arranged to evacuate some employees and dependents from Saudi Arabia. ``There's no order back in Kuwait. Nobody goes to work, there's no police, no services. We don't intend to go back there,'' said Kimberly El-Zahr, 29. She, her husband, Camille, 33, and two young children were with her parents in Portland, Ore., after escaping Kuwait. On Aug. 2, when Mrs. El-Zahr heard Iraqi warplanes overhead, the family stocked up on food and got what cash they could from the bank. ``We lived right behind the crown prince's palace, like the vice president's palace, and they started taking over that palace,'' she said. ``It was a terrific bombing-shelling. Artillery rounds and everything was going off. ``We ended up on the floor in the kitchen and we just huddled on the floor until we could get through that.'' The family spent three days at a friend's house, then left in a three-car caravan for the Saudi border. ``Nobody stopped us,'' El-Zahr said. ``Nobody looked at us. I guess we were lucky. There were soldiers and big machine guns and we were scared.'' Texan Benny Whitaker and his wife joined a convoy of his co-workers who left the Hamad Al Hamad oil company for Saudi Arabia on Aug. 3, one day after the invasion. The group was stopped twice by Iraqi soldiers during the 75-minute drive. The second time, ``I just acted like I didn't hear him and kept going,'' said Whitaker, who returned Sunday to Abilene. Steve Betts, 35, of Houston, who formerly coached Kuwait's national swimming squad, said his car stalled at a checkpoint during his 85-mile drive to the Saudi border. An Iraqi soldier allowed him to pass after being offered a soft drink. ``I had about six to eight Diet Pepsi's with me and I handed them to him,'' Betts said in an interview from Washington. ``He had fever blisters on his mouth and the Diet Pepsi _ well, that rang his bell.'' The estimated 3,400 Americans still in Kuwait and Iraq left many loved ones in this country ignorant of their whereabouts and condition. Thirty-eight Americans were still being held in a hotel in Baghdad, Iraq, but were reported to be in good condition. Bush received high marks in the latest ``Pulse of America'' survey conducted in Lubbock County, Texas _ the president's adopted sounding board for America. Sixty-four percent of 400 people surveyed Aug. 6-8 said they would support Bush if he opted to use military force to push Iraq out of Kuwait. Twenty-one percent did not support military use. The survey, sent to Bush on Thursday, was conducted by Southwest Research Associates and has a margin of error of 4 percentage points. Arab-American groups were divided in their reaction to U.S. military action. The Southern California American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee opposed both Iraq's annexation and U.S. military involvement. ``The best way is to leave it to the Arab states,'' said regional director Nacih Bayda. ``Our confidence is behind President Bush and the government of the United States of America,'' the Detroit-based Chaldean Federation of America said in a statement. Chaldeans are Christian Arabs, mostly from Iraq. M.T. Mehdi, president of the American-Arab Relations Committee and the National Council on Islamic Affairs, held a news conference in New York City with about 30 other Arab leaders. He said about 60 percent were anti-Saddam, about 40 percent pro, but they unanimously opposed the U.S. military deployment. ``We feel it will increase Arab and Muslim hostility to the U.S. and only increase Saddam Hussein's prestige in the Arab world,'' Mehdi said. But he said most Arab-American leaders in the area favor economic sanctions.

DOC.HEAD: Uprising Leadership Critical of U.S. Moves Against Iraq
With PM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The leading pro-PLO activist in the Israeli-occupied lands has said Palestinians are angry about U.S. military action in the Persian Gulf and accuses Washington of using a ``double standard'' with the Arabs. ``Why ask only Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, why not ask Israel to withdraw from the West Bank?,'' the Baghdad-born Faisal Husseini said Thursday. Israel has occupied the West Bank and the Gaza Strip since the 1967 Middle East War. Husseini's comments underscored sympathy for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein among the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied lands. Saddam, whose army invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, has also received the backing of Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat. Only a few Palestinians expressed fears of being hurt themselves if Iraq made good on threats to attack Israel with chemical weapons. Most Palestinians hail Saddam as a hero for flexing his muscles against the world's superpowers at a time they are fighting a seemingly hopeless battle against Israeli rule. In the 32-month uprising, 727 Palestinians were killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians, and another 246 were slain as suspected collaborators by fellow Arabs. Forty-seven Israelis have also been slain. ``Israelis are behaving like thugs in this area and so now Saddam is telling them, you are not the only ones who can control things,'' said Ahmad Abu Salom, 39, a Palestinian actor in Jerusalem. A local Palestinian faction sympathetic to Syria, called the Popular Struggle Front and headed by Jerusalemite Samir Ghoshi, published a leaflet Thursday comparing Saddam's actions to their protests against Israel. ``The Arab masses and the children of the stones are now hoping to see victory through you,'' said the leaflet. ``We express full support and solidarity with Iraq in its revolutionary steps.'' Husseini, 50, said Palestinian support for Iraq was largely a sign of frustration. The United States has failed to exert effective pressure to prevent Israel's heavy-handed policies against Palestinians, but came swiftly to the defense of oil-rich Kuwait, he said. ``Okay, the United States sends forces to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Very good. You are the police in the area. So why not do the same thing with Israel?'' said Husseini. ``So what you are seeing is a reaction of anger at the United States,'' he said. ``It is not that the Palestinians support the regime in Iraq or believe in Saddam Hussein's ideology, but because they believe there is a double standard in the area,'' Husseini said. Husseini spent a year of the uprising in jail without trial on allegations of pro-PLO activism. Since his release in 1989 he has emerged as a popular leader. His father, Abdel Kader Husseini, was a Palestinian war hero killed leading fighters against the emerging state of Israel in April 1948. Husseini said the PLO believes the Persian Gulf crisis ``must be solved without letting foreign forces interfere ... we are strongly against outside interference because it will complicate the situation.'' An opinion poll of Israeli Arab citizens in northern Galilee also indicated strong support for Iraq. The poll, in which 208 people were questioned by telephone, showed 62 percent supported Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and 69 percent considered Saddam a national hero. Fifteen percent felt he was mad and irrational. No margin of error was given for the poll. Pro-Iraqi and anti-American sentiments were also prominent in editorials run by Palestinian-owned newspapers published in Arab east Jerusalem. ``It would be better for the Saudis to seek the opinions of the sages before seeking help from enemies,'' wrote the pro-Jordanian An Nahar daily. ``The language of escalation by the United States means dragging the entire region into a brutal war,'' wrote the pro-PLO Al-Quds newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Galveston Bay, Ship Channel Reopens After Oil Spill
DOC.TEXT: Seafood-rich Galveston Bay opened today to shrimpers for the first time in eight days, but officials warned against fishing in waters stained with residue from a 700,000-gallon oil spill. The Coast Guard said it hoped to fully open the Houston Ship Channel, which courses through the bay, to all traffic today for the first time since a tanker collided with two barges on July 28. A sunken barge is obstructing the waterway. Texas Health Commissioner Robert Bernstein said bay shrimping could resume today. But he cautioned shrimpers and consumers to beware of fish with visible oil, or fish caught in oily water. Bernstein shut down the bay to all fishing on Aug. 2 because of a 17-mile slick. Two days later, he reopened the bay to fin fishing and allowed seafood harvesting in some areas. Shrimpers said the ban cost them thousands of dollars a day. A ban also was lifted today on the taking of crabs and oysters. ``This is clearly good news for the men and women who rely on the bay for their livelihoods,'' Gov. Bill Clements said. The spill occurred when a Greek tanker collided with two barges under tow. One barge sank and the other ruptured, spilling heavy oil that threatened sensitive marshes, birds and other wildlife. Coast Guard spokesman Rick McCullor said salvage crews were expected to end the cleanup today and reopen the channel to all traffic. Crews used cutting torches to take apart the sunken barge and removed half on Thursday, leaving the other half for today. Divers had pugt a sling around one end of the barge last week and crews moved the vessel into shallow water beside the shipping channel, where it limited traffic to one-way, tug-assisted ships and two-way, slow-moving barges. The Coast Guard said that the cleanup has cost more than $1 million and that the total might be about $3 million. ``Almost all the visible oil has been recovered,'' McCullor said.

DOC.HEAD: Surprising Link Found Between Elephant Man's Disease and Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Scientists may have accomplished far more than they thought when they found the gene for Elephant Man's disease. The gene, it turns out, appears to be a switch that can turn on cancer, researchers reported today. ``The payoff here is going to be that we may come up with a treatment for brain tumors,'' said Dr. Allan Rubenstein, medical director of the National Neurofibromatosis Foundation in New York. Neurofibromatosis is Elephant Man's disease. The surprising discovery could bring about an explosion of research toward a treatment for neurofibromatosis _ a disfiguring disease that ``a couple of years ago was an obscure phenomenon which practically the whole scientific world ignored,'' Rubenstein said. That research also holds promise for many people with cancer, though scientists cautioned that treatments may be years away. ``It's the kind of understanding we hoped discovery of the gene would lead to,'' said the author of the new finding, Raymond L. White of the University of Utah. ``I expect it to make a fundamental contribution to our understanding of cancer genetics.'' White's findings appeared today in the scientific journal Cell. The report concludes that the neurofibromatosis gene is one of the family of GAP genes that may operate as anti-cancer genes. That is, when the genes are normal, they keep cancer growth switched off. When they are defective, they allow cancer tumors to grow. These so-called tumor-suppressor genes have been found to be among the causes of lung cancer, breast cancer and colon cancer. White said his findings suggest that neurofibromatosis tumors, which are not cancerous, may be an intermediate stage between normal tissue and cancer. Similar discoveries have been made in colon cancer, where White and other researchers have shown that benign polyps have some, but not all, of the genetic changes required to form colon cancer. Neurofibromatosis afflicts 100,000 Americans. Symptoms can include learning disabilities and crippling, non-cancerous tumors all over their bodies. Until now, researchers have had no clue to its cause. A month ago, White and Francis Collins of the University of Michigan reported that they had independently discovered the neurofibromatosis gene. That opened the door to further studies to determine precisely what goes wrong in neurofibromatosis and how it might be fixed. The latest findings are an important step in that direction, researchers said. ``The potential to start to design therapies is now a couple of years closer than it could have been otherwise,'' Collins said. ``I don't want to raise false hopes, but the implication is it might be possible to treat some forms of NF,'' said Michael Wigler of the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory in New York. The GAP genes are known to switch off certain cancer genes called ras genes, which have long been known to contribute to the formation of cancer tumors, said Wigler. White said he made his discovery by determing the DNA sequence, or genetic code, of part of the neurofibromatosis gene. He then compared it to known sequences stored in a computer, and ``the GAP genes popped out as clearly as could be.'' It is not yet proven that the neurofibromatosis gene acts like a GAP gene, but researchers believe it does because its sequence is so closely related to the GAP genes, White said.

DOC.HEAD: Atlanta Study Finds One in Four Assaults in Family, Intimate Setting
DOC.TEXT: A study of violence in Atlanta found that one in four assaults takes place in a family or intimate relationship, with most of the assailants men and most of the victims women. The findings, reported Thursday by the national Centers for Disease Control, were based on 1984 police reports, the latest available at the time the survey was begun. Police reported 27 fatal family or intimate assaults for the year, and 3,295 non-fatal ones, said Dr. Linda Saltzman, a behavioral scientist with the CDC. Incident reports were taken from a broad range of police categories, including assault, robbery, rape and disorderly conduct. Overall, 14 percent of reports in those categories were in families or intimate relationships, and about 25 percent of the assaults were in such situations, Saltzman said. Analysis of 177 assaults found that 52 percent of the fatality victims and 73 percent of the non-fatality victims were women; 74 percent of the fatal assaults and 80 percent of the non-fatal ones were committed by men. Twenty percent or more of the Atlanta incidents studied involved broken relationships, and between 26 percent and 37 percent of the parties involved had been reported to the police in similar assaults before, the CDC said. ``Violence between persons who are related, share a household or are otherwise intimate with each other is a widespread public health problem,'' the CDC concluded. ``In particular, intimate violence is a leading cause of injuries to women.'' The CDC noted a 1986 survey concluding that battering was responsible for more injuries to women than car crashes, rape and mugging combined.

DOC.HEAD: Donor-Search Leukemia Patient Gets Mother's Marrow in Transplant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Her condition ...' to CORRECT surgeon's name, spokeswoman's name.
DOC.TEXT: A college student with leukemia whose search for a compatible bone-marrow donor drew celebrity support and 50,000 volunteers underwent a last-ditch transplant using her mother's marrow. Allison Atlas, 20, opted for the surgery Thursday although her mother's tissue is not a perfect match. She said she wanted to try the life-saving procedure while she was still relatively strong. Her condition today at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center was withheld at the family's request, said hospital spokeswoman Alice Burgess. The transplant team was headed Dr. Edward Agura. The marrow from her 54-year-old mother, Arline Atlas, matched only four of six antigens, or cell identifiers, from her daughter's marrow. The operation could work if Miss Atlas' body does not reject her mother's tissue. ``They're both fighters,'' said Sy Atlas, a cousin. ``They're both people who are determined to beat the odds. Arline was excited to be the donor for her daughter.'' Miss Atlas, a student at New York University when she became ill last year, heightened awareness of the need for bone-marrow donors with a publicity campaign that drew 50,000 volunteers in the United States and Israel. Supporters raised $3 million, including a six-figure check from actor Dustin Hoffman, to process the 50,000 blood tests. No match was found for Miss Atlas, but 10 other leukemia patients were matched with donors. Bone marrow provides necessary components of the human immune system, and transplant patients are at high risk of infection for three weeks after the operation until the new marrow begins to work. Miss Atlas, of Bethesda, Md., will recuperate in a sterile environment at the cancer center, where more than 3,000 bone-marrow transplants have been performed, more than any other clinic. Anatoly Grishchenko, a leukemia-stricken Soviet helicopter pilot who flew firefighting missions over the damaged Chernobyl nuclear reactor, underwent a bone marrow transplant at the center earlier this year. He died July 3 of complications of a lung infection that took hold during the period when he had no natural defenses. In leukemia, a form of blood cancer, white blood cells multiply out of control. Since bone marrow produces blood, doctors can combat leukemia by replacing the diseased marrow with healthy tissue. Before the operation, Miss Atlas reassured her mother with humor and encouraged family members. ``She was really cool,'' Sy Atlas said in a TV interview from Washington, D.C. ``Last night, talking with her mom, she jokingly said ... `Mom, your marrow better be good for me tomorrow.''' ``She's really positive. With that kind of attitude, we're confident she's going to do well.''

DOC.HEAD: Shares Fall in Tokyo; Dollar Up
DOC.TEXT: Continuing pessimism over the Middle East sent shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange down further today, traders said. The dollar gained marginally against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 286.18 points, or 1.04 percent, closing the week at 27,329.55. It was the Nikkei's lowest closing level since Oct. 24, 1988, when it ended trading at 27,281.54. A total of 320 million shares changed hands, down from the previous day's 380 million shares. On Thursday, the Nikkei plunged 893.41 points. Traders said the stock market opened moderately higher, but market players then dumped issues because of pessimism over the situation in the Middle East. Akira Shimoda, an equity analyst with Yamaichi Securities, said there had no news about major new developments in the Middle East today, but ``the situation there is hazy, resulting in a negative psychological impact on investors.'' The Nikkei index gained nearly 300 points in the morning, but later suffered from sporadic arbitrage selling to take advantage of price gaps between the spot and futures markets, he said. Among losers were chemical, drug, shipbuilding and trading company issues. The Nikkei index has lost a total of 4,634.19 points since July 20 because of rising interest rates in Japan and the Persian Gulf crisis, which began last Thursday when Iraq invaded Kuwait. In currency dealings, the dollar finished the week at 149.75 yen, up 0.07 yen from Thursday's close of 149.68 yen. It opened at 149.75 yen and ranged between 149.53 yen and 149.85 yen. ``It's very quiet with only a small number of calls and customers,'' said Megumi Morita, a dealer with Sanwa Bank. Ms. Morita said many market players conducted position adjustments in the absence of fresh incentives, including fresh news from the Middle East. Meanwhile, oil prices remained steady in Tokyo throughout the day, said a trader with a major Japanese trading company. North Sea Brent crude oil for October delivery was trading at $23.70 a barrel, unchanged from Thursday's close. In bond dealings, the yield of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 7.995 percent, up from Thursday's 7.985 percent. Their price slipped to 83.47 points from 83.52 points.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Abuse Program Born of AIDS Epidemic Reports Success
DOC.TEXT: An anti-drug program born of the AIDS crisis recorded success rates ranging from 47 percent in Miami to 16 percent in Chicago in getting intravenous drug users to kick the habit, officials say. The program, begun in 1987 in 41 communities by the National Institute on Drug Abuse, was aimed at studying and changing the behavior of intravenous drug users and their sex partners. More than 30,000 people who were not then in drug abuse programs enrolled, and follow-up interviews in five cities found from 16 percent to 47 percent stopped all use of IV drugs, the Centers for Disease Control said Thursday. ``If the results at other sites prove to be consistent,'' it would provide ``strong evidence of the considerable impact this approach could have,'' the agency said. AIDS is transmitted chiefly through sexual contact, contaminated blood and sharing of contaminated needles. More than 38,000 of the 139,000 AIDS cases reported in this country have occurred in IV drug users. An additional 3,000 involved sex with IV drug users, and 1,400 were children born to IV drug users or their sexual partners. The National Institute on Drug Abuse project contacted IV drug abusers through community workers, many of whom were former addicts. Drug users were paid for participating in the program. Results were reported from Chicago, Houston, Miami, Philadelphia and San Francisco. Between 45 percent and 78 percent of the participants came back for the follow-up interviews. Success rates in getting addicts off drugs included 17 percent in San Francisco, 26 percent in Philadelphia and 32 percent in Houston. In Chicago the percentage of participants not sharing needles with friends rose from 18 percent to 47 percent. In Houston, it went from 47 percent to 88 percent six months later.

DOC.HEAD: Squish! Grapes Are Getting Stomped for Charity
DOC.TEXT: Grape stompers can cast off their shoes and squish for charity at Stone Hill Winery. For the 13th year, the winery is sponsoring a Grape Stomp on Saturday to raise money for a workshop for the disabled, and hundreds of contestants were expected to have a go. Last year, the event raised $1,900. Contestants paying a $3 entry fee get 30 pounds of red grapes and two minutes to show their stomping style, said Betty Held, co-owner of the 143-year-old winery. ``They will be stomping to the music of Otto's Polka Band from St. Louis,'' she said Thursday. ``The judges will grade them 80 percent on the amount of juice the stomping produces and 20 percent on their style.'' Age groups for contestants range from pre-teen to over 55. The best stompers will get prizes, and all contestants may keep the juice from their efforts. Hermann is on the Missouri River about 60 miles west of St. Louis.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was higher against all other major foreign currencies in early European trading today amidst continuing concern over the Middle East crisis. Gold prices were higher. Traders said they expected the dollar to continue gaining ahead of an Arab League meeting in Cairo today and on reports of further Iraqi troop movements toward Kuwait and toward the border with Turkey. ``The market is reserved,'' said a trader at a major West German bank in Frankfurt. ``The (Middle East) situation looks like it can only get worse.'' In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.07 yen to a closing 149.75 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 150.10 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: _1.5974 West German marks, up from 1.5915 _1.3455 Swiss francs, up from 1.3385 _5.3607 French francs, up from 5.3340 _1.7985 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7930 _1,170.50 Italian lire, up from 1,164.75 _1.1473 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1467 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.8690, compared with $1.8720 late Thursday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $387.00 a troy ounce, up from $385.25 bid late Thursday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $388.75. In Zurich, the bid price was $388.75, up from $385 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $3.84 to close at a bid $388.01. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $4.90 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $4.87.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in East, South and Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms were scattered over the East and South early today and rain also fell in the Northwest. Skies were mostly clear elsewhere. A low pressure system was expected to bring another day of rain to the East today with showers extending from the Carolinas to Maine and some thunderstorms in Florida. Sunny skies were forecast for the South and most of the Midwest, but heavy rain was developing in a narrow band from eastern Montana to central Nebraska. Thunderstorms were expected in Oregon, Idaho, Nevada and northern California. Scorching summer heat was again predicted for the Southwest, with temperatures in the 100s and even the 110s in southern Arizona. Elsewhere, temperatures were expected to be in the 90s in the South, the 80s in the East and Midwest and the 70s in the central northern region and West Coast. The high temperature for the nation Thursday was 121 degrees at Death Valley, Calif. DOC.HEAD: AIDS Couple Guilty of Marijuana Possession, Medical Necessity Defense Denied
DOC.TEXT: An AIDS-stricken couple who say they smoked marijuana to relieve painful side-effects from their AIDS treatments were found guilty by a judge who rejected their medical necessity defense. But justice was tempered with mercy as Circuit Judge Clinton Foster on Thursday sentenced Kenneth and Barbara Jenks to a year's probation and 500 hours of community service _ to be completed by caring for each other. ``The events of this case are horrifying, and evoke sympathy and compassion for the defendants by all persons acquainted with the facts,'' Foster said after a non-jury trial. ``There is no cure for this disease.'' The husband and wife were convicted of cultivating and possessing marijuana. Jenks, 28, is a hemophiliac who contracted AIDS through a tainted blood transfusion. He passed the disease to his 24-year-old wife before he was aware he was infected. ``I've never had that sweet a sentence in my 20 years of practicing law,'' said attorney John Daniel, who represented the couple for free. Nevertheless, he filed notice of appeal, an effort he hopes will reverse Foster's rejection of the medical necessity defense. The couple said they smoked marijuana especially to relieve intense nausea and vomiting caused by the anti-AIDS drug AZT. ``When I started taking AZT, I lost all reason to eat,'' Jenks has said. He and his wife declined to say whether they will continue smoking marijuana. Foster noted the medical necessity defense has been approved by some courts around the nation, including a judge in Fort Lauderdale who authorized it for another disease. But he concluded it should not be recognized across the board unless the state Legislature gives ``statutory authorization addressing the scope and parameters of that defense.'' The Jenkses have applied to take part in a federal program allowing the use of marijuana for medicinal purposes. They said neither they nor their doctor knew about the program before they were arrested March 29. Marijuana has been used to treat the nausea that accompanies cancer chemotherapy, as well as to treat glaucoma and multiple sclerosis.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Army To Stay Put for Now in Mohawk Dispute
