DOC.TEXT: The army won't enter the armed standoff between the Mohawk Indians and Quebec police unless a federally appointed mediator asks them to intervene, an army commander said. Also Thursday, the Mohawks warned that any military presence at barricades they have erected between themselves and provincial police might jeopardize a settlement of the conflict. The standoff began a month ago when the Mohawks occupied what they claimed to be sacred land that was earmarked for a golf course expansion. ``A build-up of military force at the Kahnawake reserve will be regarded by the Mohawk people as something akin to gunboat diplomacy,'' said Owen Young, legal advisor to the Mohawks. The army's role in the conflict will depend on the efforts of mediator Alan B. Gold, chief justice of the Quebec Superior Court, to bring both sides to the mediating table, said Armed forces spokesman Lt. Gen. Kent Foster Thursday. ``If Chief Justice Gold finds in his discussions that there is a role for us to play ... we would do our best to react to that,'' Foster said. ``Clearly we are going to continue to get ready to put our forces in place and so on for that eventuality.'' He said the earliest the soldiers could be ready to move is Saturday. The soldiers would move toward Montreal from Canadian Forces Base Valcartier, just outside of Quebec City, and then into position in the town of Oka and outside the Kahnawake reserve. At Valcartier 4,400 troops and 1,400 vehicles are available, Foster said. A land dispute led to a July 11 gunbattle between Mohawks and Quebec police at Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal, and the two sides have faced each other across barricades since then. An officer was shot to death in the clash that began when police tried to storm a barricade put up by the Mohawks. Responsibility in the death has not been established. Earlier this week, Premier Robert Bourassa asked the federal government for authorization to bring in the army. Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said Wednesday the military would be at the province's disposal to help police. Bourassa said in Quebec City that Gold started work Thursday, talking with provincial government officials and the Mohawks. Also Thursday, Quebec announced that the provincial government will build a section of highway to bypass the Mercier Bridge into Montreal, blocked for nearly a month now by Mohawks as part of the dispute. Quebec's public security minister, Sam Elkas, said two lanes of the road will be built this year at a cost of $8.5 million (U.S.) and it will be broadened next year. The road will allow residents of suburbs on the South Shore of the St. Lawrence River to bypass the blocked bridge and get to Montreal by way of other bridges.

DOC.HEAD: Regional Force Being Assembled, Doe Reports U.S. Attempt, Food Aid On Way
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with U.N. food shipment being sent to Liberian refugees; Pickup 4th, `West African...'
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS: The following is based in part on a pool report from journalists including AP correspondent Michael Goldsmith.

Neighboring West African countries were assembling troops to halt a 7-month-old civil war between rebels and the government of President Samuel Doe. A Doe spokesman accused U.S. Marines of shooting at the leader Thursday, but the State Department in Washington denied it. A close advisor to the president was hospitalized with chest and neck wounds after the attack in which the Marines allegedly shot at Doe from a helicopter, said Selly Thompson, a spokesman for Doe. He spoke in an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp. In Rome, A U.N. agency said it would send $16 million in emergency food aid to help feed about 400,000 people uprooted by Liberia's war. The food will be shipped to Liberia and the neighboring Ivory Coast, Guinea and Sierra Leone, where tens of thousands of Liberians have taken refuge. The shipment includes more than 21,000 tons of rice, 1,200 tons of oil and 1,700 tons of canned meat and fish, the Rome-based World Food Program said. West African peacekeeping troops massed across Liberia's northern border in Guinea and to the east on the Sierra Leone border, according to military sources in Ghana and Sierra Leone. There were reports 500 troops might be airlifted into Monrovia. Rebels battled Doe's troops within a mile of his executive mansion Thursday in a bid to take Monrovia before a five-nation African task force, dominated by Nigerian soldiers, arrives to impose a cease-fire in the war-ravaged nation. At least 5,000 people have died in the war, which began in December when rebels invaded from the Ivory Coast seeking to depose Doe, whom they accuse of corruption and mismanagement. The war has become a tribal conflict, pitting people loyal to the rebels against those loyal to Doe's government. On Wednesday night, rebels loyal to former bureaucrat Charles Taylor pushed into eastern Congo Town _ an eastern suburb of Monrovia _ where they ransacked the Nigerian Embassy and attacked the Guinea Embassy. They forced thousands of people seeking refuge at the Nigerian Embassy _ mostly Nigerians _ into streets where battles raged. It was not clear whether anyone was injured, said a relief worker in Congo Town. Nigerian Foreign Minister Rilwanu Lukman said in Lagos that his government told Taylor ``that we will hold him personally responsible for any harm done to Nigerians inside the embassy at the time of the attack.'' In Bonn, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said 300 people from the Nigerian Embassy sought refuge at the West German mission. He said that swelled the total at the mission to 500 refugees, including Americans, Belgians, French, Dutch, Irish, Liberians and Filipinos. It was not clear what happened at the Guinea Embassy, which gave sanctuary to 5,000 people from the Mandingo tribe seeking safety from the rebels who have killed thousands, accusing them of backing Doe's regime. Guinea Radio called the attack on its embassy a ``provocation'' and said three guards were taken hostage by rebels. In Abidjan, sources were quoted as saying one woman was killed in the attack on the Guinean Embassy. Doe spokesman Thompson said former Justice Minister Isaac Nyaplu was wounded in the assassination attempt against Doe and appealed for the international community to pressure the United States to ``excessive harassment to remove Doe.'' But State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said the 235 Marines airlifted into Monrovia Sunday to evacuate Americans were there to protect the embassy and Americans and not to intervene in the fighting or take sides. Boucher said the United States has evacuated 150 people from Liberia this week, including the French and Italian ambassadors. The West Africans moving into Liberia say they will enforce a cease-fire to allow formation of an interim government charged with organizing free and fair elections within a year. Doe and Johnson have welcomed the West African initiative, but Taylor is opposed. He fears Nigerian participation because Nigerian President Gen. Ibrahim Babangida has been an ally of Doe.

DOC.HEAD: Grads Defend Offbeat Learning at Unconventional College
DOC.TEXT: Students of Thomas Jefferson College got credit for some unusual activities _ carving Indian flutes, painting portraits of comic-book characters and observing the antics of roving bands of mongrel dogs. About 250 graduates, former faculty and administrators will gather this weekend for a weekend reunion marking the closure of the college 10 years ago. ``I felt that we were on the cutting edge of something really exciting,'' said T. Dan Gilmore, who guided the college through two-thirds of its 12 years in existence. ``There was almost a feeling of a new-age mentality.'' The college, a subdivision of Grand Valley State University in Allendale, had as many as 600 students in the mid-1970s. It allowed students to design their own classes and experiment with learning. The college was born out of the freewheeling 1960s, when alternative higher education programs sprouted nationwide. The experimental approach drew criticism from some who thought credit was given too easily for such pursuits like wilderness backpacking. Many graduates said some of their best years were spent at there, and defended the learning experience there. ``TJC taught me how to learn, how to adapt to a changing world,'' said Mark Miller, who spent part of his academic career following the movements of a roving band of mongrel dogs on the inner-city streets of Grand Rapids. Miller said he later put his knowledge of urban animal behavior to good use as director of an animal shelter. Susan Haskins, who traipsed the shores of Lake Michigan in search of new rock forms, now works for the federal government as a geologist. ``The college gave me the freedom to chart my own course,'' she said. ``It encouraged my independence. TJC did fine by me.'' Dan Anderson, a Grand Valley physics professor, said teaching at the college ``was the mountaintop of my career.'' The school's alumni include doctors, dancers, mental health workers, teachers and business owners. Jeff Brown, who received credits for helping transform a shoe store into a theater, now owns a nut shop in Kalamazoo. ``TJC was almost like a schoolwide encounter group,'' he said. ``It was magic.''

DOC.HEAD: Storm Almost Stationary North of Mid-Atlantic Azores Islands
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Edouard hovered just north of the Azores today and forecasters expected it to lose strength on its slow-moving northeastward drift past the mid-Atlantic Portuguese archipelago. At 6 a.m. EDT today, Edouard's center was located about 95 miles northeast of the island of Terceira, according to the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. The storm had maximum sustained winds near 40 mph, and was heading east northeast at 6 mph. ``This system hasn't got much rain in it, and it'll probably drop below tropical storm strength today,'' said Miles Lawrence, hurricane specialist at the center. Hurricane Diana killed at least 38 people and injured 80 as it battered the Mexican states of Veracruz and Hidalgo this week, relief officials said. Eleven people were reported missing.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Open Up Part of Hitler Bunker for Viewing
DOC.TEXT: Journalists allowed into parts of Adolf Hitler's underground concrete bunker have seen a half-dozen dark rooms that some day may be turned into an exhibition. In a tour Thursday, journalists saw rooms at the edge of the once-bustling Potsdamer Platz in East Berlin that historians believe were dining facilities for the Nazi dictator's bodyguards. There were doors marked ``toilet'' and ``shower.'' A rusting steel door led to the ``Reichsrundfunk,'' or government radio station, which Hitler used to broadcast propaganda messages to the German people during World War II. The only objects left in the rooms, which lie under a small hill visible to the passersby, were a blown-up safe and what appeared a water tank. There were pools of water on the floor. Other parts of the bunker were opened up earlier. The Soviets blew up still other parts at the end of the war. The underground bunker is off limits to the public and East Berlin officials are faced with the issue of what to do with the labyrinth. East Berlin city councilor Thomas Krueger said Thursday the bunker rooms may one day become a ``historic exhibition,'' but cautioned, ``there is still no clear plan.'' German officials fear that keeping the rooms intact would attract neo-Nazis, but they have made a commitment to turning relics of the Third Reich into stark memorials to prevent a return of fascism. Vandals occasionally have slipped into the bunker in the past, sometimes leaving pro-Nazi slogans written on the walls. The rooms opened up for viewing on Thursday do not include the one where Hitler and Eva Braun, his longtime mistress and wife of one day, committed suicide on April 30, 1945.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuela's Economic Crisis Raises Concerns About Democracy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS dropped letter in ``continue'' in lead. Sty also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: In one day, the defense minister was replaced and 143 officers retired. It was peaceful, unlike many military changes in Latin America, but some Venezuelans wonder how long that will continue.
DOC.HEAD: Similar promotions, 2nd graf
Friend Arrested In Presumed Drownings of Teen Girls
DOC.TEXT: A 17-year-old was charged with manslaughter today for allegedly pulling two friends into the raging rapids of the Niagara River, police said. A search for the girls, presumed drowned, resumed at daybreak. The youth, Rudolph Rogler of Niagara Falls, pulled the girls off a rock they'd clung to Thursday evening after earlier escaping the turbulent water, said officer Kenneth Lewis of the New York State Parks police. He was charged with two counts of second-degree manslaughter. Lewis said Jessica Currie, 14, and Shelly Pembleton, 17, were among a group of friends smoking marijuana and drinking beer in Whirlpool State Park Thursday evening. The girls, both of Niagara Falls, went swimming in a forbidden section of the gorge and got caught in the current, but managed to swim ashore and clung to a rock, he said. ``They made it back to shore the first time. Then this individual came along and pulled both of them off the rock'' as a prank, Lewis said. ``If he hadn't touched the two females, they would have both been still alive.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Patrols Restore Order in Town After 33 Die In Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Heavily armed soldiers in armored cars and police riot squads were restoring order today in Port Elizabeth after at least 33 people were killed in four days of rioting and looting. Police commanders said they were regaining control of colored, or mixed race, townships around the city on the south-east coast. Scores of South African army soldiers backed by armored units and helicopters aided police. Police Lt. Gen. Mulder van Eyck said today that security forces were in control of much of the area. ``The police and the army are now involved. We are patrolling the areas,'' he told reporters. According to police, 33 people were killed in the fighting. Some had been killed by police gunfire, but there was no breakdown on how many, police said. Authorities said that about 160 people had been arrested for looting, arson and other offenses. Telephone, trash collection, mail and all other public services were still cut off in the riot-hit areas. Municipal employees had been targeted for attack and they, along with most other residents, stayed home to protect their houses. The government had appealed to Port Elizabeth residents to stop the unrest. Van Eyck said residents told him the unrest was caused by the ``high rental of homes, the lack of proper water supply, lack of facilities and the inadequate schools.'' The riots in the northern Port Elizabeth suburbs of Bloemendal, Arcadia, Chatty Windvogel and Hillside began on Monday in a clash between members of a political group and police. But police and political organizations in the city said criminal gangs and roving mobs of looters took advantage of the unrest and were responsible for much of the violence and looting. The local Northern Areas Action Committee and the affiliated African National Congress did not appear to have any control over the hundreds of rioters who stormed through the streets, throwing rocks and gasoline bombs. Police repeatedly opened fire with shotguns and pistols to disperse the mobs. Businessmen also reportedly fired at looters before fleeing with their families. The car manufacturing plants which employ a large percentage of Port Elizabeth-area blacks remained at a standstill today. Public transport was not running in most areas. Shops, factories, schools, a church, police and private vehicles were burned, said the Port Elizabeth police spokesman, Maj. Bill Dennis.

DOC.SECOND: PM-What Are Vital Interests, 1st Ld-Writethru, a0428,670
DOC.HEAD: Saudi Oil: Lifeblood of World Economy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS graf 11, So far..., to CORRECT U.S. imports from Saudi Arabia to more 1.2 million barrels a day
DOC.TEXT: The vital interest America sees in Saudi Arabia is no mystery: it's the oil. The desert kingdom sits on a sea of crude whose flow is crucial for running the engines of the modern global economy. Saudi Arabia is the world's biggest oil exporter, and its 255 billion barrels of proven reserves give it 25 percent of the world's total. ``The sovereign independence of Saudi Arabia is of vital interest to the United States,'' President Bush said in dispatching American troops to face off with menacing Iraq. Experts agree that if Saudi oil fell to conquest, destruction or intimidation, the consequences would be devastating. ``The word unthinkable is correct,'' said John Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. ``If Saudi Arabia were out, 7 millionbarrels a day would be lost. You couldn't close the gap with prices. You'd have to have worldwide rationing and shortages.'' It gets worse. Any set of events that blocks Saudi oil would presumably cut supplies from other Persian Gulf oil exporters as well _ certainly Abu Dhabi and maybe Iran. Who knows what would happen next? ``It would be a major international conflict,'' Lichtblau said. ``Oil would no longer be the only consideration.'' But the oil shortage would certainly be a major consideration, if only because petroleum is so essential to the modern way of life. Gasoline, of course, powers nearly all the 180 million cars, trucks and buses on America's roads. Many people use oil or liquefied petroleum gas to heat their homes, and power companies consume 730,000 barrels a day generating electricity. Besides, petroleum products and derivatives are used in items as diverse as detergents, plastics, fertilizers, drugs, paint, cosmetics and clothing. So far this year, Saudi Arabia has exported more than 1.2 million barrels of oil a day to the United States, covering about 7.5 percent of the nation's consumption. A barrel contains 42 gallons. The Saudis have been pumping 5.3 million barrels a day recently, nearly 10 percent of what is consumed worldwide, excluding the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, which is how the figures are still compiled. Many people believe the Saudis now will boost output to more than 7 million barrels, replacing nearly half of the Iraqi oil being blocked by a worldwide embargo. ``If Saudi Arabia increases production, that puts them in a more overt confrontation with Iraq,'' said James E. Akins, a former U.S. ambassador to Saudi Arabia. ``We'd have to assume there would be an attempt by Iraq to sabotage Saudi oil production.'' The oil fields of Saudi Arabia, as it happens, are concentrated in the east near the borders with Kuwait and Iraq, making them all the more vulnerable to attack. Even if American and other forces are able to keep Iraq from gobbling up the Saudis as it did tiny Kuwait, it would be hard to prevent any damage. ``It's a huge complex. It's very difficult to protect every checkpoint,'' Akins said. Increased production from countries outside the region, such as Mexico and Venezuela, will not be enough to replace the missing Iraqi oil, let alone cover for a disaster in Saudi Arabia. The United States has about 600 million barrels of crude oil in its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which should be able to deliver up to 3.5 million barrels a day to refineries if Bush orders it tapped. West Germany, Japan and other industrial powers have similar emergency oil reserves. Akins joined other critics in urging Bush to release oil immediately from the strategic reserve to head off panicky price increases and lines at gasoline stations. He also said it was time to put a gas rationing system in place, to be ready if drastic shortages and zooming prices make it necessary. ``Price rationing would be catastrophic. Physical rationing need not be catastrophic,'' Akins said.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Contract Agreement Averts Strike by Supermarket Workers
DOC.TEXT: A tentative contract was reached with about 80,000 supermarket workers in California shortly after union members began walking off their jobs. Members of the United Food and Commercial Workers will vote on the proposed contract this weekend. The tentative pact was announced Thursday night about 15 minutes after a strike deadline, said union spokesman Bob Bleiweiss. Some union members had already walked off their jobs, but quickly returned to work, he said. John C. Sperry, president of UFCW Local 324, said the proposed agreement contained improved wages, pensions, working conditions and health benefits. Union spokesman Michael O'Rourke said earlier that the Food Employers Council's most recent offer provided three-year raises of 9.8 percent to 10.7 percent for veteran employees. The union represents about 73,000 clerks and 7,000 meat cutters at 800 supermarkets from San Diego to San Luis Obispo. The clerks currently earn between $4 and $13.05 an hour. Meat cutters make from $9.31 to $14.33 an hour. The Food Employers Council represents Vons, Ralphs, Alpha Beta, Lucky, Albertsons and Stater Bros. supermarkets.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: August in Washington _ Iraq Around the Clock?
With PM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 13-14 to show Bush going ahead with his vacation plans
DOC.TEXT: What could be more anesthetizing than the first August in Washington of the post-Cold War era? Answer: Just about any August of the Cold War era. This city seemed headed for one of the laziest Augusts ever just a week ago. With communists a disappearing species, what passed for controversy here was the way Roseanne Barr butchered the National Anthem. The sounds of summer could be heard at households everywhere. ``Don't forget the beach towels.'' ``Where's the sun block?'' Some of the people who were saying those things never made it out the front door. August was only about 18 hours old when all hell broke loose in the Middle East. Nothing has been the same here since then. Saddam Hussein has reduced Roseanne Barr to a mere footnote. Washington has become a city of frayed nerves and furrowed brows, of countless canceled vacations. The work days have become longer and the tempers shorter. George Lewis of NBC News had it right when he put new words to an old Bill Haley tune, titling it, ``Iraq Around the Clock.'' As bureaucrats throughout the city fret over Saddam's deed, their mail piles up unread. Spouses and children feel neglected. Books reserved for summer reading will have to wait until fall. Doctor and dental appointments get put off. That cholesterol check? Kuwait can't wait. Those things can. People who planned to be at Nantucket or Nag's Head now find themselves manning State Department telephones from midnight to 8 a.m. Others who had already arrived at the shore never had a chance to unpack; the boss summoned them back to duty. President Bush has shown the strain. He has been testy with reporters, replacing the usual evasions with ``watch and learn.'' At his news conference Wednesday, Bush sounded even more exhausted than he looked. But Bush is the boss, and he's beginning a 3{-week vacation today at his summer home in Kennebunkport, Maine. ``Life goes on,'' Bush said Thursday when asked if he really planned to go on vacation. And as the boss, Bush was taking extra staff along to help monitor events in the Middle East. And he plans to return to Washington for a military briefing one day next week. It's doubtful anyone's schedule has been more mutilated than that of Secretary of State James A. Baker III. He had just arrived in Mongolia and was planning a hunting expedition when Saddam devoured Kuwait. Baker was soon on his way to Moscow for talks with his Kremlin pal, Eduard Shevardnadze. Since leaving Mongolia, the shredding of Baker's schedule has continued unabated. He canceled a trip to Houston for his mother's birthday and gave a visiting Mexican delegation two hours of his time instead of the 12 that had been planned. His Thursday meeting with the Israeli foreign minister? Forget it. His three-week vacation that was supposed to start today looks more and more like an Arabian desert mirage. Other Augusts have produced other villains. Two years ago, it was Willie Horton. Last year, Manuel Noriega was at the top of the hate chart. But next to Saddam, Willie Horton looks like the soul of goodness. Never used poison gas in his life. Another big August was in 1968. The Soviets invaded Czechoslovakia one week and Chicago's cops had a street fight with anti-war protesters the next. Then there was August of 1981 when Ronald Reagan's jets blew two of Moammar Gadhafi's MiG fighters out of the sky over the Gulf of Sidra. But that wasn't too much of a big deal. They didn't even wake Reagan up to tell him the news. After all, it was August.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for The Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Abu Nidal's Group Says Swiss Made Deal for Release
DOC.TEXT: The extremist Palestinian faction led by Abu Nidal claimed today that the release of a 33-year-old Swiss hostage this week came after a deal with the kidnappers. The Fatah-Revolutionary Council, in a statement published by Beirut's An-Nahar independent newspaper, called on the Swiss government and the International Committee of the Red Cross to ``break their silence and declare the real identity of the side that concluded the release deal.'' But the statement did not elaborate on the alleged deal or give a source for the group's allegation. The group's spokesman, Walid Khalid, was not immeditately available for comment. Swiss and Red Cross officials have denied that any deal took place for the release Thursday of relief worker Emanuel Christen. France said the release may have been a result of its decision last month to pardon Anis Naccache and four other members of a pro-Iranian assassination team. The Fatah-Revolutionary Council statement reiterated that it was ``not involved at all in the abduction crime or the release deal.'' It challenged ``those who call themselves the ficticious Palestinian Revolutionary Squads faction to reveal its true identity and shoulder the responsibility of their acts instead of blaming them on revolutionary fighting forces.'' The previously unknown Palestinian Revolutionary Squads announced Tuesday that Christen, 33, and fellow Swiss captive Elio Erriquez, kidnapped Oct. 6, would be freed within 24 hours. There was no explanation why Erriquez was not released. Both men worked as orthopedic technicians at a Red Cross clinic in Sidon, 25 miles from Beirut. No group had claimed the Swiss pair's abduction, but Lebanese police suspected Abu Nidal's group, which repeatedly denied the charge. Abu Nidal, whose real name is Sabri al-Banna, broke away from Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization in 1973 and set up his own group based in Iraq, Syria and Libya. Christen was the first Western hostage released since two Americans were freed in April. His release brought to 15 the number of foreigners held hostage in Lebanon. The longest held is Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Scalia Says States Should Decide Abortion Issue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to ADD further background on Scalia's stand and voting record; to tighten and to drop extraneous words. Picks up 15th graf, `Motorists creeping ...'
DOC.TEXT: The nation's highest court should not decide on abortion, U.S. Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia says. ``The Constitution says nothing about it either way,'' Scalia said Thursday. ``That's how I read the document. It's an issue the states must decide for themselves.'' His remarks came in response to written questions submitted after a speech before the Los Angeles World Affairs Council. About 1,100 people attended. Scalia did not specifically discuss abortion in his talk, focusing instead on his belief that judges should not engage in public debate. Still, his speech was interrupted by two abortion-rights activists. ``You have blood on your hands,'' shouted one of the demonstrators. ``You're killing women. Women will die because of you.'' Both were quickly escorted out of the ballroom by security personnel. Scalia also avoided discussion of David Souter's nomination to the high court. And he declined to answer a question about what the Senate should be allowed to ask a Supreme Court nominee during confirmation hearings. ``The Senate and I have an understanding,'' Scalia said. ``They don't kibitz about how I do my business and I don't kibitz about how they do theirs.'' The 54-year-old Scalia, appointed to the court in 1986 by then President Reagan, has tried to pull the court further to the right and has been outspoken in criticizing conservative colleagues who prefer incremental change. Though he has a libertarian streak and strict adherence to constitutional principles that occasionally produce a surprise, Scalia is considered one of four solid votes poised to overturn the Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalized a woman's right to an abortion. Hundreds of abortion-rights demonstrators crowded outside the hotel. ``We want to send a message to the president and the Senate that we want no more Scalias,'' said Kathy Spillar, national coordinator of an activist group called the Feminist Majority. Ms. Spillar was referring to Scalia's reputation as an abortion foe and Souter's nomination. Souter has not made public his stand on the abortion issue. ``American people have a right to know where Souter stands on abortion,'' Ms. Spillar said. ``He could be the fifth vote, the swing vote on the Roe decision.'' Motorists creeping along Wilshire Boulevard in rush-hour traffic honked and waved at demonstrators who lined the sidewalks and chanted slogans. The protesters waved signs with such slogans as, ``U.S. out of my uterus,'' ``How many black children do you plan to adopt this year?'' and ``Women are not incubators.'' Among the demonstrators was Rosemary Stasek, 27, a member of Southern California Catholics for Choice. ``Because Antonin Scalia is a Catholic, we want him to know that the majority of Catholics are pro-choice,'' she said. Demonstrators also included members of the newly formed Nurses for Choice and the National Organization for Women.

DOC.HEAD: Cheap Gas Promotion Turns Into Chaos
DOC.TEXT: Fueled by motorists' frustration with rising gas prices, a gimmick to sell cheap gas at a service station turned into chaos that took police three hours to control. Before it was over, hundreds of motorists had lined up Thursday to buy gas for 48.9 cents a gallon at Kar Kleen, which has only six pumps. That was 64 cents less than the price at some competing stations in suburban Kansas City. ``It's like somebody giving you seven or eight bucks,'' said Clel Hall, who ran out of gas while waiting in line and had to push his car to the pump. The idea was promoted by radio station KBEQ-FM, known as Q104, which offered $1,004 to the station with the cheapest gas in the metropolitan area. The price of gasoline has risen since war broke out in the Middle East. The special, which included premium grades, was supposed to last for 104 minutes beginning at noon. Cars started lining up at 10:30 a.m. and extended more than a mile about an hour later. Station manager Roger Weibrecht said he expected to sell about 3,000 gallons during the special. Police were not warned of the promotion, and 11 Grand View and Kansas City officers were sent out to direct traffic, answer complaints from area businesses and mediate traffic altercations. ``I'm all for stunts, but this could be dangerous,'' Grandview Officer H.R. Ellis said while directing traffic. ``There are people leaving their cars, running for food, and they could get run over.'' Business owners complained about blocked driveways and tempers flared as cars tried to cut into line. Waiting motorists were detoured to avoid clogging the U.S. 71 interchange. Police closed the line at 1 p.m. and the last tank was filled at 2:30 p.m. There were no reports of serious accidents. But, customer Debbie Gross said the good price was tempered by the dent in her convertible, which was hit by another waiting car. ``I don't know. The price is wonderful, but now I have to go home and tell my husband about the car,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Stabbed, Decapitated in West Bank
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with killing of collaborator. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian militants fatally stabbed a suspected collaborator with Israel, cut off his head and hung it from an electrical line in a West Bank town, an Arab witness said today. The army confirmed the death Thursday of Idris Akeel and said it was under investigation by police. Police officials refused comment. Akeel, 45, was driving near the town of Dura when he was ambushed by militants hurling stones at his car, said a villager who would only give her first name, Salma. ``He came out with a pistol in his hand and began shooting,'' Salma said. She said Akeel was eventually overcome by his knife-wielding attackers. ``The activists cut off his head and hung it from an electricity wire. They pushed his car with the body in it into a valley,'' Salma said. Israel radio confirmed that the victim was stabbed to death, but did not mention anything about him being decapitated. Whistles of joy were heard throughout Dura after news of the killing spread, the reports said. Akeel's death brought to 247 the number of Palestinians slain by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of helping Israel, since the December 1987 start of the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the Gaza Strip and West Bank. The killing of Akeel was one of the must brutal cases reported. Another 727 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians. Forty-seven Israelis have died. Villagers said Akeel was the leader of a group of from 10 to 15 armed Palestinians who patrolled Dura, an isolated hill town of 10,000 people near the West Bank city of Hebron. Akeel and his men reportedly raided houses and frequently threatened activists at gunpoint. Villagers blamed Akeel for the shooting deaths of two activists in confrontations in the past year. In other developments today, the army sealed one room in the five-room house of Abdul Sami Karaz in the Gaza Strip refugee camp of Deir el-Balah. Karaz' son is accused of throwing a stone at a woman soldier and injuring her, the army said. The measures brought the number of such actions this week to eight, in addition to one house demolished Wednesday. The army seals houses by bricking up windows and doors. Soldiers then frequently patrol the area to make sure people do not move back in. The practice has been condemned by the United States and other Western nations as collective punishment. In the vast majority of the cases, houses are sealed or demolished while a suspect is still awaiting trial.

DOC.HEAD: Harvard Under Fire For Alleged Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: Harvard University has come under fire for alleged discrimination after the reassignment or dismissal of several minority administrative staffers, according to a published report today. Several minority employees have been fired or reassigned in the past year, and two have taken legal action, The Boston Globe reported. Another employee has filed a discrimination complaint with the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which is investigating the matter at Harvard Law School this week, the newspaper said. University spokeswoman Merry Touborg declined to comment on the allegations. Lawrence Watson, an assistant dean at the Harvard School of Design who was laid off in June after more than five years, was said to be taking legal action, the Globe reported. Watson declined to comment about the matter. Watson was co-chairman of the Harvard University Association of Black Faculty and Administrators with Harvard Law Professor Derrick A. Bell Jr. ``I am appalled that a senior administrator like Watson with an outstanding record could be summarily fired under the guise of a budget cut, when there was no suggestion of any problem with his job performance,'' Bell said. ``His termination will have a chilling effect on black administrators at Harvard,'' Bell said. ``Here was a guy who was outspoken, and look what happened to him.'' Last spring Bell promised to step down if the law school failed to give tenure to a black female professor, which it lacked. A black female administrator at the Harvard Business School also was dismissed recently after four years. She said she has sought legal representation. The woman, who asked not to be identified, said she was told there was not enough work for her to perform. But two consultants were reportedly hired to fulfill her duties within days of her firing, the Globe reported. Kunmi Toyu, a black computer operations assistant at Harvard Law School, was to be released at the end of this month. Toyu was allegedly hired below the posted salary level after a white male was hired for the same position at higher pay. Toyu said she filed a complain with the EEOC over her dismissal. An official with the federal agency said it does not comment on investigations. A fourth administrator, Mildred Allen, was reportedly reassigned from personnel director of the law school to the medical school. Allen, a vocal affirmative action advocate, would not comment. Harvard has 8,512 non-faculty positions, and 1,410 are held by minorities, according to the school's Affirmative Action Plan. At the law school, 54 of the 343 non-faculty positions are held by minorities, and the business school employs 59 minorities in 538 positions. The design school includes 12 minorities on a staff of 92.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Government To Test For Pesticide In Honey
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration will test the nation's honey after some in Massachusetts was found with 22 times the legal amount of pesticide, according to a published report today. Officials identified two large beekeeping operations which allegedly misused the chemical, fluvalinate, in hives used to pollinate cranberry bogs in Massachusetts, The Boston Herald reported. Inspectors found fluvalinate in honey taken from hives owned by one of the companies. The company sells honey to the public as well as to the federal government, which gives it to schools and senior citizen centers. John A. Hamilton Jr., compliance director for the FDA in Boston, said the agency was concerned that dozens of beekeepers who travel between Florida and New England pollinating everything from citrus groves to apples orchards may be misusing the pesticide. ``We don't know whether this is (in) food for human consumption or not at this point, so we are actively investigating it and we will begin testing the honey that is sold for human consumption,'' he said. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency describes fluvalinate as ``low to moderately toxic.'' It is made by the Sandoz Crop Protection Corp. and can cause skin, eye and throat irritation, the EPA said. Fluvalinate, which is legal for use in hives which do not produce honey, is used to kill the varroa mite, which kills bees. Officials are concerned that some of the 169.3 million pounds of honey purchased by the U.S. Department of Agriculture and distributed to schools, centers for the elderly, and other human services agencies may be contaminated. A source close to the investigation who spoke on condition of anonymity said officials from at least two other states, including Florida, are cooperating with the investigation by the EPA and FDA, the Herald said. ``This is just symptomatic of the rest of the (industry),'' the source said. ``The FDA is looking at honey all across the country.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Deliberating in Central Park Jogger Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs., `Justice Thomas ...' with one graf to UPDATE with jury resuming deliberations.
DOC.TEXT: The defense in the Central Park jogger case was dealt a setback when the judge told the jury that the law did not necessarily require that the young defendants' parents be present during questioning. Justice Thomas Galligan's instructions came in response to a request for clarification from the jury during its first day of deliberations Thursday. Jurors resumed deliberations in the rape and attempted murder case shortly after 10 a.m. today. ``The fact that a parent was not present during the questioning of a juvenile does not automatically mean the statement is involuntary,'' the judge said. Peter Rivera, 15-year-old Raymond Santana's lawyer, had argued that Santana's incriminating statements were no good because his grandmother, who spoke little English, was the only adult with him during questioning. ``The attack on the confession was our central issue. The judge's instructions hurt my case,'' Rivera said Thursday. Santana, Yusef Salaam, 16, and Antron McCray, 16, are charged with attacking a jogger in Central Park in April 1989. They were tried in an adult court as juveniles, meaning a conviction would bring limited prison terms. Prosecutors said the jogger was dragged into the woods, gang-raped, bashed with a brick and pipe and left to die in a pool of blood. She is back at work as an investment banker but her sight, balance and smell are impaired. The savagery of the attack and her extraordinary recovery captured the attention of the city and the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Lower, Dollar Higher, Oil Prices Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with early Wall Street trading, latest oil prices and dollar trading. No pickup. Version also moved on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices moved lower today in New York, Tokyo and London, the dollar edged higher and oil prices rose slightly as traders awaited new developments in the Persian Gulf crisis. Arab leaders were meeting today in Cairo, Egypt, where President Hosni Mubarak told them they either must persuade Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or allow foreign powers mobilizing in the region to resolve the crisis for them. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last week drove oil prices sharply higher and rocked world financial markets because of the possibility of a dropoff in oil supply, which could fuel inflation and crimp industrial production. As the Cairo meeting got under way, stock prices were slightly lower on Wall Street, with the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks down 7.42 points to 2,752.49 as of 10 a.m. EDT. On London's Stock Exchange, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 6.80 points at 2,237.80. Earlier, stock prices lost ground on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, where the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average fell 286.18 points, or 1.04 percent, to close at 27,329.55. It was the Nikkei's lowest closing level since Oct. 24, 1988, when it ended trading at 27,281.54. The index had fallen 893.41 points Thursday. Akira Shimoda, an equity analyst with Yamaichi Securities, said the uncertainty about the Middle East left ``a negative psychological impact on investors.'' On Thursday, the Dow Jones average gained 24.01 to finish at 2,758.91, extending a rebound that began with a 24.26-point jump Wednesday. In currency dealings, the dollar moved higher in New York this morning, trading at 150.20 yen as of 10 a.m. EDT, up from 149.805 yen late Thursday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 150.15 yen, up from 149.80 yen late Thursday. Earlier, the dollar closed at 149.75 yen in Tokyo, up 0.07. Meanwhile, oil prices rose in early New York trading, were up in London and closed steady in Tokyo. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, oil for September delivery was up 20 cents per 42-gallon barrel to $25.87 as of 10 a.m. EDT. On Thursday, the September contract lost 29 cents to settle at $25.67 barrel. The contract had plummeted $2.35 per barrel Wednesday. Crude oil contracts traded between $25.35 and $26.60 per barrel Thursday, which some traders described as the narrowest range in the last several trading sessions. Among refined petroleum products traded on the New York Merc, the near-term contract for home heating oil dropped 0.36 cent to 69.77 cents per gallon Thursday. The September contract for unleaded gasoline gained .21 cent to 76.42 cents per gallon, partly on technical trading factors.

DOC.HEAD: NICOSIA: last week. The unidentiffied spokesman accused Western nations and Kuwait's former leaders of having used ``sly methods'' to corrupt the oil-rich emirate. He said Iraq had invaded Kuwait to correct that situation. The spokesman said ``imperialists'' had always tried to ``divide the (Arab) nations so that their interests come first.'' MORE
NICOSIA: its fight.
DOC.TEXT: The spokesman called on Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, ``the son of Nasser,'' to stop the ``foreign fleets'' from passing through the Suez Canal. Iraq's invasion was intended to bring the priniciples of religion to all Arab countries, the spokesman said. In a reference to the multinational force, called on all Arabs to ``condemn the invaders and collaborators.'' ``God will be with you. Victory is always on the (side) of believers'' The spokesman ended the 15-minute address in name of Saddam, quoted from the Koran, and reiterated the call for Arab unity.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Man With AIDS Kills Mother Who Came To Care For Him
DOC.TEXT: A man with AIDS beat his mother to death after she came from California to care for him, police said. The man then set himself on fire, but jumped in the shower after deciding he did not want to die. Earl Imbert, 39, was charged Thursday with second-degree murder and criminal possession of a weapon. He was in critical condition today at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center with second- and third-degree burns over 25 percent of his body, said hospital spokeswoman Kathy Robinson. Police went to Imbert's apartment Thursday morning after receiving a call from the woman's other son in California who was worried because he could not reach anyone at the apartment, said police spokeswoman Tina Mohrmann. Imbert, who was incoherent and had blood on his clothing, let them in without resistance, Mohrmann said. Officers found the body of his 63-year-old mother, Leona, wrapped in a blanket. She had been hit on the head with a hammer and a wooden statue. The woman had planned to take her son back to her home in Van Nuys, Calif., to take care of him, Mohrmann said. Police found airplane tickets in the apartment. After he killed his mother, Imbert wrapped himself in a shower curtain and set it on fire, authorities said, but he put out the flames in the shower.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Screening Legislation; Praises Mrs. Quayle
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, praising Marilyn Quayle for her efforts to fight cancer, signed legislation today that will provide federal money to screen women for breast and cervical cancer. Mrs. Quayle, wife of Vice President Dan Quayle, attended the bill-signing, her first public appearance since undergoing a hysterectomy nearly three weeks ago. Doctors said pre-cancerous cells were detected during a routine checkup. ``You're looking so well,'' Bush told Mrs. Quayle, who lobbied for the legislation. Mrs. Quayle adopted the cause in part because her mother, a pediatrician, died of breast cancer. Bush didn't refer directly to Mrs. Quayle's recent surgery, but said she was a ``source of strength to all of us.'' Calling breast and cervical cancer a ``women's and family issue,'' Bush signed the legislation authorizing $50 million in fiscal 1991 for grants to states. Under the legislation, states would use the grants to screen women for cancer, develop and disseminate information about the early detection and prevention of cancer and improve the education of health professionals in the area. To receive the funds, states could be required to match $1 for each $3 from the federal government. They would also have to provide free testing services to low-income women. Bush said 150,000 women develop the diseases each year and 50,000 women die from them. ``So many sad stories of loss could have happy endings if more women are aware of the life-saving technologies that are now available,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed, Three Injured Trying To Disarm WWII Bomb
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads throughout to UPDATE with three injured, bomb discovered Thursday by children, details on explosion. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A World War II bomb found near Wetzlar exploded today during attempts to disarm it, killing two explosives experts and seriously injuring three, police said. The bomb was discovered a day earlier by children playing behind a factory, police said. The explosion occurred near this town, which is about 30 miles north of Frankfurt. Police in nearby Giessen said two explosive experts were killed, two were severely injured and one was slightly hurt. The bomb went off as a demolition team prepared to lift it, police said. A police spokesman said the bomb had been dropped on the area during World War II but did not detonate.

DOC.HEAD: New Orleans Trying to Spruce Up Its Tombs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7th graf, `As a result ...,' to CORRECT that lightning strike happened last week, not last August. ^By MARY FOSTER
DOC.TEXT: Patrick Halpin probably thought the mausoleum he built 125 years ago would be his family's final resting place. But unless one of his descendants can be found, the generations of Halpins inside the dilapidated tomb will be exhumed and the crypt will be renovated and sold. The reason: a 1974 law under which New Orleans tombs in need of renovation can be confiscated and the remains moved to unmarked mausoleums elsewhere in the same cemetery. Called ``The Cities of the Dead,'' New Orleans' 31 historic cemeteries mirror the city in miniature and in marble. Laid out along twisting lanes, bedecked with cast iron fences and carved in elaborate architectural detail, the tombs form whitewashed neighborhoods. Hundreds of tourists a day visit the tombs, which were built above ground because New Orleans is below sea level, too wet for graves. Some tombs, such as those of William Claiborne, the first American governor of Louisiana, and New Orleans voodoo queen Marie Laveau, are maintained through a special preservation fund. But other tombs are the responsibility of the family. As a result, the cemeteries have been ravaged by years of neglect. Last week, for example, lightning blasted apart a brick wall of 56 vaults in the Lafayette Cemetery, exposing rusty coffin hinges, bags of bones and skulls. The New Orleans Archdiocese, which owns six of the old cemeteries on almost 50 acres, has upgraded streets, drainage and monuments in the cemeteries over the years. Now the church, along with a volunteer group, hopes to use the 1974 law to restore hundreds of abandoned tombs built 60 to 200 years ago. ``It's your house and the city isn't going to come in and renovate your house,'' said Bret Clesi, president of Save Our Cemeteries, which gives tours to raise money for restoration. ``If the family doesn't maintain it, it should go to someone who will.'' Among the tombs in need of repair is the Halpin family crypt on the main street of St. Patrick Cemetery No. 3. Its soft red bricks are loose and weeds grow along the edge of the roof. ``This tomb could be beautifully restored. If it's left as it is, it will just continue to deteriorate,'' said Michael D. Boudreaux, assistant director of the New Orleans Archdiocesan Cemeteries. The archdiocese is trying to locate tomb owners by advertising in newspapers, by mail and through notices posted on the crypts. Under the 1974 law, officials must try for a year to trace heirs, then wait three more years before repossessing the tombs. Over the last five years, the archdiocese has located 40 to 50 descendants, many of whom didn't know about their family tomb until they were contacted about restoring it, Boudreaux said. So far, no tombs have been confiscated. Boudreaux put the costs of restoration at $2,000 to $3,000 per tomb, although Save Our Cemeteries said some could run $30,000 or more. Families also must pay a one-time $2,400 for perpetual care to assure the tombs don't fall into disrepair again, Boudreaux said. If a restored tomb is resold, the remains inside will be put in another crypt and records will be kept to show where they are, Boudreaux said. He said there have been no objections so far. ``If the tomb is ready to fall down anyway, I'm not too sure you can be concerned about moving the remains,'' Clesi said. Boudreaux hopes eventually to restore the Cities of the Dead to their former glory. ``We're seeing some derelict areas really being upgraded,'' he said. ``Some day, it may be like it once was when families brought picnic lunches and spent the day working on their tombs.''

DOC.HEAD: Hidlay Appointed Portland, Maine, Correspondent
DOC.TEXT: William C. Hidlay, a newsman on the Foreign-World Services Desk of The Associated Press, has been named correspondent in charge of the AP's Portland bureau. The appointment was announced Friday by Larry Laughlin, the AP's bureau chief for Northern New England. Hidlay, 31, succeeds Dirk Beveridge, who recently transferred to the AP's Business News desk in New York. Hidlay joined the AP in Chicago in 1986 and transferred to New York two years later. He previously worked for the Bloomsburg, Pa., Press-Enterprise; the Fayetteville (N.C.) Times; and The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer. Hidlay is a native of Bloomsburg and a graduate of Syracuse University.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Says Defense Dept. Has Asked About Troop Flights to Middle East
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Miami-based Eastern Airlines is among a handful of major U.S. air carriers approached by the military to fly thousands of American soldiers into Saudi Arabia, an airline spokeswoman said. ``We have been contacted by the government about our airplane availability,'' Eastern spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak said Thursday. No flights have been scheduled yet, she said. In South Florida, scores of Eastern pilots and flight attendants have been asked to staff charters that could carry thousands of soldiers on the 6,000-mile flight from the United States to the Middle East, employees said. Mary Jane Barry, president of the Eastern flight attendants union, said flight attendants are being contacted by crew-scheduling managers and asked if they are interested in working the charter flights. Not all carriers have jets available to airlift the soldiers. ``We were called but this is our busiest time of the year. We just don't have any planes available,'' said Jim Faulkner, spokesman for TWA in St. Louis. A spokesman for Chicago-based United Airlines would not comment on that carrier's plans, while Northwest and Delta airlines said their companies were not planning charters.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Disbands Special Drug Force after Finding Small Problem
DOC.TEXT: A special task force to combat crack cocaine is being disbanded because officials concluded Britain does not have a signficant crack problem outside of London. ``Because the problem has been identified at such a low level, it is no longer considered necessary to devote permanent resources,'' a spokesman for the Customs and Excise department said Friday. The force, including officers from Customs, London's Metropolitan Police and regional crime squads, was established in December. Its formation came at a time of heightened concern among politicians that the crack epidemic in the United States would spill into Britain and other European countries. In seven months, the unit handled 14 cases, police said. Twenty-seven people were charged, and officers seized about 29 pounds of cocaine, including some crack cocaine. The Customs spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Britain's crack problem is ``very limited, almost exclusively confined to London _ at this time. The danger remains, we're not being complacent.''

DOC.HEAD: West German Airline Applies to Fly to Berlin
DOC.TEXT: The West German national carrier Lufthansa said Friday it wants to begin flights to Berlin by late October. The airline has not been allowed to fly to the divided city since the end of World War II. Lufthansa, founded and based in Berlin until the end of the war, said it had applied to the West German Transportation Ministry in Bonn to begin the flights. Only airlines that were based in the nations of the four victorious World War II powers _ the United States, Soviet Union, France and Great Britain _ have been allowed to fly to West Berlin. Lufthansa is also barred from the air space above Berlin. An airline spokesman said it was not clear whether the four powers would also have to approve the application. But a spokesman at the U.S. Embassy in Bonn said: `The application is being reviewed like any other. No decision has been made.'' The Germanys are racing toward unification, and Allied privileges are to be lifted after unification.

DOC.HEAD: Talks Resume Amid Renewed War Jitters
DOC.TEXT: India and Pakistan met Friday on relaxing border tensions amid uneasiness in New Delhi over the dismissal of Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. Indian opposition members in Parliament expressed fears the caretaker government in Pakistan would increase aid to Moslem separatists in India's Kashmir Valley and to Sikh militants in the Punjab. Pakistani Foreign Secretary Tanvir Ahmad Khan said Thursday the dismissal of Ms. Bhutto's government would not affect Pakistan's foreign policy or its ambition to build good ties with India. Ms. Bhutto's government was dismissed and the National Assembly dissolved on Monday, in a move analysts said was engineered by the army. During a scheduled two-day meeting that began Friday, Khan and Indian Foreign Secretary Muchkund Dubey were to consider a package of confidence-building measures. The two nations nearly went to war in May over Kashmir, where Moslem militants are seeking to break away from predominantly Hindu India. India accused Pakistan, an Islamic nation, of giving military support to the rebels. Pakistan denied the allegations. At a first round of talks last month, the foreign secretaries drafted the text of agreements concerning violations of air space and exchanging information on military exercises, Khan said. More than a half dozen other measures remain to be discussed, he told reporters on his arrival here Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Burmese Government Blames Diplomats for Reports of Fatal Rally
DOC.TEXT: The military government blamed Western diplomats Friday for what it called exaggerated reports of bloodshed in a clash between soldiers and a group of Buddhist monks and students. The diplomats said soldiers were reported to have killed at least two monks and two students who were demonstrating peacefully in the central city of Mandalay on Wednesday. Government radio said one monk and three policemen were injured. It said police fired to disperse the crowd after demonstrators stoned policemen and tried to seize their guns. At a news conference Friday, government spokesman Col. Than Tun said the foreign media accounts of the clash came from two groups of Western diplomats who were in Mandalay at the time. He would not identify them. ``Diplomats should refrain from indulging in mean acts incompatible with diplomats of civilized nations,'' he said. Reporters reached the diplomats in Rangoon by telephone from Bangkok. They said while they could not independently confirm the deaths, the reports came from usually reliable sources. They said the demonstration reflected the growing frustration at the government's refusal to hand over power to the National League for Democracy, which won a majority of seats in the May 27 parliamentary election. The authorities still hold party leader Aung San Suu Kyi under house arrest, and other opposition leaders remain imprisoned. The military government came to power in September 1988, when soldiers crushed a nationwide uprising for democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Tourists Cancel, Anxious Over War Atmosphere in Middle East
DOC.TEXT: Travel agents said Friday they had received cancellations and were being swamped by phone calls from anxious tourists worried about an Iraqi chemical attack on Israel. Also Friday, an Israeli newspaper reported the United States has vowed to launch a full military strike against Iraq if that country attacked Israel. The U.S. assurance was part of a message sent by Defense Secretary Richard Cheney to his Israeli counterpart, Moshe Arens, Hadashot said in an unattributed report. Defense Ministry spokesman Dan Naveh did not return several telephone messages Friday. U.S. Embassy spokesman Don Cofman would not refer to specifics, saying only that ``U.S. support for Israel is well-known.'' Sixteen Americans in a 40-member tourist group canceled at the last minute Thursday and many more cancellations were expected, said Ofer Eshed, manager of Ophir Tours in Tel Aviv. ``It is not the (Persian) Gulf crisis but the stories of the gas masks that are worrying American tourists,'' Eshed said. ``Tourists are asking if they will also be given gas masks.'' The cancellations could mark the start of a deep slump in Israel's tourism industry, just recovering from a two-year decline attributed to the Palestinian uprsing. Tourism is Israel's largest source of foreign capital, bringing in more than $1.7 billion last year. On Wednesday, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein threatened to launch a missile attack on Israel if the Americans launched a military strike in the gulf. In April, Saddam threatened to burn half of Israel with chemical weapons if Israel attacked Iraq. The Hyatt Regency Hotel in Jerusalem has received many overseas inquiries about the situation in Israel, said the hotel's public relations manager, Ezra Astruc. ``People abroad want to know if Israel has really mobilized its troops and if everybody has been given gas masks,'' Astruc said. Both Astruc and Eshed said there was a lull in reservations for spring 1991, which usually pour in this time of year. Tourism Ministry spokesman Yossi Shuval confirmed that reservations for spring were down and said some Americans might think twice now before buying a ticket to Israel or any other overseas destination. ``Those who have tickets in hand will still come but those who haven't bought their tickets yet may change their plans,'' Shuval said. ``If there is World War III, people will prefer to stay home,'' Shuval said. Another tourism official said most short-term cancellations over the gulf crisis would come from ``holiday makers from Europe looking for sun and fun.'' The official said pilgrims, who account for 38 percent of Israel's tourism, are less easily deterred by troubles. Before the Persian Gulf crisis, Israeli tourism enjoyed a 1990 comeback after the plunge set off by the Palestinian uprising. Figures released by the Ministry of Tourism said the number of tourists coming to Israel in the first six months of 1990 was up 10 percent from the same period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Would-Be Hijacker Hits Pilot On Head With Heavy Object
DOC.TEXT: A passenger trying to hijack a passenger plane in central Russia hit the pilot on the head with a heavy object but was apprehended by another pilot, Tass reported Friday. The official Soviet news agency said the male passenger, identified only by the surname Chernyavsky, tried to hijack the Antonov-2 passenger plane Thursday as it was landing in the town of Livny. The brief Tass report did not say how many were on board the plane, where the flight originated or where the man wanted to go. It quoted an Interior Ministry spokesman as saying the man, born in 1947, had a criminal record and had recently worked as a watchman in a kindergarten. It said the injured pilot received unspecified medical aid. More than a dozen attempts were made to hijack Soviet aircraft to Scandinavia or Turkey in June and July.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Cuts Millions of Dollars in Exports to Iraq
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Cash-strapped East Germany halted millions of dollars in trade with Iraq on Friday, joining a worldwide embargo but endangering the fragile existence of some East German factories. The Economics Ministry said it was complying with a U.N. resolution to cut economic ties with Iraq because of its invasion of Kuwait. East Germany had been a big exporter of electronics, agricultural machinery, industrial equipment and some chemical products to Iraq, said Rainer Schuster, head of the ministry's office for economic relations with developing nations. The trade agreements with Iraq were made by the former Communist regime, which was toppled in the fall and replaced with an elected democratic government in March. Schuster said East Germany has in the past exported $200 million to $300 million in goods annually to Iraq, but that amount has been cut to less than half in the past year because of Iraq's own economic problems. He said his office had no specific figure for the current dollar value of trade between the countries. East German exports often were paid for in Iraqi oil. East Germany, which relies solely on Soviet crude for its own petroleum needs, would then sell the Iraqi oil to other countries, Schuster said. He said East Germany received $70 million to $100 million in Iraqi oil in 1990. East Germany has only negligible trade with Kuwait, he said. East Germany's economy has taken a beating since the nation switched to a free market on July 1 in anticipation of unification with West Germany later this year. Jobless is skyrocketing and hundreds of factories are threatened with bankruptcy. Schuster said he did not think the trade embargo with Iraq would significantly worsen East Germany's already dire economic situation, but said ``it may be harmful to some enterprises'' that manufactured products sold to Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Lightning Kindles Forests in West, Yosemite National Park Hit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with increased acreage of fires in Idaho, and California, including Yosemite park and Tehama County. Picks up 12th graf: `In Oregon ...'
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters today battled lightning-kindled wildfires that have burned more than 275,000 acres in the West, including 12,000 acres in Yosemite National Park, which was closed to most visitors. Scattered fires in California left 100,000 acres charred by morning. More than 90,000 acres of forest land have burned in Oregon in recent days, more than 80,000 acres burned in Idaho and nearly 5,500 in Utah. In Yosemite, the park immortalized by naturalist John Muir and photographer Ansel Adams, 10,000 visitors were stranded overnight to keep roads clear for emergency vehicles. Two villages were evacuated and 25 structures burned. The park was closed to most visitors late Thursday, after fires blocked all the main roads. Fire officials planned to escort out the stranded campers early today. Only California Route 395 over Tioga Pass, a small road near the Nevada border, remained open. Spokeswoman Paula Brown said only visitors with reservations at the Wawona camp on the park's south end would be allowed in. About 200 miles to the north, a 3,500-acre blaze forced some residents to flee Ravendale, said state forestry spokesman Chris Parker. A 2,500-acre fire threatened the town as well, he said. A total of 17,608 lightning strikes were recorded from Aug. 3 through mid-week, sparking more than a thousand fires, Parker said. He said more than 6,000 firefighters were in action, including 2,000 brought in from out of state. A 39,000-acre fire burned in Tehama County, and 20 rural families were evacuated. A 17,500-acre fire threatened campgrounds in Sequoia National Park. In Idaho, smoke from wildfires blanketed Boise Valley today as a growing army of firefighters hustled to keep up with several blazes. ``It could be several days before we'll see clear skies again,'' said Kathleen Eide, a National Weather Service meteorologist in Boise. Low humidity and temperatures topping 100 helped scores of blazes sear central Idaho forests, while three large range fires burned out of control on the southern Idaho desert. The largest of the range fires _ a 60,000-acre blaze _ ripped across sagebrush and grass 35 miles northeast of Twin Falls and created weather of its own Thursday. ``It looked like a cyclone with black clouds and a wall of flame rising about 1,000 feet in the air,'' said Dale Chatterton, a U.S. Bureau of Land Management dispatcher. In Oregon, a 70,000-acre blaze turned away from three small towns in the southeast corner of the state after 60 mph winds switched direction. Some residents of Riley fled when flames came within a mile, while residents three miles from the fire in Burns and Hines watched its progress closely, said state forestry spokeswoman Christie Sohn. More than 6,500 people from state and federal agencies were fighting fires statewide. In Utah, crews on Thursday cleared landing spots for helicopters planning to ferry firefighters battling a 5,350-acre blaze into hard-to-reach areas on the Uintah and Ouray Indian Reservation. The blaze in the ponderosa pines and oak brush was nearly contained Thursday before thunderstorms slowed firefighters and started new fires. Meanwhile today, firefighers in northwestern Utah battled five brush fires totaling 1,800 acres, including one that threatened homes in the desert community of Terra about 40 miles west of Salt Lake City.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Indicates Support For French Combat Role In Gulf
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: By a slight margin, the French want their armed forces to fight alongside the United States in the event of war with Iraq, according a poll released Friday. Of 800 people surveyed this week by the IPSOS polling firm, 47 percent said they favored French participation in a multinational force if war breaks out, while 43 percent were opposed. The poll, conducted for the weekly magazine Le Point, said 46 percent of the respondents hoped U.S. forces would confront Iraq directly, while 34 percent hoped this would not happen. Asked if they had confidence in President Francois Mitterrand's ability to serve French interests in his handling of the crisis, 59 percent said ``yes'' and 31 percent said 'no.' No margin of error for the poll was given. France prepared to bolster its Persian Gulf forces to seven ships and 3,200 military personnel Friday. The aircraft carrier Clemenceau, guided-missile cruiser Colbert, anti-submarine frigate Montcalm and supply vessel Var will steam out of the Mediterranean port of Toulon in coming days. On arriving in the gulf region in two weeks, they will raise the total French military presence to seven ships and 3,200 sailors, airmen and soldiers. France will coordinate with a U.S.-led multinational force in the gulf but not belong to it, Mitterrand said. French ships will remain under French command.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts of Saddam Hussein Statement Friday
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from the statement Friday from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, which was monitored in Bahrain and translated from Arabic by The Associated Press.

The foreigner used to respect the Arab and did not trample them under foot nor their sacred shrines and the Arabs were one nation ... They were dignified. The ruler was a wise man and one of the most courageous, leading the vanguard wherever the fighting ... strong, standing in the front lines ... the most generous among them. He was honest and feared God, was loved and respected by his people.... A real leader ... he distributed the riches of the nation to the people. He didn't obey the foreigner.... He was close to God and kept distance from evil ... Look at where the Arabs are today ... The foreigner entered our homes, the Western imperialism has divided us, setting up small states to facilitate the task of occupying Arab land ... Imperialism made sure they guaranteed the major points by creating those states, kept away the riches from the majority. With the riches in a minority, it was used for the foreigner and the minority ruler. They used schemes to help the imperialists. Because of this condition, they give the worst picture of the Arabs to the foreigners because of their shameful behavior. (They were) stooges of the foreigner. There had to be a fundamental correction of this picture changing this minority control that is spreading disease in the body of the majority. And so, in the south of Iraq, Iraq responded to save Kuwait ... The traitors who betrayed the nation collapsed ... It is the battle of the entire Arab nation the battle of freedom from hunger and humiliation away from God. It's the beginnning for the foreigners to respect the Arab demand and respond to them everywhere. It's the gain on which the Palestinians can base... Imperialism and Zionism (are) standing (up) to Iraq because it represents the conscience of the Arab world. Iraq, oh Arabs, is your Iraq. (Iraq is) moving darkness (away), and after (we) all stand in one line, God will bless us ... The evil ememies' ranks will collapse no matter how strong and no matter what traitors. The American forces came and Saudi Arabia opened its doors to it under false pretext that the Iraqi army will continue toward them. Denials and clarifications were of no avail ... It means that there are plans for aggressive intentions. The joint policy with the foreigner has become exposed. So they are not only defying the Arab and Islamic nations and their own ... They were challenging God the day they put Mecca and the tomb of Mohammed under the soil of the foreigner. Oh Arabs, oh Moslems, oh believers in God wherever you are, this is your day to rise and spread quickly in order to defend Mecca, which is captive to the spears of the Americans and the Zionists. This is your day to rise quickly to defend the Prophet Mohammed ibn Abdallah, who carries the noble message in this noble land for it to remain holy. Rise up against evil, against the foreigner who has trampled our sacred rights. Keep the foreigner away from our sacred shrines ... Tell the traitors there is no place for them on the soil of the Arabs after they humiliated Arab honor and dignity. Burn the soil under the feet of the aggressors and invaders who want harm for your families in Iraq. Until the voice of right rises up in the Arab world, hit their interests wherever they are and rescue holy Mecca and the grave of the Prophet Mohammed. Don't let the enemy pass from the soil of Egypt to use your water. Sons of the Strait of Hormuz, stop the fleets from moving. Sons in Ras al-Khaimah and Sharjah, Arabs everywhere, your brothers in Iraq are determined on holy war without hesitation and without any slowing down. Victory with God's will. We shall be victorious, God willing, and evil and corruption will be trampled wherever it is, and the sun will rise on the Arabs and the Moslems and God will be happy. After we purify our souls and land from the foreigners, oh brothers, denounce them. Hit their interests wherever they are and rescue Holy Mecca.

DOC.HEAD: Spacecraft Ready for Venus Exploration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE NASA confirming Magellan in orbit, quotes. Picks up 7th graf pvs: `NASA plans ...' Times are PDT.
DOC.TEXT: Magellan, the first U.S. planetary spacecraft launched since 1978, fired its braking rocket and dropped into orbit around Venus today on a mission to make the best pictures yet of the planet's cloud-covered terrain. ``The system worked as planned. A lot of hard work was rewarded,'' said George Alexander, chief spokesman for NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``I'm tremendously gratified we were able to do something for NASA and the public that shows this is a capable agency'' following troubles with the shuttle fleet and the Hubble Space Telescope, he said. ``This breaks the string of bad luck.'' Magellan dived over Venus' north pole, then ignited the forward-facing rocket at 9:32 a.m., slowing from about 24,600 mph to roughly 18,500 mph. That allowed Magellan to be captured by Venus' gravity and start orbiting the second planet from the sun, said mission commentator Steve Wall. The rocket ignition happened when the spacecraft was behind Venus, out of radio contact with engineers on Earth. Magellan emerged at 9:53 a.m., but preliminary confirmation that all went well came 13 minutes later because of the time Magellan's radio signal takes to reach Earth. ``We are now in orbit!'' said David Okerson, a Magellan project engineer. In the Magellan project office, ``there was cheering and applause and whistling and hooting'' by scientists and engineers, said secretary Sharon Kyle. Magellan encountered Venus 144 million miles from Earth after circling the sun 1{ times during a roundabout, 948-million-mile journey. The $413 million Magellan, the heart of a $744 million mission, was designed to use radar to penetrate thick Venusian clouds, allowing the spacecraft to make maps and pictures of the planet's deformed, volcanic landscape with unprecedented detail. Mapping is slated to start by Sept. 1. NASA plans to release the first pictures in September, but may do so this month if images made during tests produce any interesting discoveries. Magellan has raised NASA's hopes after its recent woes, including the temporary grounding of the shuttle fleet because of hydrogen leaks and a defective mirror that crippled the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope. ``The major pressure we feel is the pressure to succeed,'' Wesley T. Huntress Jr., NASA director of solar system exploration, said Thursday. ``I'd prefer not to speculate on what failure might mean.'' The 21-foot Magellan, deployed from the shuttle Atlantis in May 1989, was the first U.S. planetary spacecraft launched since 1978, when NASA sent the Pioneer 12 orbiter and the Pioneer 13 probes to Venus. ``Magellan is the beginning of a new era of planetary exploration,'' Huntress said. ``We're looking forward to the drama.'' The Voyager probes explored Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune between 1979 and last year, but they were launched in 1977. Galileo, launched in October, is headed toward a 1995 rendezvous with Jupiter. During the coming decade or so, NASA also plans to send spacecraft to explore Mars, the moon, Saturn, comets and the sun's polar regions. NASA has said Magellan would return more data than all previous NASA missions combined. Venus is similar to Earth in size, density and position in the solar system, although a runaway ``greenhouse effect'' raised its surface temperature to 900 degrees Fahrenheit, about as hot as a self-cleaning oven. NASA wants to learn if the planet's geological processes are similar to Earth's. Venus has tens of thousands of volcanoes, but no one knows if any are active. Magellan was named for the Portuguese explorer Ferdinand Magellan, who sailed around the world in the early 1500s. The spacecraft was built by Martin Marietta Corp. and its radar was built by Hughes Aircraft Co.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Promotes Soviet Specialist
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Friday he has promoted Condoleezza Rice, a staff member of the National Security Council, to the position of special assistant to the president. Rice, 35, has served on the NSC staff as the principal Soviet specialist since February 1989. She became senior director for Soviet affairs in May, a month before the U.S.-Soviet summit at which she played a leading role. Rice is on leave from her post as associate professor of political science at Stanford University.

DOC.HEAD: Roll Over Tiffany's And Tell Macy's the News
