DOC.TEXT: Shirley Kagan and Matthew Dubroff did not want to begin married life buried by the usual wedding presents, so they created their own bridal registry _ a list of classic rock 'n' roll compact discs on file at a record store. ``We figured that we'd never remember who gave us the ceramic Dalmatian, but we'd always know who gave us Van Morrison's `Moondance,''' said Kagan. She and Dubroff, both 22, get married Sunday. Since they plan to spend the next two years in Japan teaching English, the couple neither want nor need a lot of household objects. So instead of registering a silver pattern at Tiffany's, Kagan decided to register at Tower Records. ``We both really love music,'' she explained, ``and this was a way to get it in bulk.'' Her plan was simple: They would list, in order of preference, the 150 compact discs they most wanted to begin their rock library. But choosing and ranking proved difficult. He liked the Grateful Dead; she liked Cat Stevens. They wound up spending three days in the store, arguing over the best of rock 'n' roll. Finally, they settled on a system: He'd pick one, she'd pick one, all the way from the complete, 16-volume Beatles collection down to Prince's ``1999'' and Earth, Wind & Fire's ``Raise.'' ``It was an experience in compromise before marriage,'' Kagan said. ``But we never even made it to the classical section. We were exhausted.'' When the couple's friends and relatives called Tower, they were told which discs on the list had not been purchased, and where they ranked in preference. Store manager Steve Harman outlined the ``packages'' Kagan and Dubroff had devised, such as a four-disc set of solo albums by John Lennon and Paul McCartney and one comprising ``The Essential Jimi Hendrix'' and ``Bob Dylan Live at Budokan.'' But some gift buyers tried to break up the packages. ``They wanted to choose music that they liked,'' Harman said. ``One woman was willing to buy Kate Bush, but she said no Led Zeppelin. She wanted to substitute Dire Straits.'' Kagan's aunt and uncle provided the most essential gift, a portable CD player. ``We've also gotten an espresso machine, some china and a bunch of silverware, but I'm much more enthusiastic about the music,'' Kagan said. ``Some might argue that I'll become more mature and regret this, but I don't see myself getting more sensible.''

DOC.HEAD: Analysts: Lower Prices Show Inflation Tame Before Persian Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale prices declined 0.1 percent in July, the government said Friday in a report showing inflation was in check before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last week sent oil costs spiraling. The seasonally adjusted decline capped a six-month stretch of virtually no change in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index for finished goods. The index had risen a modest 0.2 percent in June. For the first seven months of the year, wholesale prices advanced at an annual rate of 3 percent, down sharply from the 4.8 percent increase for all of last year. ``Obviously this number is history,'' said economist Donald Ratajczak of Georgia State University. ``But what it shows is that heading into the oil shock, inflation was tame.'' Financial markets shrugged off the good news. Stock prices fell after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein called for Arab unity to condemn U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia and to overthrow the Saudi royal family. The effect on world oil markets of Iraq's action last week means the July report is the end of the inflation respite, analysts said. ``The numbers almost appear like the calm beach scene before the shark in `Jaws' arrives,'' said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors. Crude oil prices, which averaged around $20 a barrel in July, have pushed past $25 since the invasion and gasoline prices are reported up as much as 16 cents a gallon at many service stations. Ratajczak predicted that overall wholesale prices could shoot up as much as 1.6 percent in August. That would be the biggest increase since a 1.9 percent jump in January when a severe cold snap froze vegetable crops and dried up fuel oil supplies. In July, energy prices fell 0.5 percent, the sixth consecutive decline. Food costs were unchanged. And, prices excluding the volatile food and energy sectors _ considered a better indicator of underlying inflationary pressures _ fell 0.1 percent, the first drop in a year. The prospect of accelerating inflation at the same time the economy seems on the verge of recession presents a dilemma for the Federal Reserve. The central bank has been fighting inflation by cooling the economy with relatively high interest rates. But last month the Fed nudged short-term rates lower in response to signs that businesses were having trouble obtaining loans. Economist David Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a government securities dealer in New York, said monetary policy makers will look beyond the oil shock, which they cannot influence, and pay close attention to recent signs of accumulating economic weakness. Those include a leap in the civilian unemployment rate from 5.2 percent in June to 5.5 percent in July, the highest in two years. ``The handwriting is on the wall for the Fed. It's going to have to ease. The question is whether it's going to ease right away or whether it's going to wait until its Aug. 21 meeting,'' he said. The Labor Department offered these details of July prices: _Gasoline fell 5.3 percent while natural gas rose 6.6 percent and fuel oil was up 0.4 percent. _Fresh fruit prices jumped 14 percent, but egg prices declined 18.3 percent. Costs were up for rice, pasta, chicken, fish and soft drinks. Prices fell for vegetables, baked goods, beef, pork and shortening and cooking oil. _Clothing prices were mixed, with a 0.2 percent rise for girls', children's and infants' apparel, a 0.1 percent drop in men's and boys' clothing and no change in women's clothing. _Passenger car prices dropped 0.5 percent. Household glassware fell 5.1 percent, but silverware rose 4.1 percent. _Tobacco prices fell 2.9 percent, but they had been rising steadily before and were still 13.3 percent higher than a year ago. The various changes put the Producer Price Index for all finished goods at 118.0 in July. That means a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $100 in 1982 cost $118 last month, up from $114.10 a year earlier. In earlier stages of the production process, prices were unchanged for intermediate goods and rose 0.6 percent for crude goods. An example of the three processing stages would be clothing for finished goods, cloth for intermediate and cotton for crude.

DOC.HEAD: Turkish President Says Country on Guard, But Plays Down Iraqi Threat
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: President Turgut Ozal said Friday that Turkey is on guard against a possible Iraqi attack, but he played down the possibility his country will become a target. ``There is no full alert yet,'' Ozal said in an interview with The Associated Press. ``I think we have to be very careful. Our chief of staff is looking at the case very carefully. We are trying to listen and gather intelligence, and act accordingly. That is a necessity.'' Citing national security reasons, the government Friday ordered an end to strikes by civilian workers at U.S. bases in Turkey. Last week, about 4,000 Turkish workers walked off their jobs at 26 American installations to demand pay increases. The air force announced Thursday it was in a state of ``advanced readiness'' to ward off any attack. Ozal denied Iraq and Turkey were beefing up forces along their 185-mile border. The Iraqi Embassy in Ankara also denied Baghdad had reinforced troops at the frontier. ``According to the intelligence I have, there is no real military buildup, not on the Turkish side, nor the Iraqi side,'' the president said. ``Probably these are already existing forces in the area. But this may change as time goes on. I don't know.'' Speaking in his office in the presidential palace, Ozal said there was no legitimate motive for Iraq to attack Turkey. Some have suggested that Iraq might retaliate because Turkey effectively shut down two Iraqi oil pipelines and froze trade with Baghdad. Ozal stressed that the sanctions were adopted in compliance with an embargo ordered by the U.N. Security Council. ``The sanctions are a United Nations decision and there is a legal basis for it,'' he said. ``I think they (the Iraqis) should understand this.'' Sanctions adopted earlier this week allowed for sale of food and medicine to Iraq. On Friday, Turkey said it was banning all food exports except for a few items, such as milk for babies. Turkish sanctions have also blocked Iraq's only land route to Europe. If Iraq attacked Turkey, Iraq's forces would counter a formidable adversary. The Turkish armed forces, with 800,000 men, are the second-largest in NATO behind the United States. Foreign ministers of the NATO alliance pledged to stand by Turkey in the event of an attack. ``It is very clear that an attack on Turkey would be considered an attack on all (NATO) nations,'' NATO Secretary General Manfred Woerner said. As the only NATO nation bordering Iraq, Turkey has taken on a central role in the alliance's strategy since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Secretary of State James A. Baker III conferred here Thursday with Ozal and other Turkish leaders on the crisis. Ozal said Baker thanked Turkey for applying the U.N. sanctions, discussed Turkey's losses stemming from the embargo on oil and trade and asssured him NATO would come to Turkey's aid in case of attack. U.S. administration officials traveling with Baker said Turkey had pledged to allow the United States to use its air bases as staging areas for attacks against Iraq in the event of war. Ozal, however, said there had been no specific discussions on the matter and denied Turkey made any commitment on the use of the bases. But he did not rule out that Turkey might eventually do so. The Americans were using the bases for training in accordance with NATO and bilateral agreements, he said. Asked whether they could be used for larger-scale military operations, he said, ``No, it is not required right now.'' The president also said Turkey had no immediate plans to join the U.S.-led multinational force being deployed in Saudi Arabia. He said any such decision would have to be approved by Parliament. A senior government official, speaking on ground rules of anonymity, said: ``It is out of the question for Turkey to take part in any kind of military action at this point.'' But the official said Turkey might reconsider if Iraq attacked Saudi Arabia. Ozal said there would be no need to resort to military action against Iraq if the worldwide embargo is strictly enforced. ``I have a feeling the world this time will not falter,'' he said. However, he said, Saddam may not take the embargo seriously on grounds that Western nations would give in to profit motives and gradually relax the embargo. ``After all, who built those chemical weapons plants in Iraq?'' Ozal asked. ``The Europeans did.'' Asked whether the embargo might force Iraq to retaliate rather than withdraw from Kuwait, Ozal dismissed the possibility. ``I know Saddam Hussein,'' he said. ``He is decisive. But he's an intelligent man. He's a first-class intelligent man.''

DOC.HEAD: Vice President's Wife Makes First Public Appearance Since Surgery
DOC.TEXT: Marilyn Quayle on Friday made her first public appearance since her hysterectomy, joining a White House ceremony where President Bush signed legislation she promoted to help detect breast and cervical cancer. ``You're looking so well,'' Bush told Mrs. Quayle, who underwent the operation three weeks ago after doctors detected pre-cancerous cells during a routine checkup. Calling Mrs. Quayle a ``source of strength to us all,'' Bush thanked her and others for their work in helping to publicize ways of detecting and stopping breast and cervical cancers. Mrs. Quayle's mother, a pediatrician, died of breast cancer. ``Marilyn has brought a special eloquence,'' to the fight against cancer, Bush said, adding: ``She told all Americans the time has come to declare war on cancer.'' David Beckwith, Vice President Dan Quayle's spokesman, said Mrs. Quayle is ``feeling fine,'' but she doesn't plan to resume a normal schedule until after the family returns from a three-week vacation in Wickenburg, Ariz. The legislation that Bush signed as his wife, Barbara, and the Quayles looked on authorizes $50 million in fiscal 1991 to give grants to states. Under the legislation, states would use the grants to screen women for cancer, develop and disseminate information about the early detection and prevention of cancer and improve the education of health professionals in the area. To receive the funds, states could be required to match $1 for each $3 from the federal government. They would also have to provide free testing services to low-income women. Bush said 150,000 women develop the diseases each year and 50,000 women die from them. ``So many sad stories of loss could have happy endings if more women are aware of the lifesaving technologies that are now available,'' he said. One of barriers to cancer detection, Bush said, is fear. That must be overcome, he said.

DOC.HEAD: National Geographic Unites Two Germanys In New Atlas
DOC.TEXT: The National Geographic Society is anticipating history and unifying East and West Germany and decentralizing the Soviet Union in its new world atlas, Society officials said Friday. The sixth edition of the National Geographic Atlas of The World removes the red line that separated the two Germanys in past editions and refers only to the nation of ``Germany.'' ``We've had to look into our crystal ball and see that the unification of Germany is inevitable,'' said John B. Garver, National Geographic's chief cartographer. The atlas shows both Bonn and Berlin as capitals, but features only the West German flag. The page on Germany was printed at a Willard, Ohio, publishing house Thursday and Friday, with the new edition of 240,000 copies to be released in November. Unification is scheduled to take place in December, although the East German parliament has called for the first all-German elections and the merging of the two Germanys on Oct. 14. Spokeswoman Barbara Hand Fallon said National Geographic's first new atlas since 1981 drops the letters ``S.S.R.,'' or Soviet Socialist Republic, from ll Soviet states except Russia to reflect impulses within the Soviet Union for greater independence. The capitals of such states as Lithuania have been clearly marked in the event they later gain independence from Moscow, she said. Other political changes to be reflected in the new book are the recent unification of North and South Yemen and the de facto division of Cyprus. The Middle East map will be flagged with a note that ``On Aug. 2, 1990, Iraqi military forces invaded Kuwait.'' ``It's a precarious time to be putting out a world atlas,'' Miss Fallon said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Doctor Was Kidnapped By U.S. Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 13th graf, `The DEA ...' to CORRECT to former police chief, sted police chief.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge ruled today that the U.S. government illegally kidnapped a Mexican doctor to stand trial in the slaying of a U.S. drug agent. U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie said the abduction of Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain violated an extradition treaty between the United States and Mexico and was an offense against Mexico's sovereignty. The judge added: ``The court orders this defendant is to be discharged and the government is ordered to repatriate this defendant to Mexico forthwith.'' But he stayed execution of his order for one week after Assistant U.S. Attorney William Fahey asked for time to consider an appeal. Alvarez' lawyer, Robert Steinberg, said he felt the judge's ruling was a warning to the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration to stop kidnapping suspects from Mexico. He added that he believed the judge's ruling would be appealed and might go as high as the U.S. Supreme Court. ``My fear is they're going to take these appeals for years while he (Alvarez) rots in jail,'' he said. Although the government suggested a bail hearing for the doctor, Steinberg said the defendant has no property to post as collateral and probably would not win release because of fears that he would flee to Mexico. Alvarez, who was wearing a blue jail jumpsuit, displayed no emotion when he heard the ruling. Asked for his client's reaction, Steinberg said: ``He's numb.'' The doctor was spirited out of Mexico on charges he administered drugs to keep DEA agent Enrique Camarena alive while he was being tortured. Rafeedie stressed that he was not dismissing the charge against the doctor but merely ruling that the case could not be tried in the United States. The U.S. Justice Department said earlier it was pressing its investigation into the 1985 torture-murder in Mexico following the convictions of four men in the slaying. The probe includes two former high-ranking officials of the Mexican government who have been indicted in connection with the slaying. The DEA is pursuing its own investigation of the possible involvement of Mexico City's former police chief in Camarena's slaying, authorities said. ``The government of the United States will spare no effort or expense in its continuing investigation of the circumstances surrounding the kidnapping and murder of special agent Camarena,'' U.S. Attorney Lourdes G. Baird said. The second Camarena trial ended Monday with the conviction of the last of four defendants. Three people were convicted in 1988 on charges of involvement in the murder. More than two dozen people have been convicted in Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Grateful Dead Member Died Of Drug Overdose, Coroner Says
DOC.TEXT: Grateful Dead keyboardist Brent Mydland, who was found dead in his home last month, died from an overdose of drugs, a coroner said Friday. ``The autopsy examination revealed a recent puncture mark on the left arm consistent with a recent intravenous injection prior to death,'' said Capt. Al Moore of the Contra Costa coroner's office. ``Toxicology tests reveal lethal levels of morphine and cocaine in the blood.'' No drugs or narcotics paraphernalia were found and there was no indication of foul play, Moore said. Mydland had reportedly been troubled over family problems, but Moore said there was no evidence of suicide. Mydland, 37, was found dead July 26 in the bedroom of his secluded Lafayette home, in the hills above Berkeley. The band had returned to Northern California two days before from a three-week national tour. Grateful Dead publicist Dennis McNally said band members had no immediate comment on the coroner's report. ``Speaking as an individual,'' McNally added, ``I can only say no matter what the cause of death, Brent was a sweet guy and it's a tragedy his music is not around any more.'' Mydland joined the Grateful Dead in 1979 and was its newest member. In addition to playing keyboard instruments, he wrote songs such as ``Far From Me'' and the environmental ballad ``We Can Run (But We Can't Hide).'' Led by guitarist Jerry Garcia, the band was formed in the 1960s in San Francisco's Haight-Ashbury district. Although it releases albums sporadically, its concerts are almost always sold out, thanks to devoted fans known as ``Deadheads.'' Mydland replaced keyboardist Keith Godchaux, who later died in an auto accident about a year after leaving the band. Godchaux had replaced Ron ``Pigpen'' McKernan, who died of cirrhosis of the liver at age 27 in 1973. Mydland and his estranged wife, Lisa, had two daughters. Half of his more than $2 million estate went automatically to his wife under California law, and under Mydland's will the other half was placed in trust to care for his two daughters.

DOC.HEAD: New Member Sworn In For Transportation Safety Board
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS `investigations' to `investigates' in lead
DOC.TEXT: Lawyer Christopher A. Hart was sworn in Friday as a member of the National Transportation Safety Board, which investigates air, land and sea accidents. Hart, who was nominated by President Bush in June and then confirmed by the Senate, fills the seat left vacant when Joseph Nall died in an airplane crash in Venezuela last November. The five-member board manages a staff of investigators, conducts hearings and draws up reports on major accidents. It has no regulatory powers but makes recommendations to government agencies, Congress and transportation companies for safety improvements. Hart, a native of Denver, Colo., has been managing partner of Hart & Chavers of Washington. He earlier was deputy general counsel at the Transportation Department and has worked as an attorney for the Air Transport Association, which represents airlines. He is a pilot with certificates for flying commercial and single- or multi-engine aircraft. His term on the board expires Dec. 31, 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers March Through Townships to Restore Order After 42 Deaths
LaserPhoto CPN1
DOC.TEXT: Armed soldiers, riot police and ANC marshals marched through mixed-race townships of Port Elizabeth on Friday to restore order after 42 people died in four days of rioting and looting. ``It would appear the situation is under control, but we cannot say if it will flair up again or what is going to happen,'' said Maj. Bill Dennis, a police spokesman in the southeastern coastal city. He said sporadic incidents or arson, looting and stone-throwing continued Friday although it was ``much quieter.'' Police Lt. Gen. Mulder van Eyck said security forces were in control of much of the area, where violence erupted Monday night following a local meeting to protest rent increases and the educational system. Police said 42 people were killed in fighting which spread Thursday night to townships around the city of Uitenhage, 15 miles inland from Port Elizabeth. Some were killed by police gunfire, but there was no breakdown on how many, they said. Police said 220 people had been arrested for ``looting, plundering and burning'' since Monday. Telephone, trash collection, mail and all other public services were cut off in the riot-hit areas. Municipal employees had been targeted for attack and, along with most other residents, stayed home to protect their houses. The government had appealed to Port Elizabeth residents to stop the unrest. The African National Congress held a community meeting and urged people to stay off the streets. Van Eyck said residents told him the unrest was sparked by the ``high rental of homes, the lack of proper water supply, lack of facilities and the inadequate schools.'' The riots began Monday in a clash between members of a political group and police at a meeting to protest rent increases and education problems. Dennis said police had learned that criminals had joined the crowd and helped spark the violence by throwing stones. Police and political organizations said criminal gangs and mobs of looters then took advantage of the unrest and were responsible for much of the violence and arson. Police repeatedly opened fire with shotguns and pistols to disperse the mobs. Businessmen have also been reported firing at looters.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Announces Reorganization
EFs: Tops with 5 grafs, Red Cross announces changes; picks up 10th graf pvs, A preliminary...
DOC.TEXT: The American Red Cross today announced that it is nationalizing the operations of its 54 regions and appointing a new senior vice president who will oversee blood services. The changes, aimed at assuring the safety of the blood supply and meeting federal regulations, came after ``searing self-examination'' as well as scrutiny by the press and the Food and Drug Administration, said Red Cross Chairman George F. Moody. The organization has been the subject of an FDA investigation into the condition of its blood supply. Moody said each of the group's 54 blood regions will have a new ``principal officer,'' appointed and paid for by the national headquarters, who will report directly to the new senior vice president, Dr. Jeffrey McCullough of St. Paul. Previously, regional blood services directors had reported to their local chapters. In addition, Moody said the organization has tripled its regulatory affairs unit in Washington from five to 14 people and doubled from eight to 16 people the unit responsible for evaluating the blood services offered by local chapters and following up their reports of accidents or errors. A preliminary report on an FDA inspection of the Red Cross's national headquarters in Washington in May found that for years, various Red Cross regional offices had not reported accidents and errors made in gathering and distribution of blood. Even when regions did make such reports, the audit found, Washington headquarters did not always review or follow up those reports. The Red Cross supplies blood to more than half the hospitals in the country. One example the investigation cited concerned the Washington regional center. About 230 cases were reported to the Washington region in which people may have contracted the AIDS virus through blood transfusions, the report said, but headquarters was alerted to only four of those cases. FDA officials said Red Cross procedures were not responsible for the infections. Almost all of the transfusions, they said, took place before 1985, when reliable AIDS tests became available. FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit said the agency was unaware of the pending changes. But ``if they're putting in a system where they can get reports from their field office, that's all to the good,'' he said. Nesbit said the FDA ``has an ongoing discussion with the Red Cross'' and ``I suspect those discussions will continue.'' The agency's regions, which have been operating ``rather independently,'' will be centralized in the Washington headquarters, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Church Wants to Dig up Ex-Slave's Grave, Is Weighing Sainthood For Toussaint
DOC.TEXT: The Roman Catholic Church asked court permission to open a grave in an old church cemetery to make sure it holds the remains of Pierre Toussaint, a onetime slave from Haiti who could become the first black American saint. ``We want to be certain that what's down there is not sticks and stones and someone else's bones,'' said Monsignor Robert O'Connell, who is directing the campaign to canonize Toussaint. On Thursday, the archdiocese of New York sought the order from state Supreme Court. Judge Phyllis Gangel-Jacob scheduled a hearing for Aug. 28 and pronounced the matter ``utterly fascinating. ... This is much more interesting than Trump.'' Although the Health Department routinely issues permits to unearth buried coffins _ mostly so they can be moved from one cemetery to another _ anyone who wants to actually open a coffin must obtain a court order. Those present when the coffin is opened, including pathologists, church officials and gravediggers, ``must take an oath to testify truthfully to what they saw,'' O'Connell said. Church officials do not expect to find any supernatural evidence of Toussaint's sainthood, such as an unusually well-preserved corpse, he said. Toussaint apparently was buried 137 years ago in the cemetery of Old St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan's Little Italy. The grave bears several markers, but O'Connell said that ``if he is declared a saint, and there is a ceremony honoring him, we must be sure.'' He said there was another reason for positive identification: If Toussaint becomes a saint, the Vatican may distribute some of his bones or personal items to ``places where his faith was nourished,'' such as Haiti, or to prominent places of worship such as St. Patrick's Cathedral on Fifth Avenue. Toussaint was born a slave in Haiti in 1766, and moved to New York with his owner's family in 1787. He became one of the city's leading hairdressers, and was allowed to keep some of his income. When Toussaint's owner died, leaving his wife and child impoverished, Toussaint secretly supported them for about 20 years. The widow freed Toussaint shortly before her death in 1807. Toussaint gave lavishly to several charities, including an orphanage and the city's first school for black children, and entered quarantined sections of the city each August to help yellow fever victims. But he took no stand on slavery, and seems generally to have avoided controversy; according to a pamphlet released by the archdiocese: ``The famous phrase, `Only my hairdresser knows for sure,' could well have had its origin in Pierre's discretion.'' When Toussaint died in 1853, the New York Post said he was ``spoken of by all who know him as a man of the warmest and most active benevolence.'' O'Connell said the case for Toussaint's sainthood is buttressed by one reported miracle: the recovery of a young Haitian with cancer who refused medical care and relied solely on prayers to Toussaint. Even if Toussaint is deemed worthy of sainthood, canonization could be years away. Cardinal John O'Connor has said he hopes Toussaint might be near sainthood by the time Pope John Paul II visits Haiti in 1992, but O'Connell said he was told by Vatican officials that no timetable could be set.

DOC.HEAD: Former Reagan Administration Official Testifies Before Grand Jury
DOC.TEXT: A former Reagan administration aide who worked with John Poindexter and Oliver North testified for more than two hours Friday before a federal grand jury investigating the Iran-Contra affair. Ronald Sable, an ex-National Security Council staff member, declined to discuss his testimony as he left the U.S. Courthouse. Sable was a witness at Poindexter's criminal trial in March. A retired Air Force colonel, Sable is now vice president for legislative liaison at aircraft manufacturer McDonnell Douglas Corp. Sable was the NSC's legislative affairs director in 1986 when Congress renewed its inquiries into reports that North was secretly assisting the Nicaraguan Contras in defiance of a congressional ban on U.S. military aid to the rebels. At Poindexter's trial, Sable testified that the national security adviser decided to ``follow the line'' of Poindexter's predecessor, Robert McFarlane. McFarlane in 1985 denied that North was raising money or coordinating the Contra military effort. Poindexter sent responses to Congress endorsing McFarlane's denials, which McFarlane eventually admitted were false. Shortly after Poindexter's letters were sent, North denied in a face-to-face meeting with the House intelligence committee that he had armed the Contras. Sable testified that he did not know the denials were false. McFarlane pleaded guilty to misdemeanor charges that he misled Congress when he denied North's contra military aid in letters to three House committees. Poindexter was convicted of obstruction of Congress in connection with his denials that North was assisting the Congress. Poindexter also was convicted of four other felony counts. His lawyers have said the conviction will be appealed. Mary Belcher, a spokeswoman for the office of independent counsel Lawrence Walsh, said she would have no comment on Sable's grand jury appearance. Since the end of May, North has appeared six times before the grand jury and Poindexter has appeared once. On Wednesday, a former national security aide to then-Vice President Bush testified for nearly two hours before the grand jury. G. Philip Hughes has been nominated by Bush to be the U.S. ambassador to Barbados. He worked with both North and Donald Gregg, who was Bush's top national security counsel aide at the time of the Iran-Contra scandal. Gregg is now the Bush administration's ambassador to South Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Denounces Saddam, Sees New Support for U.S. From Western Allies
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 11th graf, House later ... to UPDATE with Canadian offer
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today he expects announcements soon from Germany, Canada and Belgium about joining military efforts to thwart Iraqi aggression in the oil-rich Persian Gulf region. At a news conference following a closed-door session at NATO headquarters, Baker denounced Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein for his invasion of Kuwait last week. But he sidestepped the question of whether the United States would like to see him overthrown by internal rebellion. He said that is an issue for the Iraqi people to decide, and added, ``I'm not going to suggest that this is something the United States is interested in, or pursuing.'' Baker also said the Bush administration is ``very disturbed'' about restrictions on travel placed on an estimated 3,500 Americans as well as other foreign nationals in Iraq and Kuwait. But Baker said ``we are not calling them hostages ... nothing has been asked or demanded for their freedom.'' He said discussions are under way to press for permission for them to leave. Baker was returning to Washington later in the day. The secretary of state expressed satisfaction with the results of his session with NATO foreign ministers over what he said was the ``first crisis of the post Cold-War period.'' He said he found solid support for President Bush's decision earlier this week to deploy ground, air and naval forces to deter Iraq from invading Saudi Arabia and seizing control of its enormous oil fields. He also said the Western allies were united in their determination to defend Turkey _ a NATO member _ from any military action by Iraq's Saddam Hussein. Baker said ``a number of members (of NATO) have indicated they do intend to send military support to the efforts that are under way in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf.'' He noted that Great Britain and France already have announced the deployment of forces, and said Germany, Belgium and Canada ``gave indications they will have announcements to make in due course.'' Hours later in Ottawa, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said his nation will send three ships and 800 sailors to the Persian Gulf as its contribution to the multinational force. He said Canada is dispatching two destroyers and a supply vessel. In Bonn, West Germany said today it is sending four or five mine sweepers and a supply ship to the Mediterranean in case Iraq tries to mine shipping lanes there, and left open the possibility they could sail to the Persian Gulf region. West German government spokesman Hans Klein said the deployment was a ``contribution of solidarity to the allies' efforts to stabilize the situation in the gulf.'' In Australia, Prime Minister Bob Hawke said today that Canada and Japan might join Australia, the United States and Britain in sending military forces to the gulf. In addition, Baker thanked Italy, Spain and Portugal for being ``very forthcoming'' in giving the United States the use of bases within their borders. Officials at the NATO meeting also said Denmark had offered to make naval ships available to fill gaps left within the alliance by units that have been assigned to help in the gulf. Baker made no mention of the possibility of whether non-NATO nations would be joining American ground forces in Saudi Arabia. An emergency meeting of Arab nations was under way in Egypt to discuss a regional response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. He noted the Soviet Union had sent a ship to the Persian Gulf region, and said he believed ``they would want to do any coordination only under'' United Nations auspices. Asked about Turkey, which shares a border with Iraq and recently shut down an Iraqi oil pipeline, Baker said ``there is some evidence of increased activity up there, up north.'' He also said there is evidence of Iraqi troops moving into Kuwait in greater numbers. Baker stopped in Brussels after a visit in Turkey at which he reassured the Turks of United States commitment to back up their own retaliation against Iraq. In casting the Persian Gulf confrontation as the first crisis of the post-Cold War era, he said NATO was demonstrating its ability at ``dealing with threats from new sources and new directions.'' In his prepared speech, he called on the 15 U.S. allies to ``examine how you might help'' enforce the boycott of Iraq approved by the United Nations Security Council. He said he found support for Bush's decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia and said each member nation will contribute in its own way to the effort. He also said there was support for the U.N. sanctions, reaffirmation that NATO will stand by its defense obligations to Turkey. Finally, he said, ``We sent another signal that NATO is the place to consult and meet together on common crises. ...'' Earlier, in his closed-door speech, Baker vowed to do what was necessary to devastate Iraq's economy. ``We should show that we will do whatever must be done in order to enforce the will of the United Nations,'' Baker said. His appeal to the NATO foreign ministers extended far beyond Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and seizure of its oil fields. ``It is not only economic progress that is threatened,'' he said. ``If might is to make right, then the world will be plunged into a new dark age.'' ``We have seen a continous and unrelenting buildup of arms,'' Baker said. ``The Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein has spared no expense to sustain a vast force, far out of proportion to any conceivable threat.'' Baker arrived in Brussels from Ankara, where Turkish leaders pledged that the United States could use their air bases to launch an attack on Iraq in the event of war. Baker called Saddam a dictator pursuing ominous nuclear and chemical weapons programs, and said he hoped Iraq was ready to ``close the book of war'' after its 12-year conflict with Iran. Surely that was in the country's interest, he said. ``Just as surely, that remains the true interest of the people of Iraq today,'' Baker said. The NATO foreign ministers were determined to stand by Turkey if Iraq threatens that NATO ally across their shared 185-mile border. Turkey, which stands to lose an estimated $3 billion a year in commerce with Iraq, received through Baker an offer of some compensation from the oil-rich Kuwaiti royal family that was overthrown in the Iraqi invasion. Baker also promised the United States would back Turkey in its request for development loans from the World Bank and would provide credits for Turkey to import industrial machinery. There was no immediate sign at the NATO headquarters Thursday that the alliance sees an imminent threat against Turkey.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush Says He'll Squeeze Iraq Even More
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines urgent series
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he's determined to see economic sanctions ``tightened up even more'' against Saddam Hussein to drive Iraq out of Kuwait. Sources said the U.S. deployment in Saudi Arabia could involve up to 250,000 troops in the event of war. ``I would advise Iraqi ships not to go out with oil,'' the president warned. He spoke with reporters aboard Air Force One en route to his Maine vacation home. The president's comments came a few hours after Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with NATO counterparts to press for common action against Iraq, saying the world could be plunged into a ``new dark age'' if Saddam's aggression went unchecked. Asked whether he was calling for a naval blockade to enforce a United Nations trade embargo against Iraq, Bush replied, ``I'm not prepared to use the word blockade, but we are prepared.'' The president said Saddam's call for an Arab holy war against the West was the ``frantic ploy'' of a man who is isolated in world opinion. ``It won't work,'' he said. Even as he said that economic sanctions ``can be tightened up,'' Bush added: ``The troubling thing is, we're up against a man known for his brutality and irrationality.'' Even as the Iraqis reinforced their troop numbers in Kuwait, Bush said, ``There's no evidence right now that Saddam Hussein would be foolish enough to cross that border'' into Saudi Arabia. As did Baker, Bush expressed concern about the fate of Americans and other foreigners who are not being permitted to leave Iraq or Kuwait. And like Baker, he shied away from calling them hostages. ``I'm not going to invite further harassment by elevating the value of any citizens. We're not helpless, no. But as we've seen with hostage situations, and I don't think this is one, sometimes it is very difficult,'' said the president. Saddam said in a speech today that Arabs everywhere should attack Western forces in the Persian Gulf region and overthrow the Saudi royal family. Said Bush of those incendiary remarks: ``It's not unexpected. He is so isolated in the world, so much backed into a corner by world opinion...'' Bush applauded a meeting of Arab leaders in Egypt, and said, ``Maybe, just maybe, and I'm not optimistic, somebody can talk some sense'' into Saddam. Bush said he would monitor the crisis _ and the continuing buildup of American forces _ from his vacation home on the Maine coast: ``I'll be in very close touch,'' he said. Baker is flying there on Saturday to brief the president on his trip to Europe this week. In his news conference in Brussels, Baker said: ``Given the significance of gulf oil to the world economy, we all have an interest in thwarting Iraq's menacing and unlimited ambitions.'' He said the United States was ``very disturbed'' that foreign citizens, including 3,500 Americans, were not being allowed to leave Iraq and Kuwait. But he said: ``Nothing has been asked or demanded for their freedom, so we are not calling them hostages.'' In a dramatic statement, Baker escalated the already high stakes of the Middle East standoff, saying its outcome would have worldwide ramifications and test NATO's clout in a time of improved Western relations with the Soviet Union. He added: ``If might is to make right, then the world will be plunged into a new dark age.'' ``This is the first crisis of the post cold-war era,'' Baker said. Germany, Belgium and Canada have indicated they soon will send forces to confront Iraq, Baker said. Fresh deployments would be a major boost to the Bush administration's efforts for a multinational deterrent force. Still, no major Arab powers have committed to the Saudi defense effort. Baker said NATO had no military role in the Middle East unless Iraq was to go into Turkey. Baker's diplomatic efforts came as naval forces were growing in the waters of the Middle East and White House officials suggesting that an international naval blockade against Iraqi commerce was possible. ``Plans are being made for a blockade,'' Fitzwater said, so that one could be imposed swiftly if ordered by President Bush. Bush, under terms of the War Powers Act, today officially informed Congress of the Saudi military deployment and played down the possibility of war. ``I do not believe involvement in hostilities is imminent,'' Bush said in a letter to Congress. ``To the contrary, it is my belief that this deployment will facilitate a peaceful resolution of the crisis.'' Bush said ``our armed forces will remain so long as their presence is required.'' He said the forces are equipped for combat and have a defensive mission. Iraq, Bush said, has ``an enormous and sophisticated war machine'' near Kuwait's border with Saudi Arabia. In a separate letter detailing the U.S. sanctions against Iraq, Bush told Congress that Iraq has ``has tightened its unlawful grip over the territory of Kuwait and has installed a puppet regime that in no way represents the people or legitimate government of Kuwait.'' Several thousand American combat troops already are on Saudi soil, supported by a powerful contingent of air and naval forces. Their mission is to defend the Saudi kingdom amid hopes that worldwide economic pressure will force Saddam to withdraw from neighboring Kuwait. U.S. officials have refused to publicly reveal the scale of the troop deployment, code-named ``Desert Shield'' and aimed at forestalling an Iraqi invasion of the Saudi kingdom, the world's largest oil exporter. But several Pentagon and administration sources, who declined to be identified by name, revealed planning that could involve the largest deployment of U.S. ground troops since Vietnam. ``We have contingency plans that could result in the insertion of up to 200,000 to 250,000 ground forces before it's all done,'' said one source, who added that the troop transfer also could be capped at any point. Such a deployment would take up to 60 days to complete, the sources said. A Pentagon official said troops could come from units in Colorado, Kansas, Texas, Georgia, Kentucky and North Carolina. ``Hussein's response will determine exactly how much combat power we put on the ground,'' one source said. But if deterrence fails and U.S. forces must do battle, ``it will be a high-intensity war with many casualties, many chemical casualties, much equipment destroyed,'' the official said. ``It will mean warfare on a scale that we haven't seen since World War II.'' Baker arrived from Turkey, where he won a promise that American forces could use Turkish military bases in the event of fighting with Iraq. The U.S. troop commitment in Vietnam reached 550,000 at its peak, plus additional personnel in other Southeast Asian countries. The new total, if deployed in Saudi Arabia, would be a significant share of the approximately 940,000 active-duty members of the Army and Marine Corps. At least 2,300 American ground troops from the 82nd Airborne Division have landed in Saudi Arabia as the first wave of the deployment. Additional F-15 fighters and A-10 ``tank killer'' jets were ordered to the region. Two Navy hospital ships _ the Mercy and the Comfort _ were being readied for deployment to the Mideast. Two U.S. aircraft carriers flanked the Saudi coasts. More than 20 other warships _ including a third carrier and the battleship Wisconsin _ will be in the Mediterranean Sea or nearby waters by next week. Earlier Thursday, the Pentagon reported that 50,000 Iraqi soldiers were moving south inside Iraq, and that if they entered Kuwait the total invasion force would number about 170,000. A day earlier, the intelligence estimates had put the Iraqi force at 100,000 men.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Gives Bush Political Ammunition in Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: Even if the American-Iraqi standoff in the Arabian desert doesn't come to a shooting war, the crisis almost surely will give President Bush new ammunition to slow Congress' assault on the defense budget. ``Saddam Hussein, for all the bad things he did, may have done us a favor,'' Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., said Friday of Republican efforts to scale back the 1991 defense spending cuts of $24 billion approved by the House on July 31. ``He sort of woke us up in America and woke us up in Congress,'' Dole said. Others argue that while the Persian Gulf crisis highlights the need for a strong American military, it also shows the need for a different sort of defense than the one built on fear of all-out global combat with the Soviet Union. ``This stresses the need in our future defense posture for mobility, for flexible forces, for ready forces, just what we're having to call on right now'' in Saudi Arabia, said Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, a member of the Armed Services Committee. Glenn, speaking to reporters on Wednesday, acknowledged that the gulf crisis may help Bush limit defense cuts. Bush proposed $307 billion in defense spending for the budget year starting Oct. 1, but last month said he would accept an additional $18 billion in cuts as proposed by the Senate. The two houses will begin negotiating a compromise defense bill when they return from recess in September. The drive to cut defenses has been fueled by a perception that, with democracy sweeping Eastern Europe and the Cold War ending, the world is a safer place. The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and Bush's decision to dispatch U.S. warplanes, ships and troops to Saudi Arabia, America's biggest supplier of imported oil, has cast the defense budget debate in a different light, analysts say. ``It probably will mean the defense cuts will be a little bit less than they otherwise would be,'' said Alexis Cain of the private Defense Budget Project. By triggering a substantial rise in oil prices, which in turn makes a U.S. economic recession more likely, the Middle East crisis also may weaken Congress' resolve to reduce the budget deficit, Cain said. Government spending helps fuel the economy. Thus, pressure to cut the defense budget might ease. Bush himself has cited the Iraqi invasion in arguing against major defense cuts. ``Notwithstanding the alteration in the Soviet threat, the world remains a dangerous place with serious threats to important U.S. interests wholly unrelated to the earlier patterns of the U.S.-Soviet relationship,'' Bush said Aug. 2, one day after 100,000 Iraqi troops swept into tiny Kuwait and overthrew the government. Bush on Friday exempted military personnel from the 1991 spending cuts other agencies are preparing for in the absence of a budget-reduction agreement with Congress. His spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said ``clearly the situation'' in the Persian Gulf played a role in the president's decision. The Iraqi threat to Saudi Arabia serves as a convenient political tool for members of Congress, too, particularly those trying to protect defense installations and weapons programs that provide jobs in their states or districts. Rep. Frank Pallone, D-N.J., cited the Iraqi crisis in criticizing the Army on Thursday for dismissing 300 civilian employees at Fort Monmouth in New Jersey. ``They are cutting at the heart of our national defense in a time of crisis while the fat survives,'' Pallone said. While a surge of patriotic fervor from the U.S. standoff against Iraq may lead to smaller-than-planned cuts in military personnel in 1991, it is unlikely to change the debate on cutting weapons programs. One of the biggest defense battles in Congress this year centers on the B-2 stealth bomber, which is expected to cost $865 million a plane. Several members of the Senate referred to the Iraqi crisis during floor debate on the B-2 on Aug. 2. The Senate rejected efforts to kill or slow production of the bomber, but advocates of ending the program said Iraq should have played no role. ``There are all kinds of weapons that we can deploy against the Iraqis if we decide to,'' said Rep. Jim Slattery, D-Kan. ``Any suggestion that we should do the B-2 because of what's going on in Iraq and the Middle East right now is just an emotional, knee-jerk reaction that lacks any basis in logic and reason.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Exempts Military Personnel From Spending Cuts
With AM-Rethinking Defense, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has exempted military personnel from the spending cuts other agencies would face in the absence of a budget-reduction agreement with Congress, his spokesman said Friday. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said: ``Clearly the situation'' in the Persian Gulf played a role in persuading the Bush administration to avoid cuts in military personnel at a time the United States is deploying forces in the Middle East. Bush, who wrote a formal letter authorizing the exemption, discussed the issue with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney at a meeting Friday, Fitzwater said. If the exclusion were not in effect, layoffs could affect U.S. armed forces, the White House Office of Management and Budget said. As a result of the exclusion, other parts of the defense budget may have to absorb larger cuts. Because Bush and Congress have failed to agree on a budget deficit reduction package, the administration has ordered federal agencies to draw up plans to cut their spending by 31.9 percent. Under a worst-case scenario, most departments would have to participate in $104 billion in spending cuts during the budget year that begins Oct. 1. Those cuts, known in Washington jargon as ``sequestration,'' would take effect Oct. 15 unless Congress and Bush agree on a package of tax increases and targeted spending reductions. Negotiations on a package have been suspended until early next month. However, there is a general expectation that the government will never permit such deep spending reductions to take effect, especially with the economy apparently falling into a recession. Even before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last week, negotiators had been planning on a deficit-reduction plan of no more than about $50 billion for 1991. Richard G. Darman, director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, said in a letter to department heads that Bush would issue the initial spending-cut order on Aug. 25. Darman's letter was made public today.

DOC.HEAD: Embattled Former Archbishop Hospitalized in Psychiatric Unit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Donal is cq in penultimate graf.
DOC.TEXT: Former Atlanta Archbishop Eugene Marino, who resigned because of an ``intimate'' relationship with a woman, has been admitted to a hospital psychiatric unit, an archdiocese spokesman said Friday. The Rev. Peter Dora confirmed that Marino, formerly the nation's highest-ranking black Roman Catholic, was hospitalized late Thursday. But he said he had no other information. ``This morning I got word that sometime late last night he was admitted to a hospital, to the psychiatric unit of that hospital,'' Dora said. ``It's very sketchy.'' Dora would not reveal the location of the hospital. Marino, 56, has been in seclusion since church officials confirmed last week that an ``intimate'' relationship with Vicki Long, a 27-year-old former lay minister, led to his June resignation. Marino had been in poor health prior to his resignation and was last known to be recuperating in New York. Last spring, church officials said he suffered from stress and a near heart attack. Ms. Long's ``intimate'' ties with a priest, the Rev. Michael Woods of Sandy Springs, also led to his resignation last week. She also has filed a paternity suit against a second priest, the Rev. Donal Keohane, claiming he fathered her daughter. Blood tests showed Keohane was not the father, but the church is paying child support. Ms. Long's attorney has said she was a victim of sexual abuse who turned to Marino for help and instead was manipulated into a sexual relationship. Ms. Long contends she and Marino were secretly married and claims her relationship with Woods, her daughter's godfather, was not sexual. The church has described Marino's relationship with the woman only as ``intimate.''

DOC.HEAD: Actors' Union to Reconsider Ban on English Star
DOC.TEXT: The council of Actors' Equity will reconsider its decision barring a white English actor from portraying a Eurasian in the Broadway production of the hit London musical ``Miss Saigon.'' Equity said it decided to reconsider actor Jonathan Pryce, who won raves in the London show, after receiving petitions signed by more than 100 of its members, Dick Moore, a spokesman for the union, said Friday. The council will meet Thursday. The ban prompted producer Cameron Mackintosh to cancel the Broadway run of ``Miss Saigon,'' despite a record $25 million advance. Petitions went up backstage Wednesday at a half dozen Broadway shows _ including ``The Phantom of the Opera,'' ``Les Miserables'' and ``Cats'' _ urging Equity to reverse the ban. The council voted Tuesday to bar Pryce from appearing on Broadway in the role of the Engineer, an amoral brothel owner. The show is set during the last days of the Vietnam War. Equity said it could not ``condone the casting of a Caucasian in the role of an Eurasian.'' Mackintosh took a hard line in canceling the show Wednesday, saying ``the debate is no longer about the casting of `Miss Saigon' but the art of acting itself.'' Newspaper ads appeared Thursday listing a post office box where ticketholders could write for refunds. Some 40 members of the 79-member council took part in vote, said Alan Eisenberg, its executive secretary. The vote was reportedly close. Mackintosh said he would not take the case to arbitration. However, in an interview Thursday with The New York Times, the producer said, ``if there was a complete about-face by Equity, under the pressure of their own membership, which changed the atmosphere, I would be happy to discuss the situation with anybody.'' Talk show host Dick Cavett, a union member, lambasted the council's ``bonehead decision'' in an editorial published in Friday's Times. ``Since when are the arts a democracy? Perhaps the only justifiable aristocracy on earth is that of the talented,'' Cavett wrote. ``Were Laurence Olivier alive and able to do `Othello' on Broadway, would Equity bar it on the grounds that black actors here are unemployed?'' Besides, in barring Pryce to protect one role, the council eliminated 34 other roles in ``Miss Saigon'' that would have been filled by Asians, he said. The union has jurisdiction over all performers appearing on Broadway and must approve actors from foreign countries. Approval is routinely given to foreign actors of ``star'' quality. Equity certified Pryce as a ``star'' in 1984 when it endorsed his appearance in ``Accidential Death of an Anarchist.'' The union said it rejected him this time solely because of his race. ``We are talking here about color and this union responding to the wishes of its membership,'' said Colleen Dewhurst, the president of Actors' Equity.

DOC.HEAD: Encouragement From a Computer May Help Obsessive Compulsive Disorder
DOC.TEXT: A pocket-size computer helped a woman sharply reduce her obsessive habit of checking locks, electrical appliances and other objects, showing promise as a treatment for obsessive compulsive disorder, a researcher said Friday. The woman, who had undergone traditional therapies for three years, showed improvement when she started using a laptop computer and again with a device about the size of a credit card. When she had the urge to check something, she logged on to the computer, which offered encouragement. The technology extends behavioral therapy into the home and elsewhere, because when patients feel the urge to perform a ritual, ``they need some help right there,'' said Lee Baer of Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. The computer approach has not been formally evaluated, but a handful of cases gives hope that it may be a useful addition to standard treatment, Baer said. As many as 5 million Americans may have obsessive compulsive disorder. It is a type of anxiety characterized by obsessions, which are persistent unwanted thoughts or impulses, and compulsions, which are repetitive behaviors in response to the obsessions. Patients recognize their behavior is irrational, but cannot control it. Compulsive hand washing and che the home, citing embarrassment, and her checking rituals there returned to previous levels.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Calls For Holy War; Arabs Vote To Send Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Arab League vote, Bush comment, CORRECTS that not all Arab league members must approve troop measure. Pick up 7th graf pvs, `As the...'; EDITS thereafter to TRIM
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY6,7,8,9
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, in an outburst of fury against Western efforts to devastate his economy and hem in his army, today called on Arabs everywhere to wage ``holy war'' against enemies of Islam. Hours after Saddam's bellicose statement, a majority of the Arab League nations agreed to dispatch an Arab force to defend Saudi Arabia and approved economic sanctions against Iraq. President Bush said Saddam's call for an Arab holy war was the ``frantic ploy'' of a man who is isolated in world opinion. ``It won't work,'' he said. Saddam had promised not to attack Saudi Arabia, but today he called for the overthrow of the Saudi royal family, and urged attacks on the Western powers who moved to defend Saudi Arabia in the wake of Saddam's invasion of Kuwait. ``Burn the soil under the feet of the aggressors and invaders!'' he said in a statement read by an announcer on Iraqi radio and television. ``The evil enemies will be defeated!'' Iraq's representatives at the Arab summit denounced the measure calling for the dispatch of Arab troops to Saudi Arabia, conference sources said. In arguments over the measure, the Iraqi and Kuwaiti delegations engaged in a shouting match and the Kuwaiti foreign minister collapsed, the sources said. Of 20 Arab League member states present, 12 supported the seven-point resolution. Three _ including Iraq _ voted against, two abstained, and three governments expressed reservations and took no position. One member, Tunis, was absent. As the Arab leaders debated, Saddam urged Moslems everywhere to ``rescue'' the shrines of Islam in Saudi Arabia, including the holy city of Mecca. ``Your brothers in Iraq are determined on holy war,'' Saddam said in the statement read on Iraqi TV. ``O Arabs, O Moslems, O believers in God wherever you are! This is your day to rise...'' Earlier today, Secretary of State James A. Baker III warned NATO allies that the world would be plunged into ``a new dark age'' if aggression like Iraq's goes unpunished. Also today, President Bush told Congress he hoped the presence of U.S. military might in the Persian Gulf would deter another strike by Saddam, who set off the crisis with his takeover of Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``I do not believe involvement in hostilities is imminent,'' said Bush, who gave lawmakers formal notice of the troop deployment under the War Powers Act. Pentagon and administration sources said up to 250,000 U.S. ground troops could eventually be sent to defend Iraq's strategic neighbor Saudi Arabia, in what would be the biggest U.S. military operation since the Vietnam War. Washington also hinted at a possible naval blockade to choke off Iraq's oil exports. Baghdad radio told the people of Kuwait today the Iraqi takeover had restored their ``genuine Arab face and real freedom.'' In Iraq, which imports $2 billion worth of food a year, people fearing shortages as a result of the international economic embargo rushed to stock up on rice, sugar, cooking oil and other foodstuffs. More than 3,500 Americans remained trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, despite pressure from the United States to let them go. The State Department said the United States and several Western allies have made joint appeals to the Iraqi government to let citizens of their respective countries depart. Baker told reporters in Brussels today the United States was ``very disturbed about the status of the stranded Americans. But, he said, ``We are not calling them hostages...nothing has been asked or demanded for their freedom.'' Iraq on Thursday reportedly sent forces to the northern border with Turkey and southward toward Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. World markets continued to register the tremors from Baghdad. Stock prices were lower today in Japan and London, the dollar edged higher and oil prices were fairly steady as traders awaited new developments in the crisis. Baker told NATO ministers the situation in the Persian Gulf was ``full of peril,'' and called on the 15 U.S. allies in the Western alliance ``to examine how you might help'' enforce the boycott of Iraq approved by the U.N. Security Council. ``It is not only economic progress that is threatened,'' he told them. ``If might is to make right, then the world will be plunged into a new dark age.'' At the Arab summit in Cairo, Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak said time was running out for the Arab world to act to resolve the crisis. As Kuwait's deposed emir looked on, Mubarak told Arab leaders they must either persuade Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face ``a foreign intervention in which we will have no say or control.'' ``It is an unbalanced and explosive situation, which gets worse every day and holds within its folds huge dangers for us all. The Arab umbrella to get us out of this crisis represents a reasonable choice,'' said Mubarak, who has emerged as the prime mover in Arab diplomatic efforts surrounding the invasion. But even before Mubarak spoke, Saddam's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, insisted to reporters that Kuwait is, and will remain, ``part and parcel of Iraq.'' Iraq annexed the emirate Wednesday, a move that was condemned by the U.N. Security Council on Thursday. Saddam himself did not attend the Cairo summit, although the other Arab nations were represented by kings and presidents. The summit was to have begun Thursday but was delayed by a day, reportedly over a dispute over who would represent Kuwait _ its Iraqi-installed government or the fallen monarch, Emir Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah. In Saudi Arabia, more U.S. fighter planes arrived to bolster the buildup of U.S. combat troops. Britain, France and Australia on Thursday announced they were sending ships and planes to the gulf in response to U.S. appeals for an international force to defend Saudi Arabia _ the world's largest oil exporter. A Pentagon source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the United States was prepared to put ``many divisions'' in Saudi Arabia. ``We have contingency plans that could result in the insertion of up to 200,000 to 250,000 ground forces before it's all done,'' said the source, who spoke on condition that further identification be withheld. The U.S. troop commitment in Vietnam reached 550,000 at its peak, plus additional personnel in other Southeast Asian countries. The Pentagon reported that 50,000 Iraqi combat units were moving south inside Iraq, and that if they entered Kuwait, the total invasion force would number about 170,000. Only a day earlier, the intelligence estimates had put the Iraqi force at 100,000 men. Besides the U.S. ground forces, powerful Navy units were converging on the tense Persian Gulf area. Fifteen vessels, the biggest of them the aircraft carrier USS Independence, were in the gulf or near its entrance. About 20 more will be in Mideast waters by next week, including the battleship Wisconsin, bristling with cruise missiles programmed for targets in Iraq. Even with so much firepower, it would be extremely difficult for the forces in Saudi Arabia to rid Kuwait of its Iraqi invaders, who are part of Saddam's million-man army. Iraq invaded after Saddam complained that Kuwaiti overproduction of petroleum had driven down world oil prices and Iraq's oil revenues. He also rejected Kuwait's demands that Iraq repay an estimated $15 billion in loans. And he reasserted longstanding claims on Kuwaiti territory.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Damaged Slightly in Storm
DOC.TEXT: Some of the heat-resistant tiles on the space shuttle Atlantis were damaged during a thunderstorm that trapped the shuttle outside a hangar for several hours, NASA said Friday. Atlantis was about to be moved inside when the storm struck Thursday afternoon, preventing workers from moving the shuttle until three to four hours later. Earlier in the day, Atlantis had been moved off the launch pad for repair of a hydrogen leak, and a newly fixed Columbia was rolled out of the hangar to take its place. Workers counted about 90 cracks or chips in Atlantis' tiles, apparently caused by hail, said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. NASA workers will fill in the small dings with a silicon compound. Each orbiter has 25,000 to 30,000 tiles, which protect the vehicle from the heat of re-entry into the atmosphere. Each tile costs about $2,000. A lightning bolt hit the launch pad during the storm, but a lightning rod controlled the strike and Columbia was not damaged. NASA plans to launch Columbia next month carrying the Astro observatory. It has spent two months inside the hangar undergoing repairs for a leak in its hydrogen fuel system. Atlantis' next flight, a classified military mission, is now set for November.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine: Captured Documents Show Noriega Plan to Blow Canal
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Noriega drew up plans during the 1970s to sabotage the Panama Canal and attack U.S. military headquarters to guarantee compliance with the treaty giving the waterway to Panama, according to confiscated documents. Notes by Noriega on the plan, portions of which are printed in the September issue of New York-based Details magazine, were found during last year's U.S. invasion. The files are currently in a warehouse guarded by the U.S. Army in Corozal, Panama. The documents indicate Noriega was behind a series of small explosions in the old U.S.-controlled Canal Zone during 1976, when Panama was trying to hasten negotiations with the United States over the canal. During the 1970s, Noriega was a rising officer in the Panamanian military intelligence service. Panama's then-leader, Gen. Omar Torrijos, died in 1983 in a plane crash and Noriega eventually took control of the military and de facto control of the country. He was ousted in December after U.S. troops invaded. ``In this operation of placing the bombs, I personally received orders from my Lt. Col. Noriega,'' said a report by an unidentified officer. ``My colonel told me he wanted 14 bombs placed, as a symbol for the 14 (U.S. military) bases.'' One of the bombs failed to explode and Noriega was asked by the United States if he knew anything about the device, but denied it, the story said. The Details article was written by Doug Vaughan, a free-lance reporter who was hired as an investigator by Michael O'Kane, a defense attorney for Noriega co-defendant Daniel Miranda. Miranda is out on bond on charges of helping to fly drug money from Fort Lauderdale to Panama. Attorneys for Noriega, who is being held here on drug-trafficking charges since his surrender Jan. 4, dismissed the reports. ``I would be very, very surprised if there were any such document with Gen. Noriega's signature,'' Jon May said Friday. ``I don't believe it. But of course, it has nothing to with our case.'' The canal treaty was signed in 1978, but only after Torrijos asked Noriega to draw up plans to sabotage the canal and attack the U.S. Southern Command headquarters at Quarry Heights. A note in Noriega's handwriting referred to a plan called ``Huele A Quemado,'' _ ``Smells Burnt'' in English _ which called for a series of commando teams to attack and sabotage the targets. When U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler, who is presiding over the case, was informed last Wednesday that O'Kane had hired a reporter, he chastised the attorney in court and ordered him to get approval of his investigators in the future. Prosecutors said O'Kane violated professional ethics by allowing the documents under military guard to be distributed publicly. In its article, the magazine said that the plan was continually updated, including after Noriega became head of Panama's military in 1983. One team was to attack the lock gates, another the locomotives that pull ships through the canal, his memo showed. A document marked ``SECRETO'' said ``Mission: Make inoperable the Panama Canal and areas of defense of same,'' it said. Six commandos disguised as civilians were to attack the underground command center at Quarry Heights, killing a sentinel, then igniting a five-gallon gasoline tank. Others were to hit the canal itself. ``We'll wait until Zero Hour to open fire against some ship passing throught the locks; if no ship passes, we will fire on the control tower,'' according to the documents.
