DOC.HEAD: 42 Opposition Activists Released From Jail
DOC.TEXT: The government on Friday announced it would free 42 anti-government activists arrested during the violence in Bucharest in mid-June, when police suppressed a 53-day opposition demonstration. The prosecutor-general's office said the reason for the ``preventative measures'' no longer exist. It did not say when the detainees would go free. The decision follows the release of student leader Marian Munteanu last week after widespread student protests on his behalf. Among those already released under the announcement was Nica Leon, leader of the Free Democrat Party and one of the rally's organizers. Leon, freed Wednesday, said his seven-week detention was a ``purely political'' punishment resulting from his criticism of President Ion Iliescu and his ruling National Salvation Front. The detentions drew criticism at home and abroad. Western countries curtailed aid to Romania after thousands of miners summoned by Iliescu terrorized the capital, beating and detaining presumed opponents at will. Leon, 25, also said he would now try to unite all the opposition parties to counter Iliescu. Iliescu, a former senior Communist party official, took over in the December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Leon described his detention as ``miserable and inhuman.'' He said he was denied access to newspapers ``other than those which speak for the government, and even out of these some articles were cut out.'' Although Leon's party controls only two seats in Parliament, he has been one of the government's most strident critics. He was a leader of the 53-day anti-government rally broken up by police June 13. Later that day, demonstrators attacked police headquarters with firebombs, prompting Iliescu to summon the miners. Six people were killed in violence June 13-15, according to authorities. Leon said he was beaten June 14 in front of his downtown party headquarters by the miners. He was arrested that day on charges of inciting violence. He said the military prosecution that took over his case Saturday freed him after witnesses testified they had ``never seen me before and were forced to testify against me'' by civilian prosecutors. Prosecutors announced in June that 89 opposition activists arrested then would be tried. Since then, however, Munteanu, Leon and several others were released without further word of legal action. Leon said he plans to work toward uniting the major opposition parties, the National Liberal and National Peasant, into ``an efficient opposition force.'' The opposition parties control about a third of the two-chamber parliament elected May 20 and dominated by Iliescu's party. The opposition protesters had demanded that former Communists such as Iliescu be banned from politics for 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: Sri Lanka Says It Will Move 1 Million Civilians From Harm's Way
DOC.TEXT: The government said Friday it intends to shift 1 million civilians from the northern Jaffna peninsula before launching a major assault on ethnic Tamil rebels there. ``We plan to get all innocent Tamil civilains out of the Jaffna peninsula and then throw the Tamil terrorists into the ... Palk Straits,'' Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne told parliament. This nation's civil war flared up again in June, when Tamil rebels repudiated a 13-month cease-fire. Since then, at least 3,200 combatants and hundreds of civilians have been killed. At least 315 people have been killed in the past week. More than 1 million people, mostly Tamils, live on Jaffna peninsula, a stronghold of the Timil Tiger rebels. ``To prevent (loss of) civilian lives, we will move them further south into large camps and then clear the north,'' said the deputy minister. However, he gave no details of the plan and did not say when it would go into effect. The parliament was meeting in special session to discuss the upsurge in the war. In violence during the day, armed Moslems avenging Tamil attacks killed three Tamil civilians in the northern village of Vavuniya, military officials said on condition of anonymity. At least six Tamil houses were burned, they said. Moslems claim neutrality in the fighting, but the separatists accuse them of siding with the army. On Thursday, five rebels and a government soldier were killed, the military officials said. The separatist Tamils began battling the Sinhalese-dominated government seven years ago. About 14,000 people have been killed in the conflict on this island at the southern tip of India. Tamils, who make up 18 percent of the country's 16 million people, claim they are discriminated against by the Sinhalese, who comprise 75 percent of the population. Moslems make up 7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Baker Voice Concern Over Civilians in Kuwait, Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with comments by Bush, new comments by Boucher, editing changes thruout
DOC.TEXT: President Bush pointed Friday to ``very disturbing reports'' of Mideast violence against Westerners, as Secretary of State James A. Baker III accused Iraq of violating ``all international norms'' by refusing to allow 3,500 Americans to leave Iraq and Kuwait. Meanwhile, the State Department warned all overseas diplomatic posts that the Middle East tensions could produce terrorist incidents against American interests abroad. It urged all posts to take appropriate security precautions. The statement blamed the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait for the increased risk to Americans, but Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein said in a fiery speech that the United States was to blame for the region's troubles. As Baker spoke in Brussels and Bush talked with reporters on the flight to his Maine vacation home, there was concern that Americans stranded in Iraq and Kuwait could increasingly become part of Saddam's political calculations as he seeks a way out of his growing international isolation. In addition, there have been reports of rapes and other assaults against foreigners in Kuwait by Iraqi occupation forces. Iraqi officials have told the United States that only diplomats will be allowed to depart, leaving the 3,000 Americans in Kuwait and 580 in Iraq with an uncertain fate. Iraq has said all borders and airports are closed but State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher noted that large numbers of non-Westerners, mostly Arabs, living in Iraq have been allowed to leave. ``The practice and the policy are different,'' Boucher said. Baker, speaking to reporters at the end of a brief trip to Europe, said he was ``very disturbed'' about the restrictions on Americans and other Westerners in Iraq and Kuwait. He said the term hostages is not being used to describe the Americans in the two countries. One reason, he said, is that discussions are going on with Iraqi authorities for their release. In the administration's view, that distinction is important because the U.S. government does not negotiate with hostage-takers. Bush, too, made a point of not calling the Americans in the two countries hostages, saying, ``I'm not going to invite further harassment by elevating the value of any citizen.'' Asked if the United States were helpless in the situation, he replied, ``We're not helpless, no. But, as we've seen with hostage situations, and I don't think this is one, sometimes it's very difficult.'' Another official said that if the government calls the Americans hostages, that would make it more difficult for Saddam to release them unconditionally. Normally, a hostage is a person who is kept prisoner until certain conditions are met. So far as is known, Iraq has imposed no conditions for the release of the Americans. Baker said they are not being mistreated to the best of his knowledge. But Saddam, who was moving troops south to add to his invasion forces, was far from conciliatory on Friday. ``Burn the soil under the feet of the aggressors and invaders!'' he said in a statement read by a spokesman. ``The evil enemies will be defeated!'' Boucher said U.S. diplomats have been in regular contact with Iraqi authorities about the fate of the Americans. He said there was no change in the Iraqi position. Most of the U.S. concern focuses on 38 Americans confined under armed guard to the Hotel Rashid in Baghdad. They have access to American consular officers and to the hotel facilities but are not free to leave the grounds. In warning of a possible terrorist strike against American interests, Boucher said there was no specific information suggesting such an incident might take place. ``If specific, credible information on a threat to the public is received, the Department of State will provide information for travelers and other concerned parties,'' Boucher said.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Tightens Blood Services Supervision
DOC.TEXT: The American Red Cross brought its local blood services programs under national control Friday, announcing dozens of new positions and tighter supervision that it said would help assure a safe blood supply. Red Cross Chairman George F. Moody called the changes a milestone and said they were prompted by ``searing self-examination'' as well as months of scrutiny by the press and the Food and Drug Administration. They symbolize a ``recommitment to our goal of ensuring that the American people can count on a blood supply that is safe and adequate to meet their needs,'' he said. FDA inspectors have found several problems in the Red Cross system of reporting, investigating and following up on accidents and errors that occur in the course of collecting and distributing blood. One of the inspectors, Mary Carden, said at a congressional hearing last month that the national headquarters sometimes took months to review reports of AIDS cases associated with transfusions of blood collected by Red Cross centers. Stephen Richards, newly named executive vice president of the Red Cross, on Friday acknowledged procedural and record-keeping problems. But he added that ``we have not seen any evidence of contaminated blood ... being transfused into a patient'' as a result of those problems. Moody attributed some of the problems cited by the FDA to a tremendous backlog of reports, which he said is almost resolved. He said the steps announced Friday are meant to address both the FDA criticisms and the shortcomings that came to light in an internal Red Cross study. Under the group's restructuring plan, each region will get a new ``principal officer,'' appointed and paid for by the national headquarters. The officers will report directly to a new senior vice president for blood services, Dr. Jeffrey McCullough of St. Paul. Previously, regional blood services directors had reported to their local chapters. But Moody said the increasingly complex business of blood services, including relatively new tests for AIDS and hepatitis, made it necessary to centralize supervision. ``We have had to clarify the reporting relationship and the line of authority,'' Moody said. The Red Cross also said it is doubling, from eight to 16, the number of people responsible for evaluating the blood services offered by local chapters and following up on their accident and error reports. And Moody said the organization is nearly tripling its regulatory affairs unit in Washington, from five to 14 people, to better comply with FDA regulations. The 54 Red Cross blood regions supply blood to more than half the hospitals in the country. The organization's $500 million blood bank network is the largest in the nation. Brad Stone, an FDA spokesman, said the agency believes the new Red Cross moves will help standardize procedures and eliminate communications problems among the central and regional offices. ``We feel that the steps they've outlined today are a very significant movement toward ... improving the overall efficacy and safety of their system,'' Stone said. FDA investigators inspecting the group's national headquarters in Washington found that, for years, various Red Cross regional offices had not consistently reported accidents and errors. And even when regions did make such reports, the headquarters staff did not always review or follow up on them. Rep. John Dingell, who held last month's hearing, said the FDA found some Red Cross blood centers had released infected blood, mixed up records or violated AIDS testing procedures. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce oversight and investigations subcommittee, said the organization has had ``serious and persistent problems with its procedures for testing and keeping track of this blood.'' Carden said she found that FDA's own regulations had been violated. She said the headquarters staff had failed at times to file reports on cases in which donors tested positive for hepatitis or were at risk for contracting the AIDS virus. Such notification is required even if the blood is discarded.

DOC.HEAD: Organization Formed For Journalism Programs at Historically Black Colleges
DOC.TEXT: Historically black colleges and universities have formed an association of journalism and mass communications programs to help promote their programs and black journalists, association officials announced Friday. Representatives from 29 historically black colleges and universities voted unanimously Thursday to form the Association of Black College Journalism and Mass Communication Programs, said Orlando J. Taylor, dean of the School of Communications at Howard University in Washington, D.C. The new organization ``represents a historic effort to ensure that the voices of black colleges and universities will be heard in journalism and mass communication education and in the media professions,'' he said. Supporters said its long-range goals are to help more journalism programs at member institutions gain accreditation, and to help increase the hiring of black journalists and other media professionals. ``This association wants to destroy the myth that there are no qualified black media professionals,'' Taylor said. The association will seek to enhance instruction, fund-raising, and faculty and student development at predominately black institutions that offer journalism and mass communication majors, minors and courses. Taylor said the organization plans ``an intensive study of the nature, scope and status of all journalism and mass communication programs at the nation's 117 historically black colleges, to be accomplished in the coming year, in order to provide the data base for enhancing these programs.'' The organization was formed during the convention of the Association for Education in Journalism and Mass Communication. Taylor said it has been given representation on the Accrediting Council for Education in Journalism and Mass Communication.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Interrogate Honecker in Murder Probe
DOC.TEXT: East Germany authorities on Friday interrogated former Communist leader Erich Honecker about his role in the killings of people who tried to flee the country. Honecker and Erich Mielke, head of East Germany's once-feared secret police agency, were interrogated by federal prosecutors, said Peter Przybylski, a Justice Ministry spokesman. More than 200 people were shot to death or killed by land mines as they tried to escape from East Germany's Communist rule. The government announced in June that Honecker, Mielke and several border guards would be investigated on possible murder charges in connection with those deaths. Honecker, 77 and in failing health, and several other members of his ousted regime already have been charged with corruption and abuse of power. The murder charge could put Honecker behind bars for life, but his poor health makes prosecution questionable. He is staying in a Soviet hospital outside Berlin. Last month, a medical panel ruled that Honecker was too ill to be jailed pending investigation but fit enough to be prosecuted. Mielke was ordered jailed. East Germany's democratic government has changed its mind several times on whether to pursue charges against the aging members of the former hard-line regime that was toppled in last autumn's pro-democracy protests.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Border Guards Kill 12 Moslem Separatists
DOC.TEXT: Indian border gaurds shot and killed 12 Moslem separatists after they crossed over from neighboring Pakistan to campaign for independence of the disputed territory of Kashmir, police said. The separatists were killed during an encounter with guards at the Trehgam border area, 50 miles from Srinagar. Srinagar is the capital of the Indian-held part of Kashmir. Details of the reported enconter were not immediately available. India and Pakistan have fought two wars over Kashmir since gaining independence in 1947. This summer, tensions between the two nations flared over the long-standing dispute over Kashmir, which both countries claim. India accuses Pakistan of supporting the Moslem secessionist movement in Kashmir by providing arms and training to Moslem militants. Pakistan, an Islamic state, denies the charge but says it will back any movement for self-determination by the Kashmiri people. At least 959 people have been killed in the Kashmir valley since New Delhi cracked down on the secessionist movement Jan. 20. Jammu-Kashmir state, which includes the valley and the Jammu plains to the south, is the only one of India's 25 provinces with a Moslem majority. At least 65 percent of its 6 million people are Moslem. Nationwide, Moslems make up 12 percent of the country's 880 million people while Hindus comprise 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
WASHINGTON: adjournment time.
DOC.TEXT: The jury had appeared divided on Tuesday over their apparent decision on one of the 10 cocaine possession charges Barry faces. After sending a note to Jackson telling him they had reached a verdict on one count, the panel balked at revealing their decision when they entered the courtroom. The new note came as deliberations in Barry's case resumed after a juror who had been hospitalized for stress returned to court. Jackson said Thursday that juror Deborah Noel, a diabetic, was ``deeply depressed'' and ``overwrought'' but should be all right after a night's rest. The seventh day of deliberations was cut short around noon Thursday because Noel said she didn't feel well. Noel, a Howard University Hospital clerk, was examined by her physician, who ``could find nothing physically wrong with her,'' the judge said. But she was admitted to Providence Hospital. If Noel for some reason was unable to return, Jackson could order deliberations to continue with an 11-member jury. A 12-member jury once was regarded to be a constitutional requirement in federal criminal trials, but the Supreme Court has more recently made clear that the Constitution does not require 12 jurors for conviction. Barry has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his drug involvement. Jackson assured the defense and prosecution that Noel would be guarded by U.S. marshals at the hospital. The jury has been sequestered during the trial. In a pre-trial questionnaire, Noel said she generally favors police undercover operations ``because (they) help police and the FBI catch criminals.'' She said she was uncertain whether Barry had been treated fairly by the government. One of the 10 cocaine possession charges against Barry stems from the FBI sting operation in which the mayor was videotaped smoking crack cocaine in the hotel room of former model Rasheeda Moore last January. Defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy has said Barry was entrapped on that charge because Moore improperly lured him to the hotel room and talked him into smoking crack.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Envoy Lashes Out at Saddam
With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia's ambassador Friday lashed back at Iraq's Saddam Hussein, ridiculing his assertion that the Moslem holy city of Mecca has been defiled and calling the Arab leader a liar. Asked whether Arabs will believe Saddam's assertion that U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia have captured their holy city, Prince Bandar bin Sultan said: ``I don't think anyone will believe him. There is 1,000 miles between Mecca and where the conflict is.'' He added, ``It is ironic that he pulled a page from the old speeches of Khomeini,'' a biting reference to the anti-Western rhetoric of Saddam's nemesis in his eight-year war with Iran. ``If anybody is to be blamed for bringing multinational forces to our region, it is the government of Iraq,'' Bandar said. In a televised statement Friday, Saddam appealed to Arab religious pride in calling for unity against foreign intervention. The Saudis, the Iraqi president said, ``are not only defying the Arab and Islamic nations. ... They were challenging God the day they put Mecca and the tomb of Mohammed under the soil of the foreigner. ``Oh Arabs, oh Moslems, oh believers in God wherever you are, this is your day to rise and spread quickly in order to defend Mecca, which is captive to the spears of the Americans and the Zionists.'' The ambassador, speaking during a picture-taking session with Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., also said he was certain that military units from other Arab countries would join the U.S.-British defensive force in his country. Dole said later that Bandar indicated Arab countries were in a better position to participate once they had exhausted all diplomatic efforts to resolve the conflict in an Arab summit that ended in Cairo Friday. Saudi Arabia had no choice but to invite outside forces to help in its defense, Bandar said. ``We are faced with a de facto superior power, intent on aggression. We could not rely on the words of the leaders of Iraq because they had lied to us and the rest of the Arab world many, many times.'' He noted that Saddam had personally promised fellow Arab leaders that he had no intention of attacking Kuwait. ``He broke his promise,'' Bandar said. ``I just put it to you: What does it look like? What does it sound like? This reminds me of the 1930s, and we have learned from history.'' And he dismissed Saddam's populist appeal to poor Arabs to rise up against the region's wealthy royal families like his own, saying: ``That is a cheap shot.'' He said Saudi Arabia has been among the world's most generous countries in giving foreign aid, and that Saddam has thanked his country recently for its largesse.

DOC.HEAD: Polish Official Says McDonald's Exploring Operations in Poland
DOC.TEXT: An official of the McDonald's fast-food company has held talks with regional officials to explore opening the first McDonald's restaurants in Poland. Andreas Hacker, McDonald's director for Central Europe, met this week with provincial officials from Warsaw and the surrounding region to review opportunities and gauge the interest of Polish authorities, according to Jacek Czerwinski, director for regional policy at Warsaw city hall. ``We are of course interested,'' added Czerwinski, in a telephone interview Thursday. However, Czerwinski said, the officials were told it will be at least one to three years before the first McDonald's can open in Poland. McDonald's first must obtain a joint-venture partner in Poland, open a Polish branch office and find suppliers, he said. It will also be conducting profitability studies. Czerwinski said the restaurant company later would contract with a private farmer or state farm to grow its potatoes. Similarly, it will hire a bakery to make hamburger buns to its specifications. Warsaw and the nearby cities of Plock and Radom were willing to offer specific locations for McDonald's restaurants, but they were told by McDonald's that it was too early to consider sites, Czerwinski said. McDonald's opened its first restaurant in the Soviet Union last year and already operates in Hungary and Yugoslavia. In West Germany, McDonald's is the country's largest restaurateur and seeks to expand into East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Allies Endorse US Moves, Steer Clear of Collective Action
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Canadian pledge, inserting new 10th graf, Later Friday
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The NATO allies on Friday unanimously approved U.S. military action to guard the Persian Gulf against further Iraqi aggression but steered clear of taking collective action themselves. Two of the allies _ Canada and Belgium _ prepared to announce their own contributions to the land force and sea armada organized by the United States in defense of Saudi Arabia's oilfields. And West Germany sent four ships to the Eastern Mediterranean. However, Manfred Woerner, the NATO secretary-general, announced after a four-hour closed meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III and 15 other Western foreign ministers: ``Military action by NATO as such is restricted to its area,'' meaning Europe. Still, Baker, in a separate news conference, said the United States, Britain and other nations that have sent forces to the region will have to coordinate their operations. If there should be a naval blockade, for example, ``there will have to be a traffic cop,'' Baker said. ``Someone or some collection of countries or individuals will have to coordinate this. That is something that is being considered and being discussed.'' Baker headed back to the United States after the meeting in Brussels. He will meet with President Bush Saturday at the president's vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine, to report on his trip, which also included a stop in Turkey. Woerner said the allies by ``full consensus'' had endorsed President Bush's military moves in the Persian Gulf and sanctions against Iraq approved by the U.N. Security Council. And they pledged to defend Turkey if attacked by neighboring Iraq. Turkey on Thursday informed Baker that U.S. forces could launch attacks from Turkish bases against Iraq in the event of war. Baker said Friday at NATO headquarters that the allies had acted with ``unmistakable resolve and solidarity.'' He noted that Great Britain and France already have announced the deployment of forces, and said Germany, Belgium and Canada ``gave indications they will have announcements to make in due course.'' Later Friday, Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said his nation will send three ships and 800 sailors as its contribution to a multinational force. A U.S. official traveling with Baker, commenting only on condition of anonymity, said, ``You will see other allied forces, some of which will be on the ground'' in the Mideast. Baker had told the foreign ministers at their closed session that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was a dictator engaged in an unrelenting buildup of missiles and chemical weapons ``far out of proportion to any conceivable threat.'' Asked at the news conference if he was calling for Saddam's overthrow, Baker said he was not going to suggest the United States was pursuing such a goal. ``That's a matter for the people of Iraq to determine; that is, who will constitute their leadership,'' Baker said. ``But I am suggesting that the entire world community has risen up in almost complete unity to condemn the aggression that has taken place by Iraq under the leadership of Saddam Hussein.'' Baker went on to condemn as ``beyond all international norms'' Iraq's refusal to permit some 3,500 Americans and thousands of other foreigners to leave the country and Iraqi-held Kuwait. ``The United States is very disturbed about the restrictions on the freedom of travel,'' Baker said. He said most if not all foreigners ``are being prevented from leaving Iraq and Kuwait against their will, he said. However, Baker said, since no demand had been made in exchange for their freedom ``we are not calling them hostages.'' Nor, he said, had they been mistreated ``as best we can tell.'' He said diplomatic contacts were continuing in an effort to secure their freedom. Baker lauded Spain, Italy and Portugal for letting the United States use bases to support its deployment of troops to the Persian Gulf. He pointed out that the NATO charter precludes the allies as a group from undertaking military action in the gulf, an area outside the alliance's territory. However, Woerner said, ``It is very clear that an attack on Turkey would be considered an attack on all (NATO) nations.'' He said, ``We have been able to deal adequately'' with what NATO terms out-of-area operations such as the situation in the gulf. Woerner said NATO will inform the Warsaw Pact nations of the discussions on Friday. In recent weeks, Warsaw Pact nations have designated their ambassadors to Belgium to act as ``diplomatic liaisons'' with the Western alliance in reply to an invitation to do so issued at last month's NATO summit meeting.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: pan-Arab leadership.
DOC.TEXT: In the United States, Bush dismissed Saddam's statements as ``a rather frantic ploy'' by a leader ``backed into a corner.'' The president sent a report to Congress declaring, ``I do not believe the involvement in hostilities is imminent'' in Saudi Arabia. He later flew off to a 25-day vacation at his home in Kennebunkport, Maine. Before and after the NATO meeting in Brussels, some U.S. allies said their navies would supplement the dozens of American warships gathering in the gulf region, led by three U.S. aircraft carriers. Canada said it would send three ships, France was preparing to expand its force to seven ships, including the aircraft carrier Clemenceau, and Australia said it would send naval units. The British and Soviets also have a handful of warships in or near the gulf. For a third day Friday, the Soviet foreign minister, Eduard Shevardnadze, conferred by telephone with Baker, Soviet reports said. But the Kremlin says it will participate only in a blockade sponsored by the United Nations. An effective blockade could strangle the Iraqi economy, heavily dependent on oil exports, most or all of which already have stopped. Iraqis clearly were unsettled by the prospect: Reports filtering out of the isolated nation told of panicky people hoarding rice, cooking oil and other foodstuffs. Up to 50,000 U.S. troops are expected to pour into Saudi Arabia in the coming weeks in Operation Desert Shield, as it has been dubbed. Pentagon sources say contingency plans call for as many as 250,000 to be sent, depending on whether a grave Iraqi threat develops. At least 2,300 paratroopers of the 82nd Airborne Division landed in Saudi Arabia as the deployment's first wave. The Air Force was deploying about 140 F-15s, F-16s and other warplanes. Many of the Americans were taking up positions in Saudi Arabia's far northeast, near the Kuwait border, facing an Iraqi occupation force in Kuwait of between 130,000 and 170,000 men. Detailed descriptions of the operation were lacking, in part because the Pentagon did not dispatch a U.S. news media pool along with the troops. Because of Arab sensitivities, some troop movements were being carried out with relative discretion. A European reporter said, for example, she saw hundreds of young Western men with short haircuts and civilian clothes _ clearly U.S. troops _ arrive at the airport in the gulf emirate of Bahrain on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Joins Fraud Suit Against Researcher
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department announced Friday that it would join a fraud suit against a medical researcher who is accused of falsifying results of scientific work financed by government grants. The suit against John L. Ninnemann charges that he falsely reported research results on progress reports and applications to renew grants from the National Institutes of Health. It seeks recovery of $1.2 million in NIH grant money given to Ninnemann for research on the causes of immune system suppression after burn injuries that he performed at Utah and the University of California, San Diego. The action was first filed under the False Claims Act by J. Thomas Condie, Ninnemann's research assistant at the University of Utah, the department said. The Justice Department said its action in the case against Ninnemann will mark the first time it has brought a False Claims Act suit for scientific research fraud. ``The government's action in assuming responsibility for the case reflects our insistence that scientific research, especially when federally funded, be truthfully reported,'' Assistant Attorney General Stuart M. Gerson said in a statement. ``The government will not tolerate the falsification of scientific data in support of research grants,'' Gerson said. The lawsuit, still under court seal in U.S. District Court in San Francisco, charges that NIH paid $544,684 to the University of Utah and $749,098 to the University of California, San Diego, on the basis of false grant applications, the department said. The suit seeks recovery of the money, plus triple damages, from both Ninnemann and the two universities. The Justice Department said that responsible officials at both institutions certified the grant applications and progress reports that Ninnemann filed about his research. The suit also seeks penalties ranging between $5,000 and $10,000 for each of 14 false statements officials claim Ninnemann made in grant requests. The case was investigated by the Department of Health and Human Services' inspector general and the Office of Scientific Integrity at NIH. Under the Civil War-era law, citizens may file suit on behalf of the government to pursue allegations of fraud. The law allows the government to intervene and take over the prosecution of the lawsuit if it determines the allegations have merit. The citizens who bring successful False Claim Act suits typically receive 15 percent of a judgment.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq-Kuwait Quotes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: These quotes can be used as a package or separated for layout purposes
DOC.TEXT:
Here are some of Friday's quotes regarding the Iraq-Kuwait crisis:
``O Arabs, O Moslems, O believers in God wherever you are. This is your day to rise and spread quickly in order to defend Mecca, which is captive of the spears of the Americans and the Zionist,'' _ President Saddam Hussein, Iraq.
``Burn the soil under their feet. Burn the soil under the feet of the aggressors and invaders who want harm for your families in Iraq. ``Hit their interests wherever they are, rescue holy Mecca and rescue the grave of the prophet (Mohammed, at Medina),'' _ President Saddam Hussein, Iraq. ``The choice in front of us is clear: an Arab act that will preserve higher Arab interests in both Iraq and Kuwait, or a foreign intervention in which we will have no say or control.'' _ Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak.
``I just put it to you: What does it look like? What does it sound like? This reminds me of the 1930s, and we have learned from history.'' _ Prince Bandar bin Sultan, Saudi Arabia's ambassador to the United States.
``I do not believe the involvement in hostilities is imminent; to the contrary, it is my belief that this deployment will facilitate a peaceful resolution to the crisis.'' _ President George Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Zoo Separating Twin Brothers
DOC.TEXT: The first gorilla twins born alive in captivity in the Western Hemisphere will be permanently separated next week when one is shipped to a Nebraska zoo. Mosuba and Macombo II have not been separated since their birth on Oct. 26, 1983, according to Columbus Zoo officials. The pair are believed to be the only known surviving gorilla twins. Mosuba, the firstborn, will be sent on Tuesday to the Henry Doorly Zoo in Omaha, Neb. His brother, Macombo II, will remain at the Columbus Zoo. The twins are the offspring of Oscar and Bridgette, a breeding loan from the Omaha zoo. When officials learned that Bridgette was expecting twins, the zoos agreed to treat the ownership as if they were separate births. Under the agreement, the Omaha zoo would own the firstborn and Columbus would take the second. The zoos agreed the gorillas should remain together in their early years. They lived here until they were 4 years old and visited Omaha for several months each year. While there has been some discussion that separating them could be traumatic, zoo keepers believe it is safe. ``They are fairly independent right now,'' and often play with other gorillas, said keeper Beth Armstrong. ``But they are obviously very good buddies. I think gorillas are really adaptable.''

DOC.HEAD: Jimmy Hoffa's Former Lawyer Convicted of Tax Evasion
DOC.TEXT: Jimmy Hoffa's attorney was convicted of federal tax-evasion charges for failing to report money he made from a proposed movie about the former Teamsters boss. Frank Ragano, 66, said he would appeal Thursday's conviction on two tax evasion counts, which could bring a sentence of 10 years in prison and $200,000 in fines. He was freed on bail pending sentencing. Ragano was convicted in U.S. District Court of failing to report $83,000 income on his 1982 tax return and $24,000 in income the following year. Prosecutors said the ploy helped Ragano avoid paying $24,199 in taxes. The money came from investors who bought shares of the profits Ragano stood to receive from ``The Life and Death of Jimmy Hoffa.'' Ragano represented Hoffa for 15 years and formed a partnership with a Washington screenwriter to produce the movie. The project was later sold to a production company, but was never made. Ragano contends the March 1989 indictment resulted from his representation of Hoffa and the late Santo Trafficante Jr., a reputed Tampa crime boss. Ragano claimed prosecutors once offered to withhold the indictment if he provided information against Trafficante's associates. Ragano was also convicted of tax fraud in 1974 and suspended by the Florida Bar for five years. Hoffa, who once led the international Teamsters union, vanished 15 years ago. Federal investigators have said he was probably murdered.

DOC.HEAD: Families Leave Homes After Sandblasting That Caused Lead Contamination
DOC.TEXT: Sandblasting on a bridge raised large amounts of lead dust that contaminated the homes of 11 families, who had to be evacuated to hotels until their homes can be cleaned, a city official said Friday. City Health Inspector Jim Wilson said residents near the sandblasting project at the Shepard bridge had been exposed to the toxic lead dust from paint for three weeks. The families, including 15 children, were moved to hotels Thursday. ``It's a pain and a nightmare,'' said Guy Vangelist, speaking from a hotel where he was staying with his wife and three children. The sandblasting was stopped one week ago after the health department found lead contamination levels of more than 27,000 micrograms per square foot on interior surfaces in some nearby homes. Levels of more than 800 micrograms per square foot on any surface are considered unsafe, according to state Public Health Department regulations. The time needed to get test results, the reluctance of some families to move and difficulty in finding hotels accounted for delays in getting the people out, Wilson said. ``Everything is being done that can be done,'' he said. Wilson, trained in lead paint inspections, said lead poisoning can cause serious health problems, especially in children. The Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority, which hired J.F. White to sandblast the bridge, said the contractor erred by not determining if the paint on the bridge contained lead. J.F. White declined ti comment, referring queries to the MBTA. However, the contractor hired Lead Busters, which specializes in removing lead, to clean the houses. J.F. White also paid for the hotel rooms. Lead Busters said the homes could be habitable by next Thursday, depending on the amount of work to be done.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead of Los Angeles-dated item to CORRECT show's name to ``Casey's Top 40 With Casey Kasem'' sted `American Top 40.'
DOC.TEXT: Radio host Casey Kasem, whose Lebanese heritage prompts him to speak out frequently on Arab issues, says sending American troops to the Middle East could provoke another Vietnam. ``Let's not provoke another Vietnam by sending troops and having an accident turn into a catastrophe,'' Kasem said Thursday before taping another of his weekly shows, ``Casey's Top 40 With Casey Kasem,'' heard on more than 450 stations. ``Gunboat diplomacy is not what the '90s is all about. Shooting from the hip is not what the '90s is about. It's the age of reason.'' The disc jockey called for diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis brought about by Saddam Hussein's decision to invade Kuwait. Several thousand American troops are already on Saudi Arabian soil, and sources said the U.S. deployment could involve as many as 250,000 troops if war imperiled Saudi oil fields. ``Why can't they do it man-to-man? Our president should call Saddam and ask him what his intentions are,'' he said. Kasem, who is also the host of the syndicated ``America's Top 10'' TV show, has been outspoken on Arab issues in the past, including protesting deportation proceedings against local Palestinians.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Heads for Maine to Vacation, Direct Mideast Effort
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 4th graf pvs, ``It's very, with Bush fishing and additional quote
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A tired looking President Bush began a crisis-clouded, 25-day vacation Friday saying he did not want to ``be held hostage in the White House to events.'' Bush said he believes Americans would be sympathetic to his decision to leave Washington as U.S. forces move into the turbulent Persian Gulf region. ``I'm determined that life goes on,'' he said. Accompanied by his wife, Barbara, he flew to their oceanside home, but said he could return to Washington on short notice if necessary. ``It's very easy to go back,'' Bush said, noting it is only a 1{-hour flight to the capital. Immediatly on his arrival, Bush went fishing for a couple hours on his racing boat, Fidelity. The excursion was interrupted by a shore-to-ship telephone call from Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, concerning the Arab League's decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia and to impose economic sanctions against Iraq. ``I think the American people want to see life go on, so long as they understand that their president and his top officials are on top of a troubled situation,'' Bush told reporters. Bush has ordered a major deployment of U.S. troops, planes and ships to the gulf area in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the possibility that Saddam Hussein's army would continue on into oil-rich Saudi Arabia. Explaining Bush's decision to go to Kennebunkport, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``Our forces are going to be in a defensive manner. It's not a conflict.'' The president appeared fatigued after long days of monitoring the crisis. Bush met at the White House with foreign policy advisers and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney before leaving. The White House originally said Bush was taking extra staff with him but Fitzwater said on Friday that was not the case. White House chief of staff John Sununu was heading for vacation in his home state of New Hampshire. Vice President Dan Quayle was preparing for a vacation in Arizona. Scowcroft, Bush's national security adviser and frequent golf companion in Maine, remained behind at the White House. The top officials accompanying Bush were Robert Gates, onetime deputy director of the CIA and now Scowcroft's deputy; Andrew Card, the chief deputy to Sununu, and Fitzwater. Bush is to remain in Maine until Labor Day, Sept. 3. Bush said this vacation ``will be different'' from previous stays when he devoted himself to golf, fishing, tennis and other recreation. ``It will be legitimately a combination of work and play,'' the president said. ``What you don't want to do is appear to held hostage in the White House to events.'' He spoke with reporters on Air Force One en route to Maine. The president is expected to break away on Wednesday to return to Washington for a day of briefings and then head back to Kennebunkport. Bush said Americans should know that his estate is equipped with a complex and effective communications system that will allow him to be in close touch with administration officials and with other world leaders. ``I will have a busy schedule, busier than I would have liked to have had,'' he said. He said Secretary of State James A. Baker III, after visiting Turkey and attending a NATO meeting in Brussels, was expected to fly to Maine over the weekend to brief him. ``If I find matters seem to be requiring my going back, it's an hour-and-a-half to go,'' he said. Bush's oceanfront home at Walker's Point has its own helipad, and is heavily protected on land by the Secret Service and at sea by Coast Guard ships. Bush has gone to Kennebunkport every summer of his life except 1944, when he was in the Pacific flying bombing missions for the Navy against the Japanese in World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Baltimore-Based Navy Hospital Ship Leaving for Mideast
Precede WASHINGTON
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to update with ship sailing Saturday, picking up at the 6th graf previous, `Comfort is...'. Changes byline.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Iraq, Bjt
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The military hospital ship USNS Comfort will sail Saturday from Baltimore on the first leg of a trip to support troops in the Middle East, the Navy said Friday. The ship will be staffed with nearly 1,200 doctors and other personnel from the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md. All elective surgery at the 350-bed military hospital was suspended Friday in anticipation of the ship's deployment. The ship will head to Norfolk, Va., on Saturday to pick up supplies, said Margaret Holtz, a spokeswoman for the Military Sealift Command, which controls the ship in domestic ports. From there, Holtz said, it will sail ``in support of Operation Desert Shield,'' the military's name for the deployment of U.S. troops to protect Saudi Arabia from attack by Iraq. Spokesman H.B. Auld said Bethesda would be on a ``reduced status.'' Comfort is one of two floating hospitals operated by the Navy. The other, the USNS Mercy, is docked in Oakland, Calif. If either ship puts to sea in response to the American buildup of forces on the Arabian peninsula, it will be the first time that Navy hospital ship has been activated fully since the Vietnam War. The Comfort, commissioned as a hospital ship in 1986, is a converted San Clemente class tanker. It is 894 feet long, 105 feet wide and is equipped with 1,000 hospital beds. Medical facilities on board include surgical suites, intensive care wards and equipment, and general wards. Unlike most ships, it has wide, hospital-style stairways and hallways to accommodate easy transfer of patients. For emergency medical care, the ship has the best available of everything, Auld said. ``It can do everything from treating a hang-nail to major surgery,'' he said. The ship is normally staffed by 1,000 medical and logistic workers. These would include doctors of virtually every speciality, dentists, corpsmen and nurses. The ship itself is run by 80 civilian workers who man the vessel constantly, even while it is in port. Comfort's wide decks will accommodate helicopters, making it possible to bring wounded or injured service directly to the vessel from a combat zone. Normally, the Comfort would provide immediate, lifesaving care. Once an injury or wound is stabilized, the patient is shifted to permanent hospitals on shore.

DOC.HEAD: NABET Union To Challenge NBC In Court
DOC.TEXT: A major union at NBC said Friday it probably will go to court to fight the network's ``final'' offer that the company plans to put into effect on Wednesday. The decision by the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians was made Thursday after NBC rejected the union's bid to resume negotiations with a federal mediator present, a union spokesman said. ``NBC's position is that we've had a number of meetings over seven months and there has been ample opportunity to discuss key issues,'' said Betty Hudson, an NBC spokeswoman. ``The contract is on the table and we have no intention of modifying it.'' There will be no salary increases when NBC puts the contract into effect because union members haven't ratified it, she said. ``They'll operate under the old wage provisions until we have a ratified contract. NBC's previous contract with NABET expired March 31. Union members have twice rejected NBC contract offers. When NBC implements its new four-year contract, ``it appears that we'll be countering with every legal means at our disposal,'' said the union's spokesman, John Krieger. This means a court challenge of NBC's action, said Krieger, whose union says it has 2,373 members at NBC, 1,300 of them engineers. Major issues in the dispute include jurisdiction, daily hires and NBC's proposals to let outside producers rent its facilities to make new programs without union members employed by NBC. No walkout is imminent. The union's members, who struck NBC for 17 weeks in 1987, have not taken a strike vote, Krieger said. NABET members work at NBC and NBC-owned facilities here and in Burbank, Calif.; Washington; Cleveland;and Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Thumbnail Biographies of Arab Leaders
With AM-Arab Summit and AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are thumbnail biographies of Arab leaders, including the heads of countries frequently in the news and all leaders of Persian Gulf and Arabian Peninsula nations.

SADDAM HUSSEIN _ Iraq's president since an internal purge in 1979, the 53-year-old Saddam has a background in conspiracy and violence in the Baath party underground of the 1950s. Saddam established a ruthless dictatorship which brought the longest period of stability to a coup-plagued country. After he came to power as strongman behind Gen. Ahmed Hasan al-Bakr as nominal, figurehead president in 1968 some 50 high military and civilian officials were executed. Twelve years later he launched the Persian Gulf war against Iran, thinking he would quickly vanquish his enemy because of the revolutionary chaos in Iran. He miscalculated, and the war halted in a stalemate in 1988, leaving both countries ruined. But Iraq's war machine was built into the mightiest in the Arab Middle East and easily overran Kuwait on Aug. 2. Like many Arab leaders, Saddam has survived several assassination attempts.

SHEIK JABER AL-AHMED AL-SABAH _ The 62-year-old emir of Kuwait came to power in 1977 after a dozen years as crown prince and prime minister. In order to lessen Kuwait's dependence on oil revenues, Sheik Jaber spearheaded the country's diversification and oversaw its huge overseas investment program. Kuwait has invested about $100 billion outside the country, partly in a ``Future Generations Fund.'' By 1990, Kuwait was making more money from its investments overseas than from its oil sales, but the border dispute with Iraq remained unresolved. The now-deposed emir's family ruled Kuwait since 1756. The family allowed democratic elections twice, but dissolved Parliament due to harsh critcism of ministers from the Al-Sabah family.

KING FAHD IBN ABDEL-AZIZ _ The 70-year-old Saudi Arabian monarch is the sixth son of King Abdel-Aziz ibn Saud, the founder of the kingdom. Fahd, who has ruled since 1982, heads a royal family of 4,000 princes who are the cement that holds the kingdom together. He is believed to the the world's second-richest person, with his worth estimated at $18 billion in 1988 _ second only to the Sultan of Brunei, said to be worth several billion more. But the title he cherishes is Guardian of the Two Holy Shrines, which is how he is always referred to inside the kingdom. His highest duty is to preserve Mecca and Medina, sites of the annual hajj or Moslem pilgrimage.

HOSNI MUBARAK _ The president of Egypt, a 62-year-old former fighter pilot and later air force commander, was chosen by the late President Anwar Sadat as his vice-president in 1975. Unlike his predecessor, he eschews grand gestures such as Sadat's shock visit to Jerusalem in 1977. Caution has been the hallmark of Mubarak's rule. The president suffered a slight hand wound in the Moslem fundamentalist fusillade that killed Sadat in October 1981. Mubarak moved to recover Egypt's traditional position as political and military anchor of the Arab world, a position it lost after the 1979 peace treaty with Israel. The Egyptian president has been at the forefront of diplomatic efforts to end the crisis triggered by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

KING HUSSEIN _ Jordan's monarch took power in 1953 as a teen-ager and has survived the tempests of Middle East politics and numerous assassination attempts to emerge as a world statesman. The 54-year-old Hussein faced down a leftist-inspired rebellion in the 1950s, rode out the 1967 defeat by Israeli forces that robbed him of the West Bank, and crushed Palestinian fighters in the 1970 ``Black September'' civil war. Following four days of anti-government rioting in April 1989, Hussein launched a liberalization drive that gave Jordan one of the Arab world's freest presses and most open parliaments. In 1978 he married Lisa Halaby, the Lebanese-American daughter of an airline executive. She took the name Queen Noor.

HAFEZ ASSAD _ The 59-year-old Syrian president, until recently holding the title as Israel's most feared enemy, seized power in a bloodless coup in 1970. He is Saddam Hussein's sworn enemy in the Arab world: Syria is ruled by a rival branch of the Arab Baath Socialist Party that also reigns in Baghdad. He supported Iran in the eight-year war against Iraq, to the annoyance of most Arab states. A peasant boy from a minority Moslem sect, he rose against great odds to become commander of the air force, and later, president. His declared ambition is to achieve ``strategic parity'' with Israel and regain the Israeli-annexed Golan Heights. In 1976 he sent Syrian troops into Lebanon, and 40,000 of them remain. He suffered a heart attack in November 1983 and cut down on his heavy schedule and stopped smoking.

YASSER ARAFAT _ Chief of the Palestine Liberation Organiation, the stocky unshaven onetime gun-runner has used both violence and diplomacy to push his Palestinian people's cause to the forefront of world attention. The 61-year-old, Egyptian-educated civil engineer co-founded the Fatah guerrilla movement in Kuwait in 1959. His group rose to prominence through its guerrilla attacks on Israel in the 1960s, and Fatah eventually became the mainstream PLO faction. In 1988 he got the Palestine National Council, the PLO's parliament in exile, to endorse resolutions that proclaimed the independent state of Palestine and explicitly recognized the state of Israel. He also renounced terrorism and the United States initiated a dialogue with the PLO, broken off earlier this year after an abortive raid by a PLO faction against Israeli beaches.

MOAMMAR GADHAFI _ The mercurial, 52-year-old Libyan leader ousted King Idris in a 1969 coup and soon sought to acquire the mantle of his hero, the late President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt, as leader of Arab nationalism. Under Gadhafi, Libya became notorious for its support for international terrorism and its leader famous for his maverick ways. Born to a family of nomads, Gadhafi often lives in a tent and has a dazzling wardrobe of traditional and more way-out costume that is a fixture at Arab summits. President Ronald Reagan ordered a bombing raid on Tripoli in 1986 after the United States accused Libya of backing a terror attack on Americans. More recently Washington has accused Libya of building a poison-gas factory, a charge it denies.

KING HASSAN II _ The 61-year-old Moroccan monarch is a wily, pro-Western leader who often strikes independent positions in the Arab world. Morocco and neighbor Algeria were the first Arab states to openly condemn Baghdad's invasion of Kuwait. Like his Jordanian counterpart he has been a frequent assassination target, and also like Hussein he claims to be a descendant of the Prophet Mohammed. Hassan, a French-speaking cosmopolitan, has pursued an independent course, breaking Arab taboos by meeting with Israeli leaders. Moroccans say the king has ``baraka,'' or the blessing of God. Despite internal unrest in the early days of his reign, which began in 1961, the Moroccan monarch has become something of an elder statesman in the Arab world.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Youth Running `Underground', Escapee Says
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A young Kuwaiti who fled her country said Friday that young men who stayed have been running an ``underground'' resistance to the Iraqi invasion force. The group has led Kuwaiti efforts to stay away from work, collect garbage and run food collectives, said the woman on condition of anonymity. ``They have decided that only the service utilities will go on working for the sake of the population and everyone is obeying. But otherwise no one obeys orders from the Iraqi forces to work,'' said the young Arab woman, who worked in a Kuwaiti bank and stole across the border into Saudi Arabia early Friday. Local telephones, bakers, electricity, water, gasoline stations were listed among the services operating. There was, she said, ``a secret code of how to conduct life and we are adhering to it ... Everything is organized. And that gives us strength.'' The Iraqis were able to coerce the Asians or workers from other Arab countries, who often are too poor to think of leaving, she said. ``But there is no way that Kuwaitis will cooperate with them.'' The woman said they were organizing teams to collect garbage, or to run the food cooperatives. Some of the young men had rushed to Kaifan and Shuwaikh, where there were military barracks close to the borders, seized arms stocks there and began military resistance. But they were outmatched by the Iraqis who have some 120,000 soldiers and 350 tanks inside the country. The sporadic acts of resistance against the Iraqis are still on a small scale. ``But we are confident they would develop if they have to, and many, many would be volunteering from inside the country and from outside,'' she said. Among acts of the developing resistance are graffiti on buildings saying ``No One But Jaber,'' she said. Jaber is the name of the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, who fled the country during the invasion. ``We did not know the emir was alive until we heard his voice on Saudi television on Sunday. It was like God's hand was balming us, and the most terrific morale booster,'' the woman said. Kuwaiti women stage demonstrations. The Iraqi soldiers let them be, as long as they just chant ``God, country, the emir.'' But once they start ``Death to Saddam!'' the Iraqis start firing in the air, she said. Because many of the women are elderly, some of them fainted at the sound of the guns in a demonstration on Tuesday, travelers reaching Bahrain said. The Iraqis tried to dress like the Kuwaitis, fellow Arabs, in taking over key administrative jobs, or running television programs, according to the woman. ``Non-Arab foreigners can't tell the difference, but we know immediately from the accent. And it is so depressing.'' ``We can go on living, but we just have to keep our nerves in the icebox,'' she said. The young woman, her sister and a friend, like many others, had to depend on a driver who knew his way about the borders. and make a dash for it across the desert if they saw Iraqi soldiers approaching. If Iraqi soldiers spot someone heading for the border, ``They shoot first at the tires, then they stop you and come breaking up the car, taking occupants out,'' said Mariam Marzooq, a Bahraini executive for an American financial institution. ``There were so many destroyed cars along the borders. I don't know what they do with the occupants. We succeeded in making it.'' They said U.S. and Western embassies were harboring remaining foreigners or keeping close in touch. Ms. Marzooq said at least two Americans, a Briton, and 300 Austrians remained in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Arab League Majority Votes To Send Arab Troops to Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14 grafs for grafs 11-20, `The proposals...' to ADD reference to U.N. charter, harshest Arab sanctions ever; implicit approval of U.S.-led force; pickup graf 21 ```The choice....' CHANGES byline
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CAI2,4,53
DOC.TEXT: A majority of Arab League nations agreed Friday to send Arab troops to protect Saudi Arabia from Iraqi aggression, approved economic sanctions against Baghdad and condemned the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The moves were by far the strongest Arab steps against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Iraq, a league member, denounced the measures and vowed that Baghdad would stand by its annexation of Kuwait. Of 20 Arab League member states present, 12 supported the seven-point resolution. Libya, the Palestine Liberation Organization and Iraq voted against the package, Algeria and Yemen abstained, and Tunis was absent. Three governments _ Jordan, Sudan and Mauritania _ expressed reservations and took no position. Egypt's representative to the United Nations, Amr Moussa, told reporters details of the deployment of the Arab force would be worked out in contacts coordinated by the League's secretary, General Chadli Klibi. Mufid Shehab, head of the international law department at Cairo University's faculty of law, told reporters that according to the Arab League charter, the resolutions were binding only on the members who voted for them. Those nations include Egypt and Syria, which have the largest Arab armies in the Middle East after Iraq. Moussa said Iraq's representative, Deputy Premier Taha Yassin Ramadan, ``opposed and rejected the whole thing.'' The gathering of Arab presidents and kings had been hastily convened with the goal of finding a diplomatic solution to the Persian Gulf crisis in order to stave off foreign intervention. The session quickly turned stormy. Conference sources said a shouting match broke out between delegations from Iraq and the Kuwait government it ousted. During the heated argument, the Kuwaiti foreign minister collapsed, the sources said. The proposals endorsed by the Arab leaders were drafted by Arab League foreign ministers. It was not clear whether an Arab force would join the multinational force already deployed in Saudi Arabia, though the summit resolution seemed implicitly to endorse the U.S.-led force. The package is the toughest the Arab League's leaders ever ordered against an Arab country in the organization's 45-year history. It marked a major diplomatic achievement for Egypt's President Hosni Mubarak, who called the summit to counter Saddam's growing belligerence against his neighbors. Conference sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that during the debate, Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz spoke out harshly against the proposals and repeated Iraq's insistence it would not withdraw from Kuwait. As the ministers were meeting, Saddam called on Arabs to overthrow the Saudi royal family and attack Western powers, including the United States, that have sent forces to defend Saudi Arabia. The troop-deployment measure cited a 1950 Arab mutual defense pact that says an armed attack on one Arab League member constitutes aggression against them all. The delegates also cited the U.N. charter's authorization of joint military action to restore peace. ``We have decided to respond to the request by Saudi Arabia and other gulf states to deploy Arab forces to support the armed forces there to defend its lands and its regional security against any foreign attack,'' the document said. The Arab leaders also supported ``the procedures taken by Saudi Arabia and other Arab Gulf countries ... as part of their legitimate right for self-defense.'' That statement was seen as an endorsement of the request for Western military help in the face of the Iraqi buildup. The Middle East News Agency said the Kuwaiti official who collapsed _ Foreign Minister Sabah al-Ahmed al-Jaber _ returned to the meeting later after resting at his hotel. Kuwait's ousted emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, whose family ruled Kuwait for more than 230 years before being ousted by the Iraqis, was present for the morning session. He sat two delegations over from the grim-faced Iraqi delegation. One of the two pool reporters allowed in the meeting hall said the 62-year-old emir looked ``terribly depressed. He looked as though he was near collapse.'' Before the afternoon session, the emir returned to Saudi Arabia, his home in exile, leaving his delegation to speak for him. As the conference opened, Egyptian President Mubarak warned that unless Arab states could unite to resolve the crisis, foreign powers would act. Thousands of U.S. troops have already moved into Saudi Arabia to protect the oil-rich desert kingdom from Iraqi attack. ``The choice in front of us is clear,'' Mubarak said, ``an Arab act that will preserve higher Arab interests and both Iraq and Kuwait, or a foreign intervention in which we will have no say or control.'' The Arab League conference had been scheduled to begin Thursday night but was delayed until Friday, reportedly because of a dispute over who would represent Kuwait _ the Iraqi-installed government or exiled ruler. The Arab League had 22 members until May, when the merger of North Yemen and South Yemen lowered membership to 21. They are Algeria, Bahrain, Djibouti, Egypt, Iraq, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, Libya, Mauritania, Morocco, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, Tunisia, the United Arab Emirates, Yemen and the Palestine Liberation Organization, now officially listed as Palestine.

DOC.HEAD: Former Thornburgh Aide Indicted in Drug Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to CORRECT lying refers to earlier drug use. SUBS 3rd graf, `The indictment... to ADD latest in series of problems among Thornburgh associates. SUBS 12th graf, `Justice Department...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Thornburgh comments, pickups 13th graf pvs, `The indictment...' ADDS 3 grafs after last graf with details on Thornburgh aides.
DOC.TEXT: A former top aide to U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh was indicted Friday on charges of using cocaine while employed by the Justice Department and lying to federal officials about his alleged drug use. Former U.S. Justice Department lawyer Henry Barr was charged with one count of cocaine possession, two counts of making false statements and one count of conspiracy. A federal grand jury in Harrisburg returned the indictment against Barr. It was the latest in a series of problems among long-time associates of Thornburgh who followed him to the Justice Department from Pennsylvania. Barr, of suburban Harrisburg, was general counsel to Thornburgh when he was governor of Pennsylvania and later was assistant to Thornburgh when he became attorney general in 1988. He resigned from the Justice Department in May 1989. The indictment is the first of a public official stemming from a 15-month federal probe. According to the indictment, Barr allegedly lied on a federal form that asked if he used or provided illegal drugs within the last five years and repeated the false statement in a subsequent interview with the FBI. He is also accused of using cocaine at a suburban Harrisburg home on April 8, 1989, about a month before he resigned from the Justice Department. The government also alleges that ``Barr conspired with others to obtain, possess, and use cocaine and to conceal his cocaine involvement from outside scrutiny.'' If convicted on all counts, Barr, 47, could face up to 12 years in jail and fines of $510,000. The false statement counts are both felonies. Barr could not be reached for comment Friday afternoon. No one answered the telephone at his Mechanicsburg home. But his lawyer, Charles F. Scarlata, said in a statement that Barr would plead innocent to the charges. ``The decision to bring the charges is particularly egregious since Mr. Barr did not seek the position but rather was asked to sacrifice his partnership in a large Harrisburg law firm, leave his family and go to Washington, D.C.,'' Scarlata said. ``The ultimate irony here is there is not even a suggestion from any source that Mr. Barr performed his duties in other than a thoroughly professional, honest, competent and loyal manner,'' the statement said. Thornburgh said in a statement he had recused himself from the case upon learning of the allegations. He called the indictment ``a personal tragedy for Henry Barr,'' whom he described as ``a capable lawyer who devoted many years of his career to public service.'' ``I have no knowledge of the particular circumstances of this case,'' he said. ``It is now up to the judge and jury to determine the facts of this case and their consequences for Mr. Barr,'' Thornburgh said. The indictment came less than two weeks after Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., asked the Justice Department to appoint a special prosecutor in the case. Scarlata also called for a special prosecutor, saying in a letter last week that he welcomed a review by a ``prosecutor whose judgments are not driven by media attention.'' Thornburgh and a number of top Justice Department officials had bowed out of the investigation, as did U.S. Attorney James West. West's chief assistant, Gordon A.D. Zubrod, has been assigned to prosecute the case. In May, Thornburgh reassigned two top aides _ press secretary David Runkel and his chief of staff, Robert S. Ross Jr. _ to less sensitive positions after it was disclosed that they had showed deception on FBI polygraph tests. Last month, Barry H. Stern, an associate deputy attorney general, resigned from the Justice Department when his temporary security clearance was revoked. All three men served under Thornburgh when he was governor. Stern was labor and industry secretary, Runkel was his press secretary and Ross was a special assistant.
Here is a transcript of President Bush's news conference with reporters accompanying him to his summer home in Kennebunkport, Maine.

And there are scattered reports, but I will say that it's not just against Americans, but I think all countries are concerned about the safety of their citizens. So, it worries me because I do view it as a prime responsibility, but I would say, you know, I'm not going to go beyond that and I'm not going to invite further harassment by elevating the value of any citizen. Q: You mean you're helpless? A: I'm not _ we're not helpless, no. But, as we've seen with hostage situations, and I don't think this is one, sometimes it's very difficult. Q: Mr. President, how can you read Saddam's call for jihad? Is this just rhetoric or _ A: Yeah, it's rhetorical because he's backed into a corner. He's been isolated by the rest of the world. But he doesn't have many options, so he's resorting to radical rhetoric, trying to mobilize opinion. But the _ his problem is everybody sees through this. Everybody around the world will see through this rhetoric. Q: (Off mike) _ Arab leaders are meeting again today in Cairo.
