DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Leader Urges Holy War to Seize Saudi Cities, Block Americans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 4 grafs after 8th graf, Saddam has ... to UPDATE with Saudi reax. Pick up 9th graf pvs, ``O Arabs ...
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein urged Arabs on Friday to join in a holy war to sweep from power the Saudi royal family, seize the Moslem holy shrines in Saudi Arabia and block U.S. warships sent to defend the kingdom. Saddam's defiant call to take back the Moslem shrines signaled his intentions are broader than the annexation of Kuwait. His rhetoric aimed at presenting himself as a champion of Arabs and Moslems everywhere. By inviting U.S. troops to protect Saudi Arabia, the Saudi leaders ``are not only defying the Arab and Islamic nations ... but are challenging God the day they put Mecca and the tomb of Mohammed under the grip of the foreigner,'' Saddam said in a statement read by a spokesman on television. ``Your brothers in Iraq are determined on holy war, without hesitation and without any slowing down. ``We shall be victorious, God willing, and evil and corruption will be trampled wherever it is, the sun will rise on the Arabs and the Moslems and God will happy after we purify our souls and land from the foreigners.'' His mention of foreigners was a clear reference to American and other Western forces in the region. The statement appeared directed at Arab League members meeting in Cairo to find a diplomatic solution to the crisis caused by Iraq's invasion Aug. 2 of Kuwait. Saddam has been under intense economic and military presssure since the invasion. Thousands of U.S. troops are in Saudi Arabia as part of a multinational force to defend the oil-rich kingdom, and a majority of the Arab leaders voted Friday to deploy Arab troops to Saudi soil. They also approved economic sanctions against Baghdad, a league member. Saudi Arabia's ambassador in Washington, Prince Bandar bin Sultan, ridiculed Saddam's assertion that Mecca has been defiled. ``It is ironic that he pulled a page from the old speeches of Khomeini,'' Bandar added, a biting reference to the anti-Western rhetoric of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Saddam's nemesis in his eight-year war with Iran. ``If anybody is to be blamed for bringing multinational forces to our region, it is the government of Iraq.'' Bandar also called Saddam a liar, saying he personally promised fellow Arab leaders he had no intention of attacking Kuwait. ``O Arabs, O Moslems, O believers in God wherever you are. This is your day to rise and spread quickly in order to defend Mecca, which is captive of the spears of the Americans and the Zionist,'' Saddam said. ``This is your day to rise quickly to defend the Prophet Mohammed ... who carried the noble message in this noble land for it to remain holy.'' ``Burn the soil under their feet,'' Saddam said. ``Burn the soil under the feet of the aggressors and invaders who want harm for your families in Iraq. ``Hit their interests wherever they are, rescue holy Mecca and rescue the grave of the prophet (Mohammed, at Medina),'' he said. The statement called on Egyptians to bar Western military fleets from using the Suez Canal. He also appealed to the Persian Gulf emirates to stop American warships, without specifying how. ``Don't let the enemy pass through the soil of Egypt to use your waters, sons of the Strait of Hormuz. Stop the fleets from moving, sons in Ras al-Khaimah and Sharjah,'' Saddam said, referring to emirates in the southern gulf. The ``soil of Egypt'' was a reference to the Suez canal, and possibly to Egyptian air bases that might be used by American forces. Addressing Arabs everywhere, he called for the overthrow of the Saudi royal family. ``Make it clear to your rulers, the emirs of oil, as they serve the foreigner; tell the traitors there is no place for them on Arab soil after they humiliated Arab honor and dignity,'' he said. ``The American forces came and Saudi Arabia opened its doors to it under the false pretext that the Iraqi army will move toward them,'' he said. ``It means there are plans for aggressive intentions.'' On the holy shrines at the Saudi cities of Mecca and Medina, Saddam said: ``Arabs, Moslems, believers in God wherever you are. This is your day to jump up and defend Mecca, hostage of the Americans.'' The statement was read on Baghdad television and monitored in Bahrain and Cyprus. In an earlier broadcast on Iraqi radio, addressed to Arab professional unions and ruling Baath party members, the government said: ``Every free and honorable Arab is required to respond to the call of the Arab conscience and the Arab land, and to choose the way he deems fit to strike at U.S. interests in the Arab land if the United States becomes bull-headed and arrogant enough to begin a military aggression. ``We pledge to you, as knights, that we will make them drink virulent poison and will deal unprecedented blows to them so that the heads of the Arabs will remain crowned with laurels of victory and glory.''

DOC.HEAD: NICOSIA: Arab world.
DOC.TEXT: SULTAN QABOOS BIN SAID _ Oman's 49-year-old leader came to power in 1970 when he deposed his father Sultan Said bin Taimur in a bloodless coup. His father had ruled since 1932 and kept Oman locked in a medieval timewarp to keep his people safe from what he considered the dangers of the modern world. In the past 20 years Qaboos, a graduate of Britain's Sandhurst military academy, has pulled his long-isolated country into the 20th century with an ambitious development program. Qaboos wears a loosely tied turban and an ankle-length white robe, and bears a khanjar _ the distinctive curved Omani dagger _ on his waist, as well as a pistol in his belt.

SHEIK ZAYED BIN SULTAN AL NAHYAN _ Sheik Zayed is president of the United Arab Emirates, formed in the 1971 merger of seven sheikdoms in the wake of Britain's withdrawal from the Persian Gulf. The 72-year-old leader was the chief architect of the federation and is also the emir of Abu Dhabi, an oil-rich sheikdom. The U.A.E. federation also includes Dubai, Sharjah, Ras al-Khaimah, Umm al-Qawain, Fujairah and Ajman under the leadership of the bigger and richer Abu Dhabi. For 20 formative years, until 1966, Sheik Zayed lived with the bedouins as required by his post as governor of the emirate's eastern province. That year, his brother Sheik Shakhbut was overthrown in a palace coup and the Al Nahyan family council appointed Sheik Zayed the new emir.

SHEIK ISA BIN SALMAN AL KHALIFA _ The 56-year-old emir of the small island state of Bahrain inherited the throne on his father's death in 1961, but full powers did not come until independence from Britain in 1971. Bahrain has been a consistent advocate of closer cooperation among the gulf nations and is a member of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council. Under his rule the island has become a modern center for regional banking and multinational companies, partly because of its welcome for foreigners.

SHEIK KHALIFA BIN HAMA AL THANI _ The 60-year-old Sheik Khalifa became emir of Qatar when he deposed the former ruler Sheik Ahmed in 1972 with the support of his ruling Al Thani family, less than six months after independence from Britain. Oil exports form the backbone of Qatar's economy. It is considered the third richest country in the world per capita, with an annual income of $25 billion a year for a population of 369,000 people according to a 1976 census. Like neighboring Arab oil producers, Qatar has diverted oil wealth into massive economic and social development plans.

ALI ABDULLAH SALEH _ The 48-year-old general, now the president of unified Yemen, belongs to the powerful Hashed tribe from the north of the former North Yemen. Saleh was elected president of North Yemen by that country's Constituent Assembly in 1978 with Saudi Arabian support, and became president of the unified Yemen after north and south merged this year. The remote Red Sea nation is on the threshold of oil wealth, with recent major discoveries. With the merger, the south abandoned its hard-line Marxism and Saleh's conservative, pro-Saudi and pro-Western stance came to the fore.

ELIAS HRAWI _ Lebanon's president was elected by Parliament in a session held amid a security dragnet thrown by the Syrian army around a hotel in eastern Lebanon. The affable Hrawi, 64, a Maronite Catholic agricultural engineer, succeeded Rene Mouawad who was assassinated by a remote-controlled bomb after only 17 days in office. The post of president is largely powerless in a Lebanon riven with Moslem-Christian, Christian-Christian and Moslem-Moslem violence. The Syrian-backed Hrawi is at loggerheads with fellow Maronite Gen. Michel Aoun, who wants the Syrians driven out of Lebanon.

CHADLI BENDJEDID _ Algeria's 61-year-old president, Bendjedid ended the ruling National Liberation Front's monopoly on power in 1989 with a new constitution allowing rival political parties and free elections. His strongest challenge comes from Islamic fundamentalists, who swept local elections in June. Hopes of reviving Algeria's stagnant economy have been thwarted by low oil prices and unbalanced demographics: about three-quarters of the country's 26 million people are younger than 30 and many are unemployed. Formerly in charge of national defense, Bendjedid became president in 1979 after the death of Houari Boumedienne and moderated Algeria's pro-revolutionary foreign policy. In 1985, he became the first Algerian leader to visit the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Violent Weather And Floods Hit The Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rains drenched the already saturated Northeast and produced flooding in parts of New Jersey and New York on Friday afternoon, and a tornado on New York City's Staten Island uprooted trees and disrupted electrical service. Flooding closed the Saw Mill River Parkway at Saw Mill and the Bronx River Parkway near White Plains, New York. There was extensive flooding at Hammonton, N.J., where more than 4 inches of rain fell Friday morning. Two gas lines were pulled out when trees were uprooted when the tornado struck Staten Island, said a spokesman for Brooklyn Union Gas. The utility shut down service along one block to stop leaks, affecting about 50 homes. Consolidated Edison power lines also were knocked down, said a company spokeswoman. The tornado started as a waterspout over Lower New York Bay. Flood watches were posted over much of New Hampshire, western portions of both Massachusetts and Rhode Island, eastern New York and the southern half of Vermont. Rainshowers and thunderstorms pelted New England as well as southeastern New York, New Jersey, eastern Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware, eastern Virginia, and parts of the Carolinas. Showers and storms extended over western Virginia, eastern Kentucky, eastern Tennessee, and from northwest Florida across the Florida peninsula. Rainshowers and storms were scattered over northeast Oklahoma, southeast Kansas, central Missouri, southern Illinois, northwest Iowa, eastern Nebraska, southeastern South Dakota, and southeast California, and from western North Dakota across Montana, northern Idaho and eastern Washington. Friday morning was another cool one for the southeast portion of the nation. Low temperature records set or tied were 61 in Atlanta, 59 in Jackson, Miss., 64 in Mobile, Ala., 67 in Pensacola, Fla., and 66 in Tallahassee, Fla. Low temperature for the Lower 48 states Friday morning was 38 degrees at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 55 at Arcata, Calif., to 105 at Needles, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Pesticide Found In Non-Commercial Honey Eaten By Bees
DOC.TEXT: A high level of pesticide was found in honey eaten by bees that pollinate East Coast crops, an official of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration said Friday. Federal and state officials said there was no apparent contamination of honey sold for human consumption. Following a complaint from beekeepers on Cape Cod, officials of the state Department of Food and Agriculture made a routine investigation of bee hives in Rochester and Middleboro on July 17. They found 22 times the appropriate level of the pesticide, fluvalinate, in one honey sample. The FDA followed up with its own investigation. Fluvalinate, legal for use in hives that do not produce honey for human consumption, is used to kill the varroa mite, which kills bees. Because the heavily dosed honey was not for human consumption, no FDA laws were broken, said John Hamilton, the FDA's New England director of compliance. ``We have not instituted any nationwide testing,'' Hamilton said, dismissing earlier reports that honey was being tested across the country. Hamilton noted the contaminated honey was not eaten by humans; it's the bees' food. August Schumacher, commissioner of Food and Agriculture, said consumers were in no danger and that his agency was ensuring this remains the case. ``These bees are not used to make honey for human food, they are only used for pollination,'' Schumacher said. The state agriculture officials received a complaint from beekeepers on Cape Cod that migrant beekeepers were using fluvalinate illegally. The migrant beekeepers travel between the citrus orchards of Florida to the blueberry barrens of Maine, their bees pollinating as they go. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency describes fluvalinate as ``low to moderately toxic.'' Made by the Sandoz Crop Protection Corp., it can cause skin, eye and throat irritation, the EPA said. ``We have an ongoing investigation on the use of fluvalinate to make sure it is properly done and that no (affected) honey is sold to the commercial markets. To the best of my knowledge, this honey has not entered the food chain,'' Schumacher said. As a precaution, however, Hamilton said the FDA planned to test honey produced by two manufacturers that used the bees from the contaminated hive. They are Mendes Apiaries of Punta Gorda, Fla., and W.D. Fisher Bee Farm of McVeytown, Pa., he said. ``If that indicates a problem, we will in fact expand our investigation,'' he said. ``We're not aware of any contaminated honey that's on the market.'' In the meantime, he said, there's no indication that consumers should throw out their honey.

DOC.HEAD: Canada Tries To Save Whales from Beaching Death
DOC.TEXT: Fisheries officials using small boats and a helicopter tried to keep dozens of stubborn pilot whales from returning to shore _ and certain death _ off Cape Breton Friday. Several close-knit groups of about 20 whales, called pods, stayed about 1{ miles off the west coast of Cape Breton Island throughout the day after being coaxed back into the water Thursday, said Tom Kiely, acting regional manager for the federal Fisheries Department. At least two whales died Thursday as fisheries officials, tourists and residents tried to rescue dozens of whales on the beach near Cheticamp. Rescuers doubted that the approximately 60 who lived could survive being stranded again because of cuts and scratches they suffered while thrashing around in the shallow waters. Whale expert John Lien, a professor of animal behavior at Memorial University in St. John's, Newfoundland, said the whales may have beached themselves because they were about to die anyway. He said it is normal for pilot whales, common in the waters of Atlantic Canada, to be involved in between three and five strandings each year. The reasons remain unknown. Some believe beachings occur when a pod follows a sick leader ashore or when subterranean geological faults hamper their navigation. Pilot whales, a toothed species also called blackfish, are among the smaller members of the whale family, growing up to 20 feet in length and weighing up to three tons.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Explosion in Azerbaijan Kills at Least 17
DOC.TEXT: A bus exploded in Azerbaijan Friday, killing at least 17 people and injuring 15, the official Tass news agency said, quoting the republic's Interior Ministry. The unofficial news agency Postfactum put the toll at 57 dead, with three people seriously injured. It quoted the Giandja People's Front, an organization in the town of Giadja. Tass said the bus was bound from Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia, to Agdam in Azerbaijan. The cause of the explosion near Nadel village was under investigation. Azerbaijan and Armenia are locked in a bitter ethnic and territorial conflict. Tensions in the area have been rising in recent weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Saddam `Backed Into Corner'; US Presses Allies for Help
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf to CORRECT invasion target from Kuwait to Saudi Arabia; INSERTS 10th graf with additional U.S. units detailed
DOC.TEXT: President Bush declared Friday that Iraq's Saddam Hussein had been ``backed into a corner'' by worldwide outrage over his aggression. With Western forces gathering in the Mideast, Bush warned Iraq against sending out oil tankers to evade an economic embargo. Bush told Congress he doubted outright war was imminent, but he also said U.S. troops would stay in Saudi Arabia as long as needed to protect its huge oil reserves. A majority of Arab League nations agreed at a stormy meeting to dispatch troops to Saudi Arabia, offering the Arab participation Bush has fervently sought for a multinational effort to deter Iraq from advancing from occupied Kuwait. It was unclear which nations would participate in the deployment, which the Arab League announcement said was in response to a Saudi government request. Bush kept up his verbal fire on Saddam as the administration pressed allies for help in breaking Iraq's ``unlawful grip'' on Kuwait. Bush said Saddam would be ``foolish'' to invade Saudi Arabia, where a growing U.S. military force was taking up defensive positions. Complicating all responses by the United States was the grim knowledge that some 3,500 Americans remained trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, potential pawns in what Saddam described Friday as a ``holy war'' pitting the Arab world against the West. Bush called Saddam's declaration ``a rather frantic ploy to try to gather some support'' among fellow Arabs. ``He is so isolated in the world, so much backed into a corner by world opinion which is almost 100 percent against him, that he has to try to find some mechanism to try to rally support. It will not work. ... Everybody around the world will see through this rhetoric,'' Bush said. The president commented aboard Air Force One as he flew to Maine for a 25-day vacation at his Kennebunkport home. Later in the day, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We welcome the Arab League statement as a positive and significant statement. We are pleased with the very strong condemnation of Iraqi behavior and the equally strong support for Kuwaiti sovereignty and the return of the legitimate government.'' As the U.S. military forces in the Mideast grew, and other U.S. allies pledged new support to the defense of Saudi Arabia, Bush indicated he was ready to act if Iraq tried to evade an international embargo by shipping oil outside its borders. ``I would advise Iraqi ships not to go out with oil,'' he said. The Pentagon detailed more units involved in the buildup, but gave no figures figures for numbers deployed: Air Force F-16 fighters from Shaw Air Force Base, S.C. and C-130 transports from Pope Air Force Base, N.C.; the Navy hospital ships Mercy, based in Oakland, Calif., and Comfort, based in Baltimore and elements of the 24th Infantry Division (Mechanized) from Fort Stewart, Ga. Bush said economic sanctions were hurting Iraq but could ``be tightened up even more.'' Asked if Iraq appeared ready to invade Saudi Arabia, Bush said: ``There's no evidence right now that Saddam Hussein would be foolish enough to cross that border.'' But he said Saddam was anything but predictable. ``The troubling thing is we're up against a man known for his brutality and irrationality,'' Bush said. The State Department said diplomatic posts around the world had been urged to ``take appropriate security precautions'' out of concern that the Mideast crisis might lead to terrorist acts against Americans elsewhere. ``You could well see terrorist groups try to take advantage of this,'' Bush said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III carried an appeal from Bush to the NATO allies, urging swift and strict enforcement of international economic sanctions against Iraq. Baker said the stakes in the standoff go far beyond the Persian Gulf and the oil that powers the industrialized world, declaring that NATO faced the first test of its clout in the post Cold War era. ``We all have an interest in thwarting Iraq's menacing and unlimited ambitions,'' Baker said after a closed-door session of NATO foreign ministers in Brussels. ``If might is to make right, then the world will be plunged into a new dark age.'' Bush headed to Maine to begin a summer vacation at his oceanside home, but not before sending two letters to Congress detailing his response to the Iraqi invasion, the greatest test of his presidency. Bush also met with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to discuss the costs of the military mission, and the White House said Iraq's aggression should bring a rethinking of calls for dramatic defense cuts. Baker was to meet with Bush Saturday in Kennebunkport. Bush told Congress that U.S. troops would remain on Arab soil ``so long as their presence is required to contribute to the security of the region.'' Sounding a hopeful note, the president said: ``I do not believe the involvement in hostilities is imminent; to the contrary, it is my belief that this deployment will facilitate a peaceful resolution to the crisis.'' But Baker said there were signs that Iraq was moving troops near its border with Turkey and also sending more forces into occupied Kuwait. The U.S. deployments continued as well, with more air, ground and sea power arriving for an effort Pentagon sources said could ultimately include 250,000 ground troops if Iraq took aim at the Saudi oil fields. Several U.S. commercial airlines said they had been asked to help shuttle troops to the Middle East. In a fiery message broadcast on Iraqi television, a spokesman for Saddam called on all Arabs to attack Western forces in the Gulf and overthrow the Saudi monarchy. Not mentioned by the Iraqi statement were Americans who are not being allowed to leave Iraq or Kuwait. The administration is loathe to call them hostages, wary that doing so would complicate efforts to win their freedom because any release would appear to be a concession on Iraq's part. ``I'm not going to invite further harassment by elevating the value of any citizens,'' Bush said. Britain, France and Australia already had promised to help the United States mount a multinational defense of Saudi Arabia, the world's biggest oil producer. Canada and West Germany pledged Friday to join the effort and Baker said Belgium was poised to help as well. The Saudi defense force is designed to deter further Iraqi aggression, with hopes for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait pinned on a worldwide effort to suffocate Iraq's economy. Fitzwater said the sanctions appear to have all but shut down Iraqi oil production. But U.S. officials were still talking about a possible naval blockade in case Bush orders that all Iraqi commerce be halted. The president's second letter to Congress explained the need for the trade embargo against Iraq. ``The Iraqi government has tightened its unlawful grip over the territory of Kuwait and has installed a puppet regime that in no way represents the people or legitimate government of Kuwait,'' Bush said. While designed to cripple Iraq's already weak economy, the sanctions were exacting a toll in the United States as well. Fare increases imposed by some commercial airlines because of higher fuel costs kicked in Friday, with more price hikes scheduled to take effect next week. And the Labor Department, in releasing encouraging data on price inflation during June, said higher energy costs _ particularly at the gas pumps _ likely would drive up inflation in subsequent reports. With the economy virtually idle now, many economists believe higher fuel prices will be enough to trigger a recession.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules U.S. Violated Mexican Treaty by Kidnapping Doctor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Rafeedie stressed ...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE on judge referring to other abductions in Camarena case; lawyer's comments about his client's abduction. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `In 1985...
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge ruled Friday that the U.S. government illegally kidnapped a Mexican doctor for trial in the slaying of an American drug agent, and ordered his return to Mexico. U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie said the abduction at gunpoint of Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain in the Enrique Camerena murder case violated the government's extradition treaty with Mexico. ``The defendant is ordered discharged and the government is ordered to repatriate this defendant to Mexico forthwith,'' Rafeedie ruled. The judge also warned the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration that such violations of another nation's sovereignty will not be tolerated even if they are launched in the interest of stopping the international drug trade. However, the judge stayed execution of his order for one week after Assistant U.S. Attorney William Fahey asked for time to consider an appeal in light of the ``significance'' of the ruling. The April 2 kidnapping of Alvarez at his office produced diplomatic tensions between the two countries. Mexico accused the United States of encroaching on its sovereignty and threatened to cut off anti-drug cooperation. Justice Department officials had no immediate comment on the ruling. Rafeedie stressed he was not dismissing the charge against Alvarez but merely ruling that the case could not be tried in the United States. He noted a long line of decisions upholding abductions, but said those cases did not involve a formal diplomatic protest, such as Mexico's over Alvarez. The judge also referred to other abductions in the Camarena case. Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, a Honduran drug kingpin, was taken by plane from Honduras. Rene Verdugo Urquidez was pushed through a fence at the U.S.-Mexican border and grabbed by U.S. agents. Matta's lawyer, Martin Stolar, has protested his abduction, but said Honduras never formally protested the violation of its extradition treaty. He said Rafeedie's ruling, if upheld, might invalidate Matta's conviction last month. Verdugo was convicted in a separate trial in 1988. In 1985, Camarena and his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar, were abducted, tortured and killed at a ranch outside Guadalajara. The doctor was spirited out of Mexico by DEA operatives to face charges he administered drugs to revive Camarena for questioning while he was being tortured. ``The DEA gave the go-ahead for the abduction,'' Rafeedie said in a 39-page decision. ``This command was approved at the highest levels of the DEA. The United States attorney general's office was consulted.'' Rafeedie said it was clear from the testimony of two DEA operatives that the agency paid at least $20,000 in rewards for the Alvarez abduction and continued to support the abductors and their families to the tune of $6,000 a week in living expenses. He rejected a government contention that the DEA was not responsible because its agents did not personally kidnap Alvarez. ``The United States is responsible for the actions of its paid agents,'' the judge said. He noted that Mexico sent three diplomatic letters to the U.S. government protesting Alvarez's kidnapping as a violation of its sovereignty. When such a protest is made and a treaty is violated, Rafeedie said, the defendant must be returned. Alvarez's lawyer, Robert Steinberg, said he felt the judge's ruling was a warning to the DEA to stop kidnapping suspects from Mexico. He said he believed the judge's ruling would be appealed and might go as high as the U.S. Supreme Court. ``My fear is they're going to take these appeals for years while he (Alvarez) rots in jail,'' he said. Although the government suggested a bail hearing for the doctor, Steinberg said the defendant has no property to post as collateral and probably would not win release because of fears that he would flee to Mexico. Alvarez, who was wearing a blue jail jump suit, displayed no emotion when he heard the ruling. Asked for his client's reaction, Steinberg said: ``He's numb.'' The defense lawyer denied Alvarez had any involvement with the drug trade in Mexico, although he acknowledged the defendant knew drug traffickers and was the doctor for the family of drug kingpin Rafael Caro Quintero. ``This man is incapable of a violent act,'' said Steinberg. ``He's a jolly buffoon who liked to hang around with the big guys. It was an honor to be invited to Caro Quintero's rancho.'' ``He enjoyed being important and being invited to the house, but half the state did, including the governor of Jalisco,'' he said. Jalisco is the Mexican state that includes the city of Guadalajara. He said Alvarez had been the personal physician to Caro's grandfather and father. The U.S. Justice Department said earlier it was pressing its investigation into the murders of Camarena and Avelar. Four men were recently convicted in Los Angeles. Three others were convicted in 1988 on charges of involvement in the murder. More than two dozen people have been convicted in Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Hungry Crowds Loot Stores in Peru; Police Fire
DOC.TEXT: Looting broke out in dozens of poor neighborhoods Friday in an angry reaction to President Alberto Fujimori's harsh austerity program. In the Villa El Salvador shantytown, soldiers fired over the heads of a stone-throwing mob of 2,000 that gathered in front of the local market, demanding that it open. Police used tear gas and clubs to control about 3,000 Peruvians in Lima's Ate-Vitarte section. The people had been waiting for up to two days for subsidized sugar, but the supply ran out Friday. Looting began immediately after the government announced an extreme economic austerity program Wednesday night. Gasoline prices jumped from seven cents to more than $2. The cost of many basic foods tripled or quadrupled. Telephone, water and electricity rates will rise, as will taxes on the rich. Lower import duties and a free-floating dollar are in store. The program aims to slash Peru's 3,000 percent annual inflation rate by eliminating subsidies. The subsidies are largely responsible for Peru's huge fiscal deficit, which in turn spurs the government to print money to cover costs. Fujimori's plan also is intended to reactivate an economy in which four of five people lack steady work. At first, the measures at first brought Lima to a near halt. Most stores were closed Thursday and buses did not run. Life in downtown Lima and in the capital's wealthier neighborhoods was largely back to normal Friday, with stores open and some public transportation available. Restaurants were largely empty. But the poor areas have been hard hit. Most people there buy food day to day. Few had money enough to buy the basics Friday. Most markets were closed for fear of looting. Venders often charged double the prices in supermarkets in wealthier neighborhoods. People blamed the government. ``They're strangling us,'' Albina Urcaya said as she stood for the third day in the sugar line in Ate-Vitarte. ``They pull us out of one crisis just to throw us into a much deeper hole.'' Julia Pomachagua stood nearby, caressing the head of her 5-year-old son. ``He hasn't eaten breakfast or lunch.'' The government has said it will give out food directly to the poor and subsidize their water and bus services. But few municipal offices in Lima had received any food by Friday and most existing soup kitchens remained closed. At least part of the anger Friday turned against Fujimori. About a third of Peru's 22 million people live in deep poverty and most of these voted for Fujimori, largely because of his promise not to implement an austerity program. ``We are ignorant people, but when someone says he will help us we believe him,'' said Deli Aguray, near Huaycan shantytown's shuttered market. ``Fujimori tricked us into voting for him and now he's abandoned us.'' A man and a woman died Thursday outside Huaycan's market, shot by the owner of a nearby grocery who fired on an enraged crowd. ``I don't know why he used his gun,'' Mrs. Aguray said Friday. ``We were just asking him to sell us what's in his store. We're hungry and we have to get food somewhere, somehow.''

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Hits Staten Island
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CLARIFY Staten Island a borough of New York.
DOC.TEXT: A rare tornado hit the New York borough of Staten Island on Friday, uprooting trees and disrupting gas and electrical service, authorities said. ``It's pretty scary. It's scary especially to look outside and see everything like that,'' said Dawn Zimmer, 27. Her home was left standing, but its aluminum siding was slashed and trees were uprooted. ``Everything's thrown all over,'' she said. Paul Egeler Sr. said he'd never seen anything like it in his 80 years on Staten Island, across New York Harbor from Manhattan and Brooklyn. He said it lasted five to 10 minutes. It was the first tornado to hit any part of the city since Oct. 5, 1985, when a tornado hit the borough of Queens, causing negligible damage, said Anthony Gigi of the National Weather Service. No major tornadoes have struck New York this century. Police said it affected only a three- or four-block area. Two gas lines were pulled out when trees were uprooted, said Bob Loftus, a spokesman for Brooklyn Union Gas. The utility shut down service along one block to stop leaks, affecting about 50 homes. Consolidated Edison power lines also were knocked down, said spokeswoman Bea Meltzer. No figures were immediately available about outages. Fire Department Lt. Jim Powell said firefighters evacuated one area until they could shut off fallen power lines and gas service. Gigi said the tornado started as a waterspout over Lower New York Bay. He said tornadoes that begin as water spouts usually are not as powerful as those that form over land. Debbie Casrovinci of Emergency Medical Services said two injuries were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Store Worker Leaps Over Car Containing Shoplifting Suspects
DOC.TEXT: A store employee tried to stop two shoplifting suspects driving away from a supermarket, then tried to leap over their car when it bore down on him. ``I lost an argument with a Pinto,'' said Duncan Walker, assistant manager of a Winn-Dixie store. Actually, Walker put one foot through the windshield of a Mercury Bobcat. Police Lt. Alvin Allcon said they do not encourage people to follow Walker's example by pursuing perpetrators, although other civilians wound up catching the two suspects. ``The history of that is we've just had too many folks that have been severely injured,'' he said. Walker was taken to the Harris Methodist Fort Worth emergency room Thursday night for treatment of gashes on his right leg. Walker, who has been working at the store for three weeks, had hoped to stop the suspects' car by running in front of it. ``I thought he was going to run over me,'' Walker said. ``I had a choice to either stand there and get run over, or jump right and I'd probably get hit by traffic. Or jump over the car. ``I didn't get high enough to get over the windshield.'' The suspects' car stopped after striking several vehicles. The two suspects fled on foot and were apprehended by neighborhood residents carrying bats and at least one shotgun, police said. Police found a supermarket basket loaded with cigarettes, key chains, sweet rolls, toothpaste, socks and underwear.

DOC.HEAD: Campeau Ousted From Retailing Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `But his ...' with 2 grafs to CORRECT bankruptcy filed in January, sted February. Picks up 6th graf, `Campeau's board...' ADDS 5 grafs of background after last graf. A version also moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Robert Campeau, the flamboyant Canadian retailer whose empire foundered under the weight of debt, was ousted Friday as chairman and chief executive of his own company. The Campeau Corp.'s board made the announcement in a terse statement from its Toronto headquarters. Campeau remains a director of the company but his future remains unclear. Campeau is an entrepreneur who went on a multibillion-dollar spending spree for American department stores in the 1980s using borrowed money, expanding his holdings to well-known names ranging from Jordan Marsh to Bloomingdale's. But his U.S. retailing operations staggered under the weight of this debt and sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last January. He has faced further pressure because of additional debts, which include millions of dollars in personal loans, and the declining value of the stock in his own company. Rumors had circulated recently that Campeau was in danger of losing his position as chairman and was in fact under pressure to resign. Campeau's board appointed James D. Raymond, a director of the National Bank of Canada, and Gary M. Goodman, a top executive with Olympia & York Developments Ltd. of Toronto, to the office of chief executive on an interim basis. The board also named Robert Despres, a Canadian investor who has been on Campeau's board since 1975, as interim chairman of the company. The company said in a statement from Toronto that it had begun a search for a permanent chairman and chief executive. Campeau Corp. spokesman Richard W. Wertheim declined to comment on what changes the board planned for the future of the company. He said while Campeau would remain on the board, ``other roles he may have in the future I can't say.'' The changes are effective immediately, he said. The Campeau board met in Toronto in a special session following its first meeting July 30. Raymond, 65, was appointed to Campeau's board Aug. 1. He is a former president of Claridge Inc., an investment firm connected with the powerful Bronfman business family in Canada. Goodman was elected to the board on July 30. He is a senior vice president of corporate development of Olympia & York in Toronto. Despres has been on Campeau's board since November 1975. He is president of DRM Holdings Inc., a Canadian investment firm. Campeau's department store divisions, Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., had a combined debt of $7.7 billion when they sought protection from creditors six months ago. Much of the debt was in high-interest junk bonds to finance the purchases by Robert Campeau, who bought Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988. He lost control of the retailing operations shortly after they filed for bankruptcy. They are now run as a separate operation headquartered in Cincinnati. Campeau Corp. lost $80 million in the first quarter of 1990, on top of $1.7 billion in losses in 1989. The National Bank of Canada in January seized about 80 million Canadian dollars in Campeau Corp. stock owned by Robert Campeau, after he missed payments on loans. He had lost much of his personal fortune in a plunge in the company's stock. But he failed to meet payments that would have allowed him to repurchase the shares and regain control of the company earlier this year. Before the bank seized his stock, Campeau and his family held 53.9 percent. Olympia & York, a property development company, still holds 11.8 percent and the remainder is publicly held.

DOC.HEAD: Rock Band Members Plead To Assault Charge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Deletes redundant 8th graf, `Prosecutors said ...' SUBS last graf to CORRECT 1985 record title to `Red Hot Chili Peppers' sted ``True Men Don't Kill Coyotes.'' Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: Two members of the rock group Red Hot Chili Peppers were ordered to pay $5,000 each to a rape crisis center and apologize to a young woman they sexually harassed during a Spring Break beach concert. Michael ``Flea'' Balzary, 26, and Chad Smith, 28, each pleaded guilty to battery. Balzary, 26, also pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct and solicitation to commit an unnatural and lascivious act. County Judge Freddie Worthen on Thursday sentenced Balzary and Smith each to pay a $1,000 fine, pay $300 to the State Attorney's Office for prosecution costs and donate $5,000 to the Volusia County Rape Crisis Center. Both also had to apologize in writing to the 20-year-old college student from Virginia who was attacked on the sand last March 14 during the taping of an MTV Spring Break broadcast. Both musicians were hustled by their lawyers from the courtroom and would not comment. They both have sent letters of apology. According to beach rangers, the woman was dancing on the sand when Balzary picked her up and swung her around on his shoulder. Despite her repeated protests and attempts to free herself, she was thrown onto the sand. Balzary and Smith spanked her and tried to peel off her swimsuit bottom. The woman fell to the sand and Balzary knelt on her legs, yelling at her to perform a sex act, authorities said. Prosecutors said the woman approved of the sentence, which included the maximum sentence for the first-degree misdemeanor. In his apology, Smith wrote: ``I clearly got carried away in the theatrics of the moment and I now realize how inappropriate and wrong my actions were.'' Kathy Wilkes, executive director of the Rape Crisis Center, said the $10,000 in donations would be a boon for the agency, which is operating on a $90,000 budget this year. Albums by the Red Hot Chili Peppers include the 1989 record ``Mother's Milk'' and the 1985 ablum, ``Red Hot Chili Peppers.''

DOC.HEAD: ANC Chief Says Violence To Stop, Despite What Winnie Mandela Says
DOC.TEXT: An African National Congress leader went on state-run TV Friday to contest Winnie Mandela's assertion that suspending guerrilla actions was merely a ``strategy'' and violence would continue. Walter Sisulu said the ANC's National Executive Committee ``decided that, as from now, the armed struggle, meaning the shooting, actually will stop. It was decided as a well-considered decision, not a mere strategy.'' Sisulu is a founder of the ANC's military wing. Later, however, the ANC issued a strong statement demanding that the government ``suspend'' the Internal Security Act, which allows suspects to be detained indefinitely in solitary confinement. The ANC said 151 of its members have been arrested recently under the law. The organization said the arrests run counter to an agreement reached with the government Tuesday, when the ANC suspended its armed struggle to make way for negotiations on the end of apartheid. The government said it would review the Internal Security Act and consider repealing some sections. The ANC asked that the law be suspended until Parliament can repeal it. In reply to a question from a TV reporter, Sisulu said no action would be taken against Mrs. Mandela, wife of ANC Deputy President Nelson Mandela, for her comments on the suspension of guerrilla actions. ``Many people make mistakes and ... we would take no further step about the matter,'' he said. The South African Broadcasting Corp. showed film of a speech Mrs. Mandela made Thursday night in Durban at the relaunch of the ANC Women's League. She said, ``To suspend military action on the part of the ANC is a strategy. It does not mean the cessation of violence.'' After the broadcast, the ANC issued a news release repeating Sisulu's comment. ANC leaders have previously disagreed with Mrs. Mandela, in particular when she gave support in a 1986 speech to use of the ``necklace'' method of killing blacks in the townships. It involves placing a gasoline-soaked tire around the victim's neck and igniting it. The ANC has called for a stop to ``necklacings,'' usually administered in the past to blacks accused of collaborating with the white-led government and which police say have caused about 400 deaths since 1984. The ANC said then that Mrs. Mandela held no position in the organization, though she has claimed to have been an ANC ``soldier.'' In February 1989, major anti-apartheid leaders in South Africa denounced Mrs. Mandela, urged the black community to shun her and accused her bodyguards of waging a ``reign of terror'' in Soweto, a black township outside Johannesburg. One bodyguard, Jerry Richardson, was sentenced to death Wednesday for murdering a 14-year-old black youth leader, who was held captive and beatn in Mrs. Mandela's home, according to court testimony. Mandela, Sisulu and other ANC leaders were sentenced in 1964 to life in prison for sabotage and plotting the overthrow of the government. Sisulu was freed last October and Mandela last February.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Protection Gear Will Do Job, Air Force Says
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force's anti-chemical attack suits and gas masks are bulky and heavy and the Saudi Arabian heat could make them more uncomfortable, two men who helped design the gear said Friday. But they said the equipment is the finest in the world and will provide ample protection from chemical weapons. Robert May, director of the Human Protection Systems Division at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base outside of Dayton that helped design the gear, said it had been used in the field with simulated environments, including hot climates in the United States. ``It's very good,'' he said. ``We believe it's the best in the world.'' ``It's good protection,'' said Burnham Foley, deputy chief of the division's chemical warfare defense branch. ``But you've got to train harder to work in it.'' A growing U.S. military force is taking up defensive positions in Saudi Arabia to protect the oil-rich kingdom from possible attack from Iraqi troops that overran Kuwait last week. Iraq's Saddam Hussein has an unknown quantity of deadly chemical weapons. Saddam used chemical weapons against Iran during the countries' eight-year war and against Iraq's rebellious Kurdish minority. Saddam also threatened in April to attack Israel with chemical weapons in the event of an Israeli attack. May said the heat of Saudi Arabia, where temperatures can soar to 120 degrees, could make wearing the suits, which he described as heavy and bulky, more stifling. ``There's no doubt that it's not comfortable stuff to work in,'' May said. ``You're not going to be comfortable, and it's not going to be fun.'' The equipment, one for air crews and another for ground crews, includes overgarments, masks, boots, gloves, decontamination devices, chemical detectors and medical supplies. The Army's gear is different. Crews can temporarily remove parts of the gear, then quickly put them back on again if an attack appears imminent, Foley said. ``If someone is surprised and they don't have their equipment on, ... it would be a problem,'' Foley said. ``(But) our troops train in it, and they typically have part of it on if there's any kind of alert status at all.'' May said that the gear provides head-to-toe protection and that the masks include vapor traps and charcoal filters and allow for insertion of drinking tubes. He declined to say what specific chemical agents the suits will repel. ``It's designed to protect against the ones we believe to be a threat,'' May said. The 1925 Geneva Protocol forbade use of chemical weapons in battle. More than 100 nations had signed the protocol by 1986, but production of chemical weapons never completely stopped.

DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin Congressman Suggests Bush Speech to Arabs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush needs to address the Arab world to counter the ``demonizing'' statements of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, an influential member of Congress proposed Friday. ``Right now we are abdicating the political rostrum in the Arab world to Saddam,'' said Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, in a statement. ``He is demonizing us and we are not responding.'' Aspin said the president needs to make a televised address to the Arab world explaining U.S. aims in sending troops to Saudi Arabia, and that Saddam Hussein is the enemy of the United States, not the Iraqi people. ``First, the Arab world, and especially the Iraqi people and military, need to be told that we will withdraw out troops if Saddam is driven from power. ... Bluntly put, we want to encourage a coup or an uprising,'' Aspin said. ``Second, we need a way to offer a hand of friendship to the Arab world in a concrete manner,'' to counter what Aspin called the ``disgusting lie'' that western countries stopped shipments of sensitive military technology to Baghdad because it wants to deny Arabs the fruits of science and technology. ``We should consider spiking that lie by offering a generous program of scholarships for young Arabs with scientific and technical skills.'' The president spoke to the American people by television on Wednesday an address that Aspin found inadequate. ``He never once mentioned that Saddam Hussein threatens our national security directly _ and that this is the reason we are deploying troops in Saudi Arabia.'' Instead, Aspin complained, Bush made the deployment ``sound like a good-government exercise.'' ``We aren't sending an army halfway around the world to help some rich oil sheikh get back his throne,'' Aspin said. Aspin said he had written Bush with his ideas, but he did not release the letter.

DOC.HEAD: More Nations Commit Warships to Western Force in Gulf Region
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Arab states joining in, other details. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Australia, Canada and West Germany on Friday committed ships to an international effort to isolate Iraq, and Secretary of State James A. Baker III pressed the NATO allies to do more. In Cairo, 12 Arab states voted Friday night to send troops to protect Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf states. Details of the joint Arab force and its relations, if any, with the U.S.-led multinational air, land and sea force will be worked out later. The United States and Britain also were sending ships to enforce a U.N. economic embargo intended to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. France and the Soviet Union sent ships to the region, independent of the multinational force. At a NATO meeting in Brussels, Baker appealed to the alliance for support. ``We should show that we will do whatever must be done in order to enforce the will of the United Nations,'' Baker said. Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney announced late Friday his country will contribute two destroyers and a supply ship to the multinational force. Representatives from Italy and Belgium indicated at the NATO foreign ministers' meeting that they would announce their decisions on supporting military moves in the next few days. Denmark said it would make ships available to take up gaps in the alliance as U.S. and other ships move into the Gulf. Hans Klein, chief spokesman for the West German government, said his country was sending four or five minesweepers to the Mediterranean in case Iraq tried to mine shipping lanes there. He said the ships might be available for duty in the gulf. Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke announced that two frigates and a supply ship would leave within five days and would be on station in the Persian Gulf in about three weeks. Hawke, who said he was responding to an appeal from President Bush, said the vessels would be ``Australia's contribution to the multinational task force in the Middle East'' and will be used ``to enforce the blockade on Iraq and Kuwait and protect the exports from other oil-producing countries.'' Britain announced Thursday that it was sending two fighter aircraft squadrons, anti-aircraft missiles and other air and sea forces totaling more than 1,000 men to the gulf area as quickly as possible. French President Francois Mitterrand announced Thursday that his nation was increasing its naval and air forces in the gulf but would operate independently of the U.S. force.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Convicted on One Drug Charge, Mistrial Declared on 12 Counts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 7th graf, bgng: Barry was xxx to CORRECT year to 1988.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry was convicted Friday on a single drug charge and acquitted on another. The judge declared a mistrial on 12 counts, including more serious perjury charges, after jurors reported they were deadlocked. An elated Barry took what amounted to a victory lap around the courthouse grounds, surrounded by supporters chanting ``four more years.'' It was a stunning end to a six-week trial that featured an FBI videotape of the mayor smoking crack cocaine in a sting operation. Asked why the jury deadlocked, foreman Edward P. Eagles said, ``Never forget that famous phrase in law, beyond a reasonable doubt. That's a very, very tough standard to meet.'' Barry insisted all along that he had been singled out by vindictive federal prosecutors. He and others argued that the government spent millions singling him out _ in part because he is black _ and the case exposed deep racial divisions in the nation's capital. The jury found Barry guilty of charges that he possessed cocaine in November 1989 with long-time associate Doris Crenshaw. Crenshaw testified that she snorted cocaine with the mayor in her hotel room. Barry was found innocent of charges that he possessed cocaine on Sept. 7, 1988. The jury was hung on the three most serious counts, felony charges that Barry lied to a federal grand jury about his dealings with Charles Lewis, a convicted cocaine dealer who was one of the government's chief witnesses. It also couldn't agree on a verdict on the cocaine possession charge stemming from the FBI sting operation. In the FBI videotape, Barry was seen smoking crack cocaine with former girlfriend Rasheeda Moore at the Vista Hotel on Jan. 18. Juror Johnnie Mae Hardeman said the panel deadlocked 6-6 on the charge arising from that night. The single cocaine possession conviction carries a maximum penalty of one year in jail and a $100,000 fine. U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens said he would review the case before deciding whether to seek a new trial. U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson scheduled a hearing Sept. 17. In a statement that reflected the racial concerns raised by the trial, Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the NAACP, urged the government not to try Barry again. ``We hope that this brings this sad, sad saga to an close,'' he said. A few hours after the verdict was rendered, impromptu celebrations broke out in predominantly black areas of the nation's capital. A short distance from the mayor's house, motorists were honking their horns and shouting ``Barry, Barry,'' and ``Four more years.' Several churches opened for unscheduled services as word spread of the outcome of the trial. All told, Barry was charged with 10 counts of cocaine possession, three counts of perjury and one count of conspiracy to possess cocaine and conceal its use. The mayor said repeatedly that he never used cocaine except for the night of the FBI sting last Jan. 18. It wasn't until closing arguments that Barry's lawyer, R. Kenneth Mundy, acknowledged that Barry had used the drug. Even so, Mundy said the government had failed to prove the specifics of its case. Barry, who sat stonefaced when the single guilty verdict was announced, smiled broadly as Jackson declared the mistrial. He threw his arm around Mundy in celebration. As he left the courthouse, Barry was mobbed by supporters urging him to seek re-election. Barry had said that he would not run for a fourth term, but there has been speculation in recent days that he would change his mind and run as an independent. ``He is relieved, obviously, and this is his 202nd day chemical free,'' his press secretary Lurma Rackley said. Barry, who sought treatment earlier this year for what he said was addiction to alcohol and prescription drugs, planned to make a statement Saturday. Stephens was heckled as he defended the prosecution of the mayor. He said that on the single conviction, the jury had held ``Mr. Barry accountable for his criminal conduct and he must now accept responsibility for that conduct.'' The end to the trial came simply, as the judge asked the jury whether it wanted to resume deliberations on the remaining 12 counts. After conferring in the jury room, the panel said it was deadlocked. ``I am prepared to declare a mistrial on the remaining 12 charges,'' Jackson said. Mundy responded, ``I move ...'' and Jackson nodded in assent. Thirteen witnesses testified during the trial that they had seen the mayor use drugs cocaine, marijuana and opium some 200 times. Mundy conceded the mayor was an occasional cocaine user, but said the prosecution had relied on liars _ ``little Lucifers'' _ to make its case and had failed to prove the charges. Several black leaders suggested that Barry was prosecuted simply because he is a high-profile black politician. Among them was Nation of Islam Minister Louis Farrakhan, who at first was barred from attending the trial. Two whites sat on the 12-member jury. The jury foreman was a white man. Barry came to the city in 1965, a civil rights worker. Three years later, after the assassination of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., the city erupted in its worst racial violence. Barry was often credited with cooling tempers in the aftermath. Many in the black community said they felt betrayed by the mayor, who had made appearance after appearance preaching the evils of drugs to the city's youth. The verdict is the culmination of a criminal investigation that began in December 1988 after the mayor's visits to Lewis' hotel room in Washington, D.C. Lewis testified that Barry used cocaine and crack repeatedly on two trips to the Virgin Islands. He said they also smoked crack in a Washington, D.C., hotel room, and that they conspired to cover up their drug use when police began investigating a complaint that Lewis had offered crack to a hotel maid. Lewis began cooperating with the government a year ago, after he was convicted of drug charges in the Virgin Islands. Barry's lawyers depicted Lewis as a liar who fabricated allegations of drug use to shorten his time in prison. Moore, the government's star witness, testified that she and Barry used drugs together ``at least 100 times'' in hotels, boats and homes around the city from 1986 to 1989. They were lovers for two years, then simply partners in drug use, she said. The defense attacked Moore's credibility and motives. She admitted that she was nearly broke and in trouble with the police when the FBI asked her to cooperate in the sting operation.

DOC.HEAD: More GM Assembly Plants Close As AC Rochester Strike Continues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lede to CLARIFY strike has already idled 10,100. SUBS 8th graf, `GM's Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac...,'' with 3 grafs to UPDATE plant to stay open until Monday and CORRECT 5,500 workers at two plants, sted 9,500. PICKSUP 9th graf pvs., `Dave Michels...'
DOC.TEXT: A version moved on the business wire.

General Motors Corp. said a strike by parts plant workers angry at use of outside parts sources would halt several assembly lines from Michigan to Louisiana, and by Friday it had idled more than 10,000 workers. United Auto Workers officials said the strike by 2,700 employees in Flint proves the union is serious in its opposition to so-called ``outsourcing'' of parts and in its demand for job security in its national contract talks with the Big Three automakers. Negotiations on contracts to replace those that expire Sept. 14 began last month. Workers at the AC Rochester Flint West plant walked out Wednesday over complaints about being assigned more work in the same hours, health and safety grievances and plans to transfer as many as 900 jobs to independent shops and other GM plants. The plant makes about 65 percent of the fuel tanks for GM cars and trucks, along with other parts such as doors for vans and grilles for vans and pickups. To avoid storing large stocks of expensive parts, GM plants rely on just-in-time delivery from parts plants like Flint West, so the effect of a strike spreads quickly. GM's pickup truck and sport utility vehicle assembly plant in Moraine, Ohio, ran out of fuel tanks and closed Thursday, idling about 3,000 workers. GM's Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac Division said statements that its Buick City plant in Flint and its Orion Township plant in Oakland County would close at midnight Friday were premature. ``Today we realized we have enough material to operate on Monday,'' spokeswoman Marsha McGee said. A first shift would run Monday at both the 3,000-worker Orion plant and the 2,500-worker Buick City plant, McGee said. The company will decide on further shifts then, she said. Dave Michels, general manager of the GM Truck & Bus Group plant that assembles pickup trucks and sport-utility vehicles in Shreveport, La., said that plant worked only a few hours Friday before running out of fuel tanks and sending its 2,400 employees home. The Truck and Bus Group's Pontiac West plant sent 2,000 workers home Friday afternoon when it ran out of tanks for the light-duty trucks assembled there, GM spokesman John Maciarz said. GM President Lloyd Reuss said Thursday the AC Rochester Flint West strike could affect six to eight assembly plants by Monday. Negotations were under way. ``We've been exchanging paperwork and talking,'' said Mike Grimes, UAW Local 659 shop chairman. ``We don't want any more people to suffer than have to. We want our people back to work.'' GM wouldn't comment on the implications of the strike on national contract talks. Job security is a major issue as the automakers seek to trim employment levels to cut their costs. ``All I know is we have one local on strike and we have GM plants being affected,'' GM spokesman John Maciarz said. ``Outsourcing is a very serious national concern ... that has strong emotional appeal to GM workers,'' said Harley Shaiken, labor specialist at the University of California at San Diego. During past national negotiations, union leaders have delayed strikes over local issues. The strike at a key plant a month before the contract expires points out the mood of the workers, Shaiken said. ``I think it sends a signal of the discontent of people being told that if you change, and put out your quality, and up your productivity, we'll take care of you _ and then they turn around and keep shipping their work out,'' said Stan Marshall, UAW vice president and director of the union's Chrysler Department.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Demonstrators Protest Justice O'Connor's Visit
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with O'Connor's speech. Picks up 4th graf, `The two groups ...' ^By GREG SMITH
DOC.TEXT: About 100 pro-choice abortion demonstrators carried signs, chanted slogans and staged a ``die-in'' to protest a visit Friday night by Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor. O'Connor addressed about 500 people at the annual banquet of the Herbert Hoover Library Association. But in her 39-minute speech, O'Connor did not touch upon the abortion issue. Instead, she gave a long history of President Hoover's three appointments _ Charles Evans Hughes, Owen J. Roberts and Benjamin Cardozo _ during his term. Hoover's appointees were picked for their qualifications as jurists instead of their political ideology, she said. Hoover believed firmly in the independence of the high court from governmental interference, O'Connor said. ``The court underwent the most fundamental shift in constitutional jurisprudence in the court's history,'' she said. Although O'Connor wasn't in town to speak about abortion, activists from both sides of the issue held demonstrations before the speech. Members of the Reproductive Rights Coalition of Iowa City and New Wave, a student group at the University of Iowa, heavily outnumbered those from the Johnson County Right to Life group, who showed up in support of O'Connor. The two groups yelled at each other and shoved signs in each other's faces but no disturbances broke out. O'Connor, who has said she finds abortion personally abhorrent, has been considered a key vote on abortion. In a 1989 ruling, she joined a 5-4 majority giving states new power to limit abortions. But she stopped short of providing a fifth vote to overturn the basic abortion rights ruling. Carrying a sign splattered with red paint that read, ``Sandra Day Go Away,'' Gregory Eiselein said he blamed O'Connor for ``moving the Supreme Court more and more to the right.'' ``It seems to me that Sandra Day O'Connor has made her impact on the Supreme Court,'' Eiselein said. ``She's leading the overturning of Roe vs. Wade,'' the landmark Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion. Members of the Johnson County Right to Life countered by yelling ``baby killers'' and carried signs just outside the Hoover association's banquet room at the Holiday Inn. ``I think we need to stand up for what's right,'' said Kevin Rocca of Iowa City. ``You can't just sit around and let a bunch of confused people who have their own ideas make policy for the rest of us.'' During the ``die-in,'' about 20 men and women lay on the red bricks of the pedestrian mall outside the hotel. A member of the New Wave group, parodied Supreme Court Chief Justice William Renquist by dressing in a white wig and black robe, stood over them and outlined their bodies with yellow chalk. O'Connor's speech would focus on Hoover's presidency from 1929 to 1933 and his effect on the Supreme Court, said Tom Walsh, executive director of the library association. The Herbert Hoover Library is located in nearby West Branch, birthplace of the nation's 31st president.

An error of about one millimeter _ called ``astonishing'' by one expert for its large size _ has been found in a measuring device used to guide the manufacture of a flawed mirror on the Hubble Space Telescope. A NASA committee investigating the defect that has crippled the $1.5 billion telescope announced Thursday that the millimeter mistake was found while testing the measuring device, called a null corrector. The space telescope, touted as an orbiting observatory that would be able to see objects up to 14 billion light years away, was launched in April. Engineers discovered two months later that a mirror in the device had been manufactured wrong. As a result, the telescope's views of stars are blurred and of severely reduced value to astronomers.

Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner is calling in airline executives to discuss the impact of sharp rises in jet fuel prices that led nearly every major carrier to announce fare increases. Some increases went into effect today, but passengers on most airlines have until next Wednesday to book flights in advance at current fares. Skinner wrote several airline presidents on Thursday, asking them to make appointments with him next Wednesday, Thursday or Friday to discuss how higher jet fuel prices following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait are affecting airline finances and the public. Delta, United and USAir all announced 5.3 percent fare increases Thursday that are to take effect in five days. Several other airlines announced increases earlier.

Bankrupt savings and loans under government management effectively added $1.35 billion to the cost of the thrift bailout in the first three months of the year. Operating losses at the 350 failed, but still open, institutions rose 35 percent from the $1 billion in operating red ink a year earlier, when the S&Ls were still managed privately, the Resolution Trust Corp. said Thursday. However, the operating losses were down 16 percent from $1.61 billion in the last three months of 1989, the bailout agency said. Analysts said the operating loss increase from the first quarter of 1989 does not necessarily mean the insolvent thrifts are being managed poorly by the government.

The Justice Department's challenge to Georgia's majority vote election runoff system ultimately could aid Republican candidates in the South and Southwest _ not blacks, a political observer says. The department sued Thursday, contending that Georgia's election runoff system has had ``a chilling effect on black political participation.'' Ten states in the South and Southwest have laws requiring a runoff election if no candidate receives a majority of the votes in a general election. ``The Republican Party can be made overnight in the South if that runoff law is eliminated,'' said Claiborne Darden, an Atlanta-based pollster. ``That would do more for the Republican Party than Republicans could do for themselves in 125 years.'' Without runoff elections, Darden said, blacks would win more Democratic primaries. But they would lose general elections to GOP candidates backed by white voters who previously supported white Democratic candidates, he said.

Army soldiers, National Guardsmen and federal agents claimed to have destroyed more than 1,400 marijuana plants in a 12-day sweep that drew protests and a lawsuit from residents and civil libertarians. The operation, which ended Thursday, was the first time that active-duty soldiers have been used to fight marijuana growing in the United States. About 50 agents from the Bureau of Land Management and the Drug Enforcement Agency and an estimated 150 Guardsmen and soldiers from Fort Ord took part in Operation Green Sweep, a raid on pot fields in the King Range National Conservation Area. There were no arrests. The rugged, 60,000-acre area and its environs along California's northwestern coast was settled in the early 1970s by hundreds of hippies and homesteaders. Marijuana was widely planted on both public and private land.

DOC.HEAD: Socialist Sanders Running Hard For Vermont's Lone Seat In House
DOC.TEXT: The hopes of maverick congressional candidate Bernard Sanders are rising right along with voters' anger at the Washington insiders who brought them, among other things, the savings and loan scandal. Sanders, a socialist trying to win Vermont's only House seat, says he wants to shake things up on Capitol Hill. He's counting on public discontent with politics-as-usual to help him get there. ``The American people are totally disgusted with the performance of the U.S. Congress,'' said Sanders. Sanders is not the only challenger running against the establishment in an era of skyrocketing federal deficits, ethical violations by politicians and public outrage over the S&L mess. But he's been using the outsider theme longer and more successfully than most. Polls show him within striking distance of Rep. Peter Smith, R-Vt., who narrowly defeated Sanders two years ago in a three-way race. Sanders portrays Smith as a slave to big money, noting that about half his campaign contributions this year have come from political action committees. Smith, on the other hand, portrays Sanders as someone who is unable to work within the system and therefore would be ineffective. ``It sure isn't anger and cynicism that will solve the problems in Congress,'' he said. That debate over style has dominated the race. Although Smith has received a 100 percent rating from the League of Conservation Voters, for example, Vermont environmental activist Cort Richardson endorsed Sanders. He said Smith is not ``a man who is really taking the initiative proposed and working for it ... you don't see the commitment there.'' Sanders' anti-establishment message has not changed over many years and races, from a marginal 1972 Senate bid on the third-party Liberty Union ticket through eight years as mayor of Burlington after a 1981 upset. What has changed is the popularity of that message. At least two independent polls taken in the state this summer indicate that Sanders and Smith are running a tight race for the House, with Democrat Dolores Sandoval lagging behind with between 1 percent and 10 percent of the vote. Smith admitted he's battling the negatives that accompany incumbency this year. ``I don't think there's any doubt that nationally there is concern about the incumbency, and to an extent in Vermont that is there. People on the street say we wish we felt better about Congress,'' Smith said. ``But you can't separate yourself (from Congress). I have to say, here's what I have done since I have gone down there.'' During his first term, Smith has demonstrated some spunk _ voting against the Bush administration 51 percent of the time, leading the call for an independent prosecutor to investigate the S&L debacle, and promoting a crackdown on the sale of semiautomatic weapons. But Sanders is calling for more dramatic moves by Vermont's lone representative. Among his priorities: slashing defense spending by $40 billion annually; nationalizing the health care system; increasing taxes on the wealthy and corporations to pay for expanded human service, education and environmental programs; guaranteeing free public transportation; and mandating trash recycling. Although Smith began the campaign with a $130,000 war chest carried over from the 1988 race, the two matched fund raising during the most recent financial reporting period that ended June 30. Each raised almost $100,000. Sanders recently became embroiled in a controversy when Republicans noted that he had listed all campaign workers as consultants _ and therefore paid no taxes on those staffers. Certain taxes, including Social Security, were paid by the workers; others, including workers compensation and unemployment, were not paid at all. The GOP charges hit close to the bone for Sanders, who has spent much of his political career championing workers' causes and blasting those who fail to pay their fair share of taxes. He is meeting with state and federal tax officials to determine if his bookkeeping methods are legal.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Mon PMS Aug 13 and thereafter

DOC.HEAD: Simplicity and Old-Time Rock 'n' Roll
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It's two hours before show time and guitarist Lonnie Mack is sitting at a table in his tour bus in the parking lot of a roadhouse. He's smoking roll-your-own cigarettes, talking about 30-plus years on the road and thinking ahead _ way ahead if the music world is lucky. ``Till I die,'' he says responding to a question about how long he will keep touring and playing his old-time rock 'n' roll. ``Just keep on. It's my life. I don't know that I'll be out here running in a bus when I'm 80 years old or something. But right now, I'm thinking more of getting into a quieter situation and to think on writing some more. ``I've been sort of letting that go downhill, because we have been running the highways pretty good.'' Mack, 49, was at Fitzgerald's, playing to celebrate the release of his new, live album on Alligator Records, ``Live! Attack of the Killer V.'' It was recorded at the suburban Chicago roadhouse in December. It was the second night of a month-long domestic tour that followed a stint in Europe and would end with a short break before a trip to Australia in August. In the calm before another lay-it-down, sweat-it-out jam, it remains unclear just when Mack will find time for quiet. It doesn't seem to bother him, however. Little does, although the man whose music celebrates simplicity in theme and style has a world of opinions he's willing to share this rainy night. _ The government: ``I'm not really happy about where the government's at at this point.'' _ The nation's education system: ``And in education, you know, I'm not a big believer in the educational system in this country right now, or any country.'' _ Modern music, particularly rap and heavy metal: ``You know, to me it's a joke. It's a joke and it's a bad joke. It's so obvious, I mean the guys are making money at it and that's what they're doing and they're in it for the money and that's strictly what it's about. They ain't in it to send anybody any good vibes.'' What's remarkable here is Mack's frame of reference. Simplicity is the thread that stitches it together. Witness the new record, which captures Mack in the setting most familiar to him these past three decades: on a roadhouse stage backed by bass, drums and keyboard. The result is a rollicking blend of rhythm and blues, gospel and rockabilly that adds up to stripped-bare rock 'n' roll. ``I like simplicity,'' he said. ``I think it's the very thing that made rock 'n' roll become what it was in the first place. ... I mean, you know, `be bop a lula you're my baby' ain't something you got to think a whole lot about.'' A native of Harrison, Ind., Mack has been in the music limelight on and off since his recording of Chuck Berry's ``Memphis'' was released in 1963. He has moved from the stage to the corporate suite, joining Elektra Records as an A&R man for a time, and back to the stage and studio. Mack's latest resurgence began in 1983 when he was persuaded by guitarist Stevie Ray Vaughn to move to Austin, Texas. The two began jamming around town and across the country. Mack's first Alligator record, ``Strike Like Lightning,'' in 1985, was a critical success and helped him attract all-star guests such as Keith Richards, Ron Wood, Ry Cooder and Vaughn on his tour. Since then, Mack's career has been steady and busy. ``But I want to try to get involved in something again that means something,'' he said. ``I mean music is about giving. You're out trying to give people a good time. You want them to enjoy themselves, you know. I mean if you're not, you feel like a failure.'' Mack delivers his aphorisms in a southern Indiana drawl that gives them more impact. The underlying conviction comes partly from realizing that he needs to please himself first. ``In the old days it used to be I was very concerned with going out and really pleasing the audience, trying to figure out the audience, do exactly what they wanted me to do, do all their requests,'' he said. ``You do this, you do everything, but most generally you find in a large group that there's no way you can do that, so the first thing you've got to do is please yourself. And if you make yourself happy and you look happy and you're having a good time, it'll show usually.'' Commercial success is another question. But once again, Mack is at ease. ``A little more wouldn't hurt,'' he said with a pause. ``A little less, I could still live with.''
