DOC.HEAD: Shanna Reed of `Major Dad' Toughs It Out
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Shanna Reed spent a summer week roughing it in the backwoods of Maine _ a tough-it-out struggle which might serve her well in her new job with the Marines in CBS' ``Major Dad.'' In the coming fall season, Maj. J.D. ``Mac'' McGillis (played by Gerald McRaney) is transferred to a small Marine base in Virginia. Reed plays his wife Polly, who braves the hazards of a job on the post newspaper. The show began last year with Major McGillis as a gung-ho Marine, a bachelor in his early 40s, who has a whirlwind courtship with a widow with three daughters and suddenly finds himself in a house full of females. In the break between seasons of ``Major Dad,'' Reed went on a strenuous canoeing trip on the Androscoggin River and Umbagog Lake in Maine. The canoe trip had some aspects of a military adventure. ``There were 12 of us, including two guides, in six canoes,'' she said. ``Every day we had different duties, like navigator one day, cook the next. The guides didn't interfere. We took a wrong turn one day and had to paddle back. ``We forgot our tents, so we roughed it. I covered myself head to foot and wrapped myself in mosquito netting and still got bit. The thing I got the most out of was the teamwork. Everyone needed someone else.'' In the second season of ``Major Dad,'' the show moves to Virginia and enlists three new characters. The camp is on the bubble _ military cutbacks threaten it with closing. A lot of the comic conflict, however, will come from Polly's new job as a reporter on the camp newspaper. ``Mac's in charge of the newspaper, so her articles will be edited by Mac and the general,'' she said. ``She'll have to do some rewriting. I'll be the editor of the feature section, called `At Ease.' We'll live on base, so the kids will also be involved in the military system.'' ``Major Dad'' is the fourth series for Reed. She was in ``For Love and Honor'' (another military series), ``I Had Three Wives'' and ``The Colbys.'' She was also a semi-regular on ``HeartBeat'' and starred in the soap opera ``Texas.'' ``Polly's feisty, and I know that's an overused description, and intelligent and independent,'' Reed said. ``She'll jump in over her head and find herself overwhelmed. I want to see more of that, where you have someone who's not completely comfortable in her environment. She has a lot of good qualities. I don't have kids, but I hope to be the kind of parent she is. She values communication and honesty with her kids. ``She's a romantic at heart. An overboard romantic, which I'd like to see more of. We have to keep romance a prominent part of the show. I think Mac and I have good chemistry. You have to get to the husband and wife and get beyond their work.'' Reed was born in Kansas City, but grew up in Phoenix. She began dancing at 16, and after a year of college went to Las Vegas and joined the Folies Bergere at the Tropicana. ``I was very green, but I had a lot of energy. I never thought about acting until I spent a year and a half in the road company of `A Chorus Line.' I moved to New York and got into the stage play `Dancin',' and I started taking acting lessons.'' Reed is married to Terrence O'Hara, a movie director and former actor she met in acting class. In addition to Reed's camping adventure, she went to Europe this summer to appear in the latest remake of ``Three Coins in the Fountain,'' the story of three women seeking romance and fun in Rome. This version, co-starring Loni Anderson, Stepfanie Kramer and Anthony Newly, will be broadcast on CBS. The original, which won an Oscar for its theme song, was made in 1954. A remake was released 10 years later, but the location was moved to Spain. The latest edition returns to Rome, but only a bit was filmed in the Eternal City. ``We filmed most of it in Luxembourg, using it for Rome,'' Reed said. ``Apparently it was cheaper and they had a warehouse we used for a sound stage. They were shooting a `Dracula' movie at the same time we were there.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for weekend editions, Aug. 24-26

DOC.HEAD: Past Use of Economic Santions Not That Successful
DOC.TEXT: The United States has achieved only limited success with coercive economic sanctions like those being used against Iraq, in part because of the difficulty in rallying the rest of the world behind them. But Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait may have changed the nature of the game. In the week since Iraqi tanks lumbered across the Kuwaiti border, the oil-dependent world, with a rarely seen unanimity, has cut off Iraqi oil shipments, barred all trade with Iraq and frozen billions of dollars of Kuwaiti assets to shield them from Iraqi looting. At the same time, U.S. forces are being deployed to the Middle East to guard against an Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia. ``I would think that if this international lesson is taught well, Saddam Hussein would act differently in the future,'' President Bush told a news conference last week. ``... A line has been drawn in the sand. We're getting strong support from around the world for what we've done.''. The economic offensive against Iraq has long and tangled roots. In 432 B.C. the Athenian leader Pericles declared economic war against Megara, a rival Greek City state. History does not record the results. But the results were clear in 1935 after the League of Nations imposed sanctions against Benito Mussolini's Italy for its invasion of Abyssinia, now Ethiopia. There was no deterrent effect although the action was seen by some as a public relations boon for participating countries. British political leader Lloyd George said, cynically, that the sanctions ``came too late to save Abyssinia, but they're just in the nick of time to save the (British) government.'' In the early 1980s, a grain embargo imposed by President Carter failed to persuade the Soviet Union to withdraw from Afghanistan. Moscow found the grain it needed elsewhere. American farmers complained they had been forced to suffer needlessly. Critics said the United States had aimed at the Soviet bear and ``shot itself in the foot,'' a phrase used repeatedly since then by congressional opponents of other attempts to impose sanctions. In a 1985 study published by the Institute for International Economics, Gary Clyde and Jeffrey Schott said economic sanctions had been used successfully only 39 times since 1914. In the remaining 69 cases, they said, the sanctions had little effect. American attempts to use the economic weapon have most often failed because other countries could not be persuaded to follow the U.S. lead. John Spanier, professor of political science at the University of Florida, says sanctions work best when there is widespread agreement by many nations about the wisdom or necessity of employing them. ``Individual national sanctions are rarely effective,'' he said in his book ``Games Nations Play.'' ``Sanctions will inflict only temporary pain if alternative sources of supplies and export markets are available,'' Spanier said. Some examples of Washington's experience with sanctions: _In 1988, U.S. sanctions wrecked the fragile Panamanian economy but did not dislodge the country's ruler, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. It took a U.S. invasion to do that. _The longstanding U.S. embargo of Fidel Castro's Cuba has done little to erode his hold on the country but has caused considerable economic difficulty. _Bush's economic sanctions against China after the 1989 massacre in Tiananmen Square in Beijing resulted in only token moderation in that nation's policies. Some of those sanctions have been eased. _President Carter's decision to stop U.S. purchases of Iranian oil after the 1979 seizure of the U.S. Embassy in Tehran gave an impression the administration was acting firmly in the hostage crisis. But it was largely symbolic since the United States purchased little Iranian oil. On the other hand, the sanctions imposed by the United States and other nations against South Africa's white minority government may have significantly slowed that nation's rate of economic growth and been a potent psychological factor in persuading white leaders to deal with the black majority. Aside from Iraq, U.S. economic sanctions still are in effect against South Africa, Libya, Cuba, Vietnam, North Korea and Cambodia. Before the Kuwaiti invasion, the Bush administration had objected to proposals for sanctions against Iraq. John Kelly, assistant secretary of State for Middle Eastern affairs, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on June 15 that ``based on past experience, we do not believe that legislating unilateral trade and economic sanctions would help us to achieve U.S. goals with Iraq.'' He said then that there was ``no prospect'' then that other nations would follow the U.S. lead. The situation changed drastically after Saddam's troops headed into Kuwait. The United States was joined by the Soviet Union in a joint condemnation of Iraq. Moscow cut off the flow of weapons to its erstwhile Middle East ally. Iraq's other major arms suppliers, including China, said they would do the same. The 12-nation European Economic Community followed the United States in imposing stiff economic sanctions. So did Japan. The United Nations Security Council voted comprehensive and mandatory trade and business sanctions, and directed Saudi Arabia and Turkey to cut off the flow of Iraqi oil through pipelines which cross their national territory. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher conceded a naval blockade might be necessary to stop the export of Iraqi oil by ship. And Bush dispatched air, naval and ground forces to shield Saudi Arabia from possible Iraqi attack. While some questioned the long-term will of the United States and its allies to accept the sanction-related rise in oil prices, others were optimistic that the sanctions would work. Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., a former chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said: ``Iraq's wealth comes only from oil and it is a food dependent country. That leaves it in a state of comparative weakness. Sanctions on food and oil will cause grave damage to the economy of Iraq.'' During the Reagan administration, after Iraq had been accused of using poison gas against its Kurdish minority, the Senate voted three times and the House twice to impose sanctions against Iraq. But the administration successfully squelched them on grounds that they would hurt U.S. agricultural exports and hinder rather than enhance efforts to encourage Hussein to show restraint. Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., said the failure to send Hussein a strong message against the use of poison gas may have encouraged him on the path that eventually led his tanks across the Kuwaiti border.

DOC.HEAD: Here It Comes Again: Gas Nozzle Pointed at America's Head
DOC.TEXT: This isn't the first time Americans have been forced to pay more for gas while U.S. oil companies profited from turmoil in the Middle East. Think back 17 years, to the Arab oil embargo of 1973, to lines at gas stations and rules restricting fill-ups to odd or even days. The circumstances were different, but the scenario was the same: The nozzle of the gas pump was held to Uncle Sam's head like a gun. Despite the jolt of that five-month embargo and a replay in 1979 during the Iranian revolution, the United States is more dependent than ever on foreign countries for its oil habit. ``This country went back to sleep on energy about 1980. Now we're in a defensive position and we don't have a game plan,'' said David Freeman, a California utility executive and an energy adviser to Presidents Johnson and Nixon. ``We were led to believe by our leaders in the 1980s we could have a party, we could go back to gas guzzling and we could continue the joyride,'' Freeman said. ``To continue the joyride on Arab oil is a risky proposition.'' The 1973 action was a producer embargo. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries shut off the tap to the United States for its support of Israel in the 1973 war with Egypt. What's going on today is a consumer embargo. The United States won't take any oil from Iraq because of its Aug. 2 absorption of Kuwait. So Americans must either make up the difference somewhere else, or make sacrifices. Although there is no shortage of oil in the United States or the world, prices rose 18 cents a gallon at the pump by Friday. Seven airlines also raised ticket prices to offset higher fuel costs. Reaction was as wrathful as it was in 1973, when most Americans blamed the oil companies and the government for their plight and not the Arabs, according to the National Opinion Research Center in Chicago. Oil companies back then pocketed record profits while gasoline escalated from 39 cents a gallon to 53 cents before the embargo ended March 18, 1974. ``A more cynical view lays the fault for this country's present difficulties to the economic greed of the oil industry,'' the American Association for the Advancement of Science said in a study at the time. Compare that to current charges of war profiteering. ``The big oil companies have gone on a feeding frenzy. This isn't panic. This is greed,'' said Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., chairman of the Senate consumer subcommittee. ``They're ripping us off,'' said New York Gov. Mario Cuomo. ``We think the oil companies carried out a pre-emptive strike not unlike Saddam Hussein's strike into Kuwait,'' said Ed Rothschild, energy policy coordinator for Citizen Action, a national consumer group based in Washington. ``They raised prices and made an immediate windfall profit.'' The oil companies contend they have acted responsibly this time, and several have publicized price decreases following a warning by President Bush against gouging. Bush also has appealed to Americans to conserve oil to head off any future shortages. He made no specific demands, saying instead that ``Americans everywhere must do their part.'' His predecessors had to take much harsher action. In 1973, the United States, then as now the biggest consumer of oil in the world, paid dearly for its insatiable oil thirst. Gas stations, if they were able to stay open, had two-mile long queues of customers who sometimes waged fist fights for gas. President Nixon ordered stations closed on Sunday, and sales were rationed on odd-even days based on license plate numbers. Billions of ration coupons were printed but never used. Thermostats were ordered set at 68 degrees in the winter, and the national speed limit was set at 55 mph to conserve. The country went on year-round daylight savings time. Independent truckers, outraged at seeing the price of diesel fuel double, parked their rigs and halted shipments _ sometimes violently. Armed convoys of the National Guard delivered goods and Army helicopters patrolled some highways. Things eased when the embargo was lifted, at least until 1979 when the Shah of Iran was deposed and Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini turned off his country's petroleum spigot. Gas prices skyrocketed from 69 cents to more than $1, long lines forced a reprise of odd-even rationing and angry truckers again shut down. President Carter, wearing a symbolic sweater, ordered thermostats at settings that would save energy. He also installed solar panels on the White House roof to heat water. Then Iran and Iraq began pumping more oil to pay for killing each other. A worldwide surplus grew in the early 1980s and finally resulted in a tumultuous price collapse four years ago, when prices plunged from more than $30 a barrel to under $10. Oil was cheap, and the energy shortage was ancient history. That situation more or less prevailed until recent months, when Iraq began making noises about raising oil prices to repay war debts. Then the Iraqis invaded oil-rich neighbor Kuwait Aug. 2 and threatened Saudi Arabia, owner of the world's richest oil reserves. Once more, American vulnerability is exposed. A nation with 6 percent of the world's population drinks up 27 percent of the world's oil. Half of the country's oil consumption _ 16.9 million barrels a day _ must be imported. That's a bigger percentage of imports than 1973, when about one-third of the oil came from foreign sources and dreams of self-sufficiency disappeared like exhaust fumes. Oil is the nation's top energy source. Oil accounts for 42 percent of U.S. energy needs, and about 63 percent of all oil used goes for transportation, mainly the 180 million cars, trucks and buses on U.S. highways. In 1973, 47 percent of the nation's energy came from oil. About 53 percent went for transportation, according to the Department of Energy. Some things have changed. Since 1973, the reliance on oil to make electricity has been halved. The average car got 12 miles per gallon in 1973 and was half as efficient as foreign cars. Today, the average is 27.8 mpg but the trend in Detroit is back to luxury, gas-guzzlers. Utilities pitched better insulation, weather stripping and more efficient bulbs and appliances to hold down increases in electric bills. The government established a stock of 590 million gallons of oil called the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which hasn't been tapped yet. But 40 states have raised the speed limit to 65 mph. President Reagan removed those solar panels from the White House roof. And even the oil interests see a disturbing trend back to old habits. ``As long as the price wasn't too high and the product was available, nobody has been thinking about it,'' said Joseph Lastelic, spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute. ``You're not going to save your way out of it when you have lots of cars, lots of air conditioners, a high standard of living and all those wonderful things,'' Lastelic said. ``People are not likely to give most of that up.''

DOC.HEAD: Controversy Bedevils Teaching of History in Modern Britain
DOC.TEXT: British students learn all about Florence Nightingale, the heroic nurse of the Crimean battlefields, but what of Mary Seacole, a Jamaican nurse who served with equal devotion in the same war? Therein lies the heart of an intellectual wrangle over how history should be taught in British schools. One side says Britain's own history comes first. The other believes that, in what has become an ethnically diverse country, one child's footnote is another's historical landmark. Most students know about Cecil Rhodes, the Victorian empire builder who dreamed of a Cape-to-Cairo railroad. But how many have heard of King William Dappa Pepple Bonny V of Nigeria, who was exiled with his wife Annie from their realm and lived in London in the 19th century? British children learn about Anglo-Saxon settlers, but the contribution of Jewish settlers in the Middle Ages is often overlooked. Debate centers on a national ``core'' curriculum mandated by the Education Reform Bill of 1988 in history as well as English, math and science-technology. The reform limits local choices, but does not do away with them. The curriculum recommended by a history study group ``is the only one that has generated the heat,'' Rozina Visram, a former teacher, said in an interview. ``Academics from high and mighty universities have thrown their hats into the ring. No other document has been given such a long consultation.'' Those who approach history as a force in molding national pride and identity view the curriculum reform as a means of regaining the ground that has been slipping away since the liberal 1960s. They want a return to teaching Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's ``great landmarks of British history'': the life of King Henry VIII, Nelson's victory at Trafalgar, the Battle of Waterloo, the Battle of Britain. Opponents contend minority history must be included in a country whose ethnic minorities now total 2.6 million people. Children of the inner cities will not ``switch on to an all-white male experience,'' said Sylvia Collicott, a senior lecturer at the North London Polytechnic. ``In the classroom, you can't tell kids what to do; they won't do that anymore. They expect to be engaged. They won't sit there and take that.'' Local schools have adapted to the cultural changes. In Bradford, where 53 of the 231 schools have non-white majorities, students learn a little of everything. Tonnie Ecker's children attend Birkby School in Kirkliees, suburban Bradford, where ``just about every ethnic festival is celebrated.'' ``It's wonderful,'' she said. ``They come back and tell you the stories about various gods and all that. Sometimes their hands are covered for three days with mehandi patterns,'' butterfly or flower designs painted in a reddish dye. The reform does not prohibit local diversity and ethnic celebrations, but critics say it makes so many detailed prescriptions of what should be in the curriculum that it leaves no room for ethnic studies. Robert Skidelsky, a historian at Warwick University, said history trains people for citizenship, ``and it touches many raw nerves.'' So vehemently have academics disagreed that some fear the government will abandon the history reforms.. Skidelsky got into the debate when his son took a test that instructed him to ``imagine that you are a Palestinian gunman attacking the Israeli Olympic team in Munich.'' The question was part of the empathy theory of teaching history, which asks students to imagine themselves as players on the historical stage. ``There were too many theories floating around,'' Skidelsky said in an interview. ``Pupils were becoming guinea pigs.'' Michael Barber, education policy director for the National Union of Teachers, feels the curriculum is too detailed. ``What we need at the national level is an interstate highway map of the country, as opposed to a map of all the local state roads and footpaths,'' said Barber, a former high school history teacher. For instance, the working group's says students aged 7 to 11 should study invaders and settlers; the Romans, Anglo-Saxons and Vikings in Britain; life in Tudor and Stuart times; Victorian Britain; ancient Egypt and Greece, and exploration from 1450 to 1550. Each topic is divided into four areas: political; economic, technological-scientific; social-religious, and cultural-aesthetic. ``There are hundreds and hundreds of detailed prescriptions,'' said Ted Wragg, director of Exeter University's school of education. He finds the proposals arbitrary. As an example, he said, students aged 14 to 16 studying modern American history would be required to learn about President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., but President John F. Kennedy and the civil rights movement would be optional. Detractors, including the teachers' union, say less than the recommended 50 percent of class time should be devoted to British history. Mrs. Thatcher supports a heavy emphasis on British history and told the House of Commons concentrating on the names of England's kings and queens, statesmen and battles was ``absolutely right.'' Skidelsky feels the proposed curriculum benefits the majority: ``Some areas have got to adopt entirely unconventional methods, but most people in Britain are part of the great middle class bulge and go to a very standard school.'' Although the opposition Labor Party accused Mrs. Thatcher of seeking to indoctrinate children with her own view of history, Skidelsky doesn't believe politics is involved. ``The government has felt a responsiblity to increase its involvement because of testing which shows British school children are behind those in other countries,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Aug. 19

DOC.TEXT: Oil prices sank and stocks advanced for the second straight day in the absence of fresh shocks from the Persian Gulf. In the stock market, the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks gained 24.01 on Thursday to finish at 2,758.91, extending a rebound that began with a 24.26-point jump Wednesday. In the oil market, the September contract for U.S. crude oil lost 29 cents to settle at $25.67 per 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract had plummeted $2.35 per barrel Wednesday.

More big oil companies froze or trimmed gasoline prices, with some cutting nearly a nickel a gallon, amid public outcry over alleged price gouging following tensions in the Persian Gulf. Others said Thursday they were holding prices steady and promised to abide by requests from President Bush and lawmakers to practice restraint. Texaco Inc., BP America Inc., Conoco Inc. and Phillips Petroleum Corp. said they trimmed gasoline prices from a penny to 4 cents a gallon. Those announcing temporary price freezes included Amoco, Unocal and Getty Petroleum Corp.

Emergency oil stockpiles do not yet need to be tapped to make up for an embargo against Iraq and Kuwait, delegates from industrialized nations decided. But the 21-nation International Energy Agency will take steps to ``sharpen preparedness if the situation deteriorates,'' Chairman Ulrich Engelmann said Thrusday. The IEA decided enough oil exists on world markets to forestall dipping into emergency reserves.

William H. Donaldson, a Wall Street veteran and friend of President Bush, was named chairman and chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange. Donaldson, 59, was named Thursday will succeed John J. Phelan Jr., who won wide praise for safely steering the nation's largest exchange through the 1987 stock market crash and helping to avert a protracted world financial crisis. Donaldson, a co-founder of the investment firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., brings broad experience on Wall Street, in government and academia to one of the most high-profile jobs in American business.

Federal regulators moved to recover $40.9 million from Charles H. Keating Jr. and five associates for losses the regulators claim the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan suffered from sour business deals. The Office of Thrift Supervision on Thursday also demanded a complete accounting within five days of Keating's personal assets as it seeks restitution from the Arizona businessman and his associates. The office said regulators do not believe Keating's repeated claim that he went broke when his American Continental Corp., the Phoenix-based holding company that owned Lincoln, filed for bankruptcy protection.

Promotions to move out summer merchandise and good weather boosted business at some big store chains in July. But modest industrywide sales growth failed to impress analysts who predict possibly tighter times in retailing for the rest of the year. Industry analysts said Thursday there was a continuation last month of a gradual slowdown in consumer spending. An index of 17 leading chains compiled by Merrill Lynch & Co. indicated that sales at stores open at least a year rose 5.7 percent in July from a year earlier, little different from June's 5.8 percent year-to-year gain.

Operating losses at the 350 bankrupt savings institutions controlled by the government at the end of March soared 35 percent from a year earlier when they were still privately run, the government said. The Resolution Trust Corp., created a year ago to conduct the S&L cleanup, said Thursday operating losses in the January-March quarter totaled $1.35 billion, up from $1 billion in the same period of 1989. The losses were down from $1.61 billion in the last three months of 1989.

Farmers are looking at a potential 1990 corn harvest of 7.85 billion bushels, up 4 percent from last year, the Agriculture Department said. The fall's harvest would be the largest since 8.25 billion bushels in 1986. The department said Thursday that dry conditions in the southeastern states reduced yields in most areas from the record levels of 1989.

An attorney formerly with a prestigious corporate law firm was accused of selling inside information about planned takeovers in a multimillion-dollar trading scheme. Steven L. Glauberman was charged Thursday with four counts of conspiracy, securities fraud and wire fraud in a criminal information brought by the U.S. attorney's office in Manhattan. Glauberman, 39, was an associate at the New York firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, where he specialized in mergers and acquisitions.

Bond prices rallied Thursday as the market cheered the successful conclusion of the government's quarterly auctions to refund the national debt. The dollar turned in a mixed performance. Grain analysts predicted a rally in corn and soybean futures prices after the Agriculture Department released harvest projections that fell short of market expectations. Soybean futures rose, wheat futures advanced while corn retreated. On other commodity markets, gold and silver futures advanced; and livestock and meat futures were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: UPS Customers Getting Creative, Warning of Delays And Higher Costs
With PM-UPS Strike, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: With the possibility of a strike at United Parcel Service of America, Inc., businesses already have switched to other delivery services, passing on higher costs and warning of slower shipments. The two choices closest to the ground-based service offered by UPS are the United States Postal Service and Roadway Package System, Inc., of Pittsburgh. Other companies, such as TNT Skypak, Federal Express, and DHL Worldwide Express, are mainly air-delivery services with faster service, but also higher prices. Beechmont Press, a commercial publishing company in Louisville, Ky., switched to RPS because it was afraid its packages might get stuck in the UPS system if a strike was called, said Beverly Anderson, a customer service representative. She said Beechmont was also using Federal Express for areas not serviced by RPS, and the added costs were being passed on to the consumer. ``It's not nearly as handy as UPS,'' Anderson said. UPS ``came here every night and loaded up the skid and was gone and that was the end of it. Now, there's a lot more planning.'' Land's End, an in-home catalog giant based in Dodgeville, Wis., has given its customers one option of spending $5 more per shipment to have goods sent via Federal Express, said spokeswoman Charlotte LaComb. LaComb said the apparel company has told customers reluctant to spend the extra money _ the $5 is in addition to a regular $3.50 handling charge _ that their other option is to order the merchandise and have Land's End hold it until the UPS situation is settled. The company already sends a small percentage of merchandise through the U.S. Postal Service, she said. But the Postal Service announced in late July that it wouldn't be able to absorb UPS's business if there was a strike. The Teamsters union has threatened UPS with a nationwide strike if a new three-year contract is rejected by its 150,000 members at UPS. Teamsters officials will start counting ballots Friday, and an announcement of the outcome could take several days. UPS delivers more than 10 million packages a day, 20 times more than the Postal Service. The Postal Service has developed contingency plans that would restrict to four the number of parcels that any one customer could send, and would require shippers of large numbers of packages to make reservations. Other companies are also turning to the Postal Service, including L.L. Bean, Inc., an outdoor clothing company based in Freeport, Maine, and Bruce Medical Supply, a home medical supply company based in Waltham, Mass. ``To the extent we can, we're allocating more than we would normally to the Postal Service,'' said L.L. Bean spokesman Kilton Andrew. L.L. Bean sent 70 percent of its 11.3 million packages via UPS in 1989, he said. Andrew said the company is using the Postal Service to deliver to points west of the Mississippi. Richard Najarian, president of Bruce Medical Supply, which sends up to 1,500 packages a day, said once a UPS contract is signed, his company is likely to return to the familiar boxy, brown trucks. ``It's really the only show in town,'' Najarian said. Spiegel Inc., of Oak Brook, Ill., the nation's largest in-home catalog company, has been making contingency plans since the beginning of July, spokeswoman Mary Dale Walters said. ``It's the first time in a long time our system has been really put to the test, but you can't survive in this business unless you have a degree of flexibility,'' Walters said. She said Spiegel, which sends out 50,000 packages by UPS each day, will send packages by other means and using other routes, but declined to discuss specifics.

DOC.HEAD: Lorenzo Replacement Harris Has Solid Reputation With Industry, Union
With PM-Continental-Lorenzo, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hollis L. Harris, the Delta Air Lines Inc. veteran named to replace Frank Lorenzo as head of Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., has a solid reputation in the industry and said he's looking forward to the new job. ``I wanted to be the chief executive officer of a major U.S. airline,'' Harris, 58, said Thursday. As president and chief operating officer at Delta, he was No. 2 to Chairman and CEO Ronald W. Allen. Allen is several years younger than Harris, ``so the chances of doing it at Delta are very slim,'' Harris said. Harris spoke with Lorenzo at a New York news briefing held to announce the change. Lorenzo, the CEO of his airline holding company for nearly two decades, told reporters his replacement is one of the most able in the business and said ``we're very excited to be able to attract Hollis Harris.'' Terms of his new job weren't disclosed, but industry analysts said it was likely to be a lucrative deal that could make Harris wealthy. ``It's a chance for him to maximize his financial net worth before he retires. I'm sure he got an attractive stock ownership package,'' said Kevin C. Murphy, an airline industry analyst with Morgan Stanley in New York. Lorenzo, one of the most well known figures in the industry, said he was getting out of the business after a stormy life at the center of major labor disputes at Continental and Eastern airlines. Harris entered Delta's executive suites in 1969 as vice president in charge of facilities and became president in 1987. He started at the company in 1954 as a transportation agent in Atlanta. ``The decision to leave Delta after 36 years was not an easy one,'' Harris said, but he called the new position ``a challenge I cannot resist.'' Lorenzo praised his successor, calling Harris ``one of the industry's most experienced and highly regarded executives.'' Analyst Murphy agreed. ``I think it's a real coup (for Continental),'' he said. ``It's a loss for Delta, but Delta has such capable layers of management that they'll be able to survive. Life will go on for Delta,'' Murphy said. Delta officials said Allen would assume Harris' duties. Harris will be entering a much more heated labor environment than he ever faced at Delta, where, other than the pilots and dispatchers, the employees are non-union. But Rhea Nicolls, a spokesman for the local Air Line Pilots Association, the union which represents Delta pilots, said Harris would be a positive influence at Continental. ``After Frank Lorenzo, everyone will be very happy to have Hollis Harris there,'' Nicolls said. ``He's fair and honest, and has always been a real gentleman. ``He had a good reputation'' with the union, Nicolls said.

DOC.HEAD: Became Known As Anti-Union During Stormy Career
DOC.TEXT: Frank Lorenzo parlayed his airline holding company into a leading force in the industry, but along the way incurred the wrath of organized labor which vilified him as a union buster. The inability of Lorenzo and the unions to make peace with each other played an indirect but important role in his announcement Thursday that he was exiting the airline business after more than two decades. The 50-year-old entrepreneur, who came to symbolize a tumultuous decade of airline deregulation, said he is selling most of his stake in Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. to Scandinavian Airlines System. The leading foreign carrier has held a small stake in Houston-based Continental for two years. Lorenzo also is resigning as chairman and chief executive, to be replaced by Delta Air Lines Inc. President Hollis L. Harris, a highly respected manager lured to Continental after a discreet search that started four months ago. The negative publicity that came to haunt Lorenzo and his company was an important element in his decision to get out, Lorenzo told reporters at a news briefing in New York. ``It's been perfectly obvious to me that I personally have become a lightning rod for many of the attacks that the company has taken in the process of making the changes that have been required,'' Lorenzo said. ``This transaction allows me to step aside and allows the company to have a new management,'' he said. Asked what he would do now, Lorenzo said, ``Take a little time to catch my breath. I haven't had much time to do that.'' The departure of Lorenzo marks the end of an era, but it didn't end the criticism of him by organized labor. ``We can all shout `hallelujah!,''' said E.J. Breen, chairman of the Eastern Airlines pilots strike committee. ``Clearly, nobody denies his genius to put deals together. But as for his ability to operate (airlines), he's a complete failure,'' Breen said in a telephone interview from Miami, where Eastern is headquartered. ``The way I'll remember him is as a tyrant who destroyed lives and walked away with pockets full of money and not a care in the world for what he has done.'' Others reacted with a similar mix of satisfaction and resentment. The International Association of Machinists, which has led the Eastern strike from the start, said he was largely responsible for the problems in his company. ``Frank Lorenzo demolished Eastern Airlines, wreaked havoc on thousands of workers' lives and severely devalued Continental Airlines,'' said John Peterpaul, IAM general vice president. ``Our condolences to whatever industry he stalks next.'' Lorenzo will get nearly $30 million in severance payments and sale proceeds. But that is only a fraction of what his airlines were worth years ago in better times. From his plunge into the flying business in the 1960s, the Harvard MBA helped pioneer innovations ranging from cut-rate fares to the industry's first hostile takeover. Lorenzo built his holding company into the largest airline company in the country, owning both Continental and Eastern. In 1966, he and Harvard classmate Robert Carney formed a financial advisory firm. Two years later, they created Jet Capital Corp., which bought a controlling interest in Texas International Airlines in 1972. Lorenzo, then 32, was the carrier's youngest president. His image as a union buster began when he fought organized labor at Continental Airlines and won. In 1981, Lorenzo merged Texas International with Continental after a bitter takeover battle. Two years later, he put Continental, then the nation's eighth-largest carrier, under bankruptcy protection, scrapped labor contracts and hired strike replacements at lower pay. Lorenzo subsequently acquired New York Air, People Express and Frontier airlines, which have been merged into Continental. He didn't face another labor fight until he acquired Eastern. The unions waged a bitter strike against the carrier and made Lorenzo the target of their hatred. Lorenzo lost control of Eastern altogether in April when U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland placed the airline in the hands of trustee Martin Shugrue. Texas Air Corp. then changed its name to Continental Airlines Holdings.

DOC.HEAD: More Oil Companies Lower Or Freeze Prices
DOC.TEXT: The public outcry over alleged price gouging has apparently lead more big oil companies to trim or freeze thier gasoline prices, with some cutting nearly a nickel a gallon. Others said they were holding prices steady and promised to abide by requests from President Bush and lawmakers to practice restraint during the rising tensions in the Persian Gulf. Four big companies _ Texaco Inc., BP America Inc., Phillips Petroleum Co. and Conoco Inc. _ announced Thursday they were trimming gasoline prices, with cuts ranging from a penny to 4 cents a gallon. The Phillips reduction of 1.8 cents a gallon was the second cut in two days. Those announcing temporary price freezes included Amoco Corp., Unocal Corp. and Getty Petroleum Corp. The companies said they largely were responding to the recent easing of oil prices following a sharp runup after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. But industry analysts said the companies also couldn't ignore the pubic outcries of price gouging and Bush's admonition. Service station owners applauded the action and many were expected to eventually pass on their savings to motorists. ``A random sampling shows that some already have lowered their prices 1 or 2 cents a gallon. Those that don't will at least keep their prices the same,'' said Joseph L. Koach, executive director of the Service Station Dealers of America in Washington. A spot check of gas stations Thursday by the American Automobile Association of America said prices on average continued to increase nationally but at a much slower rate than in recent days. It said the average price of self-service unleaded regular was $1.237 a gallon, up 1 to 2 cents from Wednesday. Unleaded gas has risen more than 16 cents a gallon since Iraq invaded Kuwait. On Wednesday, Atlantic Richfield Co. froze its wholesale gas prices for a week and Phillips Petroleum Co. cut its price by 4.5 cents a gallon after Bush in a nationally televised speech urged big oil companies to show price restraint. Other big companies like Exxon Corp., Chevron Corp., Mobil Corp. and Shell Oil Co., said they haven't raised prices in recent days and would practice restraint in making any future price changes. All the companies said any pricing decisions would directly reflect market conditions. The oil companies have been denying allegations by consumer groups and politicians that they've been using instability in the Persian Gulf as an excuse to drive up prices at the pumps. The companies said the increases reflected a huge jump in crude prices on the open markets as well as the threat that oil supplies might be disrupted. ``Since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, crude prices have increased approximately 35 percent and the openly traded market for gasoline supplies has jumped about 20 cents a gallon,'' Houston-based Shell Oil Co. said in a statement. Although Koach said many gas stations would be in a good position to pass on oil company rollbacks to their customers, some experts said it may take some time for stations to actually realize any savings. That is because gas deliveries vary, from as little as once a week to as frequent as three times a week. Koach also indicated it might be hard for some station operators to lower prices now, especially those who had been reluctant to pass on the previous price increases for fear of losing customers. ``It's economic suicide to bite the hand that feeds you,'' said Dennis DeCota, owner of Red Hill Union 76 station in Novato, Calif., about 35 miles north of San Francisco. DeCota said he had raised prices 11 cents a gallon since the Iraqi invasion, but more than half of that went to offset a recent gas tax instituted in California. Among the specific changes announced Thursday: _Texaco cut its gasoline price to resellers by as much as 3 cents a gallon. _BP cut prices at its gas pumps by 3 cents per gallon. _Conoco lowered by 3 to 4 cents its wholesale prices for gasoline and by a penny its price for diesel fuel. _Getty froze gas prices for a week. _Unocal froze prices until Aug. 16. Oil companies have been criticized frequently since gas prices soared from about 39 cents a gallon in 1973 to 53 cents a year later following the Arab oil embargo. Prices climbed to 69 cents by 1978, before surging above $1 when Iranian supplies were cut off after its 1979 revolution. More recently, prices jumped after the Exxon Valdez spill off the Alaska coast last year and heating oil skyrocketed during a severe December freeze. Despite allegations, no profiteering or collusion by companies was proven. In defending the price hikes, companies have said that while it can take up to 90 days for crude oil to reach the United States from the Middle East, companies usually pay the market price in effect when it arrives at the refinery, not the price when it was contracted for. They also noted that large amounts of gasoline are purchased on often volatile ``spot'' markets.

DOC.HEAD: Donaldson Brings Long Resume To High-Profile Job
LaserPhoto NY21 of Aug. 9
DOC.TEXT: William H. Donaldson has a resume that seems to run on and on like a stock ticker tape. The 59-year-old securities industry veteran will need to call on his experiences on Wall Street, in Washington and in the Ivy League as head of the nation's largest stock exchange during what promises to be a turbulent 1990s. Donaldson, a friend of President Bush, was named chairman and chief executive officer of the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, taking over one of the highest profile jobs in American business at a time of rapid evolution. He succeeds John J. Phelan Jr., who is stepping down at the end of the year after winning almost universal praise for calmly shepherding the Big Board through the nightmare of the October 1987 market crash. ``There's a whole slew of things,'' Donaldson said about his challenges in an interview after his appointment, which was rumored for weeks on Wall Street, was formally announced. More specifically, he cited the globalization of securities trading, increased competition from overseas, rapidly changing technology, new regulations and 24-hour trading _ which threaten to dramatically alter the 198-year-old exchange. ``All of that with a bottom line emphasis of maintaining the believability of the marketplace,'' Donaldson said. ``The fluctuations of the last decade _ a lot of people don't understand it.'' Before he officially takes over Jan. 1, Donaldson is expected to solicit advice and support from his many contacts. Already he appears to have broad support on Wall Street. ``One of the important things is to earn the confidence of the people with whom he's dealing,'' said James J. Maguire, chairman of Henderson Brothers Inc., a top NYSE floor firm. ``I think he's very acceptable because of his broad experience not only in the securities industry but in politics and elsewhere.'' ``He's a very conceptual guy,'' said his former partner, Richard Jenrette, now chairman of Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. ``He thinks through things quite carefully. He will have interesting ideas and angles.'' A native of Buffalo, Donaldson's first job on Wall Street was at the old brokerage G.H. Walker & Co., run by Bush's uncle Herbert Walker. Donaldson was a classmate of the president's brother, Jonathan, at Yale University and is friends with the Bush family. Friends describe Donaldson as proper in the mold of Wall Street's stodgy old ``white-shoe'' investment firms. ``But not a preppy snob at all,'' Jenrette said. ``He would be kind of an intellectual white-shoe type.'' At his news conference Thursday, Donaldson appeared slightly stiff. In 1959, just one year out of Harvard Business School, Donaldson and two friends founded Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. He left in 1973 after the company grew from its initial $100,000 investment to the nation's 10th largest brokerage. Donaldson served in the Nixon and Ford administrations, first as an undersecretary of state to Henry Kissinger in 1973-74 before becoming special White House counsel to Vice President Nelson Rockefeller. In between he helped New York Gov. Hugh Carey, a Democrat, pick a new administration. ``It was just out of the blue,'' Donaldson said of the appoinment by Kissinger. ``I didn't know him, I had never met him. It was the last thing in the world I expected to do at that time but I did it.'' Donaldson helped Rockefeller devise an extensive plan for the nation to utilize alternate energy sources. The proposal died in Congress when the Carter administration arrived. A Yale trustee, Donaldson in 1975 helped found and served as dean of Yale's School of Organization and Management until 1980, when he returned to Wall Street to open a private investment firm, Donaldson Enterprises Inc. Donaldson said his experience setting up the school _ which specializes in the public as well as private sector _ would help at the exchange, a private institution with an awesome public responsibility. Donaldson becomes the fourth full-time, paid chairman of the Big Board since the job was created in 1972. He was tabbed by a nine-member search panel appointed after Phelan in February announced plans to retire at the end of the year. Phelan, 59 and chairman since May 1984, will remain an adviser for NYSE relations with foreign stock exchanges.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales May Suffer as Consumer Spending Slows Further
With PM-Retail Sales-Table
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Fear of rising inflation and unemployment coupled with anxiety over shrinking personal net worth will restrain retail sales growth for the rest of this year, industry analysts say. The nation's major chain stores on Thursday reported mixed July results, with business at several big retailers getting a boost from price markdowns and other promotions to unload summer merchandise. But industrywide results were unimpressive and a growing number of forecasters raised red flags about the outlook for the second half of the year, a time when retailers do the bulk of their annual business. ``The events over the past several weeks cause us to be much more concerned about consumer sentiment and consumers' willingness to purchase aggressively,'' said Thomas Tashjian, a retail analyst at Seidler Amdec Securities Inc. Seidler Amdec recently reduced its 1991 earnings projections for the retailers it follows and recommended slimmer holdings of retail stocks in investment portfolios. Jeffrey Edelman, who tracks retailers for the investment firm Barclays de Zoete Wedd, said this year's steady erosion in consumer spending could worsen due to economic fallout from the Middle East crisis. Inflation fears and weakness in the stock market have shaken confidence and caused consumers to reassess their financial health. People already were feeling poorer because of the slide in real estate values. ``I think general merchandise sales are likely to weaken through the end of the year,'' Edelman said. Sales growth was mixed last month. Specialty apparel chains mostly fared better than general merchandisers. An index of 17 leading chains compiled by Merrill Lynch & Co. indicated that sales at stores open at least a year rose an average of 5.7 percent in July from a year earlier, little different from June's 5.8 percent year-to-year gain. ``We would characterize the July sales reports as mixed with some benefits from the seasonal weather,'' said Merrill Lynch analyst Jeffrey Feiner. ``Moreover, sales were aided by heavy promotion on the part of retailers to clear inventories as they move into the more important back-to-school selling season.'' July typically is a cleanup month for retailers. They clear out summer leftovers and start rolling out new autumn lines. Price cuts and other promotional activity may have slightly exceeded normal levels. Store operators were left with too much merchandise because May's poor weather discouraged shoppers and led to disappointments at the cash register. Several nationwide general merchandisers posted results that fell short of the industry average. Sears, Roebuck and Co. said its sales in the four weeks ended Aug. 4 rose 3.7 percent from a year earlier. Sales at stores open at least a year moved 3.1 percent higher. These same-store results are widely regarded as the best indicator of a retailer's performance. Tallies that include new stores can be inflated because business frequently is busier immediately after an opening than it ends up being over time. Sears, the nation's largest retailer in terms of sales volume last year, has been struggling to keep ahead of its faster growing competitors. The company on Wednesday announced a major change in command in an apparent bid to salvage a merchandising strategy that analysts say isn't working. Edward A. Brennan, chairman of the corporation, will run the merchandise group, ousting Michael Bozic, who took over a new position as president. ``By deposing Bozic, they are publicly acknowledging they are doing very, very poorly,'' said New York-based retail consultant Kurt Barnard. Second-ranked retailer K mart Corp. reported its total July sales rose 12.1 percent over July 1989. But on a comparable store basis, sales grew a more modest 2.2 percent. Wal-Mart Stores Inc., as usual, beat its two bigger rivals. Total sales leaped 21 percent while same-store sales grew 8 percent in July. The rapidly growing discounter is expected to challenge Sears and K mart for the No. 1 ranking in terms of nationwide revenue this year. Several specialty apparel retailers also outperformed the industry. The Gap Inc., for instance, said its July sales jumped 36 percent. Sales at stores open a year or longer rose 28 percent. The Limited Inc. said its total sales grew 19 percent while its same-store sales rose 6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Flint Strike Stops Ohio Plant Production
DOC.TEXT: A strike by workers at a General Motors Corp. parts plant forced a work stoppage at an assembly plant in Ohio and could halt production in at least two other plants, officials said. The walkout at GM's AC Rochester Division Flint West plant came Wednesday after negotiations with the United Auto Workers union on employee grievances about health and safety issues broke off. The strike left the Moraine, Ohio, assembly plant without enough parts to continue producing pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles, so GM was forced to idle about 3,000 workers on Thursday. ``With no fuel tanks we can't assemble trucks,'' said Tony Henderson, vice president of the International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers Local 801, which represents union employees at the Moraine plant. The 2,800 Flint workers make van doors and grilles, pickup truck grilles and gasoline tanks. GM spokesman Tom Tatham said there are more than 3,400 workers employed at the Moraine plant, which had been producing 56 vehicles per hour. Two more plants could shut today, GM spokesman John Maciarz said. Maciarz said he was unable to say which plants might close next if the strike continues. ``Obviously we want to see this settled as soon as possible,'' he said. One of the plants fed by the striking Flint facility is GM's luxury-car Orion plant in Oakland County. Meanwhile, bargainers from the company and United Auto Workers Local 659 resumed negotiations Thursday in an effort to end the work stoppage at the AC Rochester West manufacturing plant that now threatens to shut as many as eight GM assembly plants. In addition to the Orion plant, the Pontiac East truck assembly plant may not be able to begin production of 1991 models next week as scheduled.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler to Replace Spirit-Acclaim in '95
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. plans to replace its Dodge Spirit and Plymouth Acclaim compact cars in about five years, and is pushing back the introduction of a new luxury car, an executive says. Glenn Gardner, Chrysler's general manager of new platform engineering, said Thursday that a new version of the Spirit-Acclaim has a potential for more sales than a new luxury car, so the introduction of the compact car was moved ahead of the luxury car. Originally, Chrysler's new luxury car, codenamed the LX, was to be introduced shortly after its new midsize car, the LH, bowed in late 1992 for the 1993 model year. Gardner said the company's most pressing product priority was the LH. In fact, he said, Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca wants the car out earlier. ``Mr. Iacocca said he wants six months (cut from the introduction schedule). I told him he can't have it,'' Gardner said. ``He's a very persistent individual.'' Gardner's comments came during the fourth day of a week-long management conference sponsored by the University of Michigan. ``An LX is obviously one of those (cars) you have a chance to do or not do and not break the corporation,'' Gardner said. ``Obviously the LH is critical to the corporation.'' Wall Street analysts have criticized Chrysler for opting to build the Viper low-volume, high-performance sports car when the company should accelerate development of the LH midsize car. Between the introduction of the LH and the Spirit-Acclaim successor, Chrysler is expected to bring out a new subcompact car. Chrysler left the subcompact segment when it shut down a Detroit assembly plant that built the Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon last February. The Spirit-Acclaim successor will be introduced sometime around 1995, Gardner said. The cars originally were introduced in the spring of 1989 and are assembled in Newark, Del. Chrysler is realigning its vehicle development programs about a year after Iacocca said a billion-dollar cost-cutting program would not alter new-vehicle development plans. ``Our $15 billion, five-year program remains intact and we don't comment on specific future products that are contained in that program,'' Chrysler spokesman Tom Houston said. Also at the conference, Ford Motor Co. officially unveiled its 4.6-liter, V-8 engine for the 1991 Lincoln Town Car which goes into production later this year. The engine to be built at Ford's $780 million revamped engine plant in Romeo, Mich., is the first of the company's ``modular'' family of engines. Modular engines give manufacturers flexibility and cost reductions by creating a common basic engine structure with interchangeable components giving each kind of engine its own characteristics. ``Overall, we estimate the new family of engines will share about 350 parts, or about 75 percent of the engine,'' said David F. Hagen, general manager of Ford's engine division. ``New V-8 variations will cost about $60 million to develop compared to about $500 million for a typical new engine program.'' He said the modular engine concept will be expanded to Ford's huge Cleveland engine plant, which will build a new series of V-6 engines to go into production in the mid-1990s.

DOC.HEAD: S&Ls Under Government Control Add $1.35 Billion to Losses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 11th graf pvs `Total losses ...,' to $2.67 billion in the first quarter of 1989, sted $1.67 billion. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Bankrupt savings and loans under government management effectively added $1.35 billion to the cost of the thrift bailout in the first three months of the year. Operating losses at the 350 failed, but still open, institutions rose 35 percent from the $1 billion in operating red ink a year earlier, when the S&Ls were still managed privately, the Resolution Trust Corp. said Thursday. However, the operating losses were down 16 percent from $1.61 billion in the last three months of 1989, the bailout agency said. Analysts said the operating loss increase from the first quarter of 1989 does not necessarily mean the insolvent thrifts are being managed poorly by the government. ``It may indicate the institutions are worse run or it may just indicate they've had another year to deteriorate. ... Also, interest rates have shifted,'' making it more difficult to earn profits, said Martin Regalia, an economist with the National Council of Savings Institutions. The figures, however, underscore the need to close the thrifts quickly, even when it must keep and warehouse the S&Ls' inherited real estate, sour loans and other assets, Regalia said. The RTC noted that $443 million of the $1.35 million operating loss occurred in 155 institutions that in the following quarter were either closed or sold to new investors. ``Keeping these institutions open doesn't seem to help them,'' Regalia said. ``It would be nice if you could say we closed them all down ... but that's what the RTC is trying to do.'' The agency announced plans recently to close or sell 130 more failed thrifts in the second half of 1990. But unless Congress provides more bailout funds as requested by the Bush administration, the RTC would have to drastically slow its operations after September and fall short of the goal. At the same time, additional S&Ls are failing _ 66 since March 31. In the next two years, the agency could end up taking over 230 to 550 more insolvent thrifts. Total losses for the failed thrifts in the first quarter of 1990 were $3.14 billion, up from $2.67 billion a year earlier and down from $6.39 billion in the fourth quarter of 1989. But analysts said comparing those figures are less meaningful because they largely reflect non-operating losses that are booked when regulators force institutions to account for past mistakes and long-delinquent loans. Total losses are largely ``the accumulated losses that occurred two, three, four, five years ago and are finally being recognized,'' said Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va. ``Operating losses are the cost of carrying these institutions. ... It's an unavoidable cost until we get rid of these turkeys,'' Ely said. The RTC's first-quarter report was released two weeks after the Office of Thrif Supervision said the 2,505 S&Ls under private management at the end of March lost $271 million. Thus, losses for the entire industry totaled $3.41 billion in the first quarter, down from $3.6 billion a year ago and $9.5 billion in the previous three-month period. It was the best overall result in a year and a half. Overall fourth quarter losses were $3 billion worse than initially reported earlier this year.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Trade Surplus Shrinks 10.3 Percent in July
DOC.TEXT: Japan's trade surplus shrank 10.3 percent in July from a year earlier, largely due to increased imports, the Finance Ministry said Friday. The ministry said the country's trade surplus declined to $5.38 billion in July from $5.99 billion a year earlier on a customs clearance basis. Imports rose 6.0 percent to $18.50 billion from a year earlier while exports rose 1.8 percent to $23.88 billion, the ministry said. The drop in the surplus marks a return to a recent declining trend in Japan's trade gap, which had been steadily falling since June 1989 until June 1990, when it jumped 27.6 percent. Ministry officials said a record increase in the imports of finished products, including an 82 percent increase in aircraft and 440 percent increase in imports of works of art, contributed to the rise in imports. The officials noted concern about economic sanctions and oil embargoes against Iraq and Kuwait, decided earlier in the week. On a regional basis, Japan's trade surplus with the United States narrowed 20.6 percent to $3.07 billion from a year earlier. Its surplus with the European Community shrank 29.8 percent to $1.15 billion, while its surplus with Asia rose 42 percent to $2.48 billion, the ministry said. Japan calculates its trade surplus on a customs-clearance basis, which includes freight and insurance costs in imports but not in exports.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Company Reports Loss
DOC.TEXT: Commodore International Ltd. said Friday it lost $3.5 million in its last fiscal quarter though sales increased. The personal computer maker, which has been struggling to increase its profitability, said the loss for the quarter ended June 30 equaled 11 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter totaled $198.1 million, compared with $180.3 million for the same quarter last year. The company said earnings were hurt by an increase in operating expenses due to greater marketing costs. The company has been promoting its Amiga model and computers compatible with those made by International Business Machines Corp. Amiga sales rose by more than 40 percent in the quarter compared with a year earlier, the company said. Sales of its older C64 model were down. ``We remain fully committed to improving Commodore's financial performance and capitalizing on the Amiga's unique capabilities for the emerging multimedia marketplace,'' said Irving Gould, chairman and chief executive officer. For the fiscal year ended June 30, Commodore said it earned $1.5 million, or 5 cents a share, down sharply from $51.3 million, or $1.59 a share, in the previous fiscal year. Sales for the 12 months totaled $887.3 million, down from $939.7 million a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: July Wholesale Prices Fall 0.1 Percent in Last Respite From Inflation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with market reaction, comment. Picks up 7th pvs, `Analysts expect... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale prices in July edged down 0.1 percent, the government said today in a report seen by analysts as the last respite from inflation before the Mideast crisis sent oil prices soaring. The slight, seasonally adjusted decline in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index for finished goods, one stop short of retail, followed moderate gains of 0.2 percent in June and 0.3 percent in May. The drop in July was even better than the 0.1 percent or 0.2 percent rise expected by most economists. ``Obviously this number is history,'' said economist Donald Ratajczak of Georgia State University. ``But what it shows is that heading into the oil shock, inflation was tame.'' The stock market shrugged off the news. After 90 minutes of trading, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks shed 17.82 points to 2,741.09. Wholesale prices, which soared in January when a cold snap sent fuel oil and vegetable costs spiraling, have remained virtually unchanged from February through July, helped by six consecutive drops in energy costs. For the first seven months of the defense budget would have to take a larger reduction.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Price Boost Could Cause Inflation, Recession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf pvs, `The oil ... to UPDATE with report on July wholesale prices. Picks up 4th graf vs `The economy ... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy faces the twin threats of inflation and recession if the oil price run-up caused by the Middle East crisis continues for more than several weeks, analysts say. ``It's a real monkey wrench that is creating real economic distress for American households and businesses,'' said Allen Sinai, an economist with the Boston Co. ``An oil price increase is essentially a tax on consumption ... that causes consumers to cut back in other areas. ``The oil shot will ... add a substantial dose of inflation as crude oil prices work their way through the chain,'' Sinai said. The government reported today that wholesale prices in July edged down 0.1 percent, but analysts predict that will be the last respite from inflation before the Mideast crisis sent oil prices soaring. The Labor Department noted that prices were surveyed in mid-July, before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Analysts expect the six-month respite from wholesale price increases to end this month, at least for three or four months until the economy absorbs the oil shock. The economy has been weakening for several months, noted Charles Stone, senior economist with Congress' Joint Economic Committee. ``No one is talking about a really severe recession but this oil situation makes things a little bit worse,'' he said. How much worse? Experts agree that depends on how long the price of oil remains in the range of $26 per 42-gallon barrel or higher, which is nearly double the price two months ago. The benchmark price rose from $18 to $21 the day Iraq invaded Kuwait, soared above $28 on Monday and dropped back to about $26 after it became apparent the United States would use military might to keep Saudi Arabia's oil fields open. ``If prices stay up for two or three months, a recession will be a reality,'' private analyst Joel Popkin said. ``Depending on how high the price goes, this definitely raises the risk of recession, because higher prices drain purchasing power out of the economy and send it to the Arabs,'' Fred Ribe of the Congressional Budget Office said. ``If the Middle East situation is resolved in the near term, I wouldn't expect a long-run impact on the economy,'' said Roy Cordato, an analyst with the Washington-based Institute for Research on the Economics of Taxation. The economy would suffer if the run-up continued for more than a few months, he said. Many economists and politicians dread any increase in the price of energy, especially oil, because no commodity has a greater influence on inflation. When the price of oil goes up, it affects the cost of fuel to plow a farmer's wheat field, to heat a baker's oven and to cool the corner grocery. That raises the price of bread. The economy, measured by the Gross National Product, has little growth to give up. It grew at an anemic rate of 1.5 percent in the first half of the year. Richard Rahn, chief economist for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, doubts any long-range impact on the economy assuming that other oil-producing countries will increase output to make up for the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil, thus stabilizing prices. But Rahn said a sustained high price would worsen the recession that he insists already is under way. ``The rule of thumb is that a price increase of $5 in place for a year costs half a percentage point of growth,'' he said. One of the most pessimistic forecasts on oil prices came from Philip K. Verleger Jr., a visiting fellow with the Institute of International Economics. He told Congress' Joint Economic Committee earlier this week that prices could hit $45 to $50 a barrel unless consuming nations open their strategic reserves. ``This new price shock will almost certainly trigger a recession in both the United States and possibly throughout the industrialized world,'' Verleger said. ``Real GNP will decline by 1 to 2 percent in the current quarter and 3 to 4 percent in the fourth. Unemployment (now 5.7 percent) could rise to 7.5 percent by the middle of 1991.'' Another big question is how the Federal Reserve will respond to higher oil prices. Many conservatives contend the central bank, in its zeal to hold down inflation, has overreacted and made credit so tight that a recession is inevitable. ``We are not contemplating recession,'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said Wednesday. But he repeated the administration's hope that the Federal Reserve will loosen credit to stimulate the economy.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Surge On USDA Crop Data
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rose sharply this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade, boosted by a government harvest projection that was below market expectations. Corn futures also rose in reaction to Thursday's Agriculture Department crop report while wheat futures were slightly lower amid profit-taking after two days of strong gains, said Walter Spilka, grain analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. The USDA estimated the 1990 U.S. corn harvest at 7.85 billion bushels, up 4 percent from last year's crop. The government projected a soybean crop of 1.84 billion bushels, down 5 percent from last year's harvest of 1.93 billion bushels. Both numbers were below market expectations, which averaged 7.92 billion bushels for corn and 1.86 billion bushels for soybeans. Spilka predicted the reaction to the crop report would be short-lived and that traders would quickly return their attention to growing conditions. ``They'll be trading weather by this afternoon,'' he said. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent to 1} cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.89\ a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 2\ cents higher with September at $2.51} a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1 cent higher with September at $1.20{ a bushel; and soybeans were 7 cents to 12 cents higher with August at $6.08{ a bushel. Cattle futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while pork futures were mixed. Live cattle were .02 cent to .13 cent lower with August at 78.75 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .30 cent lower with August at 89.55 cents a pound; hogs were .15 cent lower to .85 cent higher with August at 57.20 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .15 cent lower to .80 cent higher with August at 49.25 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled lower on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 18 Percent Profit Increase for Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch food and home products group, said Friday its second-quarter profit rose 18 percent, helped by growth in its major markets. Unilever said its net earnings for the three months ended June 30 came to 311 million pounds, or $516 million, compared with 263 million pounds a year earlier. Pre-tax profit rose 4.8 percent to 477 million pounds, or $781 million, from 455 million pounds a year earlier. Sales rose 14 percent to 5.72 billion pounds, or $9.37 billion, in the quarter from 5 billion pounds a year earlier. For the first six months of the year, its profit rose 18 percent to 541 million pounds, or $898 million, from 457 million pounds a year earlier. Sales gained 14 percent to 10.8 billion pounds, or $17.77 billion, from 9.51 billion pounds a year earlier. Sir Michael Angus, Unilever's chairman, said the six-month results represented ``satisfactory progress.'' Angus said that a ``measure of caution'' is needed for the second half, however, given the uncertain outcome of events in the Middle East and how they could affect world economies. On a regional basis in the second quarter, the company said it had a 7 percent gain in operating profit to 332 million pounds, or $544 million, in Europe, its biggest market. North American results for the second quarter showed a 13 percent rise in operating profit to 94 million pounds, or $154 million. In the rest of the world, Unilever's operating profit rose 41 percent to 127 million pounds, or $298 million.

DOC.HEAD: Beer Company Starts India's First Private Airline
DOC.TEXT: When the Indian government ended its 37-year monopoly on airlines in April, visions of belly-dancing hostesses undulated through Deepak Anand's head. Anand, one of India's new breed of capitalists, has yet to realize his dream of sashaying stewardesses. But he has a private airline flying in India for the first time since the country nationalized eight carriers in 1953. UB Air took to the skies on June 1, led by Anand, who is corporate planner for the UB Group, India's biggest beer brewery and one of the country's largest companies. ``On time, every time,'' is UB Air's slogan. Its nickname is ``Beer Air'' _ in reference to the company's main product _ and Anand said the airline would soon relaunch canned beer in India by offering UB's Black Label and Kingfisher brews on board, a first in India. UB Air is targeting business travelers. With fares about 30 percent higher than Indian Airlines, Anand says he is committed to getting people ``where they want to go in time for their business meetings.'' ``I also wanted belly dancers,'' Anand said. ``But I got shot down.'' Company officials thought dancing on board would be too disruptive, he said. Many seem to be taking UB Air seriously. It began by flying the 180 miles from Bangalore, a southern city of high-tech industries and 4 million people, to Mangalore, a beach resort on the west coast. Since June, it has added a route from Bangalore to the eastern city of Madras. A round trip to Hyderabad, in central India, and the capital, New Delhi, are also planned. As of late July, the company had flown about 60 flights. All of them have been on time, a highly unusual occurrence in India, the land of the endless wait. When 18,000 Indian Airlines' employees went on strike July 12, UB Air responded with two special flights to Madras. ``It was fun to stick it to them,'' Anand said. ``It was our small way of saying, `Wake up, India.''' The young airline operates with a single plane, a 15-seater Donnier 228-100, which flies six round trips a week between Bangalore, Madras and Mangalore. Next month, UB Air pans to purchase a 19-seater Donnier 228-201 from Druk Air, Bhutan's state-run airline. It is also trying to lease a 77-seater BAE-146 jet from Druk. The appearance of a private airline in India's skies highlights attempts made by recent governments to liberalize this vast nation's rigid economy. Since independence from Britain in 1947, India has sheltered itself from the world economic system, erecting huge tariffs on items from bicycles to automobiles to soft drinks. Most major industries, such as power, steel, transportation and communication, were state run. When Rajiv Gandhi became prime minister in 1984, he moved to increase India's competition with the outside world, lowering some tariffs and pushing trade. Gandhi's loss in the 1989 election to V.P. Singh didn't stop this process. In May, the government announced a new industrial policy, approving foreign investment as long as the foreign partner holds less than 40 percent equity. The government also opened up India's state-run power industry to private investors. And the Ministry of Defense published a list of items which could be produced domestically by private industry. In April, the government announced its ``open skies'' policy, permitting private airlines to fly. Many thought the announcement was overdue. In India's air industry, the gap between supply and demand has been acute. Of India's three state-owned airlines, Air India, Indian Airlines and Vayudoot, only Air India is considered passable and its flights are mainly overseas. One airline analyst in Hong Kong called Indian Airlines ``the worst way to travel east of Iran.'' Vayudoot lost an estimated $25 million last year. Even with liberalization, the government is not allowing fair competition in the skies. Private airlines are prohibited from advertising schedules and are banned from using India's foreign exchange to buy airplanes. As such, India's fledgling airlines will have to rely on wary foreign banks or rich non-resident Indians, interested in investing in their homeland, for funds to buy planes. UB Air is currently negotiating with West Germany's Deutschebank for a loan, said Devapriya Guha, a senior manager in corporate planning. Still, Anand and other entrepreneurs remain undaunted. ``Competition is a process that India cannot avoid,'' he said. ``It's the only way to improve service and enter the modern world.''
