DOC.HEAD: Strike Threat Pending at World's Largest Delivery Company
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS last 6 grafs, The proposed ... to CLARIFY wage increase; DELETES reference to part-time benefits increase
DOC.HEAD: With PM-UPS Customers
DOC.TEXT: Teamsters union officials count United Parcel Service of America Inc. workers' ballots on a proposed new contract today in a vote that could start a nationwide strike against the giant package shipper. Company officials were optimistic that a strike would be averted, even if the proposed contract is rejected. ``The sentiment we're hearing right now is an actual work stoppage is one of the last options being considered,'' UPS spokesman John Flick said Thursday. ``Both of us will go to great lengths to avoid a work stoppage.'' UPS officials said the results of the voting could be announced Satrday, but a man who answered the telephone at Teamsters' headquarters in Washington said no announcment would be made until Monday. Teamsters spokesman Duke Zeller in Washington did not return calls. Members had until 10 a.m. EDT today to send their ballots to union headquarters in Washington. UPS, the world's No. 1 package handler, has about 150,000 part-time and full-time Teamsters members out of a total work force of 230,000. It delivers more than 10 million packages a day, and made 2.8 billion deliveries in 1989 for $12.4 billion in revenue. Teamsters President William McCarthy, who helped negotiate the proposed new three-year contract, told UPS officials early in the negotiations that the union would call for a work stoppage if the pact wasn't ratified, said Ken Sternad, another spokesman for UPS. ``But that was one verbal comment made at one moment in time, and we've heard very little, if any, of that talk since then,'' Sternad said. The old contract expired July 31, and the company has agreed to make the new one, if ratified, retroactive to Aug. 1, Sternad said. Rival shippers and UPS customers have been scrambling to make alternate plans if a strike is called, and some customers said they have already stopped using UPS to avoid getting packages caught in the system during a walkout. Spiegel Inc. of Oak Brook, Ill., the nation's largest in-home catalog company, has been making contingency plans since the beginning of July, said spokeswoman Mary Dale Walters. The Postal Service said last month that it could not absorb UPS's business, and the company's other main ground competitor, Roadway Package System, Inc., echoed that sentiment Thursday. ``Nobody has that kind of capacity,'' said Bram Johnson, spokesman for Pittsburgh-based RPS. Other options to UPS include Federal Express, DHL Worldwide Express and TNT Skypak. If a strike is called, packages would be cleared out of the UPS system by any means possible, Sternad said, adding that volume had decreased slightly by last week. ``We will do everything up to and including getting everybody up to the chairman of the board to get our customers' packages either returned to them or forwarded to where they are going,'' he said. The proposed contract calls for higher wages, benefits and better working conditions, Sternad said. It would raise the wages for the average UPS full-time driver a minimum of $1.50 an hour by August 1, 1992 from $16.10. The contract also calls for a cost-of-living allowance of up to 20 cents per hour each year, depending on the rate of inflation, Sternad said. Inflation would have to be 10 percent for the drivers to get the full 20 cents, he said. Part-time workers, who start at $8 or $9 an hour, would receive $1.50 more, Sternad said. Company contributions for health benefits and employees' pensions, currently at $8,300 a year for full-time workers, would increase to $10,500 by the end of three years, Sternad said. The proposal also offers a one-time bonus, to be paid within the first month of ratification, of $1,000 to full-timers and $500 to part-timers, he said. Sternad said there has never been a national strike against UPS, which has had a national Teamsters contract since 1979, but sporadic work stoppages and strikes have occurred regionally. The mostv recent and biggest was in 1976, when 18,000 workers in 15 Northeast states walked out for 13 weeks.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Air Fares Going Up, Skinner Calls in Airline Presidents
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES in 5th graf with Northwest scaling back increase to 5.3 percent. This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner is calling in airline executives to discuss the impact of sharp rises in jet fuel prices that led nearly every major carrier to announce fare increases. Some increases went into effect today, but passengers on most airlines have until next Wednesday to book flights in advance at current fares. Skinner wrote several airline presidents on Thursday, asking them to make appointments with him next Wednesday, Thursday or Friday to discuss how higher jet fuel prices following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait are affecting airline finances and the public. Delta, United and USAir all announced 5.3 percent fare increases Thursday that are to take effect in five days. Several other airlines announced increases earlier. Northwest dropped a planned $8-per-flight fuel surcharge and announced a 10 percent fare increase instead _ which it amended to 5.3 percent late today. American on Thursday scaled back its increase from 10 percent to 5.3 percent. Other airlines that have announced increases include America West, Midway, Pan Am, Southwest, Trans World and the Trump Shuttle. Prices of jet fuel shot up from a level of 70 to 75 cents a gallon before the invasion to 80 to 90 cents this week, airline officials said. The government has no power to regulate fuel prices or airline fares, but Skinner earlier asked all transportation companies to show restraint in raising rates in response to increasing fuel costs. ``I am concerned about the effect of the rise in fuel costs, both on the financial position of the industry and on the traveling public,'' Skinner said in a two-paragraph letter to several airline presidents. He asked the officials to brief him on the situation. ``Airline ticket prices are going up, and we want our passengers to know why. Jet fuel prices have gone through the roof,'' Robert J. Aaronson, president of the industry's Air Transport Association, said at a news conference Thursday. Aaronson said he expects all airlines to honor advance tickets sold before the price increases take effect. Calls to several carriers indicated that tickets bought before the increases would be at lower prices, even for flights several months away. Many carriers already had sold 30 percent to 40 percent of their seats over the next two months before the announcements, Aaronson said. The fare hikes come at a time when domestic air travel has shown little increase over last year and some airlines have reported first- and second-quarter declines in profits. It also comes toward the end of the summer vacation season, after which travel volume is expected to drop. ``While the industry struggles to hold down costs and to keep people flying at reasonable prices, we are faced with these new, enormous fuel bills,'' Aaronson said. A $1 increase in the price of a barrel of crude oil results in a 3 cent increase in the cost of a gallon of jet fuel, which in turn costs airlines $500 million a year, the industry spokesman said. With crude oil up from $22 a barrel last week to $26 a barrel on Wednesday, the increased costs would total $2 billion. But Aaronson noted that crude oil prices were declining Thursday and he said if jet fuel costs follow, the industry is likely to lower fares. He said a Bush administration proposal to increase domestic ticket taxes and a House-passed bill to impose passenger charges at airports would add to the cost of air travel. Although the airline industry has not taken a unified stand on the taxes, Aaronson said, ``To put it mildly, if ever there was a wrong time to raise taxes on airline passengers, it is now.''

DOC.HEAD: State Sues Exxon, Alleges Deceptive Practices
DOC.TEXT: North Carolina's attorney general filed a lawsuit Friday against Exxon Corp., charging the oil company with deceptive trade practices since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last week. Attorney General Lacy Thornburg charged that Exxon is quoting wholesale prices which it fails to honor, and is imposing retroactive wholesale price increases. Superior Court Judge Robert Farmer signed an injunction to halt the practice. A spokesman for Exxon said officials were unaware of the lawsuit and had no immediate comment. North Carolina's action follows the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, which set off a spiral of higher gasoline prices across the United States. The lawsuit is based on an investigation by the attorney general's office which uncovered documents showing that Exxon had raised its wholesale prices by as much as 6 cents a gallon after having already contracted and sold the gas at the lower price. Thornburg said records indicate that in some cases, distributors had picked up loads and already made deliveries to service stations before being informed of the price hikes. Documents show that some oil and gas distributors have suffered significant losses by relying on Exxon's alleged misrepresentation of price, Thornburg said. According to the lawsuit, because the Exxon distributors don't know whether Exxon will impose retroactive price increases on gas which they have already purchased, the distributors must build a cushion into their resale prices. ``Ultimately, the public pays the price,'' Thornburg said. ``When Exxon or any other company unfairly raises its prices to the distributors, it sets off a chain reaction of price increases which hit the consumer in the pocketbook.''

DOC.HEAD: Kellogg Takes Nabisco to Court Over Shredded Wheat Claims
DOC.TEXT: The Kellogg Co. is taking Nabisco Brands to court over shredded wheat, contending Nabisco is trying to crush Kellogg's plans to introduce a more nutritious cereal. Kellogg has been planning since June to put its Whole Grain Shredded Wheat on the market this month with the claim it's ``very simply, the most nutritious shredded wheat you can buy.'' The company contends the shredded wheat has 33 percent more dietary fiber and more thiamine, riboflavin, niacin, iron, vitamins B6 and B12, folic acid, magnesium and zinc _ with no sugar or salt _ than the famous shredded wheat manufactured for 89 years by New Jersey-based Nabisco Brands, a division of RJR-Nabisco. But on July 27, attorneys for Nabisco told Kellogg that it, too, had developed a more nutritious shredded wheat _ with nearly identical nutritional value as the new Kellogg product _ that would be on the market in mid-August. Nabisco sent a letter to Kellogg, saying the Battle Creek company must ``take immediate steps to avoid any false claims of nutritional superiority for its fortified shredded wheat cereal on packaging, advertising, point of sale and any other materials whatsoever.'' Instead, Kellogg filed suit Aug. 3 in U.S. District Court in Kalamazoo. The company contends Nabisco had known since early June that Kellogg was preparing to spring the new shredded wheat onto the market, but said nothing. Kellogg had been sending samples and promotional materials since that time to various test markets. ``That Nabisco should wait for 89 years and a competitive challenge from Kellogg before manufacturing its own unsugared, fortified shredded wheat biscuit was itself suspicious,'' the suit says. ``But ... Kellogg has learned other facts which clearly indicate that Nabisco set out to copy both the features of and marketing strategy behind Kellogg's new cereal in a cynical attempt to prevent vigorous competition in a sector of the market for ready-to-eat cereals that it has dominated for so long.'' Nabisco spokesman Mark Gutsche said Friday the company denies the charge and called the lawsuit ``a reaction to Nabisco's own threat of legal action.'' He said the company's new cereal, Spoon Size Plus Shredded Wheat, a fortified version of its regular product, already has been sent to grocers. ``Nabisco is absolutely confident that Kellogg will be stopped from confusing consumers that its new cereal is the most nutritious shredded wheat,'' he said, reading from a prepared statement. Kellogg spokesman Neil Nyberg said the company is asking the court to rule that its product claims are legal and that Nabisco may not sue Kellogg over those claims.

DOC.HEAD: Two Chrysler Proposals Shot Down by UAW
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union has rejected proposals that would give workers a stake in the financially struggling Chrysler Corp. and would establish a new way to figure profit sharing, a UAW official said Friday. UAW Vice President Stan Marshall said a third company proposal, which would establish a multi-employer health-care trust, is still under consideration. The three concepts were introduced by Chrysler Vice President Anthony St. John on July 20, the day national contract negotiations began between the UAW and General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler. Current contracts covering more than 450,000 workers _ 60,000 of them at Chrysler _ expire Sept. 14. Marshall said Friday that the union had rejected the employee ownership plan and the so-called ``gain-sharing'' proposal. ``It's pretty close to being laid to rest from the union's position,'' he said. ``We're rejecting unless the membership said differently.'' Marshall said he expected union members to agree with the bargainers' position. However, UAW negotiators are likely to hear about the two proposals later. ``I'm sure all those discussions will come up again at the bargaining table,'' Chrysler spokesman Tom Houston said. St. John offered few details about the proposals for the employee ownership program or the ``gain-sharing'' scheme. Currently, Chrysler workers nationwide receive annual profit-sharing payments if the company's North American earnings are high enough. St. John said the gain-sharing program would alter that by including other factors, such as employee attendance and productivity. It also would be operated on a plant-by-plant basis rather than nationwide. He said the two programs, along with the multi-employer health-care trust, would save Chrysler money, although GM and Ford officials have been cool to the ideas. ``You don't hear about buying in (to the corporation) or gain-sharing until they (the companies) are in trouble,'' Marshall said. ``They are willing to include workers in their misery.'' Chrysler said it made $180 million during the second quarter, down 47.2 percent from last year. Wall Street analysts have forecast that the company will lose a substantial amount of money in the third quarter because of a minivan production interruption. Marshall, speaking at a management conference sponsored by the University of Michigan, criticized St. John harshly for talking about the three proposals to reporters before discussing them with the union. He said negotiations got off to a rocky start partly because of that. Since then, Marshall said, the atmosphere at the talks has improved but distrust remains between the union and management. In a speech to the conference, Marshall endorsed an expansion of joint labor-management programs and said the union would consider a three-crew, two-shift manufacturing schedule. The union's leadership once before backed such a plan at Chrysler's car assembly plant in St. Louis. The UAW overwhelmingly rejected the proposed change. Shortly after, Chrysler announced it would close the plant in late September.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Gain, Wheat Retreats in Late Plunge
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rose sharply Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade after the government issued a lower than expected harvest estimate. Corn futures were mixed and wheat ended lower after a dizzying late-session plunge sparked by a huge sell order that was believed to have come from one speculative fund. ``They hit it hard. It was a big mess in there,'' said John Frazier, director of agricultural trading for Gerald Inc. in Chicago. Soybeans finished below the day's highs after a powerful rally linked to Thursday's Agriculture Department crop report. The government projected a soybean harvest of 1.84 billion bushels, about 20 million less than expected. The USDA's estimate for the corn harvest _ 7.85 billion bushels _ was about 70 million lower than expected. Wheat futures settled 10\ cents lower to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.80 a bushel; corn was unchanged to 1{ cents lower with September at $2.50{ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to 1\ cents higher with September at $1.19{ a bushel; soybeans were 10\ cents higher to 13{ cents higher with August at $6.08{ a bushel.

Stock prices retreated from their worst levels but were still sharply lower today as a call for Arab unity from Iraq's leader sparked new fears that hostilities in the Middle East would escalate. The broad, downward move gathered momentum as traders digested a statement from President Saddam Hussein, who signaled for the first time that Iraq's intentions are wider than the annexation of Kuwait. ``It was quite inflamatory, and it added fuel to the fire'' in an already pressured stock market, one analyst said. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was off 41.34 points at 2,717.57 an hour before the closing bell. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 11 to 4 on the New York Stock Exchangewith issues 1,063 down, 382 issues up and 502 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Boardtotaled 122.28 million shares as of 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Saddam's speech, broadcast on national Iraqi television and read by an unidentified announcer, upset a market that was beginning to find its equilibrium. In reference to the U.S.-led multinational military presence in nearby Saudi Arabia, Saddam called on all Arabs to ``condemn the invaders and collaborators'' and to seize Islam's holiest shrines, which lie within Saudi borders. Analysts had expected the market to turn lower today as traders cashed in on the gains of the previous two sessions and lightened up their stock holdings to protect against any surprises overseas this weekend. But Saddam's speech was a catalyst for further selling, even though Arab leaders meeting in Cairo denounced Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Oil issues were mostly higher as the price of crude futures rose. Atlantic Richfield was up 1 at 136~; Texaco was up ~ at 63}; Chevron was up } at 77| and Pennzoil was up [ at 81. Airline stocks fell as carriers continued to announce price hikes. AMR was down ~ at 51[, and Delta was off 1 each at 59]. UAL was off 5\ at 108{ amid uncertainty over an employee-led buyout. Among other actively traded Big Board issues, Unitel was up } at 26[; Boeing was down 1] at 53[; Wal-Mart was down } at 29~, and IBM was down 1\ at 102. The NYSE composite index of all its listed common stocks was down 2.01 at 184.23. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index stood at 338.88, down 2.61.

DOC.HEAD: Strike Averted at UPS
DOC.TEXT: At the request of federal mediators, the Teamsters union agreed Friday to postpone a strike and resume negotiations with United Parcel Service of America Inc. if union members reject a proposed contract. ``There will not be a work stoppage, at least not for the foreseeable future,'' said Alan Caminiti, a UPS spokesman at company headquarters in Greenwich. The Federal Medliation Service asked that the company and the union go back to the bargaining table if the Teamsters rejected the new pact, said Bernard E. DeLury, mediation service director. The votiation and Concies were being counted Friday, and Caminiti said no word was expected on the results until Monday. ``Now, people will be at work Monday, regardless,'' Caminiti said. If the contract is ratified, UPS and the Teamsters have agreed to make it retroactive to Aug. 1. The old contract expired July 31, but the Teamsters asked for an extension to collect all the ballots. Caminiti said UPS expects that work will proceed at a normal pace Monday and throughout further contract talks. ``We haven't seen any dogging,'' he said. ``They're going to work, they're doing what they have to do, working as professionals, and we would expect nothing less of them.'' A man who answered the telephone at Teamsters headquartloyees' pensions would increase from $8,300 a year for full-time workers to $10,500 by the end of three years, Sternad said. The proposal also offers a one-time bonus, to be paid within the first month of ratification, of $1,000 to full-timers and $500 to part-timers, he said. There has never been a national strike against UPS, which has had a national Teamsters contract since 1979, but sporadic work stoppages and strikes have occurred regionally. The last and biggest was in 1976, when 18,000 workers in 15 Northeast states walked out for 13 weeks.

The stock market moved broadly lower today amid fears that tensions in the Middle East were poised to escalate. Five minutes before the closing bell, the Dow Jones industrial average was down 39.85 at 2,719.06.

DOC.HEAD: Heinz Signs Chief Executive to Five-Year Contract
DOC.TEXT: H.J. Heinz Co. has signed chief executive Anthony J.F. O'Reilly to a five-year contract that includes options to buy 4 million shares of stock, officials said Friday. ``We see it as a way to put a handcuff on Tony O'Reilly and keep him at Heinz,'' said James McDonald, a board member who heads the compensation committee for the Pittsburgh-based food giant. Under the agreement, O'Reilly cannot exercise the option to buy the stock until 1995. O'Reilly only would earn a profit on the stock if the price exceeds the option's exercise price of $29.87. ``This does not pay off unless the stock does,'' McDonald said. ``Unless the company continues to perform, it can't be a good deal for him.'' Heinz stock closed Friday at $33. The board struck the agreement to keep the 54-year old chairman and chief executive at the company, which has grown steadily under his 11-year tenure into a $6 billion company. McDonald said O'Reilly has become increasingly attractive to other companies because of his record. O'Reilly introduced Weight Watchers and other lines and began an aggressive marketing campaign in the United States and abroad. ``If you look at his performance, it has been outstanding,'' McDonald said. Other terms of the contract, which must be approved by shareholders at next month's annual meeting, remain the same as last year, when O'Reilly earned $534,688 in salary and other compensation and about $1.4 million in bonuses.

Stock prices declined broadly today as traders remained jittery over developments in the Middle East. The downward move, exacerbated by light volume and program trading, gathered momentum in early afternoon following a statement from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Rising oil prices and a declining bond market also pressured stocks. Saddam's speech, which signaled for the first time that Iraq's intentions are wider than the annexation of Kuwait, ``was quite inflamatory, and added fuel to the fire'' in an already pressured stock market, one analyst said. At one point the Dow Jones industrial average was down 50 points, triggering a limited on computerized trading strategies that can aggravate price volatility. The market later retreated from its worst levels. Saddam's speech, broadcast on national Iraqi television and read by an unidentified announcer, upset a market that was beginning to find its equilibrium. In reference to the U.S.-led multinational military presence in nearby Saudi Arabia, Saddam called on all Arabs to ``condemn the invaders and collaborators'' and to seize Islam's holiest shrines, which lie within Saudi borders. Analysts had expected the market to turn lower today as traders cashed in on the gains of the previous two sessions and lightened up their stock holdings to protect against any surprises overseas this weekend. But Saddam's speech was a catalyst for further selling, even though Arab leaders meeting in Cairo denounced Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Southmark Emerges from Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
DOC.TEXT: Southmark Corp. emerged from bankruptcy Friday, transferring $75 million to senior creditors and shareholders under its reorganization plan. Southmark chairman, president and chief executive officer Arthur G. Weiss resigned Friday, as did the board of directors. Two directors agreed to remain in office for a brief transition period. Glen Adams was named chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Dallas-based real estate and financial services company, Southmark announced. Adams, who previously managed the liquidation of the Great Western Sugar Co., will be joined by a new board of directors elected by the new shareholders of the reorganized company. Southmark filed for protection from creditors in July 1989. The Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing, made in Atlanta and transferred to Dallas, listed total book value assets of $1.046 billion, secured debt of $152.4 million, unsecured debt of $1.051 billion and other liabilities of $190.9 million. To comply with the reorganization plan approved by the bankruptcy court in Dallas last April, the company transferred $76 million in cash along with new securities to various agents on behalf of Southmark's creditors and shareholders. Holders of old Southmark securities will receive their portion of cash, new notes, new preferred stock and new common stock upon surrender of their old certificates. Southmark also transferred $100 million in assets to its Houston-based thrift subsidiary, San Jacinto Savings Association. A key feature of the reorganization was the recapitalization of San Jacinto. Southmark will have no managerial control of San Jacinto. The rest of Southmark's assets will be liquidated, with proceeds being used to redeem the new notes and new preferred stock of the reorganized company. The new preferred stock and common stock will begin trading over the counter on Aug. 13. In order to ensure Southmark has adequate working capital, the company wants to defer paying an estimated $8 million in fees to professionals that represented the company, creditors' committee, equity holders' committee and the court-appointed examiner. The fees would bear 10 percent annual interest from Nov. 1, 1990 and would be payable no later than April 15, 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Polaroid Announces $90 Million Plant
DOC.TEXT: Polaroid Corp. flashed some light into Masasachusetts' dark economic picture Thursday by announcing a $90 million plant to produce film for its new electronic imaging products. The plant in New Bedford will employ more than 100 people and is expected to be built by late 1992. Polaroid officials said it would be the company's largest investment in a manufacturing plant, and its products should help lift the company's weak profits. Chairman I. MacAllister Booth said the expansion also reflected ``Polaroid's confidence in the commonwealth of Massachusetts as a great place to do business.'' Recent events have shaken the business climate in that state. A once-booming economy has tumbled, increasing unemployment. State government wrestled for months with a fiscal crisis before raising taxes and cutting programs. The expansion may be a needed shot for Polaroid. Its instant film business has been lackluster, and the company must find new products to stimulate sales, said Alex Henderson, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Polaroid last month reported drops in second quarter operating income, net earnings and worldwide sales. Booth said electronic imaging products are ``a key element in our growth strategy.'' That includes making devices that can be used in hospitals to give doctors instant images when they examine patients. The company is set to test the products later this year and begin selling them in 1991. Polaroid looked at sites around the world after choosing New Bedford, where the company operates another plant that employs 500. Booth acknowledged Polaroid did not look favorably on the instability in Massachusetts. ``But it wasn't enough of a factor to send us outside the state,'' he said. Gov. Michael Dukakis and business leaders hailed Polaroid's announcement as a positive signal to other companies. John Gould, president of Associated Industries of Massachusetts, called it a ``lightning rod'' that could help the state attract other investments.

DOC.HEAD: Shareholders Approve Shearson's Merger With American Express
DOC.TEXT: Shareholders of Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc. on Thursday approved the Wall Street firm's merger with its parent, American Express Co. Shearson said the merger will take effect at 12:01 a.m. Friday. At a shareholders meeting, 91.59 percent of the votes cast were in favor of the merger, said Shearson spokesman Steven Faigen. Since American Express owns almost all the shares, the vote was a formality. Shearson is the parent company of the retail brokerage Shearson Lehman Brothers and the investment bank Lehman Brothers. The divisions recently were created by American Express out of what formerly was known only as Shearson Lehman Hutton. Earlier this year, American Express took greater control of Shearson after it experienced internal turmoil and weak financial performance. The financial services company increased its ownership of Shearson, ousted its chairman, Peter A. Cohen, and injected more than $1 billion in fresh capital. The merger is the final step in that process. Shearson lost an industry record $915 million in the first quarter, in part because of expenses to pay for a restructuring that includes about 2,000 layoffs. Most Wall Street firms have been forced to cut back because of an industry slowdown since the 1987 stock market crash. A large part of Shearson's problems were due to overexpansion in the 1980s, when the firm acquired the brokerage E.F. Hutton & Co. and the investment bank Lehman Brothers Inc. At the shareholders meeting, Shearson's chairman and chief executive officer, Howard L. Clarke, said the company does not expect to take any additional restructuring charges, Faigen said. In addition, Shearson said it does not expect it will require any additional cash infusions by American Express, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Judges Consolidate Cases in Step Toward National Solution
DOC.TEXT: Two federal judges in Cleveland and Texas on Friday consolidated thousands of asbestos liability lawsuits in a first step toward resolving claims against manufacturers for worker deaths and illnesses. The joint class-action ruling was issued by federal district judges Robert M. Parker of Beaumont, Texas, and Thomas D. Lambros of Cleveland following a meeting of judges to consider ways of clearing a burgeoning asbestos case backlog. More than 100,000 lawsuits are filed in state and federal courts nationwide against companies that produced asbestos, a mineral used widely for insulation that causes cancer and other respiratory illnesses. ``The need for a multi-court cooperative effort to dispose of these cases is compelling,'' Parker and Lambros said in their order. ``The transaction costs are unacceptable. Thousands of claimants die before they can get their cases resolved. Trials have become repetitive, with the same issues and the same products being litigated time after time,'' they said. The judges consolidated all pending asbestos liability cases in their jurisdictions into one case. It is the first such grouping made by judges handling the asbestos docket. Parker, Lambros and eight other federal judges held an extraordinary meeting Friday in Washington. They heard proposals by plaintiffs and defense lawyers for taking steps to clear the asbestos docket. The order was approved by all the judges, although it was issued by Parker and Lambros, who have the most cases. ``I'm not sure it will result in a national class being established but it's a step in the direction of having a forum created so that an equitable solution to the problem can be arrived at,'' said Louis Robles, a Miami plaintiffs lawyer handling 1,000 asbestos claims. Parker and Lambros also scheduled a Sept. 14 hearing in Cleveland to discuss certifying a national class action in Texas consolidating all pending asbestos lawsuits nationwide. That hearing also would examine which companies have too little money on hand to pay claims against them. The judges' order does not stay on any pending asbestos litigation. Parker and Lambros said they want to establish procedures to determine defendant companies' national or regional share of asbestos to apportion their liability. Many of the claims involve exposure dating to the 1930s and '40s, much of it during World War II at government shipyards. The government to date has avoided liability for asbestos diseases, but is being challenged in several courts. Separately, a court-appointed adviser is New York is developing a plan to restructure the Manville trust. The trust, which was created after Manville Corp. was driven into bankruptcy court by thousands of asbestos claims, is out of money to pay new claims. Further spending by the trust has been frozen until Sept. 6.

DOC.HEAD: Six Months After Benzene Scare, Perrier Still Hard to Find
DOC.TEXT: Perrier bottled water hasn't reappeared in large quantities in the city where discovery of benzene contamination in the famous drink stopped distribution in 120 countries. Progress also apparently has been slow in reintroducing the drink in some other areas as well. ``We've got our work cut out for us,'' said Jane Lazgin, spokeswoman for the Perrier Group of America, the water's U.S. distributor. ``We have to earn their (customers) trust again. That's our job. We feel our first step was the best one to take. Now it will take an educational campaign.'' It's been six months since a local health official discovered traces of the chemical benzene in Perrier samples, prompting the worldwide recall. The company began reintroducing the water into the United States in some areas in April. Hellen Berry, who works for Beverage Marketing of New York, an industry consulting firm, said it will take a long time for Perrier to restock all of its customers. ``They have to restore the entire pipeline,'' she said. ``That includes a store's shelves as well as the back rooms and warehouses.'' Ms. Berry estimated the company's sales for May were about 67 percent of what they were in the same month last year. She also said the benzene scare could have a long-lasting impact on Perrier sales. ``Before this, most restaurants stocked only one brand of bottled water,'' she said. ``Now I'm being told their customers expect them to offer more than one.'' Patrons at Charlotte restaurants are discovering Perrier's still difficult to get. ``I can't find it and you know how upsetting that can be to the owner of a French restaurant,'' said Daniel Quillec, owner of Chez Daniel. ``My customers are asking for it.'' At Eli's, another popular Charlotte eatery, owner Larry Campbell has switched to another bottled water, Quibell. ``As far as I know it's not available and no one's been asking for it,'' he said of Perrier. One grocery store said it has been selling Perrier for about a week. ``It isn't blowing off the shelves,'' said Janice Keifer, assistant manager at the Fresh Market. ``It looks like people got used to (rival products) Quibell and LaCroix.'' Another store manager said she expects the first shipment of Perrier next week. The company says it resumed distribution in Charlotte on June 15. In February, Perrier announced an international recall after benzene traces were found in some samples by Mecklenburg County environmental lab director Tom Ward. In his small lab, which tests 25,000 water samples a year, Ward routinely uses Perrier as a diluting agent. When he found benzene in six bottles, he notified the Food and Drug Administration and sent it two unopened bottles from the same batch. The FDA found similar levels of benzene in the samples. Perrier _ which eventually traced the contamination to naturally occurring benzene that inadvertently had not been filtered from the water _ responded by ordering the dumping of 160 million bottles, including 72 million in the United States, and halted distribution to 120 countries. Last month, the company said the recall had cost it nearly $150 million. Before the recall, Perrier was the nation's biggest selling imported bottled water brand and third overall. According to the research firm Beverage Marketing Corp., Perrier had 5.7 percent of the overall $2.2 billion bottled water market in the U.S. in 1988. It trailed only Arrowhead at 7.7 percent and Sparklettes at 5.9 percent. Ms. Lazgin said the company wants to regain about 80 percent of its U.S. markets by next August. The company does not disclose its sales. ``We gave ourselves 18 months to do it so we're doing well after six months considering we were out of the market so long,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Nears $400 Amid Mid East Anxiety
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices raced to their highest levels in nearly five months Friday as fiery rhetoric from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein reignited fears that a Middle East war would wreak economic havoc on the West. On other markets, petroleum futures soared; soybeans rallied strongly while wheat futures plunged; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $11.10 to $12 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in August at $396.90 a troy ounce, the highest spot-month settlement since March 19. Silver futures settled 11.1 cents to 12.7 cents higher with August at $4.969 a troy ounce. The gold market surged after Saddam, in an outburst of fury against Western efforts to devastate his economy and hem in his army, called on Arabs everywhere to wage ``holy war'' against enemies of Islam. Hours after Saddam's statement, a majority of the Arab League nations agreed to dispatch an Arab force to defend Saudi Arabia and approved economic sanctions against Iraq. The developments triggered a runup in oil futures and a drop of more than 40 points in the Dow Jones industrial average. Both of those moves supported the gold market, which tends to attract investors during times of inflation and economic and political uncertainty. ``Gold is getting helped twice, once by the political instability in the Middle East and once by the price of crude oil,'' said Jim Paul, chief commodities analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Gold has rebounded with increasing momentum since tumbling below $345 an ounce in June. And Paul said the chart patterns, on which many large institutional investors and commodity funds make their trading decisions, indicate the precious metals are likely to move higher. But he cautioned, ``we're not trading gold and silver _ we're trading political events in the Middle East and we don't know what's happening next.'' In energy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 17 cents lower to 69 cents higher with September at $26.23 a barrel; heating oil was .90 cent to 2.84 cents higher with September at 72.61 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.2 cents to 3.03 cents higher with September at 79.45 cents a gallon. Soybean futures ended sharply higher, but below the day's highs, on the Chicago Board of Trade after the Agriculture Department issued a lower-than-expected harvest estimate. The market dropped from its highs on spillover selling from the grain pits, where a large wheat sell order sparked a dizzying plunge late in the session. ``They hit it hard. It was a big mess in there,'' said John Frazier, director of agricultural trading for Gerald Inc., in Chicago. Analysts said the strength in soybeans was mainly a reaction to Thursday's USDA report. The government projected a soybean harvest of 1.84 billion bushels, about 20 million less than expected. The USDA's estimate for the corn harvest _ 7.85 billion bushels _ was about 70 million lower than expected. Wheat futures settled 3 cents to 10\ cents lower with September at $2.80{ a bushel; corn was 2{ cents lower to \ cent higher with September at $2.50\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent lower with September at $1.19{ a bushel; soybeans were 10 cents to 14 cents higher with August at $6.08} a bushel. Near-month hog futures rose sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, rebounding from recent losses on ideas that lower wholesale prices for pork products would encourage retailers to promote pork. Pork-belly futures and most cattle futures retreated in light trading. Live cattle settled .30 cent lower to .20 cent higher with August at 78.97 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .33 cent to .65 cent lower with August at 89.52 cents a pound; live hogs were .07 cent lower to 1.42 cents higher with August at 57.77 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .30 cent to 1.75 cent lower with August at 47.62 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Climbs, Dollar Mostly Lower in New York
DOC.TEXT: Gold prices climbed Friday in heavy trading after Iraq's call for an Arab holy war against Western forces in the Persian Gulf region. The dollar, meanwhile, finished lower against most major currencies despite the possibility of an escalation of Middle East hostilities that could disrupt oil flows from that region and damage economies. Analysts said weakness in the U.S. economy and the prospect of lower U.S. interest rates weighed on the dollar. Trading was described as light. Gold for current delivery jumped $11.10 a troy ounce to close at $396.90 on New York's Commodity Exchange. In later dealings, Republic National Bank in New York quoted a bid for an ounce of gold at $396.25 as of 4 p.m. EDT, up $10.65 from Thursday's late bid. David Ryan, chief bullion trader for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said trading volume was heavy and reflected a feeling that ``tensions are getting worse instead of better'' in the wake of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. As Arab leaders gathered for a meeting Friday in Cairo, Egypt, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein called on Arabs everywhere to attack Western forces in region, overthrow the Saudi royal family and take back the Moslem holy sites in Saudi Arabia. But a majority of the Arab League nations attending the Cairo meeting later agreed to send troops to protect Saudi Arabia from Iraq, approved economic sanctions against Baghdad and condemned the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Ryan said Saddam's call for a holy war against Western forces ``really played on traders' nerves today.'' He said gold was bid higher higher because of its perceived safety in times of distress and as a hedge against inflation likely to result from the recent sharp increase in oil prices since Iraq's move against its neighbor Kuwait. Earlier in the day, gold prices rose by smaller amounts in Asia and Europe in what analysts there attributed to short-covering by professionals who bought gold to fulfill earlier agreements to sell it. Gold rose to $391.25 a troy ounce in London from $385.25 late Thursday and to $390.50 an ounce in Zurich from $385.00 late Thursday. In Hong Kong, gold rose $3.84 an ounce to $388.01. Silver bullion rose in London to $4.95 a troy ounce from $4.87 Thursday. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery rose 11.2 cents an ounce to $4.969. In the currency markets, the dollar fell in New York trading against every major currency except the Japanese yen and the Canadian dollar after turning in a mixed performance on foreign exchange markets overseas. ``We saw dollar weakness at the close of the European session, and it carried over to New York,'' said Marc Chandler, a currency markets analyst at MMS International in Chicago. Chandler said the dollar is suffering because of the weakness in the U.S. economy, the likelihood of rising inflation and chances that U.S. interest rates will fall while rates in Germany may rise. He said the dollar would probably be even lower were it not for the Persian Gulf situation. Some investors turn to the dollar during international strife on the theory that it offers more security than other currencies. ``The danger for the dollar now is for a protracted and costly U.S. involvement in the Persian Gulf,'' Chandler said. The dollar rose to 150.40 yen in New York from 149.805 yen late Thursday. In Tokyo, the dollar edged up 0.07 yen to 149.75 yen. The dollar was quoted at 150.20 yen in London. But the dollar fell against the British pound. In New York, the pouind rose to $1.8735 from $1.8680 late Thursday. In London, the pound rose to $1.8730 from $1.8720 late Thursday. Dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.5895 German marks, down from 1.5965; 1.3375 Swiss francs, down from 1.3435; 1,165.00 Italian lire, down from 1,168.50; 5.3325 French francs, down from 5.3510; and 1.14705 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14695. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.5895 German marks, down from 1.5915; 1.3400 Swiss francs, up from 1.3385; 5.3360 French francs, up from 5.3340; 1.7925 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7930; 1,166.50 Italian lire, up from 1,164.75, and 1.1476 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1467.

DOC.HEAD: NII Chairman Steps Down, Group Wins Board Seats
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of National Intergroup Inc. stepped down from the holding company's board of directors Thursday as a dissident group claimed three seats on the panel. Candidate slates for the seats had been nominated by NII and the dissident group, Centaur Partners of New York, the company's largest stockholder with 16.5 percent of outstanding shares. Centaur's nominees won about 63 percent of the votes cast at the company's July 25 annual meeting, National Intergroup said as the meeting resumed Thursday. Howard M. Love's seat was one of those at stake on the 10-member board. Although he resigned as chairman, he remains the company's chief executive officer and has said he would like to finish the company's restructuring if the board permits him to stay. Also approved were Centaur proposals to prevent NII from increasing its anti-takeover defenses, to require confidential voting in company elections and to require stockholder approval for severance payments to managers. The company's proposal to change the name of the corporation to FoxMeyer Corp. received more than half the shares voted but failed to achieve the two-third majority needed to ratify the proposal. ``While we are disappointed with the vote outcome, we plan to continue to implement the final steps of our restructuring program,'' NII said in a statement. ``We remain convinced that the continued growth and development of FoxMeyer Drug Company is in the best interests of all of our shareholders.'' Centaur wants the company to sell all its assets and distribute the proceeds to stockholders. NII has agreed to place most of its businesses up for sale and close its Pittsburgh headquarters but has insisted on keeping FoxMeyer, the nation's third-largest wholesale drug distribution network, as the foundation for a continuing company. Before beginning its restructuring, NII was a conglomerate that owned National Aluminum, a major aluminum producer; the Ben Franklin variety store chain; Permian, an independent energy wholesaler; and 50 percent of National Steel Corp. Ben Franklin is on the block, Permian will go on the block once NII completes its tender offer for shares held by the public, and the other operations have been sold.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Extends Authority to Tap Strategic Petroleum Reserve
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed legislation Friday that extends his authority to begin pumping oil from the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve into the market should Iraq's invasion of Kuwait disrupt world oil supplies. The bill, passed by Congress shortly before lawmakers left for vacation last week, temporarily extends the Energy Policy Conservation Act, which established the 580-million-barrel stockpile of unrefined crude oil in response to the 1973-74 Arab oil embargo. Without the extension, Bush's authority to pump crude oil from the stockpile to relieve shortages would expire Aug. 15, while Congress is out of town. The stockpile, stored in salt caverns along the Louisiana-Texas coast, has been accumulated at a cost of more than $20 billion over the last decade. The system could now replace 80 days of oil imports, according to the Senate Energy Committee. That cushion has fallen from 110 days in the middle 1980s because of growing U.S. dependence on foreign crude. Congress and the administration have been battling the last 18 months over whether to increase the reserve to 1 billion barrels. Bush has opposed increasing the reserve beyond 750 million barrels.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Believe Continental Can Still Fly Without Lorenzo
DOC.TEXT: Now that Frank Lorenzo is leaving Continental Airlines, the question remains whether the carrier can rise above the problems it accumulated on its way to the top. Lorenzo's departure may have stemmed the flow of harsh criticism from organized labor, but the carrier still faces other obstacles. Heavy debts and a bitter strike at sister carrier Eastern Airlines have hurt business, and Continental still suffers from an image problem. But despite those hurdles, several analysts said Friday there is room for optimism. ``It is a fairly low-cost provider. With a different kind of management, it could be a very powerful airline,'' said industry analyst Andrew Geller of PNC Financial Corp. in Philadelphia. ``I think it definitely has a better future now, or a heightened chance of a better future with this happening,'' Geller said. ``Whether I think it's a survivor, I don't know yet.'' Continental Airlines Holdings Inc., formerly known as Texas Air Corp., announced Thursday that Lorenzo was selling most of his stake in the company to Scandinavian Airlines System and resigning as chairman and chief executive. Lorenzo will be replaced by Delta Air Lines Inc. President Hollis L. Harris. The Houston-based company once commanded 20 percent of the domestic airline market through its ownership of Continental and its sister carrier, Miami-based Eastern. Robert J. Joedicke, of Lehman Brothers in New York, said the carrier has several advantages and disadvantages as it moves into the post-Lorenzo era. ``Its labor costs are lower than the industry average. Whoever takes it over is blessed with a low-cost airline,'' he said. ``They can be quite competitive among the major carriers.'' The company's debt, however, ``sort of counterbalances that,'' Joedicke said. Its success, he said, depends on whether management can realign the structure of its debt, which totaled some $4.8 billion as of March 31. Joedicke also said he believes Harris will make strides in improving service, which should help attract additional business travelers. ``They kind of had a reputation of bad service that they were slowly getting rid of, this may hasten that,'' said Thomas Canning of Standard & Poor's in New York. Canning said Harris is well respected in the airline industry and should be instrumental in polishing Continental's tarnished image. But Continental also faces problems common throughout the airline industry, including high fuel costs, sagging traffic growth and increased competition, he said. Continental, he said, needs to attract a loyal following and obtain a larger share of the flying public. He said that except for Lorenzo's surprise departure, he doubted there would be any major changes immediately.

DOC.HEAD: GM Announces 1.9 Percent Average Price Increase
DOC.TEXT: Consumers will pay an average 2.3 percent more for General Motors Corp. cars and trucks in the 1991 model year, as GM on Friday joined the other two Big Three automakers in announcing price increases. Chrysler Corp. said last week that its 1991 cars, Jeeps and minivans would cost 0.9 percent more than this year's models, while Ford Motor Co. said a week earlier that its 1991 cars would cost an average 3.2 percent more than this year's. Ford's trucks will cost 3.6 percent more. While GM's price increase isn't expected to keep pace with inflation, the company doubts its profits will suffer. ``There are a couple of dynamics to determine profit other than hiking prices,'' said Terrence P. Sullivan, manager for sales and financial reporting. ``If you have a modest price increase, you can increase profit by increasing sales and cutting costs,'' he said. Sullivan said GM would likely release prices for various models early next week. He said 1.9 percent of the increase is to cover health care and production costs and 0.4 percent is for installing airbags on several models. The price comparisons are for comparably equipped vehicles, but year-to-year comparisons are difficult because automakers pad prices to allow for incentives. During the past several years, each of the Big Three has offered a variety of incentives, mostly cash rebates and low-interest financing, to help sell its vehicles. Sullivan said the cost of incentives at GM were about the same as at Ford and Chrysler _ about $1,000 per vehicle. The cost of incentives come directly out of profits. During the last three weeks, the Big Three have all blamed incentives for cutting their second-quarter earnings. Overall, Big Three profits tumbled 43.3 percent in the April-June quarter this year compared with the same 1989 period. Chrysler's earnings dropped to $180 million, 47.2 percent less than earnings for the 1989 second quarter. Ford said it made $770.7 million in the second quarter, down 45 percent from the year-earlier period, while GM reported second-quarter earnings fell 40 percent to $900.1 million. Nonetheless, Sullivan said dealer inventories are at lower levels than they were at this time last year, when GM increased its incentives to get vehicles off the showroom floors. ``This year there is no need for a big, year-end announcement of incentive packages,'' Sullivan said. ``There are rebates on most vehicles now, but they're not as big or as aggressive as before.''

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Slip as Mideast Fears Grow
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices slipped Friday in light, volatile trading as participants took profits and fears grew that a war could erupt in the Middle East, traders said. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell 11-32 point, or $3.44 per $1,000 face amount. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, rose to 8.79 percent from 8.75 percent late Thursday. The yield on the 30-year bond due in August 2020, which was auctioned Thursday as part of the Treasury's quarterly refunding, also fell 11-32 point in when-issued trading. Traders said the market had little reaction to a report showing inflation moderated last month. The government reported that wholesale prices in July edged down 0.1 percent. Analysts said the report, which normally would be positive for the bond market, was discounted because it occurred before the Middle East crisis sent oil prices surging. ``The market disregarded it as old news,'' said Kevin Flanagan, a money market economist with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``The Mideast situation is not going to go away.'' Instead, bond prices were sent lower by bondholders who sold issues to take profits after the Treasury's quarterly refunding, which concluded Thursday, said Gib Clark, chief trader at Daiwa Securities Inc. In addition, investors concerned that the Iraqi situation could escalate were unwilling to hold large amounts of bonds over the weekend, furthering the selloff, Clark said. The market has been concerned that the turmoil and resulting rise in oil prices could heighten inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-return securities such as bonds. Also influencing bond prices was a rumor that the Federal Reserve would inject money into the banking system to lower interest rates, Clark said. Lower rates benefit bonds. The Fed did add some funds, but only to make a technical adjustment in the monetary supply, Flanagan said. The size of the injection made it clear the central bank had not changed its tight-money policy, he said. ``The market was a little disappointed about that,'' Clark said. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments were unchanged to [ point lower, intermediate maturities fell from 3-32 point to 5-16 point, and long-term issues were down by as much as ] point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 0.98 to 1,153.00. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.61 percent as the discount fell 2 basis points to 7.38 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 7.64 percent as the discount fell 1 basis point to 7.27 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 7.65 percent as the discount fell 3 basis points to 7.15 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 percent, unchanged from late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell 1-16 point. The average yield to maturity remained at 7.45 percent due to rounding.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets Aside Verdict Against GTE
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. District Court judge Friday set a aside a $15.9 million jury verdict against GTE Products Corp., calling for a new trial in a case filed by an inventor who claimed the company stole his idea. The jury in June had awarded the money to George Panagiotou, a former rock band manager who had charged GTE appropriated trade secrets for his cool lamp, which is used in movie studios. GTE had maintained that Panagiotou failed to show that any trade secrets existed, or a contract had been breached. Judge John J. McNaught set aside the verdict, but Panagiotou's attorney, Sydelle Pittas, said an appeal is likely. ``It was a big award, but we feel that the grounds on which it was set aside are not valid and are confident of winning an appeal of the judge's decision,'' she said. A spokesman for GTE said the company is pleased with the judge's decision. ``GTE welcomes the retrial and the opportunity to completely vindicate itself,'' the company said in a prepared statement. Panagiotou's lawyers had argued that he started developing the cool light when he realized how uncomfortable performers were under the heat of movie studio lamps in the 1970s. His cool lights were used in the production of numerous popular television shows. The trial, originally filed in California in 1984, brought such television stars as Ed Asner and Michael Landon to testify on Panagiotou's behalf. Panagiotou has since started a successful home video light company in Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: NWA Profit Down 33 Percent In Second Quarter; TWA Up On Asset Sales
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines Inc. said Friday second-quarter earnings fell 32.6 percent from a year earlier, partly due to rising expenses, while Trans World Airlines Inc. said second-quarter earnings rose sharply due to gains from asset sales.
DOC.HEAD: Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Northwest, which is privately held, reported earnings of $60 million for the three months ended June 30, compared with $89 million for the year-earlier quarter. Second quarter operating revenue rose to $1.8 billion from $1.6 billion. Operating expenses rose 13.5 percent, causing operating profit to drop to $64 million from $107 million a year earlier. ``Our results were characterized by moderating fuel prices and a continued devaluation of the yen in relation to the dollar earlier in the quarter,'' said John Dasburg, executive vice president of finance and administration. The company derives much of its income in yen because of highly traveled U.S.-Japan routes. Dasburg said operating cash flow dropped from a year earlier due to significant investments in maintenance and customer promotions. Northwest was taken private in August 1989 former Mariott Corp. executive Alfred Checchi and other investors. As a private company, Northwest is not required to make its finances public. The second quarter figures were disclosed as required, however, to the U.S. Department of Transportation and released by Northwest.
DOC.HEAD: TWA
DOC.TEXT: TWA reported second quarter earnings of $103.4 million, compared with a $4.4 million loss a year earlier. Earnings in the latest quarter were boosted by one-time gains totaling $160.2 million from sales of assets that included certain airport facilities in Chicago, aircraft and a portion of TWA's interest in the WORLDSPAN passenger reservation system. There also was a $19.8 million gain from the repurchase of long-term debt securities, some at a discount. Without the one-time gains, operating profit fell by 45.5 percent, to $43.9 million from $80.5 million, due to increased fuel costs, higher labor rates and other rising business costs. TWA operating revenue rose to $1.23 billion during the quarter from $1.20 billion a year earlier, while operating expenses rose to $1.18 billion from $1.12 billion. For the six months ended June 30, the airline had a net loss of $39.6 million, compared with a loss of $87.4 million a year earlier. Operating revenue in the six months rose to $2.24 billion from $2.19 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Sharply Lower on Middle East Jitters
DOC.TEXT: The stock market tumbled sharply lower Friday as concerns flared up over the volatile Middle East. The widely followed Dow Jones industrial average of 30 stocks was off 42.33 points at 2,716.58, putting its loss for the week at 93.07 points. At one point in the afternoon, the Dow was down 50 points, triggering a New York Stock Exchange limit on computerized trading strategies. Analysts said the so-called circuit breaker helped pull the market back from its worst levels. Analysts had expected traders to lighten their stock holdings ahead of an uncertain weekend, but a flurry of heated statements surrounding the Persian Gulf crisis combined with higher oil prices and higher interest rates to pressure stocks lower. ``Things got very nasty'' as investors flocked to safe havens like short-term U.S. government securities and precious metals, said Hugh Johnson, senior vice president at First Albany Corp. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by about 5 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,038 down, 436 up and 515 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 145.34 million shares, down from 155.81 million Thursday. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 179.42 million shares. After advances the past two days, many traders were beginning to think that the market had found an equilibrium and that the Middle East crisis was showing signs of stabilizing. The amount of stock selling began to ``trickle down,'' said Gene Jay Seagle, a vice president at Gruntal Financial Inc., as evidenced by the session's relatively light volume. ``Most investors who wanted out are pretty well out.'' But what fanned the downturn, according to Johnson, was ``saber-rattling from all corners.'' The market was hit with a flurry of news, beginning with a statement from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein urging other Arabs to wage ``holy war'' against America. Elsewhere, Arab leaders in Cairo said they would send troops to help protect Saudi Arabia while denouncing the Iraqi invasion. In addition, a number of nations were poised to send troops to join U.S. forces in the Arabian desert. ``So far the game seems to be going against Saddam, which is positive for the market,'' Seagle said. Traders ignored a report showing wholesale prices declined a better-than-expected 0.1 percent in July. ``It was an extraordinarily good number, but the market's behavior dramatized how much the focus is on the Middle East,'' Johnson said. Oil issues were mostly higher. In the energy sector, Texaco rose \ at 63[; Chevron was up 1[ at 78; Pennzoil was up { at 81], but Amoco was down 1 at 55} and Exxon lost \ to 51|. Precious metals stocks rose as gold prices jumped higher. Hecla Mining was up { at 12\; Placer Dome rose ~ to 17~; Newmont Gold was up 2 at 51[; Homestake Mining was 1{ at 21~, and ASA Ltd. was up 1} at 52}. Among other actively traded Big Board issues, IBM was down 1\ at 102; Wal-Mart was off } at 29~; Boeing lost 1\ to 53\; Eli Lilly was down 2} at 75\, and Unitel was up 1[ at 26{. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $34.21 billion, or 1.06 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 2.09 to 184.15. Standard & Poor's industrial index lost 5.38 to 395.82, and S&P's 500-stock composite index declined 4.42 to 335.52. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 4.95 to 408.03. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 339.32, down 2.17.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Fines Bank over Currency Reports
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury Department said Friday a $368,000 civil penalty had been assessed against the National Bank of Washington because of what the government said were improper currency transaction reports discovered during a money laundering investigation. The penalty was assessed before the government took over the bank on Aug. 1 after its parent, Washington Bancorporation, filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors. The Treasury said the penalty was based on the bank's failure to file currency transaction reports as required by the Bank Secrecy Act. Most of the violations were discovered during a federal undercover operation, it said. ``Despite an earlier warning by Treasury and the involvement of its former senior vice president in money laundering, NBW continued to rely on a woefully inadequate Bank Secrecy Act compliance program which led to a number of violations and created a situation rip for money laundering,'' said Assistant Secretary Peter K. Nunez, who announced the fine. The penalty is the maximum authorized.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Tumble, Oil Prices Rise on Middle East Tension
DOC.TEXT: The stock market tumbled and oil prices climbed Friday as belligerent rhetoric by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein unnerved investors and heightened fears of an oil shortage. ``We're still seeing an underlying tension swelling in that region,'' said Randall Rothenberg, a oil broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York. ``The situation has not been averted.'' The stock market closed the week with its worst performance since Monday as virtually all sectors except gold and oil were battered by tensions in the Middle East. The Dow Jones average of 30 blue-chip industrial stocks fell 42.33 points to 2,716.58, extending its weekly drop to 93.07 points. Analysts had expected some selling by investors reluctant to hold on to stocks in case of further developments over the weekend. But Saddam called for a ``holy war'' against Western forces, while Arab nations agreed to dispatch troops to Saudi Arabia, where U.S. forces are positioned in what President Bush called a defense against Iraqi invasion. Bush raised tensions by warning Iraq against sending out oil tankers to evade an economic embargo. He also said Saddam would be ``foolish'' to invade Saudi Arabia. Those events created jitters in the oil futures market on a belief they might lead to further disruptions of oil supplies from the Middle East, a critical source of world fuel. A supply shortage would boost demand, in turn pushing up prices. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the September contract for U.S. crude oil rose 56 cents to $26.23 per 42-gallon barrel. Crude oil has risen nealry $6 per barrel since the Iraqi invasion Aug. 2. Among refined petroleum products traded on the Merc, the near-term contract for home heating oil soared 2.84 cents to 72.61 cents per gallon. The September contract for unleaded gasoline jumped 3.03 cents to 79.45 cents per gallon. In addition to Saddam's speech, oil futures prices were helped by a statement by Venezuela denying it planned to raise output to cover production by Iraq and Kuwait. Western nations have embargoed oil from the two nations. Meanwhile, gasoline prices at the pump dropped for the first time since Iraq invaded Kuwait. The Automobile Association of America said the average price of unleaded fuel nationwide was down 0.3 cent Friday to $1.25 a gallon. On other financial markets, gold for current delivery jumped $11.10 a troy ounce to close at $396.90 on New York's Commodity Exchange. The dollar was lower against most major currencies despite the threat of escalating hostilities. Gold rose because it is viewed as a safe haven in times of distress and as a hedge against inflation likely to result from the sharp increase in oil prices. Bond prices fell as traders reduced their portfolios before the weekend. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond fell 11-32 point, or $3.44 per $1,000 face amount and its yield rose to 8.79 percent. Earlier in Tokyo, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 286.18 points, or 1.04 percent, closing the week at 27,329.55, its lowest closing level since October 1988. The London stock market lost 11.1 points to close at 2,233.8.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuelan Energy Ministry Denies Ordering Oil Production Increase
DOC.TEXT: The Venezuelan Energy and Ministry on Friday denied reports that it had ordered the state oil industry to raise output to cover Iraq and Kuwait's OPEC quotas. ``Until this moment, the minister has not ordered any increase and our production is still limited to our OPEC quota of 1.945 million barrels per day of crude,'' a ministry spokesman told The Associated Press. ``However, a new order could be given later on, depending on OPEC agreements,'' he added. Venezuela will not make any unilateral hikes, and in any case, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is awaiting word from Arab leaders on the success of their peace efforts before changing the level of output, the spokesman said. Energy Minister Celestino Armas is in ``constant touch'' with other OPEC ministers. The cartel has yet to make any decision about making up for Iraq's 3.1 million barrels per day and Kuwait's 1.5 million, the spokesman said. ``But depending on what happens in the Arab world, minister Armas may make an announcement within a day or two,'' he said. Reports from New York and elsewhere had indicated that the state oil monopoly Petroleos de Venezuela, S.A. (PDVSA) had already ordered its subsidiaries to raise output by around 500,000 bpd. However, by law, the ministry imparts instructions to PDVSA, which cannot raise production on its own. According to a recent nationwide test, Venezuela has the capacity to produce between 2.6 and 2.7 million barrels of oil per day, excluding heavy crudes. Its reserves are sixth in the world, not counting oil in the Orinoco bitumen belt. Venezuela's OPEC limitations have led to friction between the ministry and PDVSA, which has advocated overproduction to finance a $20 billion program to expand the oil and petrochemical industries over the next 10 years. A main goal is to raise production capacity to 3.5 million barrels per day by 1995 and to 4 million by 2000.

DOC.HEAD: South East Says it May Lay Off Workers
DOC.TEXT: Kentucky's third largest independent coal company said Friday it was notifying more than 800 workers of possible layoffs in October. The United Mine Workers, which won the right to represent South East Coal Co. workers last month, dismissed the announcement as a ``scare tactic'' designed to influence upcoming contract talks. South East President Harry LaViers Jr., made the announcement in a one-page press release. He and other South East officials could not be reached by telephone for comment. ``We hope not to have to layoff everyone, economics will determine that, but we are not currently in a position to determine which employees, or how many, will be affected,'' LaViers said. ``Therefore, we believed it was necessary to notify all employees.'' South East has underground mines and a coal processing plant in Kentucky. It has about 740 hourly workers; the rest are managers, foremen, office staff or engineers. The statement said South East believes more than 50 employees will be laid off by Oct. 12. The company was notifying all workers to comply with a federal law that requires companies to give workers 60-day notice of impending layoffs.

DOC.HEAD: Scientist, Inventor Who Once Headed Arthur D. Little Dead at 75
DOC.TEXT: Inventor Howard O. McMahon, a former head of Arthur D. Little Inc., has died at the age of 75. McMahon, who lived in Cambridge, died of heart disease Sunday at Mount Auburn Hospital, said an Arthur D. Little spokesman. The Cambridge-based firm specializes in international management and technology consulting. McMahon joined Arthur D. Little as a research associate in 1943. He succeeded Gen. James M. Gavin as its president in 1964. In 1951 the scientist received the Franklin Institute's Edward Longstreth Medal for co-developing the Collins helium cryostat, which liquefies helium gas at minus 452 degrees Fahrenheit. The American Ceramics Society gave McMahon the Frank Forrest Award in 1952 for his research in thermal radiation. In 1979, he received the Samuel C. Collins Award from the Cryogenic Engineering Conference. McMahon earned a doctorate in physical chemistry and physics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. While still an undergraduate, a Canadian neon sign company paid him $100 for his patent on a bubbling Christmas tree candle. After becoming president of Arthur D. Little, McMahon began to organize programs at the American Academy for the Advancement of Science in which the public, scientists and students discussed political and social issues. McMahon also began pushing corporations to conduct social audits, essentially the costs to their employees, customers and the community at large of their doing business. After retiring from Arthur D. Little in 1977, McMahon founded the Helix Technology Corp., which manufactures cryogenic refrigeration systems in Waltham.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Firm Announces 83 Percent Jump In Fiscal 1990 Profits
DOC.TEXT: Boosted by a 62 percent increase in revenues, Sun Microsystems Inc., on Thursday reported $49.1 milion in profits in the fourth fiscal quarter, up from a loss a year ago. The profit works out to 51 cents per share. In the same period last year, the company lost $20.3 million, or 25 cents per share, the computing systems company said. Sun Microsystems had revenues of $700.1 million in the April-June period, compared with $431.2 million for the same three months in 1989. Scott McNealy, president and chief executive officer of Sun Microsystems, attributed the company's strong revenue growth to its workgroup computing business, including powerful workstations. ``More than 34,000 units were shipped in the fourth quarter, bringing our worldwide installed base to more than 285,000 units,'' McNealy said in a statement. ``We had record booking during the quarter and ended the period with a record backlog of orders.'' For the fiscal year, Sun Microsystems had earnings of $111.2 million, or $1.21 per share, on revenues of $2.47 billion. For fiscal 1989, earnings were $60.8 million, or 76 cents per share, on revenue of $1.77 billion.
